HEADLINE: Caring for Poor, and for Profit;
Bronx Hospital Shakes Up the Medical Establishment

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

 BODY:
St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx was founded in 1866 as the Home for the Incurables, a place where people with cataclysmic strokes or crippling heart disease went to die. By the early 1980's, this anachronism of a hospital might have expired itself, but for its ambitious and enigmatic young president, Dr. Ronald Gade.
Dr. Gade tells how he imposed rigorous economies a decade before the rest of New York's health-care industry realized its own bloat. By reducing the size of the staff and discouraging long hospital stays, among other things, he not only saved St. Barnabas; he figured out something few before him had: how to make money -- lots of it -- caring for poor people. 
 "We were almost broke," he said. "We had to be efficient."
That efficiency soon translated into personal gain: a salary of $1 million a year, unusually high for a relatively small hospital. And Dr. Gade, a radiologist, began building an empire to match.
Over the last year and a half, he surprised the jealous world of New York medicine by locking up two huge city contracts worth almost $450 million, one to provide doctors for Lincoln Hospital in the South Bronx, the other to care for prisoners on Rikers Island. In the process, he and his hospital have become what Dr. Luis R. Marcos, head of the city hospital system, calls "sort of the intruder in the health-care industry." And those are words from one of Dr. Gade's strongest supporters.
In part, this is a matter of personality and personal history. A somewhat reclusive man who almost never grants interviews, Dr. Gade has always operated far from the fiercely competitive center of New York academic medicine. But his outsider status also has a lot to do with the way his cost-cutting strategies have challenged a medical establishment that remains notably behind the curve of the managed-care revolution in American medicine.
In short, he has placed himself square in the middle of a debate of almost operatic intensity: whether low-cost medicine can equal high-quality medicine.
To Dr. Marcos and other top city officials, St. Barnabas offers a model that the city would like to see replicated throughout its public health care system. To them, Dr. Gade offers much lower costs and quality they say is comparable to the big medical institutions', but with more accountability and less attitude. But to his critics -- who include competitors, union leaders, and doctors and health officials who disagree with his approach -- fewer doctors, fewer staff members and shorter hospital stays can lead only to a lower level of service.
In the debate, one statistic stands out: In February 1997, 345 prisoners at Rikers Island were sent to a hospital. This February, the second month since St. Barnabas took over medical care at the jail in a three-year, $342 million contract, the number was 121.
Dr. Gade and his supporters point to the drop as an impressive rendering of fat. They say that doctors have stopped referring inmates to hospitals for minor problems, and that routine procedures like blood tests as well as more specialized services like dermatology or orthopedics are being handled at the prison.
But Dr. Gade's critics worry that he may be sacrificing prisoners' health to make money.
"The concern we have -- and it's a concern with this whole H.M.O. approach -- is that there appear to be incentives not to send people to the hospital," said Robert Gangi, executive director of the Correctional Association of New York, which monitors the treatment of inmates.
It seems too early to draw either conclusion. And aside from accounts of sick prisoners waiting too long for hospital care or overworked Lincoln residents waiting for outside specialists, no major problems have gained attention outside the institutions' walls.
Beyond the partisans, though, many more people in New York's health-care industry are following this latest step in Dr. Gade's career.
"Ron Gade has been a pioneer in looking at new approaches in cost-effective health care," said Pamela S. Brier, a former top city health official who is the executive vice president of Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn. "But the health care community is really watching to see whether he can couple this pioneering approach with the maintenance and improvement of health care standards that benefits the patients.
"The jury is still out."
 
Criticism Dismissed As Rivals' Jealousy
Dr. Gade, who is 53, seems wearily aware that he is destined to play the heavy. But he brushed aside his critics' charges as motivated by ignorance and jealousy.
"A lot of people just don't know very much about us," he said, breaking his habitual public silence in a long interview at St. Barnabas, at 183d Street in Fordham-Tremont. "And so they look at the fact that we're a successful hospital and try to superimpose their template of: 'We can't do it; why should they be able to?' "
It is simply careful management that has left St. Barnabas positioned so well against other competitors now, Dr. Gade said. He said he had stemmed losses of roughly $10 million a year by using technology like automated laboratories, computers for billing and records, and machinery for quick diagnoses that avoid the need for multiple tests. Last year, the nonprofit hospital was more than $13 million in the black.
Perhaps most important, as the hospital grew, were changes in two crucial areas: staffing and revenue. Today, he said, St. Barnabas uses far fewer workers -- about three per bed when other hospitals rely on five or more -- without compromising care.
On the revenue side, he greatly increased income from a source long shunned by many hospitals -- Medicaid, the government insurance for the poor. Medicaid's reimbursement rates were traditionally low, but they have become more attractive as managed care drives down what private insurers will pay. When Dr. Gade took over, fewer than 10 percent of St. Barnabas's patients were on Medicaid; more than half are today.
"You can do very well on Medicaid," he said. "And as a result, we have."
Although opinion in St. Barnabas's mostly poor Fordham-Tremont neighborhood seems divided on how good the hospital is, state regulatory officials have not cited it for major problems in quality. And Dr. Marcos said he had not seen major problems at Lincoln or Rikers, either.
"We don't have any evidence to support the notion that the quality of care is any worse," he said. "In fact, we have evidence to the contrary." He said, for example, that the number of incidents of bad care at Lincoln that needed to be reported to the state were down.
Dr. Gade himself is fond of citing his route to St. Barnabas as proof that money is not his first concern, even though he admits his salary is "without question a lot of money."
In 1980, Dr. Gade gave up what he said was a highly profitable private practice on Long Island to become head of radiology at St. Barnabas, after 15 other doctors turned down the job. The hospital is not affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church or the medical center in New Jersey with the same name.
It was, he said, "the worst hospital I had ever been to in my entire life," debt ridden and adrift as it made the transition from what was essentially a nursing home to an acute-care hospital. In 1983, he became its president, and began dismissing many doctors and opening clinics and a new emergency room. (That internal growth has continued with several expansions of the emergency room, the creation of a health maintenance organization and a nursing home, and the takeover of nearby Union Hospital, which was turned into an ambulatory care clinic.)
But the extent of his ambition has become clear only in the last several years. First, in 1996, came the three-year contract to provide doctors to Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center. Dr. Gade's approach drew praise from city health officials and cries of shock from the medical establishment. Not only did he dismiss or fail to rehire a significant number of doctors on the way to shrinking the medical staff; he abandoned the model of having residents provide much of the care. The idea was to have the work done by far fewer attending doctors, with many medical specialties performed by groups of doctors outside the hospital but on call. (Residents say these doctors come only late and reluctantly.)
 
Doctors Allege Dangerous Savings
While the academic tradition that Dr. Gade has de-emphasized is often criticized as costly, residents and senior doctors at Lincoln soon complained that staffing had become so low that it endangered patient care. The cuts, they said, had left clinics overcrowded and the residents often without proper supervision. Doctors were also told they could be dismissed at any time.
"Any time a physician is fired, the care becomes episodic and discontinuous," said Dr. Joseph Z. Kazigo, a Lincoln surgeon active in an ongoing effort to form a union. "To me that is not the mark of good care or of a good hospital."
Dr. Gade, along with Dr. Marcos, offers a somewhat conflicting account of success at Lincoln. On one hand, they contend patient care has actually improved, citing the fact that the hospital passed national accreditation in November.
On the other hand, both say the transition in some departments has been rocky, and Dr. Gade now concedes he has had to hire more doctors than he anticipated.
He also seemed to provide ammunition to opponents who accuse him of low-balling the bid by conceding that St. Barnabas would probably lose money on the deal.
By contrast, the contract to provide medical services at Rikers Island, where roughly 133,000 prisoners cycle in and out each year, has been going so well, Dr. Gade said, that he may have to return "windfall profits" to the city.
At Rikers, it is again a clash of philosophy that separates St. Barnabas from the previous provider of medical care, Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, which had had the contract since the early 1970's. City health officials had felt that Montefiore sent prisoners on costly trips to hospitals at the first sign of medical problems. Montefiore officials say they acted in the interests of patients' health, but in this latest contract, the city made the winner liable for all hospitalization. St. Barnabas has pursued that notion with zeal.
In addition to the huge overall drop in Rikers patients' visits to hospitals, one official in the city hospital system said that nonpsychiatric visits to Bellevue Hospital, one of three hospitals used by Rikers, had dropped markedly. On Jan. 5, when St. Barnabas took over, there were 23 such patients in Bellevue's prison ward. On Feb. 3, there were only 6.
"There are people who are sick that should be in the hospital but they are not being referred," said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "People are worried, even down to the clerks."
Dr. Gade disputes the contention that he is reluctant to send patients to a hospital, saying that in fact care is better with the addition of round-the-clock specialists in emergency medicine. The number of visits, he said, has dropped so greatly because more routine medical procedures like sutures or blood tests are performed at Rikers, as are more specialty services like dermatology or orthopedics.
"There is plenty of money in the contract to pay for hospitalization, and we are not going to take the risk with someone's life," he said.
The Rikers deal has also engendered a lawsuit, with one of the losing bidders, St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan, arguing that the city improperly awarded the contract to a bidder with no experience in prison health care.
In a sense, that suit is a measure of St. Barnabas's surprising rise. Until St. Barnabas won the contract, it was barely considered a player by its big-name rivals, said St. Vincent's medical director, Dr. Lambert N. King, who once ran the health system at Rikers.
"We frankly didn't consider them to be competition," he said.

INTERNATIONAL A3-9
 
U.S. Offers Russia a Deal To Stop Iran's Missile Plan
The United States is offering Russia the opportunity to expand its lucrative business launching foreign satellites if it clamps down on the sale of missile technology to Iran, senior American officials say. The plan is part of broad effort to discourage Russia from helping Iran develop a new surface-to-surface missile. A1
 
Islamic Women Speak Out
More Islamic women's groups are speaking out against what they call the Muslim system of apartheid, where texts of the Koran and a range of appendages attached in the Middle Ages are invoked to deny equal rights to women. The issue of how women are viewed is at the heart of much conflict in Muslim nations, from fundamentalist policies in Afghanistan and Iran to demands to abolish discrimination in family laws in Morocco and Tunisia. A1 

Serbs Claim Kosovo Victory
A three-day assault on the city of Prekaz by Serbian police and paramilitary units ended over the weekend, with Belgrade claiming victory over ethnic Albanian separatists in the southern Serbian province of Kosovo. Serbian officials said at least 26 ethnic Albanians and 2 police officers were killed, but there were indications that the toll may have been much higher. A3
 
The Foreign Ministers of the United States, France and Germany agreed on the need for "firm and clear measures" to stop the violence in Kosovo before it spreads. But with an emergency meeting scheduled for today in London, it was not clear that they agreed what those measures should be. Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said the Serbs should recognize "the legitimate political rights" of the ethnic Albanians. A3
 
Suharto Cool to I.M.F. Plan
President Suharto of Indonesia said that the open economic system promoted by the International Monetary Fund may not be right for his country, where the economy is based on "family principles," an Indonesian political leader said. The President's remarks came two days after the I.M.F. said it would delay the release of $3 billion to Indonesia. A8
 
TV Suicide Stirs Debate in Spain
A national debate in Spain on legal assisted suicide took an unexpected turn last week when a Spanish television station broadcast a homemade video that showed a quadriplegic man, Ramon Sampedro, saying farewell and then drinking cyanide-laced water through a straw. Mr. Sampedro had fought unsuccessfully for years in the courts to be helped to die. A9

Turks and their American friends maintained at the annual conference of the American-Turkish Council that the alliance between their countries is more vital than ever, but would not develop fully until Turkey improved its human rights record and presented its case more forcefully to Congress. A9

Congress will begin work in earnest this week on its tax and spending plans for next year. Immunizations for Meningitis

The disease has claimed the lives of 3 young Rhode Islanders over the last two months and has infected at least 12 people in that small state. The state hopes to inoculate some 250,000 people over the next six months at a cost of around $7 million. A10

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1565 words

HEADLINE: Heirs Try to Keep A Black Press Heritage Alive

BYLINE: By NICHOLE M. CHRISTIAN 

 BODY:
When John Sengstacke, the longtime chairman of Sengstacke Enterprises, died last spring, he left behind three things. First, a chain of black-owned newspapers, most notably The Chicago Defender, which is closely linked to 20th-century black history. Second, a family trust, the legal owner of the estate's assets, including the newspapers. And third, six grandchildren, the beneficiaries of the trust.
He also left two sets of instructions. To Northern Trust, the bank that he named trustee of the trust in 1975, he gave orders that his heirs have maximum financial security. From his oldest granddaughter, Myiti Sengstacke, he extracted a promise that the newspapers would stay in the family. 
 Now, the 26-year-old Ms. Sengstacke has decided to replace Northern Trust as trustee, fearing that its dedication to its fiduciary duties would result in the sale of the newspapers and force her to break her promise.
For what John Sengstacke did not leave behind was $4 million to pay his estate's tax bill. His chief assets -- four newspapers, including The Defender, a pioneering daily, and tons of publishing equipment -- are tied up in the trust fund.
Ms. Sengstacke recently dismissed Northern Trust and is embarking on the delicate task of finding a successor trustee and investors willing to step into the middle of a classic family business problem.
The closely held chain, which also includes weeklies in Detroit, Memphis and Pittsburgh, is valued at $10 million to $12 million before taxes. Like many other businesses that focus on ethnic minorities, the newspapers have lately found themselves struggling to keep up with the changing tastes and rising incomes of a market that is becoming increasingly attractive to advertisers.
Considering the black populations of the cities that the newspapers serve, some media experts say the papers are an untapped gold mine for an investor with enough cash and vision to modernize.
The chain's most profitable paper, The Michigan Chronicle, has a circulation of just more than 43,000 in a city with the nation's highest percentage of blacks in its population, 75.7 percent, or just more than one million people. The Defender's paid circulation is now 17,000 to 19,000, down from its high of 50,000 in the 1950's.
Reports in both papers lack the drama of the days of Jim Crow laws or the civil rights movement and urban riots of the 1960's and reflect a more affluent, if more complicated, era. Articles in both papers in recent days have focused on subjects ranging from the arrival of casino gambling in Detroit to new black business ventures.
"There is money to be made by black newspapers in the future," said Jake Oliver, the publisher of The Afro American, a weekly newspaper in Baltimore, "especially now that major corporations are beginning to reach out to the market we serve and are realizing that these newspapers are one of the fastest ways to get the minority audience."
It is unclear why Mr. Sengstacke allowed a company with one of black America's richest heritages to end up in the hands of a white bank instead of its founding family.
The Defender, a tabloid, helped nurture the careers of writers like Langston Hughes and W. E. B. Du Bois, a founder of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. And long before white politicians began to oppose the South's Jim Crow laws, The Defender published editorials decrying the treatment of black sharecroppers and promising a better life in Chicago's factories.
Many black intellectuals and business leaders thought that newspapers with this heritage would remain under Sengstacke control well into the next century. But for Northern Trust, which also serves as the executor of John Sengstacke's estate, the immediate issues were settling the estate and raising money to pay the taxes. A sale of the newspapers seemed in order; the race of the buyer was irrelevant.
"The greatest failure in estate planning is not communicating your plan to the people it will affect," said Mark Rubin, founder of the Metropolitan Group, a family-business consulting firm in New Jersey. "You wouldn't expect a trustee to have an interest broader than the financial interest." Finding a successor trustee, he added, is not unusual, but in some cases such a move can jeopardize both the company and family harmony.
What happens now that the company is off the auction block depends largely on whether Ms. Sengstacke can find a bank to back her plan. If she fails, the company will revert to Northern Trust's control.
"This is not an easy trust assignment," said Elias Matsakis, a lawyer with McBride, Baker & Cole in Chicago, the firm representing Ms. Sengstacke. "But we're pleased with the recognition that a number of major Chicago financial institutions have for the legacy this family is attempting to preserve."
Mr. Matsakis said six banks in Chicago and Detroit had already met with Ms. Sengstacke about the trust. He declined, however, to identify them or say whether they included black-owned institutions.
One option suggested by Ms. Sengstacke's advisers involves paying off the tax debt and then reorganizing the company under either a merger or the issuance of additional stock, possibly nonvoting common stock. Another possibility would be to have an investor pay off the debt in exchange for nonvoting preferred stock.
Assuming such options are viable, Ms. Sengstacke said, her family would quickly put together a management team to entice advertisers and try to lure back many of the black readers, now middle class, who have abandoned black newspapers across the country for more upscale newspapers and magazines.
"The challenge," said Larry Grimes, president of W. B. Grimes, a Maryland media brokerage firm, "is to convince the advertising community that the markets these papers serve is made up of professionals and families and not just the unemployed people that are perceived."
The newspapers in the Sengstacke chain have spent several generations battling preconceptions. John Sengstacke inherited the company from his uncle, Robert Sengstacke Abbott, who was the son of former slaves. Robert S. Abbott, who turned himself into one of America's first black millionaires, sat in a one-room apartment in downtown Chicago in 1905 and drew up The Defender's first issue with just 25 cents worth of pencils and paper.
When his nephew and heir, John Sengstacke, died last year, Myiti Sengstacke was attending Hampton University, the same historically black college in Virginia that her grandfather attended, at his uncle's instructions, to learn the business.
Robert Sengstacke, who is Myiti's father and John Sengstacke's only living child, said in an interview that his family's quandary epitomized the problems family businesses face when no clear heir is groomed. He said he had been overlooked in favor of his children because of a feud with his father.
Ms. Sengstacke maintains that her decision to remove Northern Trust is in the best interest of her family. "We never saw eye to eye about my grandfather's intentions for the company," said Ms. Sengstacke, who said she was acting as the proxy for her brothers and sister.
She added: "This is something we've given a lot of thought to. We understand that the trust has to be funded and that we have to be taken care of."
For its part, Northern Trust called Ms. Sengstacke's move a disappointment, saying, "We believe we have acted from the outset to follow faithfully the clear directions left by John Sengstacke in the trust and to serve the best interest of all the trust beneficiaries." The trust controls 65 percent of the company's stock on behalf of Mr. Sengstacke's grandchildren. Nine other family members control the rest.
When the Sengstacke board and its minority shareholders, including Robert Sengstacke, voted to sell, Ms. Sengstacke was the only person to oppose the decision publicly. Soon after the vote, she stepped down from a management trainee post at the Detroit paper to spend more time devising a plan to block the sale. She is living on savings, though she continues to sit on the board along with a great-uncle and three Northern Trust appointees, who will remain until a successor trustee is chosen.
People who have seen the Sengstacke trust documents say they include a clause allowing any two dissatisfied adult beneficiaries to seek a successor trustee. These people say Ms. Sengstacke persuaded two brothers, Saief, 24, and Omhari, 20, to sign a letter to Northern Trust notifying it of their dissatisfaction. She then met with the bank one last time before serving notice, thus blocking the sale.
Those in the black community who fear the end of black ownership are cautiously watching Ms. Sengstacke's efforts, some even preparing their own purchase plans should she fail.
"If it's not owned and operated by a black group, we will begin a boycott," said the Rev. Al Sampson, pastor of Fernwood United Methodist Church and head of a community coalition that is meeting with investors and starting a subscription drive. "This will not be another one of our institutions that dies because black people didn't try to save it."
And Ms. Sengstacke said: "My grandfather could have sold this company to anybody he wanted to before he died. He left it for us because he knew we would carry the torch and keep the legacy alive."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
After taking some recent lumps, Texas Instruments may be poised for an upturn.

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson 

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
THOMAS J. ENGIBOUS, the chief executive of Texas Instruments, wasted no time Thursday in putting an upbeat chip industry forecast delivered by his economist, Vladi Catto, in the right perspective.
"I'm always encouraged by what Vladi says," Mr. Engibous told about 160 analysts and money managers at his company's annual conference. "But judging by what the market says, I'm the only one who is." 
 He was alluding not only to the 12.5 percent plunge in Intel's stock price that day on a gloomy earnings outlook issued the day before but also to the 3.75 percent decline in his company's shares, to $52.9375. Motorola likewise warned late Thursday of disappointing earnings because of weak chip sales in Asia. But on Friday, Texas Instruments shares rose $1.5625, to $54.50.
Unlike Intel, Texas Instruments is becoming less and less attached to the personal computer industry -- a combination of good luck, years of planning and efforts by Mr. Engibous since he became chief executive at age 43 less than two years ago.
Only one of the company's 10 largest customers makes personal computers, down from about about 6 of 10 in the early 1990's. Today, the largest customers for the company's chips are Nokia, Ericsson and other telecommunications manufacturers.
Mr. Engibous has bet the company's future on specialized chips, called digital signal processors. While these chips are used in computer components like modems and hard drives, they are finding rapidly growing markets ranging from cellular telephones, computer networking equipment and cars to talking dolls and precision scales used in fishing tournaments.
As in any yard sale where someone else is not paying for the move, Mr. Engibous has sold off some items that were valuable but too heavy to take along. The military electronics business went to Raytheon, the laptop computer business to Acer.
For investors willing to differentiate among semiconductor stocks, Texas Instruments appears to be better poised to resist the industry's afflictions. While the first quarter looks weak enough to justify some caution, the rest of the year might be almost as encouraging as Mr. Engibous hopes.
Over recent months, analysts, with the company's guidance, have been trimming their first-quarter estimates to less than 50 cents a share from 66 cents a year earlier. They cite Asian financial turmoil and slower growth in demand from American customers in businesses including personal computers. The company's current weakness and short-term outlook account for a decline in its stock from a peak of $71.25 on Oct. 13.
The full year, and next year, are different stories. Though the current price-to-earnings ratio hovers around 70, analysts' expectations of a rebound for the full year mean that the ratio based on forecasts of 1998 earnings is only about 22. For the semiconductor industry as a whole, Mr. Catto said, last year's 4 percent growth in revenue, constrained by a nearly two-thirds drop in prices for memory chips, will rise to 10 percent this year, then 20 percent to 35 percent next year, as memory chip prices recover and Asia rebounds.
The glut of memory chips, or D-RAM's, is likely to subside later this year because Japanese and Korean makers have sharply cut their investments in new plants and equipment. The prime beneficiary will be Micron Technologies, whose shares rose $1.5625, to $34.5625, on Thursday even as other semiconductor stocks fell. Micron, which specializes in memory chips, is challenging Samsung of Korea for the largest share of the market.
Analysts and investors continued pressing Texas Instruments on Thursday to unload its memory chip business, a steady money-loser that even in good times remains highly volatile. Mr. Engibous refused, as usual, to make any promises.
But just watch what he does, not what he says. Abandoning a previous strategy of sharing the memory chip risks through joint ventures, he has recently sold the company's interest in a partnership with Acer of Taiwan and ended the Twin Star joint venture with Hitachi of Japan. The Twin Star plant, near Dallas, could be converted to making digital signal processors.
These chips, which are much less versatile than Intel's microprocessors but much faster, translate inputs such as sound and light into the ones and zeros of digital signals in products like cellular phones, automobiles and camcorders.
The growth in sales of these chips has consistently exceeded 30 percent, with Texas Instruments growing even more rapidly, controlling about half the market. "We don't use the word dominate," Mr. Engibous said, his manner about as coy as a tornado. "But we're trying to get more and more every day."
Texas Instruments thus argues that it deserves better treatment from investors than they are giving Intel.
And, in fact, some analysts are advising nervous investors who still want to play technology stocks to look at Texas Instruments. "There has been a lot of money in Intel that will be looking for another home," said Michael Gumport of Lehman Brothers. "The Texas Instruments story is much more compelling."

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Pressing Moscow on Iran And Missile Aid

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 8

 BODY:
The United States is offering Russia an opportunity to expand its lucrative business launching foreign satellites if it clamps down on the sale of missile technology to Iran, senior American officials say.
The American position has been conveyed confidentially to the Russians and is part of a broad effort to discourage Russian companies and institutes from helping Iran develop a new surface-to-surface missile. 
 The offer is potentially worth hundreds of millions of dollars to Russian companies and the Western companies that have formed partnerships with them.
"We are prepared to go forward and enhance cooperation in this area, but we cannot do it in the absence of progress on the Iran ballistic missile front," a senior Clinton Administration official said today.
Washington has long been worried about Russian nuclear cooperation with Iran. More recently the United States has also become concerned about Iran's effort to develop missiles that could carry a nuclear warhead, poison gas or germ weapons.
The nuclear and missile issues are on the agenda of this week's Washington meetings between Vice President Al Gore and Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia.
Many of the satellites launched are American, and the United States already has an agreement that permits a limited number of Russian satellite launches.
Iran has been developing a new missile, called the Shahab 3, that has a range of about 800 miles -- long enough to reach Israel and Saudi Arabia and more than twice the range of a Scud missile.
American intelligence experts expect Iran to flight-test the missile over the next year or so. Much of the missile design is based on North Korean technology. Increasingly, however, American officials have become worried about the flow of missile technology from Russia.
Under strong American pressure, the Russians have taken a number of steps, including a new decree by President Boris N. Yeltsin tightening controls on the export of missile know-how to Iran. But American officials are waiting to see if the Russians strictly enforce the measure.
If the Russians do crack down, Washington is willing to ease limits on Russia's launching of foreign satellites, American officials say.
"This is not a carrot that is being created for this issue," said an American specialist, who like some of the others willing to discuss the issue, spoke on condition of anonymity. "The idea of allowing more launches is something that makes commercial sense, unless something disturbs the atmosphere and makes it difficult to do. If Iran did not exist, it is something that would probably proceed."
Certainly, the easing of the limits could be a major boost for Russia's hard-strapped space program and a boon for the American companies, which have begun to join forces with the Russians in offering services launching communications, imaging and navigational satellites.
The current limits on satellite launches are enshrined in a 1996 agreement, which was signed by Mr. Gore and Mr. Chernomyrdin. Using a complicated formula, it limits the launches of foreign satellites that are placed in stationary orbits 22,300 miles above the earth, enabling the satellite to stay over a fixed spot.
The 1996 accord sought to protect American companies from Russian competition. Since then, however, the space launch business has changed.
Lockheed-Martin, for instance, is now part of a consortium with the Khrunichev State Research and Production Space Center, which offers space launch services using Russia's Proton rocket.
Boeing is involved in a consortium with Russian, Ukrainian and Norwegian companies to launch satellites from a sea-based platform, which will operate near the equator.
"The increase of the quota is an important and necessary issue for us," Yuri N. Koptev, the director of the Russian space agency and the official in charge of preventing sales of missile technology to Iran, said in an interview. "It is not only a problem for Russia, it is also in the interest of American companies. We know that on Feb. 5, the main manufacturers contacted Mr. Gore with a proposal to abolish these restrictions."
Charles Vick, a research analyst at the Federation of American Scientists, estimated that the cost of each satellite launch could range from $80 million to $100 million.
"There would be more missions, more contracts, and it would really help the U.S. balance of payments as well as provide more money for the Russian economy," Mr. Vick said.
Still, given the political sensitivity of the Iran issue and uncertainty about Russia's enforcement of its new technology controls, lifting the restriction will not be quick or easy.
To encourage Moscow to act, American officials have been sharing intelligence with it about suspected Russian deals with Iran.
Robert Gallucci, the former official who helped resolve the stalemate over North Korea's suspected nuclear program, was recently named a special Administration envoy to Russia on the missile technology issue and visited Moscow last week.
Responding to American concerns, Russia has expelled an Iranian diplomat who was trying to purchase missile technology. It has also suspended a contract between a Russian rocket engine manufacturer and Iran.
But there have been allegations that Iranian missile scientists are still being trained by the Baltic State Technical University in St. Petersburg. And while Mr. Yeltsin ordered the tightening of export controls, the Russian bureaucracy has not always effectively carried out his orders.
"They have taken a number of important steps, but the issue now is implementation," a senior American official said.
Russia's recently disclosed plans to increase the number of nuclear reactors it will sell to Iran has also clouded the picture.
Russian officials insist, however, that they are cracking down.
"The 13 cases which our American colleagues have so nicely informed us of have been considered, and we have provided detailed explanations," Mr. Koptev said. "In the cases where we saw some doubtful aspects, these contacts were severed."
Both sides have been careful not to link the question of raising the space launch quota publicly with the Iran issue, though privately officials on both sides acknowledge that the questions are bound together.
Mr. Koptev said the Americans had not made an "official" proposal to ease the quota on launchers in return for Russian cooperation on Iran. But he quickly added, "I take dinner conversations very calmly, and I don't consider it an official discussion."

LENGTH: 1084 words

HEADLINE: Energizing The Future Of Black Theater

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW 

DATELINE: HANOVER, N.H., March 8

 BODY:
In an intensive marathon of talks and panel discussions on Saturday at Dartmouth College here, a wide cross section of theater artists and business and foundation executives confronted a crisis in black theater and searched for new ways to carry that theater past the millennium.
"Black theater is black America's imagination, intelligence and humanity," the playwright August Wilson said on Saturday night in his rousing address. In answer to a question he was repeatedly asked, he said that black theater definitely had a future. He and other speakers expressed the hope that its organizations would be self-determining and self-sufficient. 
 The closing session, the only day open to the public, was attended by an audience of 300. It was the culmination of a five-day conference on black theater convened by Mr. Wilson, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of "Fences," "The Piano Lesson" and other plays. Saturday's forum on the Dartmouth campus here followed a series of private meetings the previous week at the college's Minary Center in Ashland, N.H.
The conference grew out of a speech that Mr. Wilson gave in June 1996 during a Theater Communications Group conference at Princeton University. In that speech, he called for black theater artists to come together in 1998 "to reignite and reunite our people's positive energy for apolitical and social change that is reflective of our spiritual truths."
While there was silence from other colleges and universities, two Dartmouth professors, Victor Leo Walker 2d and William W. Cook, answered the playwright's call. The conference was jointly sponsored by the Rockefeller and Ford Foundations and Dartmouth. Mr. Wilson is teaching playwriting this semester at Dartmouth.
The Saturday meeting was high on dramatic language and performance flair. There were repeated outbreaks of dancing and singing before and after the panels, some planned, some spontaneous. In contrast with other theater conferences, this was partly a public celebration.
As a panel on economics was about to begin, a man stood up in the audience and shouted, "I want to know about 'the dollar.' " Moving on stage he continued his spiel while tap-dancing. The man was Idris Ackamoor, himself a panelist as well as a performance artist. His entrance had, of course, been scheduled, but it still caught the audience by surprise.
Before a luncheon panel on "African and New World and diaspora theaters," Ntozake Shange, a playwright and performer, joined the other panelists in a dance: mambo and hip-hop ending with a "glory shout." Then the panelists settled down, somewhat, for a vigorous exchange, with Ms. Shange making an artistic statement, "It is through movement and language and ritual that we know freedom and if we know freedom we can know art."
Although some of the issues raised were familiar, and few answers were forthcoming, there was fervor in the air and apparently a desire to make a difference in black theater, which, as Mr. Wilson and others explained, had declined in visibility and public support since its heyday in the 1960's.
Given all the opportunities for negativism, most of the discussions were positive. As Mr. Cook said, "With a powerfully shared feeling that a crisis had to be met, people decided to forget their differences." Anticipating argument, he said, it was instead an optimistic week followed by "a soul-filled afternoon," an afternoon that extended late into the evening.
There was criticism, however, of mainstream theater companies that commission the work of black playwrights -- work that is sometimes not produced -- in order to be eligible for grants to encourage racially diverse art. As a result, it was said, money is drawn away from those companies that specialize in African-American theater.
One of the primary proposals to emerge was for a national coordinating agency, which might become a major foundation that would directly support black artists and organizations. It was also suggested that there be more collaboration between companies and community organizations, and that there be even closer ties between professional theater and colleges and universities, which often have the best-equipped theaters.
A library and video archive might also be established, especially to accommodate those unpublished plays. Alternatively there is the possibility of creating a black publishing company, which would print those plays. Responding to that idea, Ed Bullins, an exceedingly prolific playwright, said, "When the black arts movement went out of fashion, I went out of print."
An important goal is to encourage black playwriting and to increase the number of large resident theaters. At present there is only one such black institution, the Crossroads Theater in New Brunswick, N.J., operating under a League of Resident Theaters contract.
Panels confronted subjects from esthetics to economics, with considerable time devoted to methods of marketing directly to blacks. Walter Dallas, artistic director of the Freedom Theater in Philadelphia, one of many smaller black companies in the United States, said that he regarded every aspect of the theater as subject to the principles of marketing. It was, he said, all a matter of presentation, and extended from the work produced to the ambiance of the theater itself.
The first concrete result of the conference is an alliance with Dartmouth's Amos Tuck School of Business Administration, which, beginning this summer, will invite heads of theaters to participate in its executive training programs. Speeches and position papers are to be collected in a book and subsequent conferences in Atlanta and Houston are to follow up in detail some of the issues raised here.
James Wright, provost of Dartmouth, struck a note for diversity, calling African-American culture "a rich and vibrant part of American culture" that should -- and does -- maintain its own identity. He said that Mr. Wilson's work reflected "the experience and the aspirations, the poetry and the cadence of early-20th-century African-American migrants to the industrial and urban north." Comparing Mr. Wilson's characters to those of Shakespeare and Ibsen, he said, "The universal themes that resonate from the lives of these individuals are based on the richness of the particular, not the abstractions of the general."
The richness of the particular, the black experience as imaginatively recreated by Mr. Wilson and other playwrights, was at the core of the discussion.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Roommates Who Resist Growing Up

BYLINE: By CARYN JAMES 

 BODY:
You're not seeing double. This week there are two new sitcoms about a group of old friends in their 20's, two men and a woman, who live in the same house and are self-consciously Peter Panish about growing up. Several more with similar themes will appear in the next weeks. (It seems married people share real estate and have trouble growing up, too.) Before you can say, "Goodbye, Seinfeld," you are witnessing the copycat boomlet that defines this year's midseason replacement shows.
The first to arrive, "House Rules," at least carries hints of a loopy humor. Set in Denver, this one features two appealing characters: an assistant district attorney named Casey (Maria Pitillo), and her childhood friend and housemate, a medical student named McCusky (David Newsom). Riley (Bradley White) is also their friend and housemate, but the apparently unemployed character is so badly defined he simply takes up space. 
 Tonight's episode reveals how lame the plots are, as Casey must decide whether to move to Paris with her arrogant boyfriend. But any "Seinfeld" clone knows that droll observations are more important than stories. "House Rules" relies on scenes like the one in which McCusky and Riley make fun of how Casey's boyfriend says goodbye to her: "Later, baby."
Next week's episode is better, with Patrick Warburton (Puddy on "Seinfeld") appearing as a intense, deadpan policeman whose idea of fun is asking Casey to shoot him in his bulletproof vest.
The show's executive producer is Chris Thompson, who created and was executive producer for the first season of "The Naked Truth," its only funny season.
But that's looking at this show's brightest possibility. The retro atmosphere of "Three's Company" hangs ominously over "House Rules," suggesting the series could nose dive any minute.
 
'Two Guys, A Girl and a Pizza Place'
 ABC, Wednesday night at 9:30
 (Channel 7 in New York)
Nothing is more cloying than a sitcom that works overtime to be cute and zany, and the strained title of this charmless comedy gives it away. This time three former college friends live in Boston. Berg (Ryan Reynolds, whose comic energy is better than his material) is a graduate student in philosophy who moonlights in a pizza place and as a guinea pig for new products (one week he tests nasal spray, the next talking shoes). His roommate, Pete (Richard Ruccolo), an architecture student, also works at the pizza place, where supposedly wacky characters hang out. Their upstairs neighbor, a saleswoman for a chemical company, is Sharon (Traylor Howard, unaccountably perky though her character is whiny).
The show was originally bought by the Fox network, then sold to ABC. Decisions like that may help explain why Fox's fortunes are rising while ABC's are not.

NBC, tonight at 8:30
(Channel 4 in New York)

HEADLINE: An Omitted Passage In Article on Dodger Sale

 BODY:
A front-page article yesterday about Rupert Murdoch's purchase of the Los Angeles Dodgers baseball team omitted several paragraphs in some copies. Following is the omitted passage, which should have appeared at the beginning of the continuation page:
If baseball does welcome Mr. Murdoch, though, it will do so with fingers crossed -- that rules governing revenue sharing or precluding outside licensing or sponsorship deals will not be broken and that, in short, Mr. Murdoch will not run roughshod over their game. "I can't judge whether he would be a good or a bad owner," said Michael Eisner, the chairman of the Walt Disney Company, which owns the controlling stake in the Anaheim Angels. "But I don't think he would not follow the rules." 
 In 1957, Walter O'Malley convulsed baseball's economics by moving the Dodgers from Brooklyn to California's virgin major league market, proving that even the most beloved team is a bottom-line business property to be exploited for its strategic value.
Now, Mr. O'Malley's son, Peter, who had grown disaffected with the sport's other owners in recent years, is about to unsettle baseball again -- leaving the sport with the disquieting parting gift of selling his legacy to a media powerhouse known for shaking up every business he acquires.
The deal -- including Dodger Stadium and its 300 acres, the Dodgertown spring training site and minor league team in Vero Beach, Fla., and a training complex in the Dominican Republic -- closes an era when families like the Yawkeys and Griffiths and Stonehams made owning a baseball team their exclusive business. Soaring player salaries have routed them, and they have been replaced primarily by investors made wealthy elsewhere and giant corporations.

HEADLINE: Albright Tours Europe to Whip Up Resolve to Punish Serbia

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: LONDON, March 8

 BODY:
The foreign ministers of the United States, France and Germany agreed today on the need for "firm and clear measures" to stop the violence in the Serbian province of Kosovo before it spreads to other nations.
But with an emergency meeting scheduled here on Monday, of six countries that monitor the former Yugoslavia, it was not clear that the six agree on what those measures should be. 
 Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, who spent the day going from Rome to Bonn to Paris and finally to London to meet her counterparts, wants a mix of diplomacy and punitive sanctions on the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic.
But the Contact Group -- composed of the Italians, Germans, French, British and Americans, along with Russia -- includes differing views. The French were noncommittal today about the types of measures needed, and the Russians have made it clear that they oppose new sanctions on Serbia.
The British and Germans are expected to support the Americans, with the Italians closer to the French.
"The time to stop the killing is now, before it spreads," Ms. Albright said in Bonn with Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel.
She said Belgrade must "understand the seriousness of the situation" in Kosovo province, where the Serbs have cracked down extremely harshly on independence movements of the Albanian population. Ethnic Albanians make up 90 percent of Kosovo's 1.8 million population.
Ms. Albright urged "immediate action against the regime in Belgrade, to insure that it pays a price for the damage it has already done, and to encourage it to finally resolve the problems in Kosovo through dialogue and reconciliation."
She said the Serbs should recognize "the legitimate political rights" of the ethnic Albanians.
While the unrest in Kosovo is raising fears of another Bosnia, there are differences. Primarily, while Bosnia broke away from Yugoslavia, no one questions Serb sovereignty in Kosovo.
For the Russians, the best analogy is to Chechnya, where Russia tried to put down an independence movement with brutal methods and resented Western criticism. Russia is unlikely to want to see a precedent of sanctions that could someday be applied in Russia.
American officials acknowledge differences between Bosnia and Kosovo, but say that Mr. Milosevic has a special history of brutality. And they say Kosovo has a unique potential to spark unrest in the region.
In her conversations today with Mr. Kinkel and the French Foreign Minister, Hubert Vedrine, Ms. Albright stressed the need to punish Mr. Milosevic. Otherwise, she said, the violence could spill over to other countries, including Macedonia -- which has its an ethnic Albanian minority -- and Albania itself.
Senior American officials said the area causing them concern stretched as far as Greece and Turkey, which are NATO members and which could get drawn in if the conflict extends to Macedonia.
Mr. Kinkel expressed concern that the violence would produce a wave of refugees who want to enter Germany, which already provides for 140,000 asylum seekers from Kosovo and 400,000 others from Albania.
Mr. Kinkel said Germany supported the kind of punitive measures that Ms. Albright had in mind. "Everything must be done to insure that another awful conflagration does not explode in Europe," Mr. Kinkel said. "We need to act in time."
The Americans and Europeans are struggling against the lessons of the recent past, when inattention and disunity in the West allowed the Bosnian civil war to take hold and spread.
But Mr. Vedrine said that while he and Ms. Ms. Albright had discussed Kosovo, "we didn't draw any specific conclusions."
Mr. Vedrine said they agreed that the situation is "serious and requires urgent measures, and we need to be firm and clear and find an immediate solution." But it was evident that there would be much talking to do on Monday to find a common position. The Russian Foreign Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, is expected to be the only one of his colleagues not to attend the meeting in London, as a form of protest.
In Paris, Ms. Albright said that "the only effective way to stop violence in that region is to act with firmness and speed," and to those who oppose economic sanctions, she said, "Moral condemnation and expressions of concern alone will get us nowhere."
But American and European officials were reluctant to discuss the terms of any possible sanctions, which the Americans said on Friday would be economic.
Given vocal Russian opposition to new sanctions, the Americans have been trying to line up support from the other members to persuade Russia of the need to punish the Serbs. "No doubt we're going to have difficulty with the Russians, that's a fact," a senior State Department official said.
If unanimity cannot be reached at the meeting, the Americans are expected to act with other like-minded nations.
A senior official said of Ms. Albright that "the last thing she would want is a repeat of the last time the world had a chance to stop something like this from spinning out of control and didn't, because of lowest-common-denominator diplomacy."
The contact group will consider diplomatic efforts as Mr. Kinkel listed them at his news conference.
They include an extension of the United Nations peacekeeping force in Macedonia, which comprises about 900 soldiers, including some 350 Americans, to keep down ethnic tensions there.
Mr. Kinkel also suggested increasing a force of European peacekeepers in Albania. He also called for an urgent meeting of regional foreign ministers. American officials said they wanted punitive measures, too. Among those, they said, was a quick reminder to Serbia that the writ of the tribunal that brings war-crimes charges also covers the events in Kosovo.
There are currently some sanctions on Serbia. It is prohibited from getting any loans from agencies like the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, and the Government is not fully recognized by Washington.

HEADLINE: Yes, Close Associates of Clinton Say, He Privately Vents Anger on Inquiry

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
It is generally in his most private mo ments with his wife, his personal lawyers, a couple of his closest aides and friends -- that President Clinton allows himself to display the anger he harbors toward the prosecutors and investigators digging into his relationship with a former White House intern, associates of Mr. Clinton said.
Seven weeks into his worst political crisis, President Clinton rarely betrays any strain to most of his White House staff and friends, who have been watching him closely for signs of stress. He believes that to show distraction or dismay, his aides said, would be to hand a victory to his antagonist, the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr. 
 And so the President has maintained a full schedule, holding meetings last week on subjects from the Middle East peace process to European monetary union to education policy -- and even taking time to play a prank on a staff member.
But the President is increasingly bitter about what he sees as the poisonous atmosphere in Washington, his friends said, and that sometimes bubbles to the surface. His advisers hear it every now and then in Mr. Clinton's wry, sarcastic asides about the news media or the prosecutors. And it has come through in some of his public remarks.
Before an adoring crowd of celebrities at a Beverly Hills fund-raiser about a week ago, Mr. Clinton departed from his generally genial and upbeat tone to deliver a scorching appraisal of the capital.
"Washington is a place where too many people take themselves too seriously," he said, "where a lot of people profess to be profoundly religious but actually worship power." Mr. Starr has been reported to sing hymns by a creek near his home.
Criticism of Washington, of course, is a hardy perennial of American politics, and Mr. Clinton has long made a point of his contempt for the capital's culture. But he has been particularly biting recently.
In addition to attacking Washington as power hungry, Mr. Clinton has taken regularly to reminding his listeners that the nation's founders were intent on preventing what he calls "the arbitrary exercise of absolute power." The paradox of such observations about abuse of power is that this is the transgression of which Mr. Clinton stands accused.
Three days before his Beverly Hills appearance, Mr. Clinton remarked at a fund-raiser in San Francisco that in Washington, "We need a lot more concern about people and less concern about power."
Later that night, at another fund-raiser for Democratic Congressional candidates, Mr. Clinton said that he had tried to "change the political culture of Washington, with, you would have to charitably say, mixed results. I don't even understand it half the time. I realize I'm afflicted by the fact that I had a real life for too long."
He thanked San Francisco's Mayor, Willie L. Brown Jr., for "sticking up for me" on the television program "Politically Incorrect."
"It's truly strange that that would be politically incorrect to do," Mr. Clinton mused, "but that's all right."
With his confidant and adviser Vernon E. Jordan Jr. testifying before the grand jury, Mr. Clinton, who has not formed many close friendships in Washington, is running out of people he trusts here.
"It's definitely a dwindling crowd," one Clinton friend said of the President's loyal Washington associates. "I bet you can't put five of them on a hand now."
He said Mr. Clinton believed that there was a "concerted effort" to "throw mud and destroy him."
Some aides and friends of the President said he had stopped reading articles about the intern matter; others say he has not stopped, but has sharply cut back.
"Who needs it?" asked one aide.
Sometimes in public recently, Mr. Clinton has seemed distracted and worn, with bags under his eyes.
When the accusations against the President were disclosed, even some of his close advisers wondered whether he could survive politically. But as the weeks have passed and his poll numbers have only grown stronger, Mr. Clinton and his aides have grown more confident.
"It has really gotten us over the hump," said the Clinton friend, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Mr. Clinton and his advisers have concluded that having denied an affair with the former intern, Monica S. Lewinsky, he can afford to remain silent about the nature of the relationship.
Mr. Clinton is never free of the accusations, but he generally treats them as a mere nuisance, at least when he is with most staff members and visitors. Still, before every public event, he must steel himself and his guests for inevitable shouted questions about Ms. Lewinsky.
Before reporters were briefly admitted to a Medicare meeting Mr. Clinton held on Thursday morning with members of Congress and experts, he warned his guests that the reporters were "going to jump all over me," said one person who was there.
After the reporters had asked their questions, and left, the group chuckled over the performance. Mr. Clinton joked about the most voluble questioner, Sam Donaldson of ABC. Mr. Clinton said he had sent Mr. Donaldson a birthday card, in which the President congratulated him on recovering from an illness.
"It looks like you have completely recovered," Mr. Clinton said he wrote, "at my expense." Asked about the card, Mr. Donaldson said he never disclosed private communications from the President.
Mr. Clinton is careful to vent his frustration only among his closest friends and advisers, most of whom, like Hillary Rodham Clinton, are protected by various forms of privilege.
"As you might expect, he's pretty judicious about where and how he expresses it," said one senior Administration official.
It is only in that tight circle that Mr. Clinton lets off steam about developments that particularly anger him, like Mr. Starr's decision to subpoena one of the President's advisers, Sidney Blumenthal, to question him about contacts with the press.
But most of the President's advisers never see that side of him. Junior and senior staff members said they had carefully watched the President's behavior, and taken cues from it to set aside the Lewinsky matter and focus on their jobs.
"Inside, to the people closest around him, he's projecting a real sense of buoyancy," said Paul Begala, an adviser to Mr. Clinton. "He's always, always self-confident. Always. And, man, that helps."
White House officials were delighted last week with an event at which Mr. Clinton called for setting a national standard for drivers' blood-alcohol levels. It showed, they said, that Mr. Clinton could still command the attention of the news media and the Congress for a matter of policy. The Senate immediately acted on the bill that Mr. Clinton endorsed.
"Lo and behold, the Senate passed the amendment," said Michael D. McCurry, the press secretary, "and everyone said 'in a White-House-backed amendment.' And we all said, 'Yes, we got it!' "
Mr. Clinton is still clipping and marking articles from newspapers and magazines and shipping them to advisers. He is still returning policy memorandums flecked with his left-handed check marks.
Gene Sperling, director of the National Economic Council, faxed Mr. Clinton on Feb. 28 with his weekly economic memorandum while the President was on vacation in Utah. On the last page of the memorandum, after items about student loan interest rates and Indonesia, he added the kind of gossip that Mr. Clinton loves. He wrote that John F. Welch Jr., the chairman of General Electric, had told him that he had beaten Greg Norman, the professional golfer, by one stroke in a round of golf.
Mr. Sperling discovered that Mr. Clinton had read the memo by the time of their first meeting on Monday morning. As Mr. Sperling walked in, Mr. Clinton was joking with Erskine B. Bowles, the chief of staff, about Mr. Welch's victory.
Mr. Clinton has gone out of his way recently to lighten the mood at the White House. During the 1996 campaign, Mr. McCurry famously took a $100 bet and, with his clothes on, jumped into the pool at the same Beverly Hills estate where Mr. Clinton attended the fund-raiser on Feb. 28. With Mr. McCurry back in Washington, Mr. Clinton had himself photographed as though he were falling into the pool, said Doug Sosnik, another adviser to the President.
Mr. Clinton signed the photograph and handed it to Mr. McCurry after the two climbed into a helicopter on Tuesday night for a flight to Andrews Air Force Base. Then he sat back and watched Mr. McCurry's expression change as he recognized the pool and the prank sank in.
"The President nailed him," Mr. Sosnik said.

HEADLINE: Clinton Partner In Whitewater Dies in Prison

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
James B. McDougal, whose accounts of business dealings with Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton ultimately led to the sprawling Whitewater investigations that continue to haunt the Clintons, died today in Fort Worth, where he was imprisoned.
Mr. McDougal, who was 57 but looked much older because of chronic circulatory problems, died of cardiac arrest, the Justice Department said. 
 Lawyers involved in the Whitewater inquiry said Mr. McDougal's death was a blow to the investigation. For years, Mr. McDougal had denounced the prosecutors and proclaimed his innocence. But after his conviction in 1996 on 18 felony counts stemming from his operation of a corrupt Arkansas savings and loan, he received a lighter prison term in exchange for his cooperation with the Whitewater investigation.
Even though he had given conflicting accounts of events and suffered from mental illness a decade earlier, he became an important witness, was debriefed dozens of times by investigators and made many appearances before a grand jury in Little Rock, Ark.
Mr. McDougal's secret testimony will almost certainly be part of the report that must be filed by the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, at the end of the investigation to the Federal appeals court that appointed him.
But with the death of Mr. McDougal, investigators have lost an important figure who would have been in a position to corroborate new evidence they might receive from another witness in the inquiry, Jim Guy Tucker, who resigned as Governor of Arkansas after being convicted along with Mr. McDougal and sentenced to probation.
After rebuffing investigators, Mr. Tucker decided two weeks ago that he would cooperate with the investigation. When Mr. McDougal was sentenced last April to a three-year prison term, Mr. Starr said Mr. McDougal had "truthfully and substantially aided" investigators, leading to new revelations "which could only be known by a few insiders."
Mr. Starr said Mr. McDougal was "at the epicenter" of an investigation that began as an examination of three people: Mr. McDougal and his Whitewater business partners, the President and Mrs. Clinton.
Mr. McDougal said Mr. Clinton had never followed through with a promised job, and it was those frustrations, Mr. McDougal said, that prompted him to tell The New York Times in 1992 about Whitewater and how he had carried a disproportionate share of losses from the venture, a real estate development deal in northern Arkansas. He also said Mrs. Clinton, a lawyer, had represented his savings and loan association, Madison Guaranty, before a regulator appointed by her husband.
Asked by the "Dateline NBC" program last year whether he had betrayed his friends, Mr. McDougal said: "I don't think so. I think the Clintons are really sort of like tornadoes moving through people's lives. I'm just one of the people left in the wake of their passing by, but I have no whining or complaining to do, because I have lots of company."
He also said of Mr. Clinton, "I just got sick and tired of lying for the fellow, you know."
President Clinton, whose complicated relationship with Mr. McDougal began in the 1970's when both men were rising political figures in Arkansas, said he was saddened to learn of Mr. McDougal's death.
"I have good memories of the years we worked together in Arkansas and I extend my condolences to his family," the President said.
Mr. McDougal, who had a history of heart disease, had been serving his prison term at the Federal Medical Center in Fort Worth. A Justice Department spokeswoman, Sue Beasley, said workers at the prison medical center observed Mr. McDougal "in distress" today at 10:30 A.M. Life-support was administered and Mr. McDougal was taken by ambulance to the John Peter Smith Hospital, where he was pronounced dead shortly after noon.
Mr. McDougal died during the same weekend that his former wife's prison term for contempt had been completed at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, a Federal prison in Los Angeles. Susan McDougal had served the term because she did not want to testify before a grand jury, having said that she feared committing perjury after Mr. McDougal decided to cooperate.
Mrs. McDougal remains in prison. She was also tried along with her husband, was convicted of four felony counts and has now begun a two-year sentence. The two separated in 1984, and their divorce became final in 1990. They had no children.
A lawyer for Mrs. McDougal challenged her former husband's credibility, even in death. In comments quoted by The Associated Press, Bobby McDaniel said, "Jim McDougal was a gentleman who was very likeable" but added that "he was also a man who had had significant emotional problems."
Mr. McDougal was an eccentric man who, in the 1980's, lavishly displayed his new-found wealth in Little Rock, driving a Bentley and wearing suits from Saville Row. But Madison Guaranty was later found to be rife with corruption, and at times he appeared to give conflicting accounts of several important incidents in the Whitewater story. After the savings and loan failure, he was found to be suffering from manic depression.
Still, some of the things he said were later acknowledged to be true. For instance, it was Mr. McDougal who first told a reporter in 1992 of the profits that Mrs. Clinton had made more than a decade earlier in the commodities markets.
In 1994, the Clintons conceded that with the help of a lawyer from one of the state's most highly regulated companies, Mrs. Clinton had turned a $1,000 investment into nearly $100,000 in profits in less than a year. And it turned out to be ultimately true, as Mr. McDougal had maintained and the Clintons had initially challenged, that the McDougals lost substantially more in the Whitewater land venture than the Clintons.
Mr. McDougal befriended Mr. Clinton early in the two men's careers, and in Mr. Clinton's first term as Governor, he tapped Mr. McDougal to be a top economic aide. But by the 1990's, after the two men's fates had taken opposite directions, the relationship had frayed.
Mr. McDougal was raised near the small town of Bradford, Ark. His father had run a variety store and restaurant nearby. By his own account, Mr. McDougal took to politics early, dazzled at the age of 16 after seeing Adlai Stevenson speak. Two years later, he got a job as a clerk at the Arkansas House of Representatives and by the time he was 20, he was elected to the Arkansas Democratic Party's central committee.
Mr. Clinton met Mr. McDougal in 1968. Out of college, Mr. Clinton was hired as a driver in the re-election campaign of Senator J. William Fulbright, an assignment made by Mr. McDougal. The two men formed a friendship that continued through the 1970's as they worked on Democratic causes. They loved storytelling and campaigning, but Mr. McDougal also had a passion for business.
In 1976, Mr. McDougal persuaded Mr. Clinton to invest in a five-acre piece of land near Little Rock, putting $500 down and paying monthly installments of $75. Two years later, Mr. McDougal sold the tract for $5,000, a 75 percent return on the initial investment of $2,850.
The Clintons then decided to become partners with the McDougals in a new venture, Whitewater, a 230-acre Ozarks land venture at the juncture of Crooked Creek and the White River. For Mr. McDougal, the prospect of such a partner was significant. Mr. Clinton had just become the nation's youngest governor.
Mr. McDougal never really dropped out of politics. He ran unsuccessfully for Congress in 1982, and he continued throughout his career to raise money for Democrats. In 1980 he decided to buy a bank, and two years later, he bought Madison Guaranty Savings and Loan.
After Mr. McDougal provided an account of the Whitewater land venture to a reporter in 1992, Federal regulators reopened their examination of the failure of Madison. In 1993, a criminal referral over the institution was made to the Justice Department that named the Clintons as witnesses. The referral, along with the death of deputy White House counsel Vincent W. Foster Jr., created a political crisis that prompted Mr. Clinton to seek the appointment of an independent counsel.
Among the incidents still under review is an allegation by an Arkansas businessman, David Hale, that Mr. Clinton asked him to make an improper Federally backed loan of $300,000 to Mrs. McDougal. Investigators have determined that nearly $50,000 of that money wound up paying Whitewater expenses.
The independent counsel ultimately indicted Mr. McDougal, and he was convicted on 18 counts of fraud, false statements, conspiracy and other infractions.

HEADLINE: An Iraqi Is Home, at Last, From the War of Long Ago

BYLINE: By HADANI DITMARS 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq

 BODY:
Majida al-Zubaida vividly recalls the morning in 1982 when her husband kissed her goodbye and left for the front to fight in Iraq's bitter war against Iran.
He was 31, she 28 and four months pregnant with their first child. Her husband, Abel al-Zubaida, tried to calm his wife's fears, telling her that the tour was a routine training exercise and that he would be home soon. 
 It was March 10, 1982, and Mr. Zubaida would not see his wife for more than 15 years.
Captured by Iranians shortly after he joined the battle, he became one of the thousands of forgotten prisoners still being held in a conflict that ended a decade ago.
Unlike the Persian Gulf war with the United States in 1991 and the crises over United Nations arms inspections, Iraq's eight-year with Iran was not closely covered by the Western press. But it was a brutal conflict in which Iraq used poison gas and Iran sent thousands of teen-age soldiers in suicidal assaults against entrenched defenders.
Mr. Zubaida says that for much of his captivity the Iranians kept him in a cell so small that he and three fellow prisoners had to take turns sleeping while the others stood. He asserts that he was repeatedly beaten and tortured. His account could not be independently confirmed.
"I'm so glad to be home," the painfully thin Mr. Zubaida, his dark eyes beaming, repeated again and again when asked how freedom felt.
Held for 15 years in virtual islolation, Mr. Zubaida returned to a world transformed. In that time, the Soviet Union collapsed. The Berlin wall tumbled. The Israeli and Palestinian leaders shook hands on the White House lawn.
And Mr. Zubaida's once-prosperous country fell into near ruin. After invading Kuwait in 1990, Iraq was devastated by the war against the American-led coalition and the economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations. A generation of Iraqis, including his daughter, had grown up knowing only the deprivations of war or sanctions.
Before it was expelled from Iran in 1992, the International Committee of the Red Cross had registered some 13,000 men like Mr. Zubaida. At that time, it estimated that there were 19,000 Iraqi P.O.W.'s in Iran, based on the reports of Iraqi families who were receiving or sending mail through the Red Cross system. Only about 1,000 have been released during the last six years.
Iran says there is no "official" number for Iraqi prisoners, and contends that 5,000 Iranians are being held captive in Iraq. For its part, Iraq acknowledges holding only one Iranian prisoner of war -- a fighter pilot shot down in September 1980 -- whom Iraq says it will hold indefinitely as "proof" that Iran started the war, which left hundreds of thousand of casualties on each side.
Whatever the actual numbers, it is clear that Mr. Zubaida's ordeal and that of his wife, who raised a child alone in war and then under an economic embargo, have become common for Iraq. His daughter, Rahma, was born and raised in Mr. Zubaida's absence.
"When he first saw her, it was a beautiful moment," Mrs. Zubaida said of her husband's meeting with their daughter. But she explained, laughing, that at first Rahma kept calling him uncle, rather than father.
"It took a while for her to get used to having her dad around, instead of someone she'd only seen in photographs," she said.
Mr. Zubaida himself was shocked to see his own mother. "When I saw her, I almost fainted," he said.
As part of the psychological torture inflicted on him in captivity, Mrs. Zubaida said, he had been told that his mother was dead. "He had already mourned her and even held a special ceremony for her in prison," she said.
That was only the first of the shocks upon his return.
"He had heard about the embargo in prison," Mrs. Zubaida said of the seven years of economic sanctions that the United Nations says will be lifted once Iraq can prove that it has given up its most destructive arms. "And he had imagined that we would be living in abject poverty. He was surprised to see we still had furniture."
The furniture is still there in their modest apartment, which like many homes here feels as if it has been caught in a time warp. The couch and armchairs -- like the photograph on the wall of Mr. Zubaida dressed in a shirt styled in the 1970's -- reflect a better but faded time, before the wars and the embargo, when buying newer things was not impossible.
There were other adjustments as well. When Mrs. Zubaida told her husband that her current salary as an administrator at the Ministry of Religious Affairs was 3,000 dinars a month, he was quite impressed; atthe time he left home that would have been equivalent to about $8,000.
But the embargo has made the Iraqi currency nearly worthless. After she explained about the dinar's devaluation, Mrs. Zubaida said, "he just stared at the wall in disbelief."
"It was hard for him to understand how 3,000 dinars could be worth only a few dollars," she said.
Mr. Zubaida said he had spent most of his time away in Iran's notorious underground prison, Arak-Masous, in a small cell with three other prisoners. The communal toilet was a hole in the ground, and their meager food rations were thrown in through a small window.
Mr. Zubaida estimates that he received 120,000 lashes, though it is hard to know for certain. He was tortured, he said, and subjected to what he described as brainwashing: prisoners were forced to recite denunciations of the Iraqi Government and shown propaganda films portraying the collapse of their country.
He and his cellmates were able to obtain a radio, he said, by bartering some detergent for it from a sympathetic guard. Prisoners passed radio news clandestinely, but even word of the end of the war with Iran did not reach them until more than a year after it had occurred.
"I remember being really shocked to hear that the Soviet Union had collapsed," Mr. Zubaida said. "And when I heard about the American bombing, I was very worried for the safety of my family," he added, referring to the air sorties flown over Iraq in the Persian Gulf war.
While Mrs. Zubaida says proudly that her husband, though obviously still frail and tired, "is a strong man," she herself also endured a time that only a strong woman could survive.
"When I married at age 26, I did not expect to spend most of my married life alone," she said.
Raising a child in wartime was a challenge, she said, but added that the hardest part had been the last seven years under the sanctions. "Under the embargo, everything is a struggle," she said.
Before the Persian Gulf war, food and medicine were subsidized by the Government, and most things were affordable. Now, just finding enough food occupies most of her time, and the cost of even basic health care is prohibitive.
But she and her husband say they are optimistic and look forward now to "a normal life," as unlikely as that may be with no end in sight to the sanctions.
Having traded the isolation of his cell for that of his country, Mr. Zubaida recalled his fellow prisoners in Iran and all they had missed. "Life just passed us by," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Abel al-Zubaida of Baghdad went to war in 1982, was captured and spent the next 15 years in prison in Iran. Meanwhile, his wife, Majida, was also suffering deprivations, first of war and then of economic sanctions. (Associated Press)
