HEADLINE: Surprise! Take Some of Duke's Millions

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING 

 BODY:
In death, Doris Duke became a creature of the tabloids, the subject of countless colorful articles about her vast estate, the butler whom she had named as her executor and an angry suit brought by distant relatives, friends and questionable hangers-on. Much more quietly, the legal battles were settled, three years after Ms. Duke's death in 1993, and a foundation was formed to distribute the money the tobacco heiress had bequeathed to philanthropic causes.
Then came an even greater lull, until one day three surprised dance institutions discovered they were each $1 million richer. 
 Ms. Duke had suggested few specific priorities for what became the $1.25 billion Doris Duke Charitable Foundation, one of the 25 largest philanthropic funds in the United States. All that the foundation's president, Joan Edelman Spero, had to go on were vague instructions that the money go to medical research in which no animals were used, to environmental preservation and to the support of "dancers, singers, musicians and other artists of the entertainment world." And by Federal regulations, the foundation had to distribute at least 5 percent of its assets by the end of 1997.
In mid-December, the announcement came. Eight environmental, medical and cultural groups would receive a total of $18.6 million in this first round, with the often neglected, impoverished field of dance receiving $3.8 million of the $5.8 million going to cultural programs.
Ms. Duke had been friendly with Martha Graham, but the grants she gave to Graham's company and to the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater were relatively small. And so the shock was almost palpable among American dance institutions when the foundation suddenly showered money on the Joyce Theater in Manhattan, which received $1 million; the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, in Becket, Mass., which also received $1 million, and the American Dance Festival, which received $1.8 million. (A grant of $2 million was also given to Jazz at Lincoln Center for a yearlong celebration of the Duke Ellington centennial next year.) The sky was falling once more, but this time it was hailing money.
From the start, Mrs. Spero had a great degree of involvement in choosing the recipients. One of the first things she did was to immerse herself in Ms. Duke's life, talking to people who knew her, visiting her homes and studying her papers and personal possessions.
"People only know about the butler," Mrs. Spero said in an interview at the foundation's midtown Manhattan office. "Doris Duke was a fascinating creature, an innovative, eccentric woman who studied piano every day and played and composed. She studied modern dance, bless her heart. I think she would be pleased that people are amazed by our grants to modern dance. I can hear her chuckling. She didn't want recognition."
Ms. Duke might also have been amused by Mrs. Spero's baptism by fire as the foundation's first president, a job to which she was appointed in January 1997. Federal law required that the first grants be awarded by the end of 1997. Mrs. Spero had served in a variety of academic, political and corporate jobs, including Undersecretary of State for Economic, Business and Agricultural Affairs in the Clinton Administration and executive vice president for corporate affairs and communications at the American Express Company. But her arts background, she admits, was meager.
She was also the foundation's only employee until August, when she broke a leg and contracted Lyme disease. And the job as a whole was huge, though exhilarating. "Creating something from scratch was just a very exciting thing," she said. "Nothing could compare with it."
Mrs. Spero got help from Mary Hays, formerly with the dance program at the New York State Council on the Arts, and Susan Bloom, an executive in the American Express philanthropic program for the arts, in deciding how to help the "quintessential American art forms" of modern dance and jazz (which, like dance, had special appeal for Duke). Olga Garay, an arts presenter at Miami Dade Community College, was recently appointed arts officer of the foundation.
Mrs. Spero explored dance on her own, too, much as she had explored Ms. Duke's life. "We did not have the capacity to decide which companies were the best, so it seemed sensible to go to the presenters," Mrs. Spero said. "Everyone in 'the field,' as I have learned to call it, said that these three institutions are leaders, providing a whole range of opportunities to established and new companies. It gave them a real surprise when we showed up on their doorsteps."
The bemused recipients were even consulted about their greatest needs rather than receiving money earmarked for programs determined by the foundation, an emphasis Mrs. Spero said would continue. The Joyce grant will support the construction of a new dance studio and dressing rooms and studio rental subsidies at the Joyce SoHo as well as renovations including air-conditioning at both Joyce theaters and electric scenery-hoisting winches at the uptown theater.
Jacob's Pillow will use its grant for commissions, artists' residencies, workshops and professional leadership forums. And the American Dance Festival will create two awards named after Ms. Duke, one an annual choreography award and six grants to modern dance choreographers and jazz composers for the creation of pieces to be included in millennium celebrations at the festival at Duke University in Durham, N.C., and at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.
It has not yet been decided whether the foundation will award the same amount of money to dance organizations each year. And for the time being, at least, the foundation is not giving money to individual dance companies, remaining "a wholesale organization rather than retail," Mrs. Spero said. National and international projects will be considered in the future, she said.
The foundation has been deluged with proposals from arts groups. "But we are self-initiating," Mrs. Spero said. "We don't know what our programs or guidelines will be. And we don't have the capacity to respond. Later we hope to create a Web site so people will know what we're doing."

SECTION: Section A; Page 19; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 670 words

HEADLINE: It's Risky to Talk Tough on Kosovo

BYLINE: By Peter Maass; Peter Maass is the author of "Love Thy Neighbor: A Story of War," which chronicled the war in Bosnia.

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration does not hesitate to express its moral outrage when a crisis unfolds in a place like Kosovo, a province of Serbia where 90 percent of the residents are ethnic Albanians.
"We are not going to stand by and watch the Serbian authorities do in Kosovo what they can no longer get away with doing in Bosnia," Secretary of State Madeleine Albright warned after the Serbian police and paramilitary units killed scores of men, women and children in what Serbia portrays as a war on terrorism. Ms. Albright's warning sounds stern, but how serious is she? It is far easier to be the world's conscience than to be the world's policeman. 
 The United States and several allies agreed yesterday to impose mild economic sanctions on Yugoslavia. But if the violence continues, will the Clinton Administration rightly insist on stiffer sanctions? Will it resort to military measures? What does Ms. Albright mean when she says the United States is "not going to stand by"? Does the Administration plan to litter Belgrade once more with Security Council resolutions?
Most likely, Ms. Albright hopes Kosovo will quiet down, averting the need for hard decisions, but she may not be so lucky. She should keep in mind a lesson from Bosnia: at the outset of a crisis, it may be better to tell the truth than say the right thing. The strong expression of moral outrage -- without an accompanying will to do anything of substance -- can be worse than useless; it can be harmful.
The expression of outrage has many effects. It reassures the American public, which wants to hear the White House say the right thing (though not necessarily do the right thing if that means risking American lives). Outrage also puts the perpetrator -- in this case, President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia -- on notice that he will be punished unless he changes his ways. Lastly, the expression of outrage gives hope to victims by letting them know that the world's superpower may come to their rescue. This is what can be harmful.
When the former Yugoslavia was falling apart in 1991 and 1992, the Bush Administration made it clear, in the memorable words of James Baker, then Secretary of State, that it had "no dog in that fight." Mr. Baker was wrong about that -- the stability of Europe and NATO was at stake -- but at least he was honest. The independence-minded Governments in Croatia and Bosnia knew they would not get much help from the Bush crowd.
But Bill Clinton, running for President at the time, called for strong action against the Serbs. Once he took office, the moral posturing became fiercer, though action was not forthcoming until 1995, when the Dayton accord was imposed and troops were dispatched to Bosnia. In the interim, Bosnians died by the thousands.
Throughout the war, Bosnia's desperate Government hoped for military support from the United States, or at least the lifting of a crippling arms embargo. Salvation seemed possible because the Clinton Administration never ceased expressing its outrage and never ruled out military intervention, notably air strikes. The prospect of American rescue was not the sole or main reason Bosnians fought and died -- but it played a role.
Needless to say, the expression of outrage in Washington no longer carries much weight in the Balkans. Mr. Milosevic knows not to take the Clinton Administration's warnings seriously. Kosovo's Albanians are well aware of their geopolitical quandary. They reside within the internationally recognized borders of Yugoslavia. They know better than to expect the Administration's actions to be consistent with its oratory.
But hope springs eternal, even when we wish it would not. If the Administration has no intention of truly standing up to Mr. Milosevic, its moral posturing should be accompanied by an honest assessment of the actions it will not take. Ms. Albright, who knows the lessons of Bosnia better than anyone else in the Administration, should not begin another process of conscientious hypocrisy.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
30-Year Yield Falls Below 6% as Low Oil Prices Spur Rally

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday amid lower oil prices and expectations that concerns about Indonesia's economy would drive foreign investors to seek the relative safety of the American bond market.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 27/32, to 102 9/32, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 5.96 percent, from 6.02 percent on Friday and below 6 percent for the first time in a week. 
 Traders cautioned that there was little evidence of large investors in the market, so with volume at only about 75 percent of normal, price changes were probably exaggerated.
Still, Jack Regan, chief derivative strategist at Josephthal & Company, said the market continued to be bullish after the release on Friday of the February employment report, which showed a slight decline in manufacturing payrolls, an indicator that economic growth may ease, keeping inflation under control.
The drop in oil prices should help keep inflation in check, and the turmoil in Indonesia hangs over Southeast Asia, he added. That could encourage more foreign investors to buy Treasuries.
Another bullish factor for the market may be the light supply of new securities that are to be auctioned in the days ahead.
Analysts also expect that economic reports to be released this week will show that inflation remains benign, despite solid growth, fueling expectations that the Federal Reserve will be able to keep interest rates steady. The Government reports February retail sales on Thursday, and producer prices on Friday.
"Treasury securities will continue to benefit from an economy that is strong, but does not have the corresponding price pressures that might force the Fed to tighten," said Dave Shabelman, a Treasury market analyst with Standard & Poor's MMS, a market research and analysis firm in San Francisco.
Mr. Shabelman said that while there had been some concern about a lack of a significant effect from the Asian crisis -- economists have been predicting that the slowdown there would help temper the growth in the United States -- the market saw the employment report as a sign of possible slowing because of the decline in manufacturing payrolls. That would be favorable for the bond market.
Yesterday's Treasury bill auction went well, with the three-month maturity showing slightly better interest. The average rate at auction was 4.97 percent, down from 5.12 percent last week, while the six-month bill produced an average rate of 5.01 percent, down from 5.125 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Technology Earning Reports Finally Drive Down Markets

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
The stock market was haunted yesterday by warnings of disappointing earnings from some of the largest technology companies late last week.
Major stock market indexes finished lower, with technology shares suffering the brunt of the declines. Investors turned away from technology issues in favor of such market sectors as retailers and multinational consumer products companies. Analysts said that the possibility of weaker sales and slowing demand for personal computers and semiconductor equipment had finally sunk in for investors. 
 There had been earnings warnings on three consecutive days last week from Intel, Motorola and Compaq Computer.
Stocks finished strongly higher Friday, as investors seemed to brush aside the first two companies' statements that first-quarter earnings would not meet expectations. But Compaq's announcement after the close of trading on Friday led to selling yesterday. "It was kind of silly to have the market up 50 to 100 points like it never happened," one trader said.
"You've got a clear Compaq-driven signal," said Alan Bond, chief investment officer at Bond Procope Capital Management in New York. Bond Procope recently sold its entire Compaq holding at 35 because Mr. Bond was concerned about possible inventory buildups.
Compaq, yesterday's most actively traded issue, closed at 25 7/16, down 2 3/16 on the Big Board.
The Nasdaq composite index, which is heavily weighted with other technology issues, fell 28.33 points, or 1.62 percent, in a retreat led by such bellwether technology issues as Microsoft, Intel, Dell, Cisco Systems and Sun Microsystems.
But as investors fled from those computer-related issues, one of the places where they sought refuge was in Internet company stocks. Internet-related shares like Amazon.com, Yahoo, Excite, America Online and Lycos soared, with many of the companies reaching new highs amid expectations that falling personal computer prices would lead to more sales and increased Internet use.
Announcements of mergers and acquisitions helped stem broader market declines, analysts said. Alcoa's plans to purchase Alumax for $2.8 billion and Qwest Communications International's deal to buy LCI International for $4.4 billion indicated that companies would continue to consolidate to buoy market share and stock prices, said Richard E. Cripps, chief market strategist at Legg Mason Wood Walker.
After trading higher during most of the day, the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 2.25 points, closing at 8,567.14. Standard & Poor's 500 stock index fell 3.38 points, to 1,052.31. Two of the Dow's technology issues, I.B.M. and Hewlett-Packard, contributed to a large portion of the declines.
Sears, Roebuck, Coca-Cola and Procter & Gamble, which had been leading the Dow higher, managed to hold onto their gains. Those increases were a sign of a more defensive stance among investors, as they pushed cash into retailers and consumer nondurables on the reasoning that demand for their products would be aided by a strengthening economy. The Labor Department reported Friday that unemployment had fallen to 4.6 percent, a 24-year low.
Mr. Bond, who became more defensive during the fourth quarter, has recently bought shares of CVS and Walgreen. He has also added to holdings in AMR, the parent of American Airlines, and Carnival, which owns Carnival Cruise Lines. Both will benefit from falling oil prices, he said.

HEADLINE: Texas Lenders Pledge $1.4 Billion in Housing Case

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
Three Texas mortgage lenders have agreed to make nearly $1.4 billion available to low-income and minority home buyers over the next three years in a settlement of housing discrimination complaints.
The settlement is the largest ever negotiated in a case involving charges of lending discrimination, far surpassing a $1 million settlement in 1996 against a North Carolina Bank, according to the Department of Housing and Urban Development. 
 Beyond its size, the settlement comes as housing officials are cracking down on lenders who make it harder for minority and low-income families, many of them urban residents, to buy homes. In a recent study, the United States Conference of Mayors found that while more Americans than ever owned their own homes, the rate of ownership in urban areas lagged far behind the suburban rate.
Federal housing officials predicted that as a result of the Texas settlement as many as 20,000 families wwould be able to secure mortgages over the next three years.
"Discrimination is inherent in the system at this point," Housing Secretary Andrew M. Cuomo said today. "This has been going on for 30 years, and in many cases, it's almost subconscious with assumptions about what neighborhoods you should live in, who has good credit, who does not and what neighborhoods are bad risks. These assumptions have become institutionalized, and the disparity is unarguable."
The message of the Texas agreement, Mr. Cuomo said, is: "If you discriminate, we will file a complaint."
The settlement followed tests in which white officials posing as mortgage applicants were treated better than black officials even though they presented similar financial profiles. For example, a white applicant qualified for a $70,000 loan by one of the companies on the same day a black applicant with more favorable finances qualified for a mortgage of only $55,000.
The results of that test and others prompted the Fort Worth Human Relations Commission to file complaints against the companies -- the Temple-Inland Mortgage Corporation of Dallas, the Banc One Mortgage Corporation of Dallas and Overton Bank and Trust of Fort Worth -- with the Federal housing agency under the Fair Housing Act.
Negotiations over the complaints prompted the three companies to agree to set aside $1.375 billion in loans and programs over the next three years to improve the chances of economically disadvantaged families' owning their own homes.
While the settlements involve no official finding that the lending companies discriminated, housing department officials said charges would be filed if the companies did not comply with the agreement.
As a company that makes loans in 47 states besides Texas, Temple-Island is bearing the bulk of the settlement, $1.353 billion, or $451 million in each of the next three years. Overton is guaranteeing $11.3 million, and Banc One, $10.4 million.
Brad Johnston, general counsel for Temple-Island, said that despite the implicit threat for noncompliance the settlement "reaffirms a lot of things we do now" in that Temple-Island made $450 million in loans last year.
"There isn't a problem," Mr. Johnston said. "We're already very active in this area. There's nothing punitive in the agreement."

HEADLINE: Omdurman Journal;
The Koran as a Cure-All? Listen to the Sufi Sheik

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: OMDURMAN, the Sudan

 BODY:
A crowd starts gathering in the dusty warehouse yard an hour before he appears. They come from all over the Sudan, the diseased and the disabled, the blind and the melancholy. They sit cross-legged in long rows in the dirt under a desert sky and wait for the healer, each wrapped in a private pain.
At 4 P.M., Sheik Abdel Aziz ibn Ali arrives with a megaphone. He is 32 and wears his hair in dreadlocks under a shiny green shawl inscribed with a Koranic verse in golden letters. His assistants wade through the crowd of 800 men and boys, carrying the crutches and walking sticks of those they say he has already cured. 
 "Leave your disease here," he says, as an assistant in a motley green costume holds the speaker up. Then he begins to sing the Koran, verse by verse. As his voice rises hoarse and plaintive into the clear afternoon, some in the crowd begin to sway and rock. A few cry out in pain. Others vomit. Some scream.
As the Sheik's eerie chant grows in intensity, the men in the crowd begin singing amen at the end of each verse. They raise their open palms to heaven. Their muted voices sound like waves crashing on a distant beach, an hypnotic bass under the Sheik's voice. At times his voice cracks and he weeps the words. One man beats his chest and screams.
"Get out of me, devils!" he says. "I am a Muslim man. I am a Muslim man."
Sheik Abdel Aziz says he is the only Islamic faith healer in the Sudan. To his admirers, he is a miracle worker. Dozens of people will testify that he has cured their diabetes and reversed blindness by reciting the Koran. His followers say he has helped polio victims to walk, fixed leaky heart valves, removed goiters, made ovarian cysts vanish and healed ugly skin diseases.
But to his detractors, the Sheik is a charlatan who is raking in more than $2,400 a day from impoverished people in desperate circumstances. The authorities have arrested him on more than one occasion. After noise complaints from neighbors, the police have barred him from preaching at his home, forcing him to set up shop in an old warehouse on the outskirts of Omdurman.
For his part, the Sheik declines to accept responsibility for healing people. He says he is doing nothing more than reciting the sacred words Mohammed received from God. God, he says, does the rest.
"This is different from the Christian faith healers you have in the United States," he said in an interview at his house. "We are just reading the Holy Koran."
Then he shows a visitor a foot-high stack of pink and green medical folders. Each one, he claims, contains proof of a miraculous cure. He points out one woman whose ovarian cysts apparently disappeared after attending his sessions, according to radiology reports. Another file has X-rays detailing the case of a man whose failed kidney repaired itself.
The Sheik points to a line of 10 pairs of eyeglasses on a coffee table. They were taken, he says, from people whose vision was suddenly restored during his prayer service. In another corner he keeps a stack of canes and crutches from disabled people who have walked on their own after listening to his chanting.
"I do the same things that doctors do," he says. "For this the doctors have become angry with me and they have complained to the Government. That is why they try to stop me." Asked why he charges people 60 cents to enter his sessions, he says: "There are some cases where people have spent thousands of dollars on doctors. I can cure them for less than 60 cents."
It was impossible to verify the Sheik's claims. But people who have attended his service are living testament to the power of prayer to at least ease discomfort and depression, if not to heal.
Tariq Issa, a 45-year-old police officer from Dubai, said he had suffered from migraines for years, as well as double vision and bad dreams. He saw several doctors, who could find no obvious cause. Since he has attended six sessions with the Sheik, he says, his symptoms have disappeared.
"It's not magic," he said. "It's just the Holy Koran. He asks people to close your eyes and concentrate and listen to the Koran."
But many people apparently believe something supernatural is taking place. Hundreds bring dates and jugs of water to the sessions. They said they believe the spirit of God transforms the water and fruit into medicines that can cure malaria and other illnesses.
"The Koran can help people without dates or water," the Sheik explained. "But people when they bring water and dates feel they have something spiritual at hand when they go home. It's a matter of psychology."
One believer in the crowd, Abbas Yusef, a 50-year-old unemployed man, said he went blind in one eye and lost some vision in the other at the age of 5 when a goat butted his head and damaged an optic nerve.
He began going to the Sheik's services about a month ago. After three sessions, he said, he had a sensation of water coming from his eyes. Thirteen sessions later, he began to see blurry images, then figures, faces, objects. "I believe it's Allah," he said. "He's just a liaison between people and God."
Whatever the merits of the Sheik's techniques, his popularity reflects the deeply religious nature of Islamic society in the Sudan. He often preaches up to four times a day and more than 800 people attend most sessions.
His success is also a measure of the influence here of Sufism, a more mystical branch of Islam that emphasizes tolerance, introspection and meditation. A vast majority of Sudanese Muslims belong to various Sufi sects.
Sheik Abdel Aziz comes from a famous family of Sufi religious leaders in the central Sudanese region of Karary al-Jezira. After graduating from high school, he attended Al-Zhar, the famous Islamic university in Cairo, where he studied theology. He first began healing people while living in Jordan in 1994, and returned to the Sudan in 1996.
In general, he said, Sufis are less likely to use religion as an instrument of political power than people from other sects, like the Shia branch that dominates political life in Iran. It is ironic, Sufi people say, that a hard-line Islamic party has come to power in the Sudan in the last decade and has set up a Government based on Islamic principles.
"Sufism is the real meaning of religion," the Sheik said. "We do religion for religion's sake. Others in the Sudan use the religion to gain political power. They are merchants of religion."

Map of Sudan showing location of Omdurman: A Sufi holy man has set up shop in a warehouse outside Omdurman.

SECTION: Section A; Page 11; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1068 words

HEADLINE: New Tinderbox, Same Fuse: A Serb Comes Full Circle

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: PRISTINA, Serbia, March 9

 BODY:
Kosovo is a sacred place for Serbs, and for Serbian politicians. The Ottoman Turks defeated an army of Serbian knights on a barren field here more than six centuries ago, and Serbs have commemorated their martyrdom ever since in poetry and song.
This is the hallowed ground where Slobodan Milosevic, Yugoslavia's President, chose to begin his transformation from Communist bureaucrat to nationalist leader. The fierce nationalism unleashed by Mr. Milosevic with a 1987 speech here began his career as a popular politician and fueled the wars that followed the breakup of Yugoslavia. 
 Now, like a protagonist in Greek tragedy, Mr. Milosevic has come full circle to confront the ghosts he resurrected. He is clearly risking renewed international isolation to crush a budding rebellion in this Serbian province by the ethnic Albanians who form its majority. And the Albanians have vowed vengeance in response.
With that, the issue has been joined here as it was in Croatia and Bosnia: will the violence kindle another Balkan war in this century?
That possibility has long worried Americans. President George Bush warned Mr. Milosevic eight years ago that violence against the Albanians who make up 90 percent of Kosovo's population could lead to military intervention.
The fear then and now is that the fighting could spread across borders. Albania's ragtag army could be drawn into war with Serbia to protect Albanian kin in Kosovo from annihilation. Restive ethnic Albanians in Macedonia and Montenegro could join a revolt, perhaps drawing Turkey and Greece into war.
The likelihood of this scenario has been debated. But it propels Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's efforts to impose sanctions against Serbia and compel Mr. Milosevic to rein in his forces.
Mr. Milosevic, who is presiding over an economically troubled nation with rampant unemployment, has much to lose if he becomes known as the man who let Kosovo get away. He can still reap political benefits from taking a tough line on the Albanian issue, provided the casualties are minimal.
He has played the Kosovo card before.
Mr. Milosevic argued in his 1987 speech that while Serbs were the largest of the ethnic groups in Yugoslavia, they were being cheated out of their fair share of jobs and economic bounty. Few Serbs lived in Kosovo, which had come to be dominated by ethnic Albanians, and the Serb-controlled press was running incendiary articles about the plight of the Serbs in the province, highlighting accusations of rapes and beatings.
Mr. Milosevic came here and pugnaciously declared that other ethnic groups would no longer be permitted to abuse the Serbian nation. He vowed a government dominated by Serbs and a Yugoslavia that served Serbian interests. He nurtured ancient myths and glory, pointing to domed Serbian Orthodox monasteries and churches that dot a landscape increasingly devoid of Serbs.
The nationalistic talk made him wildly popular among the Serbian population. Like all groups in former Yugoslavia, it was suffering under the economic collapse brought about by $10 billion in debt to international lenders.
It also played on the deep xenophobia of Serbs, who after 500 years of brutal Ottoman occupation had come to worship warrior-saints and distrust all outsiders. Most important, it seemed to offer a solution to the needling problem of cohabitation with other ethnic groups -- which Tito had quelled with his considerable personal authority and a ruthless secret police network.
The triumphalism of the Serbs, not surprisingly, deeply frightened the Slovenes, Croats, Muslims, Macedonians and ethnic Albanians, who had had their fill of Serbian hegemony under the monarchy that ruled between the wars. Those politicians who spoke of cooperation with Belgrade found themselves ridiculed and alone. As Mr. Milosevic rose to power, nationalist leaders from competing ethnic groups rose alongside him.
Mr. Milosevic, as President of Serbia, did indeed turn the state over to Serbian nationalists. He revoked the limited autonomy and self-rule granted by the Communists to other ethnic groups, including Kosovo's Albanians.
In Kosovo, however, the independence movement did not follow the path of such movements elsewhere and take up armed rebellion. Mr. Milosevic's forces kept a lid on unrest for nearly eight years, and as war raged in the rest of Yugoslavia, there was in Kosovo a deceptive appearance of calm.
The ethnic Albanians mounted a disciplined and nonviolent resistance. They set up a shadow government and schools and clinics. They collected their own taxes. Diplomas and certificates were granted from the nonexistent Republic of Kosovo. All contact with the Serbians, who now live in isolated and well-guarded villages and neighborhoods, was severed.
The failure to get concessions from Belgrade, coupled with the decision at the Dayton peace accord negotiations to ignore the Kosovo conundrum, increasingly left ethnic Albanians bitter and frustrated.
The growth of the Kosovo Liberation Army and its increasing attacks over the last year have captured the imagination of many here, especially the young. An increasing number of ethnic Albanians no longer speak Serbo-Croatian. Their only contact with Serbs is being stopped, and often abused, by heavily armed police officers.
It was the United States' special Balkan envoy, Robert S. Gelbard, who made a remark during a visit to Belgrade last month that many now cite as a trigger to the latest crackdown. Mr. Gelbard praised Mr. Milosevic for his cooperation in Bosnia and branded the Kosovo Liberation Army "without question a terrorist group."
The statement stunned the ethnic Albanians, and echoed Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who argued in 1991 that Yugoslavia should remain one nation. Mr. Baker's assertion was apparently interpreted by Mr. Milosevic to condone attacks against Croatian separatists.
Mr. Milosevic, despite the talk of Kosovo as a Serbian homeland, knows he has little time to quell any rebellion. Serbs are not ready to die for Kosovo. Most have never been there. Yet at the same time he cannot afford to lose the province, for it would be his crowning defeat. He has already dismembered his country, filled it with some 400,000 embittered Serbian refugees from other parts of the former Yugoslavia, wrecked its economy and turned it into an international pariah.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
A 2-Way Contest to Pick Up Philadelphia's Options

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
The American Stock Exchange and the Chicago Board Options Exchange have each approached the Philadelphia Stock Exchange about combining their options businesses, according to exchange officials.
The Philadelphia exchange, plagued by regulatory problems in recent years, confirmed that it was considering two unsolicited proposals. The exchange also announced yesterday that its chairman and chief executive was stepping down after just seven months. Leopold Korins, who got the post with the support of the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, could not be reached for comment last night. 
 But his departure appears to pave the way for new leadership, and any joint venture could be a prelude to an outright merger. Chicago, which is the largest of the four options exchanges, has offered to provide some interim management assistance and would like to pursue a merger in the long term, according to industry officials.
Management continues to be a sore spot for Philadelphia, a small regional exchange that has had trouble regrouping after a series of embarrassing incidents. One official was forced out after a conflict of interest was disclosed. Another stepped down after the S.E.C. had criticized the exchange for favoring its own interests over those of investors.
Like the Chicago exchange, the Amex, which is in New York, believes it can help. While it is an also-ran to the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq, its image has improved under the direction of Richard F. Syron, the former chief economist and president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston. When he became chairman of the exchange four years ago, Mr. Syron informed companies and investors that unscrupulous business practices would not be tolerated and stepped up scrutiny of companies that were joining the exchange.
Philadelphia might benefit from his hard-nosed approach because board members there were said to be frustrated with the slow pace of change. Merger talks were, in fact, begun by the two a few years ago, but about half the board members in Philadelphia did not want to be engulfed by another exchange, said a former member of the Philadelphia board. Half the board is now made up of outsiders to satisfy regulators.
Losing the bidding for Philadelphia would again raise questions about the future of the Amex. It suffers from an identity problem despite making great strides to increase its equity offerings and to retain growing companies. Mr. Syron vows not to walk away from any part of its business, which includes options, equities and structured products.
But it is a niche player at best in equities. And after losing a bidding war with the Chicago Board last year to acquire the options business of the New York Stock Exchange, Mr. Syron has few choices left for expansion. He has set his sights on being No. 1 in that market in five years, a lofty goal for an exchange that is now a distant second.
"We have in no sense accepted that we're going to be No. 2 in options," he said in a recent interview."
In the options market, the Chicago Board Options Exchange has 53 percent of the total trading volume, the Amex accounts for almost 25 percent and Philadelphia has nearly 9 percent. The other player is the Pacific Stock Exchange, with 13 percent.
In equity options, the Amex is stronger. It has about 31 percent of the market, compared with 43 percent for Chicago, whose overall lead comes from its exclusive contracts to trade index options, namely those based on the popular Standard & Poor's 500 contract. Philadelphia's portion of the equity options business is slightly more than 9 percent.
Merging with Philadelphia would give the Amex some additional heft as it continues an aggressive push into new products, said Price Headley, a senior vice president at Schaeffer's Investment Research, a Cincinnati firm specializing in options investment strategies. In recent years, the Amex has introduced new equity products, including the Standard & Poor's depository receipts, known as Spiders; international index funds, known as WEB's, and an index based on the Dow Jones industrial average, known as Diamonds.
Philadelphia would benefit from the Amex and Chicago's more advanced computer and software systems as well as their ability to monitor trading activity throughout the day. Now, Philadelphia can only receive reports on trades at the end of the day. The Amex would benefit from increased trading volume. If they were to ultimately merge, the exchanges probably could combine trading floors as well.
"There could be more consolidation, and we would not be opposed to it," said Michael Schwartz, chief options strategist at CIBC Oppenheimer, adding that securities firms that are members of the exchanges would save money if they did not have to pay employees at an additional options exchange.
In a letter on March 3 to the Philadelphia exchange, Mr. Syron proposed an "affiliation" between the two exchanges. He suggested that the members of the Philadelphia exchange would continue to operate at their current site, and the Amex would take over operations and surveillance of some of the biggest accounts.
"Beyond that, we estimate that in a total of 6 to 12 months, your entire options floor could be converted to our surveillance and trading platforms," he wrote.
At the Philadelphia exchange, Mr. Korins will be replaced temporarily by John F. Wallace, who preceded him as acting chairman and now is the market's on-floor vice chairman. Preceding Mr. Korins as chief executive was Nicholas A. Giordano, who resigned after an inquiry by the S.E.C. into exchange practices. Vincent J. Casella resigned as chairman in late 1996 after an investigation into his investment in a company that won a major contract with the exchange.
That investigation prompted a visit by Arthur Levitt Jr., the S.E.C. chairman, who chided the exchange's board for failing to act promptly when it had learned Mr. Casella might have a conflict of interest.
Though the Philadelphia exchange comes with some baggage, Mr. Syron has few choices. After shelving the emerging company markets program, which was designed to aid small companies that could not meet normal trading standards, and making clear that companies that were suspect would face pressure, he has turned his attention to expanding and forging an identity for the American Stock Exchange. Since 1994, when Mr. Syron became chairman, options volume has grown more than 80 percent, new listings have doubled and initial public offerings of stock have increased 75 percent, though they are still dwarfed by the figures for the Nasdaq and the Big Board.
Investors have generally yawned at these accomplishments.
"They haven't been very successful in conveying to people what their image should be," said Daniel G. Weaver, a finance professor at Baruch College. "A lot of people are asking, 'Why do we need it?' "

HEADLINE: Americans Take a Dim View Of the Government, Survey Finds

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
Most Americans still deeply distrust the Federal Government, despite the end of the cold war, the robust economy and the highest level of satisfaction in their own lives in 30 years, a new national survey has found.
Only 20 percent of Americans are satisfied with the state of the nation and only 34 percent basically trust the Government. Underlying both is a sense that politicians are corrupt, according to the survey released today by the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press. 
 But even though Americans do not trust their politicians, two-thirds have a positive view of Federal workers and of many Federal agencies, according to the survey.
The Post Office is the most-favored agency, viewed positively by 89 percent of the people, up from 76 percent a decade ago. The least popular agency remains the Internal Revenue Service, dropping to 38 percent favorability from 49 percent.
But the generally positive view of particular agencies stands in sharp contrast to the negative view of the Federal Government as a whole.
Americans' dim view of Government has never recovered from its plunge in the 1960's, beginning with the assassination of President John F. Kennedy and continuing through the Vietnam War and Watergate, the Pew study noted. The public felt slightly better during the Reagan Administration, but that ended with the Iran-contra case.
Trust in Government hit bottom at 21 percent in 1994, when that sentiment helped Republicans win Congress for the first time in 40 years.
It has climbed 18 percentage points since then, but pollsters are divided over whether this represents a permanent turnaround or only a temporary uptick that could fall again with new revelations in the sex scandal embroiling the White House.
"The great criticism of Government in the 1980's has stopped and begun to reverse itself," said Andrew Kohut, director of the Pew Research Center. But he also said the investigation into President Clinton's sex life appeared to be "thwarting" any increase in trust. Trust in Government fell from 39 percent in October to 34 percent in late February, when the story had been in the news for more than a month.
Speaking at a seminar on the Pew research held here today by Pew and the Annenberg Public Policy Center of the University of Pennsylvania, Samuel Popkin, a political analyst at the University of California at San Diego, said that Mr. Clinton cleverly deflected trust as an issue in the 1996 campaign by narrowing his proposals to small-bore issues like school uniforms and cellular phones for neighborhood street patrols.
Mr. Kohut said that trust remained relatively low because the Government had failed to solve perceived problems like crime, drug use and Medicare and because politicians were seen as being corrupt. Many analysts said that the press, with its focus on bad news and scandals, had fostered this view.
Senator Fred Thompson, the Tennessee Republican who heads the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, said the perception that politicians were corrupt was "the most serious problem we have."
"I assume they mean the old-fashioned money-type corruption," Senator Thompson said. Despite the concerns caused by excess money in political campaigns, that kind of corruption, he said, was "the one charge that I think we're probably not guilty of."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
What Suharto Knew

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Being a simple sort of man, I sometimes wonder: When the emissaries of President Clinton visit the President of Indonesia to talk about his country's economic disasters and how we can bail it out, do they ever ask him if he knows that his sons, daughters, in-laws and dearest friends stole the country bare and blind?
And if so, could he say when he first knew it? 
 Then I rebuke myself, knowing the questions would be a waste of time. Everybody in Washington and Jakarta understands he not only knew but from the beginning helped his children take over Indonesian banks, trusts, factories, airlines, agriculture monopolies, automobile and other transport companies and so on, plus foreign power plants, military-supply operations, shipping lines and so on.
He also helped them set up new, creative forms of businesses at home or abroad free of the problem of paying taxes. And good father that he is, President Suharto made sure his children got a nice share of the deals he bestowed on his friends. Family values are important to him.
Anyway, emissaries know the questions could be dangerous. Mr. Suharto is a touchy man. He might get so mad he would turn down the International Monetary Fund bailout package.
The I.M.F. and the U.S., with the necessary American backing, want to lend Indonesia $43 billion to save it from the economic desperation it fell into because Mr. Suharto has been such a splendid father and friend.
They plead with the onetime general, who helped slaughter hundreds of thousands of Indonesians in 1965 and then made himself President, again and again and again. Please, make reforms in the economic booby trap your largess created, so that we can give you the bailout money.
Forty-three billion is quite a lot of dollars. But Mr. Suharto is defiant about making suitable reforms.
The prevailing belief of Indonesia experts is that he is afraid of liberalization and other changes because they might weaken his control of the country and the clout of his family economic powerhouse. The Suharto empire is at the heart of many of the problems of the national economy.
Some of his children's enterprises lost money when the Indonesian economy started its slide down, down. But they are still the largest banking family in Indonesia, the political machine most dangerous to trifle with. Suharto children already are hedging promises they made to give up their monopolies.
Foreign and Indonesian lenders and investors lost hugely more than the Suhartos, and do not have as many untaxed holdings and other delicacies. They want the I.M.F. to deliver the bailout billions so they can get their money back.
Mr. Suharto's friends bolster his defiance with warnings about Indonesian history. They say that although Indonesians built the once-plump economy with foreign help they are terribly resentful at foreigners who come bearing reforms as the price of bailout, and suspicious of an unfettered economy, otherwise known as a free market.
So, they say, if pressed too hard, Indonesians might riot, kill and generally create civil disorder that would wreck the economy altogether and ruin foreign trade. And they won't like America anymore.
Indonesia specialists with memories say that if Indonesians do not take the hint about how violent they might get, Mr. Suharto will show them the way. He will again select Chinese Indonesians as the scapegoats, and look away if other Indonesians go get them.
That could happen. So we can be sure how it will turn out. If Mr. Suharto makes some changes to lessen inflation and other unpleasantnesses, the I.M.F. will deliver the $43 billion.
Foreign and Indonesian investment-losers will indeed get their money back. They will escape the fundamental safeguard of free markets: the risk of losing money if investments turn bad.
If and when the loan is paid off, through sacrifices of Indonesian workers and taxpayers, the I.M.F. and the U.S. will again cry out what a triumph for the bailout system, but they will call it something fancier.
Still, being a simple sort of man, I wonder: How many Americans will enjoy handing $43 billion to a man who in the U.S. would long ago have been indicted, convicted and sent to jail, to join his children?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Giuliani Visits Michigan for a Fund-Raiser

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

DATELINE: NOVI, Mich., March 9

 BODY:
Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Mayor of New York City, endured a turbulent flight to Detroit this afternoon that included a mother soothing her crying child with a loud rendition of "Mary Had a Little Lamb." Then he sat, buckled in the coach section, as the airplane toured the tarmac for 15 minutes. Then he took a 20-mile limousine ride to the Novi Hilton, which looms over a highway intersection and a Big Boy restaurant.
Mr. Giuliani was a long way from New York City -- but by choice. He came to the Midwest primarily to speak at a fund-raising dinner for the state's House Republicans, as a favor to Michigan's Governor, John Engler. But there was a tangential benefit: the speaking engagement raises Mr. Giuliani's national profile at the same time that he has acknowledged harboring political ambitions that extend beyond City Hall. 
 "People are here to take their measure of Mayor Giuliani," Ken Sikkema, the Michigan House Republican leader, said. "The word I'm struggling not to use -- I don't want to use this word -- is curiosity."
The Mayor has several appointments this week that have nothing to do with governing New York City and everything to do with determining his political future. After tonight's appearance, he was scheduled to rush back home to attend an 8 A.M. breakfast meeting on Tuesday with his finance committee, which will be discussing fund-raising plans for the as-yet-to-be-determined aspiration of Mr. Giuliani. Then, on Thursday, he has three speaking engagements in Washington, including one to deliver the keynote address at the annual meeting of the Republican National Committee.
His aides say that the week's schedule is an aberration and does not reflect an emerging pattern of distraction for a mayor who prides himself on the long hours he spends on city business. Nevertheless, it does suggest that Rudolph W. Giuliani is, at the very least, a political curio, and that Republicans west of Staten Island are interested in what he has to say.
Take Novi, for example. More than 900 people have paid $500 each to attend tonight's annual dinner and to hear Mr. Giuliani. His appearance has made for the most successful event in the history of its sponsor, the Michigan House Republican Campaign Committee; it has raised an estimated $520,000 to help the Republicans here reclaim the House and therefore dominate the Legislature, since it already controls the Senate.
The cachet of the Giuliani name worked, said Val Tillstrom, the Republican who organized the event. "He's definitely a national figure, very exciting," she said, adding that last year's speaker was the former Republican Presidential candidate, Steve Forbes.
But Mr. Sikkema, wearing a red-white-and-blue tie depicting American flags and elephants, acknowledged that Michigan Republicans tend to be conservative -- and would oppose Mr. Giuliani's support, for example, for abortion. "Sure he's viable" as a Presidential candidate, he said. "But it's a little premature from our standpoint to make judgments on Presidential sweepstakes. We're happy that he's here because he's helping us sell tickets."
Dan Gustafson, another House Republican, also sidestepped questions about the Mayor's national appeal. "But the level of excitement here -- of people wanting to hear what he has to say -- is higher than I've ever seen," he said.
At a news conference before the dinner, Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Engler engaged in mutual admiration: the Governor complimented the Mayor for inroads he has made in crime reduction; the Mayor applauded the Governor for economic initiatives and approaches to welfare reform. Then both men dodged questions about the Mayor's political viability.
"The field is wide open," said Mr. Engler, who is said by Republicans here to be a possible Presidential candidate himself. "Mayor Giuliani is one of the leading Republicans in the country."
Mr. Giuliani helped his Republican friend by saying, "I'm not testing any waters right now." When asked whether he had interest in the Iowa and New Hampshire Republican primaries, the Mayor smiled and answered, "I don't see it in my travel plans right now."
Then the Mayor joined some 200 guests crammed into the St. Clair room at the Hilton, where the combined body temperature was high enough to melt the elephant ice sculpture prematurely. He shook hands and posed for photos. Then he walked into the main ballroom, which was wall-to-wall Republicans.
After a lengthy and laudatory introduction by Mr. Sikkema, the Mayor stepped to the lectern to a standing ovation. Behind him hung a banner that said: "The March to House Majority Starts Here."
He began with a couple of jokes about organized crime -- using the Don Corleone voice he sometimes affects -- and then launched into the familiar Giuliani themes of ending parole and reducing crime. He also praised Governor Engler again for his own accomplishments.
Then the Mayor and his small entourage stepped outside, where it was snowing, and into a limousine that would whisk him back to the airport, where an airplane bound for New York City awaited.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Merger of Weapons Giants Faces Unexpected Hurdle
Lockheed Martin's $8.3 billion acqusition of Northrop Grumman is running into unexpected resistance from the Government, suggesting that Washington may now believe that the consolidation among military suppliers, which it had been encouraging, has gone too far.
Lockheed and Northrop said in a joint statement that they had been told over the weekend that the Justice Department was "fundamentally opposed" to the proposed combination of the companies. Page A1. 

Qwest to Buy LCI International
Qwest Communications International agreed to buy LCI International for stock worth $4.4 billion. It would become the nation's fourth-largest long-distance carrier, with some $3 billion in revenue, if Worldcom's acquisition of MCI goes through. D2.
 
Technology Stocks Down Sharply
Stock prices were lower, though technology stocks, hurt by last week's announcements of lower earnings by several bellwether companies, bore the brunt of the selling. The technology-heavy Nasdaq index fell 28.33 points, to 1,725.16, though the Dow industrials were down only 2.25 points, to 8,567.14. D9.
 
The yield on the 30-year Treasury fell back below 6 percent as prices rose, helped by lower oil prices and expectations that concerns about Indonesia's economy would drive foreign investors to the relative safety of the American bond market. D9.
 
3 to Leave Times Mirror Board
Three key directors on the Times Mirror board are retiring: Otis Chandler, a member of the company's founding family, and two of his top lieutentants, David Laventhol and Robert F. Erburu. The three were the core of the leadership of Times Mirror, the parent of The Los Angeles Times, Newsday and other newspapers, before the arrival of Mark H. Willes as chief executive in 1995. D8.
 
Rulings Cloud Same-Sex Issue
The Supreme Court took action in two more sexual harassment cases, disposing of them in a way that underscored how unsettled the law remains after last week's ruling that brought same-sex harassment within the coverage of Federal discrimination law. A14.
 
Rest of Havas to Be Sold
Generale des Eaux, the diversified French water utility company, has agreed to buy the 70 percent of the media company Havas that it does not own for $5.6 billion. D3.
 
Publishers' Merger Deal Unravels
Reed Elsevier, the British-Dutch publishing giant, and Wolters Kluwer, a Dutch rival, said they had canceled plans to merge after they were unable to renegotiate their deal, which had encountered regulatory objections. D3.
 
Indonesian Anger at I.M.F.
As a new round of arm-wrestling gets under way between Indonesia and the I.M.F., expressions of nationalist resentment are mounting. A9.
 
Newsprint Makers Consolidating
Bowater agreed to acquire Avenor for $2.47 billion, creating the second-largest newsprint manufacturer in North America. The price far exceeds a $1.4 billion bid Avenor rejected two weeks ago from Abitibi-Consolidated, which like Avenor is based in Montreal. Bowater is based in Greenville, S.C. D3.
 
Japanese Airline in 2 Deals
All Nippon Airways, the largest airline serving the domestic Japanese market, reached separate alliances with United Airlines and with Lufthansa of Germany, the latest agreements as global airlines play musical chairs. D3.

Serbs Return Bodies From Attacks in Kosovo
Serbian police returned for burial 51 bodies of ethnic Albanians killed in a sweep of what they said were rebel strongholds in central Kosovo Province. Serbian officials contended that the women and children who died were killed by armed rebels who refused to let them surrender. But there was mounting evidence that the Serb police had killed unarmed civilians and executed males whom they had detained. A1 

The United States and a group of allies imposed modest diplomatic and economic sanctions on Yugoslavia because of President Slobodan Milosevic's use of force against the ethnic Albanians in Kosovo. A10
 
A former Bosnian Serb paramilitary commander pleaded guilty to rape as a war crime before an international tribunal in the Hague. Dragoljub Kunarac, who turned himself in to French NATO peacekeeping troops last week, admitted that he had raped Muslim women during the Bosnian war in 1992. Human rights groups have estimated that more than 30,000 women were sexually abused in the Balkan fighting. A10
 
U.N. Plan for Iraq Unveiled
Secretary General Kofi Annan presented his plan for continuing to monitor Iraq's disarmament and sent a new commissioner to Baghdad to oversee the operation. Senior United Nations officials said that inspections of eight so-called presidential sites would begin in about two weeks. Mr. Annan's recent initiatives have emphasized direct links with Iraq, which has been told it must rid itself of weapons of mass destruction. A3

Vietnam Dispute Resolved
The Vatican announced a new archbishop for Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon. Pope John Paul II nominated Archbishop Jean-Baptiste Pham Minh Man, 64, and prelates for two other cities after a high-level Vatican delegation held talks in Vietnam with officials and church leaders. For three years, Vietnam had blocked the Vatican's attempt to appoint a prelate it considered too influential, according to Fides, the news agency of the Vatican's missionary service. The city has 500,000 Roman Catholics. (AP)

HEADLINE: With New Inspection Setup, a New Annan-Iraq Link

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 9

 BODY:
Secretary General Kofi Annan forged another direct link with Iraq today by unveiling procedures for Iraqi presidential sites to be inspected under the watchful eyes of diplomats. He also sent a new commissioner to Baghdad tonight to oversee the operation.
The inspections, which could begin in two weeks, are the latest in a series of steps taken by Mr. Annan, deferring to Iraqi concerns about weapons inspections and allowing Baghdad to bypass the Security Council. Within the last two weeks, Iraqis have effectively moved from near-pariah status to regular and direct contact with the highest ranking United Nations officials. 
 If President Saddam Hussein continues to abide by his side of the bargain struck with Mr. Annan in talks on Feb. 22 and does not interfere with arms inspections at any site in Iraq, the United States will be significantly more isolated in the Security Council in any attempt to prolong sanctions indefinitely.
Emboldened, Iraq is already trying to test its power. The country's Foreign Minister, Mohammed Said al-Sahaf, wrote to Mr. Annan over the weekend demanding to know why arms inspectors were not being disciplined for talking to the press "despite the promises that have been made to us." High-ranking officials said that they do not know what promises Iraq is talking about.
Risking his own reputation if Mr. Hussein does not keep his word, Mr. Annan has taken these steps in the last few weeks:
*He traveled to Baghdad to meet Mr. Hussein, an important gesture the Iraqis had long sought.
*He appointed a political representative, Prakash Shah of India, who will be based in Baghdad and report directly to the Secretary General. Mr. Shah said today that "it is very clear that the Secretary General feels there is need for improved lines of communication between Iraq and the United Nations headquarters."
*He invited Iraq's Foreign Minister to come to New York to discuss Baghdad's complaints about the way the United Nations is administering the "oil for food" program that allows the country to sell limited amounts of oil to pay for urgent civilian needs. Today, Mr. Annan appointed his Deputy Secretary General, Louise Frechette, to oversee the program here.
*He passed on to the Security Council a request from Russia that a Russian be appointed co-deputy chairman of the special commission disarming Iraq, which is known as Unscom. The current deputy is an American, Charles Duelfer, about whom the Iraqis have also complained.
Bill Richardson, the United States representative, did not welcome the idea, saying in an interview that he had "serious reservations" about the proposal.
"We believe Unscom runs very effectively and efficiently under its present hierarchy," he said.
On Wednesday Mr. Annan is to go to Washington to meet with President Clinton and other high-level Administration officials to talk about Iraq -- and American dues owed the United Nations.
The visit is taking place after the Secretary General made several public statements in the last week supporting the view of a number of Security Council members that in a resolution last week endorsing Mr. Annan's Baghdad mission, the United States did not win the right to use force automatically against Iraq.
Until last fall, the United States had successfully isolated Iraq by insisting that all discussions about Mr. Hussein's relations with the arms inspectors be channeled through the Security Council, where Washington brooked no discussion of lifting sanctions at any time in the foreseeable future.
That consensus began to weaken after a series of challenges to inspections from Iraq, which resisted efforts to enter presidential properties and other sites, insisting that it had accounted for all its weapons of mass destruction and should be freed from an embargo that has crippled its economy. The United States responded with threats of force.
The crisis reached a perilous point by mid-February, by which time the United States and Britain had amassed an armada in the Persian Gulf and were prepared to strike Iraq. Mr. Annan then went to Baghdad and effectively ended an era. He apparently intends to remain deeply involved with the Iraqi issue.
Today, officials who briefed reporters on the composition of teams that will inspect the eight presidential sites previously off limits to Unscom acknowledged that the initial visits will merely establish the right of access and not be intensive investigations of the sites.
Iraq will have had months to prepare the sites, and officials admit that any element of surprise, which inspectors have always tried to employ, will be long gone before these initial visits are made. Officials say that the critical test will come later, when inspectors ask to go back.
There is a suspicion among some officials and diplomats that Iraq will try to pass off the initial visits by inspectors and diplomats as final tours of the once-prohibited areas.
Inspectors focused today on another aspect of the agreement reached by Mr. Annan, a general Iraqi pledge to open other areas not included in the presidential properties. In the last few days, the American specialist in concealment, Scott Ritter, and a team of 50 arms experts have been able to visit eight areas that Iraqi had labeled "sensitive."
In agreeing to orderly if largely pro-forma visits to presidential areas and in allowing Mr. Ritter -- whom Iraqis have excoriated and tried to ban in the past -- President Hussein appears to be gambling that under his agreement with Mr. Annan he will be rewarded if he can at least be seen to be abiding by the rules after months of throwing up obstructions. An important assessment of Iraqi cooperation is due in October, and there are many here who believe that Baghdad may have set that as its target for ending sanctions.
After years of threatening to keep a total embargo on Iraq in place until Mr. Hussein is gone, the United States may in the not-too-distant future find itself having to live with only the long-range monitoring system that will replace intrusive inspections if the arms control experts can no longer justify a large-scale active presence in Baghdad.
Iraq, which has not been allowed to sell oil in any but very limited quantities for nearly eight years, is in need of the oil revenues, a former Iraqi minister now in exile in Europe said in an interview.
Jayantha Dhanapala, a Sri Lankan arms control expert who was recently appointed Under Secretary General for Disarmament Affairs, is to go to Baghdad to take over the process of inspections at the eight presidential sites: one in the north, two near President Hussein's birthplace of Tikrit, three in Baghdad, one at a air base west of the capital and one in the south.
Under Mr. Dhanapala's supervision, diplomats will be assigned to inspection teams at presidential sites -- only one of which is a major palace -- to insure that Iraqi concerns are respected. Iraqis have complained that arms inspectors do not show respect for special complexes and are prone to offend national sovereignty and the dignity of the President.
Although Mr. Dhanapala will have his own channel of communication with Mr. Annan, he will be reporting in the field to Richard Butler, executive chairman of Unscom.
In an interview today, Mr. Butler said that he was pleased with the new arrangements, which he described as "unambiguous and simple." He said that all of the commission's prerogatives had been respected in drawing up the inspection procedures, since professional inspectors from Unscom or the International Atomic Energy Agency are to lead the teams.

HEADLINE: U.S. and Allies Set Sanctions on Yugoslavia

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: LONDON, March 9

 BODY:
The United States and its Western allies decided today to impose modest diplomatic and economic sanctions on Yugoslavia for President Slobodan Milosevic's "unacceptable use of force" against the ethnic Albanian majority in the province of Kosovo.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, who had been seeking immediate and firm action against Mr. Milosevic, said today's decision was "satisfactory." It was made in a four-hour emergency meeting of the so-called contact group that monitors Yugoslavia and the four neighboring republics that seceded from it. 
 Ms. Albright has said she wants to approach Serbia -- the republic that dominates what remains of Yugoslavia -- with a mixture of diplomacy and punishment, and she has insisted that the Serbs recognize the legitimate rights of the ethnic Albanians.
She said today: "We are obviously going to keep our eye on the ball and make sure that this agreement sticks. If we don't get the kind of result we want, we need to remember that the only kind of pressure President Milosevic understands is the kind that imposes a real price on his unacceptable behavior."
It was difficult for the members of the contact group -- the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Russia -- to reach consensus, even on the sanctions imposed today.
Italy and France began the day wishing only to threaten Mr. Milosevic now and take action, if necessary, later, and Russia ended the day by dissociating itself from the only sanctions likely to have much bite in Belgrade.
No measures will take effect until 10 days have passed and the situation in Kosovo has been reviewed. At that point the contact group could add to or subtract from the list of sanctions it has approved.
The group agreed to push for a resolution by the United Nations Security Council imposing a comprehensive arms embargo against Serbia.
It also decided to stop supplying equipment that could be used for internal repression or terrorism, to deny visas to those responsible for repression in Kosovo and to halt financing of export credits by foreign governments for trade and investment.
The last includes money for privatization of state-owned companies, which American officials say Mr. Milosevic uses to finance his Government. Italy is currently helping to finance the privatization of the Serbian telephone system, a project that is likely to go ahead despite the sanctions.
But even after a long telephone call by the foreign ministers of Britain and Germany and the American Secretary of State to their Russian counterpart, Yevgeny M. Primakov, Moscow was willing to agree only to the first two measures, which are the least painful.
But Mr. Primakov agreed to consider the two other sanctions if Mr. Milosevic did not stop the harsh crackdown on ethnic Albanians who favor greater autonomy or independence for Kosovo, said Foreign Secretary Robin Cook of Britain.
Russia has historically been an ally of the Serbs and has often had to make delicate choices regarding international decisions to punish them.
American officials said they were pleased that Moscow had moved as far as it had, but one official noted that Russia might not vote in favor of an arms embargo in the Security Council, though he said it was unlikely to veto one. A senior German diplomat, Wolfgang Issinger, said, "We realize it's been extremely difficult for the Russians here."
There will be another meeting of the contact group in Washington on March 25, when Mr. Milosevic's conduct will be judged again.
"We want President Milosevic to know we will be watching very closely how he responds," said Mr. Cook, speaking for the group. "I hope that when we meet again we will see evidence that the situation in Kosovo is stabilizing on the basis of respect for civil liberty, peaceful expression and international law."
Within the 10 days, a statement by the group said, Mr. Milosevic should take "rapid and effective steps to stop the violence and engage in a commitment to find a political solution to the issue of Kosovo through dialogue."
In particular, the statement said, he should withdraw special police units from Kosovo, allow access by the International Committee of the Red Cross and contact group diplomats and commit himself publicly "to begin a process of dialogue."
The officials are concerned that ethnic tension in Kosovo could spread to the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia and even beyond, to Greece and Turkey. But the analogy to Bosnia and the "ethnic cleansing" that Serbs carried out there during the war over the breakup of Yugoslavia that began in 1991 is a legally awkward one.
No one in the West challenges Serbia's sovereignty over Kosovo or the right of the authorities to put down an armed insurrection there. At issue is the brutality with which Mr. Milosevic has moved to repress the Albanians, and the American conviction that unless he is checked, the kind of ethnic purging that changed the face of Bosnia will begin again.
"We don't want a repeat of 1991," Ms. Albright said today, "when the international community did not react with sufficient vigor and force."
This time, she said, the West must act and see this crisis not as an internal affair, but as "an affront to universal standards of human rights we are pledged to uphold." She said it represented the kind of conduct that had drawn the former Yugoslavia into civil war.
"Once again, President Milosevic is playing with fire," she said. "Once again, he has tried to solve his problems not with the force of argument, but with the argument of brute force."
The entire contact group, including the Russians, also agreed on a series of measures intended as "preventive diplomacy," including an agreement to have some form of international peacekeeping presence in Macedonia after the mandate of the current force ends in August. The current force includes some 350 Americans and patrols the republic's border with Serbia.
The group also urged the international tribunal for war crimes in the former Yugoslavia to investigate the recent violence in Kosovo, in which more than 70 civilians have died, and urged a new mission by former Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain on behalf of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.
It also called on the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights to visit Kosovo and for other diplomats and officials of non-governmental organizations to visit there.
"We need to know what is happening in Kosovo," Mr. Cook said. "An international presence on the ground may be the best way to deter violence there."
 

CORRECTION-DATE: March 11, 1998, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about sanctions against Serbia for its crackdown on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo Province misstated the timing of the measures. The sanctions, imposed by the United States and its allies, take effect immediately. (There is a 10-day period for a review, after which the sanctions may be revised.)
