HEADLINE: Moab's Natives Struggle With an Overabundance of Wildlife

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER SMITH; Christopher Smith is the roving reporter for The Salt Lake Tribune and writes frequently about Western issues.

 BODY:
IT is called a sky anchor, and when folded is about the size and heft of a silk handkerchief. Will Oxx throws one skyward as he runs and leaps off an orange sandstone cliff, free falling toward the rocky canyon bottom, a quick 440 feet below.
After a few sphincter-tightening seconds, the sky anchor opens and tugs hard on a string attached to a backpack Oxx is wearing, and an oblong canopy parachute is deployed, the rushing air colliding with the nylon surface so violently it echoes off the canyon wall like a shotgun blast. 
 "Some people go to a church and stand in front of a big manmade monolith to feel the power of God," Oxx, a cliff jumper from California, said after floating to the desert floor. "Me, I feel it here in that compressed moment when I've crossed a line and I can't turn back. It's an intense, total commitment, a life expression."
To worshipers of the almighty adrenaline, this desert community in southeastern Utah is the new Mecca. Within a 20-mile radius of the town of Moab can be found one of America's premier white-water stretches, an internationally known mountain bike trail, scads of unclimbed cliff faces, tree-lined back-country ski runs and a spidery maze of treacherous Jeep tracks, all set against an otherworldly backdrop tinted with red, yellow, black, purple, white and gray.
A landscape of extremes, it is also extremely dangerous.
"Wherever we look there is but a wilderness of rock," wrote Maj. John Wesley Powell, the Colorado River pioneer, one of the first whites to gaze upon the Moab canyon country. "Deep gorges, where the rivers are lost below the cliffs and towers and pinnacles; and ten thousand strangely carved forms in every direction; and beyond them, mountains blending with the clouds."
Later in the journey, Powell, who had lost an arm in the Civil War, became "rimrocked" -- unable to move up or down -- while climbing a redrock wall. In what was probably the first recorded "technical rescue" in canyon country, the Major needed a climbing companion to lower a pair of long underwear and hoist him from danger.
Situated where the Colorado River begins its piercing descent to the Grand Canyon, Moab was the "land beyond the Jordan River" to the Mormon settlers who bestowed its biblical name. Populated by fruit growers and cowboys, it was an isolated outpost until 1952, when the discovery of uranium prompted a mining boom that had dwindled by the 1970's.
Moab's economy and population eroded until two brothers who were out of work as uranium miners, Bill and Robin Groff, began selling newly introduced "mountain bikes" from a converted warehouse in 1983. The Groffs discovered that the fat-tired, multigeared bicycles were perfect for traversing the Slickrock Trail, an undulating nine-mile circuit over smooth mounds of pink, 200 million-year-old rock that had been blazed by Jeeps and dirt bikes.
"That trail was a terror on a motorcycle," said Bill Groff, whose Rim Cyclery bike shop remains a staple of the spandex bike short set. "There are places where it can go Monday on you real fast, and you don't want to be riding something that weighs 300 pounds. You have much more control with a bicycle."
Today, more than 110,000 mountain-bike trips are made over the Slickrock Trail every year, the path worn black with the rubber left by screeching tires. Nighttime mountain biking has gained in popularity because of crowding during the day and more powerful bike lights.
T HE trail has made Moab a mother lode of recreation that Groff -- sometimes to his dismay as a native -- gives little chance of petering out, "because this country is mesmerizing," he explained.
"I used to fly air tours, and the country says it all -- you don't have to speak," she said, "you can go from one foot off the ground to 18,000 feet, and it is constantly changing."
The landscape is a wrinkled, weather-worn desert skin that invites exploration and serves as a backdrop for an average of 50 television commercials annually, hawking soft drinks, energy bars, sport utility vehicles and feminine hygiene products. Nike and Chevrolet have borrowed Moab's name and image for beefy sneakers and sporty auto-option packages.
"We definitely thought we could associate our product with this area as the most extreme testing ground, where you can be snowboarding in the mountains in the morning and mountain biking in the desert in the afternoon," said Michael Jackson, whose Moab-based Zeal Optics sunglasses are sold worldwide. Another local company, Dura-Ride, manufactures bicycle seat covers from bulletproof Kevlar materials.
Even the tobacco giant Philip Morris has used Moab for the last 15 years as a backdrop for its Marlboro Adventure Team, a cigarette sales promotion targeted at international markets. Selected contestants from Europe and Asia are brought to Moab for a week of white-water rafting, off-road racing and horseback riding beneath stoic red mesas. Of the 1.5 million recreation visits to the Moab area last year, many were made by international tourists fulfilling John Wayne fantasies.
"Those Europeans, the harder you go, the better they like it," said Val Dalton, a third-generation Utah cattleman who requires "guest cowhands" to ride horseback 10 to 12 hours a day, paying $140 a day to haze wayward steers out of slot canyons on a 200,000-acre ranch south of Moab. "The foreigners, they enjoy that we offer no cushy extras like electricity or running water. But the Californians, forget it. Most of them are the biggest wimps you've ever seen."
Thousands of domestic Walter Mittys flock to Moab as well, perhaps inspired by too many Jeep Wrangler commercials and REI outdoor gear catalogues. Moab's lure as a haven for adventure recreation fuels the town's tourist-based economy, but it has caused an outbreak of what local paramedics call testosterone poisoning. Others suffer from ignorance.
"So many people assume these trails are like Disneyland, with water bubbling out of fountains along the way," said Kaaron Jorgen, who helped publish a desert environment safety brochure after befriending the mother of one of two Iowa boys who died of dehydration while lost on a 1995 mountain bike trip near Moab.
"She told me her son had all these magazines spread across his bed when he was planning his trip, with beautiful pictures and exciting stories about the canyon country," Jorgen said. "After he died, she went back and read those magazines, and not one of them ever mentioned what a harsh environment this is."
N OT only are some greenhorns unaware of the need to carry water -- as many as three gallons per person per day may be required in summer heat -- but many know little about the expensive, high-end equipment they've brought along.
"People come out here with their brand- new, $2,500 mountain bikes and don't even know how to shift," said Russ von Koch, the Moab recreation planner for the Bureau of Land Management, which administers much of the region's popular recreation sites.
The incursion of adventurers has put a significant strain on local services and taxpayers. Grand County, of which Moab is the seat, averages 145 search-and-rescue missions a year, most for newcomers who overestimate personal abilities and underestimate wilderness.
"It's difficult for local people to continue to foot the bill for these searches, which are primarily for people who are visitors to the area," said Sheriff Jim Nyland, whose rural county of 12,000 swells to more than 20,000 from Easter weekend to Halloween. "This place is beautiful, there's lots to do, but we get so many foreigners and people from outside the area who have no idea of the desert environment."
The growing popularity of once-elite sports like technical rock climbing has forced volunteers on the local search-and-rescue team to learn the intricacies of recovering victims in high-angle or vertical situations.
"Five years ago, a technical rescue was tying a rope to the bumper of a Jeep and hauling it up," said Frank Mendonca, the search-and-rescue coordinator for Grand County. Now, team members must be familiar with climbing specialties like Prusik Hitches and Petzl Stops, as well as night rescues and redundant backup systems.
Cataract Canyon, an 18-mile stretch of the Colorado River near Moab with 26 rapids significant enough to have names, has become a magnet for white-water junkies during the spring runoff, when the chili-colored water can rise into 30-foot-high standing waves that peak in a haystack of foam. During a 42-day period last spring, National Park Service rangers rescued 43 people who had been thrown from rafts by the snowmelt-charged current. Another 90 who were tossed overboard swam to safety or were rescued by other rafters.
"The river was carrying everything: tires, trees, dead animals," said Steve Swanke, a Canyonlands National Park river ranger. "Shoot, I even saw a refrigerator float by. In those conditions, we know we're going to have rescues because even if it's 90 degrees in the canyon, the water is cold enough to cause hypothermia."
But it is exactly those conditions that draw the thrill-seekers, novice and veteran.
"It's fabulous, spectacular, a little scary and sometimes a lot scary," John Williams, a Moab river runner for 30 years, said of the Cataract spring flood. "I can't explain it. All I know is the way I feel when I get to the bottom -- and it is utter exhilaration."
Oxx, whose Cliff Jumpers of America organization counts 200 active members, understands the appeal. During breaks from his job as a Federal Express pilot, he scouts Moab for a new ledge to leap off, finding salvation on the edge.
"It's beautiful country, but not everyone is satisfied driving a Winnebago and being a windshield tourist," he said. "Knowing I'm doing something where my life could be taken away makes me feel more alive than ever."

HEADLINE: Wine Talk;
Why New Jersey Loves Pennsylvania And Other Strange Liquor Law Tales

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
IN Chicago, it's now O.K. to feed wine to a dog. Or so one must assume, as a city law that banned serving Champagne to Skippy has been repealed. There is no way of telling how the dogs feel about this, but among connoisseurs of ludicrous wine legislation, the dog law will be missed.
Not that there is any shortage of laws designed to inconvenience wine drinkers. Around the country, hundreds of state and local laws, ghosts of Prohibition, make buying and selling wine, spirits and beer far more complicated than it should be. 
 For example, New York State bans the sale of wine in grocery stores, to keep it out of the hands of minors. Or so we are told.
Yet, beer is sold in grocery stores, in full view of impressionable youngsters -- and only in grocery stores. Every day, hundreds of out-of-state visitors are surprised to hear clerks in New York liquor stores say, "We're not allowed to sell beer."
New York is one of 15 states that ban the sale of wine in grocery stores outright. In Minnesota, however, only grocers in the three largest cities sell wine; Rhode Island limits wine sales to towns with 10,000 or fewer residents, plus Newport.
Once credit cards were banned in liquor stores and wine shops, but now Arkansas is the only state where they are not allowed. In New York, you can use a credit card to buy wine, but only if you show up at the store in person. In Alabama, it's illegal to buy any alcoholic beverages by telephone, fax or E-mail.
Let's say you are a wine connoisseur and you've decided to sell your collection of rare wines to another collector. Don't even try it in New York, or in most other states. Wine must be sold through a licensed retailer. Naturally, there is a busy and lucrative trade in illicit wine sales.
It's the same with wine auctions in New York. They were banned for years until an arrangement was made that puts the retailers in charge. Any wine purchased at an auction in New York must be cleared through a licensed retailer, who adds his fee to the cost.
In states where wine prices are regulated, a retailer can't give away even a cheap corkscrew. Such premiums are seen as a reduction in the price of the wine, though in fact the consumer pays the full amount. On the same principle, Arkansas bans that old saloon standby, the free lunch. Should a Little Rock barkeep so much as offer a customer a ham sandwich, he risks a $100 fine and 30 days in the county jail.
In Utah, a restaurateur takes similar chances in offering a customer a wine list. If the patron asks for the list, no problem, but offering it unbidden is looking for trouble with the law. So is serving a second glass of wine to someone who hasn't finished the first.
Most of these outlandish or silly rules date from just after Prohibition's repeal, when they were meant as concessions to the prohibitionists, who were still active at the time. Originally, these laws dealt with the moral aspects of drinking: banning sales of it on Sundays, for example, and seeing that taverns were not established anywhere near a church.
In recent years, laws against wine and liquor have taken on a more protectionist role. The controversy over direct shipments from California wineries to consumers around the country is a case in point. Direct shipment of wine into New York State is banned, ostensibly because minors might buy it, using phony identification and a parent's credit card. In fact, this issue has little to do with concern for minors and much to do with the state's well-organized wine and liquor distributors, the industry's middlemen, who lose income on every direct sale. Pressed by distributors, several states have made direct shipment a felony.
The Wine Institute, which represents most of the California wineries, works to abolish anti-wine laws and to head off new ones.
"They range from the unnecessary to the absurd, but they effectively rob the American consumer of economic rights and freedom of choice regarding wine," said John DeLuca, president of the institute.
Not surprisingly, the institute is not reluctant to point out some of the laws its sees as most restrictive. Like the Colorado law requiring wine to be sold in containers no smaller than 24 ounces and spirits in containers no smaller than a fifth of a gallon. What this does is prevent the average drinking man from slipping a pint of his favorite into his jacket or back pocket. It also means that splits of Champagne and half-bottles of wine are illegal.
At the same time, Colorado decrees that nothing can be stored in hotel mini-bars but miniatures; no cans of beer, no half-bottles of wine. Half the law says "nothing too small," and half says "nothing too large."
In Florida, wine can't be sold in a container larger than a gallon. In Kentucky, where some counties are dry and some are not, it's illegal to take alcoholic beverages into a dry county but O.K. to take them out, so long as they are in containers no smaller than three gallons. Presumably, this is for whisky distillers who happen to be based in dry counties.
Probably the most egregious government encroachment on America's drinking habits is the controlled state. In 18 states, plus Montgomery County, Md., sales of wine and spirits are controlled by a state-run monopoly. The largest of these states is Pennsylvania. Over the years Pennsylvania governors have sworn to rid the state of this uncompetitive relic. None have been able to overcome the unions of the Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board's employees.
Pennsylvania wine drinkers vote with their feet or, more accurately, with their cars. Liquor store owners in neighboring states estimate that more than one-third of their fine-wine customers come from Pennsylvania.
Mark Squires, who teaches at Temple University in Philadelphia and puts out a wine magazine on the World Wide Web, estimates that wine enthusiasts in Pennsylvania probably buy only 20 to 30 percent of their wine in the state. The other 70 to 80 percent they buy across the Delaware River in New Jersey, where selections are greater, clerks more knowledgeable and prices 10 to 15 percent lower.
One thriving Camden, N.J., retailer said of the Pennsylvania liquor bureaucrats, "I bless them every day."
 
Tastings
Coppola Opus
Niebaum-Coppola Rubicon 1993, Napa Valley. About $55.
 
RUBICON, the proprietary wine from Francis Ford Coppola's California estate, has become something like the head of a large and growing family of Italian-American wines. Each year, it seems, new wines emerge from the imaginations of Mr. Coppola and his winemaker, Scott McLeod. But Rubicon is still the best. It is a cabernet-based wine with varying amounts of merlot and cabernet franc, depending on the vintage.
In earlier vintages, beginning with 1978, Rubicon was not released until it had aged about seven years in the winery. This 1993 obviously spent less time in the cellars, but it did have 25 months in French oak, and it has great depth and intensity to show for it. The price is a bit stiff, considering that the first Rubicons were about $29. But then, what good Napa Valley wine isn't a lot more expensive now than it was a decade ago? In fact, given the proliferation of $75 and $100 wines recently, Rubicon is something of a bargain. Dare one say, Get them while they last?

HEADLINE: Gain in Productivity Slowed in Late 1997

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
Growth in productivity, an indicator of how quickly living standards can rise, slowed a bit as 1997 ended.
The gain in the fourth quarter, 1.6 percent at an annual rate, was revised from last month's 2 percent estimate, the Labor Department said today. And it was less than half the 3.6 percent spurt in the third quarter. 
 The revision in output per hour by nonfarm workers did not alter the estimated productivity gain for all of 1997 -- 1.7 percent. That followed a 1.9 percent increase in 1996.
Judged by recent standards, gains in productivity during the last two years have been relatively strong. Productivity advanced just 1 percent a year, on average, from 1974 through 1995 after having risen at a annual average of nearly 3 percent during the 1960's and early 1970's.
Sluggish productivity in the 1970's and 1980's has been cited as the cause of a host of economic problems, including widening economic inequality and slipping consumer purchasing power.
Conversely, the pickup of the last few years could help explain the peaceful coexistence of strong economic growth and declining inflation. Strong rises in productivity mean employers can pay workers more -- because they are producing more -- without raising prices.
Many analysts say that productivity growth has been higher than has been reported by the Government recently. They say the discrepancy comes from the difficulty in measuring output gains in services, which are being helped by the rapid advance of high-technology tools.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Championing Lady Justice In the Bronx

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
LADY JUSTICE presides over the entrance to the old Bronx County Courthouse, her sandblasted robes fairly gleaming in contrast to the fenced-in hulk's soot-encrusted walls. She casts her gaze beyond Third Avenue, over a vista of newly built homes that have slowly brought this section of Melrose back to life.
Yolanda Garcia takes pride in that statue, which she used to see all the time growing up in the neighborhood, where her family runs a carpet business. After all, Lady Justice remained untouched by the scavengers who descended on the building in search of Beaux Arts booty when it was shuttered in the late 1970's. 
 "But we still have the statue," Ms. Garcia said. "Remember, our statue is not blindfolded. She doesn't have the scales of justice. She does have a shield and a sword. She knew what was coming. She's one tough broad."
As tough as Ms. Garcia and her neighbors, who belong to Nos Quedamos (We Stay), a grass roots planning group that has spent years literally drawing up a new vision of homes, streets and parks for their once-ravaged community. Although the group secured $1 million in government and foundation grants to turn the courthouse into a civic center, the city auctioned it for $130,000 in 1996 to an electrical contractor who never made clear what plans he had for the 1914 landmark structure.
Nos Quedamos unsuccessfully sued the city to try to stop the sale. It became a moot point late last year, when the city repossessed the building after declaring the contractor in default on payments. But rather than try to work out an agreement with Nos Quedamos -- whose work has been praised by architects and featured in museums -- the city will once again put the building on the block next week.
The insistence on making a buck from the auction has angered Ms. Garcia and her supporters, who noted that the city has sold some buildings to community groups for $1. Officials had no problems ceding management of Central Park to a nonprofit group, so why won't they let Nos Quedamos relieve them of a building nobody uses?
"The city seems intent on making some kind of political point here," said Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer, who enlisted Nos Quedamos to help with the area's redevelopment. "The political point is obvious. This is something I want to do, and my guess is that some folks at City Hall don't look too kindly at that."
The City Hall press office did not respond to a request for comment. Paula Young, a spokeswoman for the Department of Citywide Administrative Services, which handles the auctions, said the courthouse would stay on the list of properties.
"We feel the private sector should be given the right to bid on the property and buy it," she said. "It's a big space. It could bring an economic viability to the area if a manufacturer purchased it, or a department store or a movie theater. Generally, the market determines a building's use."
So do zoning laws. The city's own maps show that the courthouse and surrounding blocks are not zoned for manufacturing. Urban renewal plans drawn up by the city have made the area a mixture of commercial and residential zones, with the courthouse the focus of a pedestrian mall closed to traffic.
Would the market work its magic though movies? There's already a nine-screen multiplex six blocks away on 161st Street.
"The city doesn't know what it's talking about," said Petr Stand, an architect who has advised Nos Quedamos. "What good is economic development if you ignore a community's infrastructure? The city refuses to work with this community, which really wants to work with them."
AS the auction nears, Ms. Garcia is lobbying elected officials to get the courthouse taken off the auction block. She is also trying to put together financing to see if her group can bid on the building. She needs to buy time.
Although it had to return about $500,000 in foundation grants after the building was sold the last time, Nos Quedamos's other efforts have not been wasted. It sponsored the construction of private homes and apartments for poor and homeless families. It lured a clinic to the area, offering an alternative to medicaid mills or endless waits at Lincoln Hospital.
Still, Ms. Garcia awaits justice, just like the courthouse statue promised.
"She's a good lady," she said. "She's making a statement, as the Bronx makes a statement. She survived. We can, too, if given a chance."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Profit Warnings Shrugged Off as Dow Climbs Over 8,600

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Dismissing the previous day's selloff as an overreaction to the first-quarter profit warnings of some high-profile technology companies, investors pushed stocks back up into record territory yesterday and gave the Dow Jones industrial average its first close above 8,600.
The gains, which also pushed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to a new high and added more than 1 percent to the Nasdaq composite index, contrasted sharply with Monday, when a buying spree was temporarily curbed. That skittishness reflected concerns about last week's warnings of weaker sales and slowing demand from bellwether technology companies, namely Intel, Motorola and Compaq Computer. 
 A sign that investors had swept aside those warnings was the gain in Sun Microsystems, one of the most actively traded stocks yesterday. It soared 12 percent, or 4 21/32 points, to 42 7/16, leading other technology shares higher after several analysts upgraded the issue, pointing out that investors may have overreacted to fears about slumping profits in pushing the stock lower. Sun Microsystems fell 10 percent last week.
But those declines and an announcement by the company that it would not forecast earnings shortfalls for this quarter led several analysts to revise their outlook for the stock.
Yet as investors chose to focus on uplifting market news, other companies continued to warn of possible earnings shortfalls, some citing Asia as the culprit.
Datum, a telephone data synchronization equipment maker, said it expects a first-quarter loss as orders fall because of the Asian financial crisis. And the semiconductor equipment maker Silicon Valley Group also pointed to the Far East, announcing that delayed Asian orders could prompt a fiscal second-quarter profit slide. Aseco Corporation, a semiconductor testing equipment maker, said fiscal fourth-quarter earnings would falter because of weakness in the computer chip market.
In addition, shares of Consolidated Cigar Holdings fell after the cigar maker said production problems and competition could result in little to no earnings growth in the first quarter.
Despite this news, the Dow average gained 75.98 points, to 8,643.12. The S.& P. 500 gained 1.13 percent, or 11.94, to 1,064.25. The Nasdaq rose 1.35 percent, adding 23.35 points, to 1,748.51.
"The market is shrugging off the earnings news rather remarkably," said Hank Herrmann, chief investment officer at Waddell & Reed.
The market's continued exuberance and ability to rebound from dips prompted the head of technical research at Prudential Securities, Ralph Acampora, to again forecast that the Dow could reach 10,000 before the end of 1998.
Late last year, Mr. Acampora had revised his forecast, saying the Dow would cross that barrier in 1999, but the continued resilience of the market means the rise could come quicker, he said. The rise will be driven by ample amounts of investor cash, declining interest rates and gains in retailing, financials, utilities, airlines and companies that benefit from declining interest rates, he said.
Mr. Herrmann, Mr. Acampora and several other analysts attributed the robust market to the continuing flow of money into stocks from a variety of sources.
Through the end of February, about $32.5 billion had flowed into equity mutual funds, a 15 percent decline from the corresponding period last year, said Charles Biderman, president of Trim Tabs Financial Services, a Santa Rosa, Calif., company that tracks mutual fund cash flows.
However, in addition to equity mutual fund flows, money is coming into the equity market as a result of stock repurchases and mergers and acquisitions, specifically those transactions done for cash, Mr. Biderman said.
This year, more than $159 billion of mergers and acquisitions have been announced, with $32.2 billion as cash transactions, according to the Securities Data Company. Corporations have announced $28.2 billion of share repurchases.
While those numbers are both below levels seen last year, that cash has been enough to sustain the market's rally and keep investors buying when stock prices decline, analysts said.
At Fidelity Investments, flows into equity mutual funds picked up in February, running at about $2.5 billion, compared with little more than $1 billion last year. Executives attributed this year's gains to the popularity of the new Roth individual retirement account, which accounted for 51 percent of the new I.R.A.'s opened by Fidelity clients this year, said Anne Crowley, a Fidelity spokeswoman.
While inquiries about retirement accounts have jumped more than 140 percent this year, investors have been attracted to the new Roth accounts by the tax-free earnings and withdrawal features, she said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Rise Slightly as Investors Await Retail Sales Report

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities were only slightly higher yesterday, as oil prices stemmed their downward slide, removing one of the bond market's most recent sources of support. Trading volume was again light.
The price of the 30-year bond was up 3/32, to 102 12/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped to 5.95 percent from 5.96 percent. 
 "They threw a market and no one came," said Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of the fixed-income department at J. W. Charles Securities Inc.
Traders said the bond market basically shrugged off the Labor Department's report of a downward revision for productivity in the fourth quarter; it rose 1.6 percent in the fourth quarter, less than the previously reported gain of 2 percent. They said the revision was in line with expectations.
The next significant economic report this week will be tomorrow, when the Commerce Department reports retail sales for February. Some analysts expect a strong number, but Mr. Pugliese said that would not alarm investors, because the economy has been robust for some time but has not generated increases in inflation.
"Everyone knows the economy is strong, so strong numbers will not surprise the market," Mr. Pugliese said.
Mr. Pugliese said he expected the yield on the 30-year Treasury to stay within a range of 5.85 percent to 6.05 percent for a while. But this week, a big supply of new corporate debt could apply some pressure to the market, at least in the near term.
The World Bank, the Student Loan Marketing Association, more commonly known as Sallie Mae, and other borrowers are planning to sell or have begun selling about $9 billion in debt. Dealers in the biggest of these deals, the World Bank issue, were selling the $4 billion of five-year global bonds at 14 basis points above a five-year Treasury note. (A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.) The bonds will be priced today through underwriters including Goldman Sachs International, J. P. Morgan and SBC Warburg Dillon Read.
In the municipal market, New York City priced $679.6 million of tax-exempt general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The bonds were initially priced to yield a maximum 5.45 percent for an issue due in 2027. Serial bonds with shorter maturities were priced to yield from 3.85 percent for securities maturing in 1999 to 5.37 percent for those maturing in 2016.

HEADLINE: Japanese Map A Plan to Aid An Ill Economy

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 10

 BODY:
Bowing to pressure from Washington and other Western governments, officials in Japan's ruling party strongly suggested this week that they are putting together a package of $80 billion or more to stimulate the nation's economy.
Only sketchy pictures of the package have emerged, but it appears that a tax cut, as favored in the West and by some Japanese business leaders, will not be a substantial part of it. Its size is uncertain, too, with amounts ranging from $48 billion to nearly $160 billion having been floated by Liberal Democratic Party leaders. 
 Politicians hope that such a stimulus can revive business confidence and prevent the stagnating economy from getting worse. But many critics are worried that the money will instead be spent on pet projects or doled out in pork-barrel fashion.
And economists say that unless the Government takes giant steps to deregulate various industries as well, any long-term recovery is doubtful.
"Basically, you have to have a kind of revolution here," said Peter J. Morgan, senior economist at HSBC Securities Japan Ltd.
While officials in Washington and Western Europe have stepped up calls for Japan to stimulate its economy, the Government here has been almost stubborn, offering a trickle of economic measures.
Even an $80 billion package would represent only about 2 percent of Japan's annual economic output, and most of the money is likely to be spent on traditional public works, rather than returned in the form of tax cuts that would leave corporations and citizens with extra after-tax money to invest or use to buy goods.
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto has apparently agreed on a stimulus package with party leaders, Japanese newspapers reported. But party officials have been cagey about announcing a package while the current budget is still being debated, and they have said that any open discussion of fiscal stimulants outside the budget will have to wait until after the budget is passed, probably in April. In the meantime, politicians hope that making pronouncements about spending will help restore confidence in the financial markets.
Nevertheless, Taku Yamasaki, the party's top policy maker, said on television Sunday that some new money would go into public projects involving telecommunications, the environment and education, and that a package would include tax incentives for corporate investment.
The stock market here seems to have shrugged off his remarks, with the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues falling 159.44 points on Monday and rising only slightly today to 16,982.82, up 10.29 points.
The American Secretary of the Treasury, Robert E. Rubin, and others are calling on Japan to reduce taxes by billions of dollars, and some economists have called for an extension of the $15.9 billion in income-tax cuts announced in December.
But Mr. Yamasaki said income-tax cuts were unlikely to increase personal consumption, and some business executives are worried that the money from tax cuts would be saved rather than spent.
Japanese society is aging, and many people worry that the pension system will go bankrupt by the time they retire, so they are trying to build their own nest eggs.
"People are not spending money," said Kazuo Nukazawa, senior managing director at the Keidanren, the leading business federation. In line with the organization's goal of stimulating he economy, he said, "I advise many friends to spend in the daytime." But like many Japanese he remains worried about the economic future, so "at night, I go home and tell my wife not to spend."
The Government has been sticking to a policy of fiscal austerity, partly because of a law passed in November that commits it to reduce the budget deficit to less than 3 percent of the gross domestic product by the year 2003. The deficit is projected to be 5.9 percent at the end of the current fiscal year, which ends on March 31, and economic growth is expected to be near zero for the year, so economists say that the economy needs more fuel, not less.
"This is not the time to be siphoning more gas out of the tank," said Robert Alan Feldman, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Japan Ltd. "Yes, they have a large deficit, and it's a serious long-term problem. But if they withdraw stimulus at this time, there is a potential for a very negative deflationary spiral."
Recent figures show that wages and wholesale prices are down slightly from their levels of a year ago, and corporate profits are also projected to be lower. The Cabinet concedes that the economy is "still stagnating."
But Finance Ministry officials, who essentially draw up economic policy in Japan, point out that 40 trillion yen in spending over the last three years, or about $320 billion, has not led to a recovery. So they say, why throw good money after bad?
"Our primary concern is to stop the rising debt," said Masakazu Sakaguchi, chief of the Budget Bureau's research division. "Our position is very strong, very firm."
The November law also decreed that by 2003, Japan must reduce to zero the bonds the Government issues to finance the budget deficit. Essentially, that limits its ability to spend, yet the law has loopholes and it can also be amended. Even now, Mr. Sakaguchi said, the Government has the freedom to spend as much as it feels is necessary on tax cuts or other stimulus measures.
Politicians, though, are more worried than ministry bureaucrats, partly because members of the upper house of Parliament face election this summer. Economists are thus skeptical of the motivation behind any economic package.
"It's focused on projects delivering political returns rather than economic returns," said Russell Jones, chief economist at Lehman Brothers Japan.
But foreign pressure has long been a powerful force in Japan, and members of the United States Congress have passed through Tokyo in recent months to express concern that the stagnating economy here could engulf the American economy, as well.
"If United States equity markets move to drop, Congress would probably blame Japan for that," Mr. Feldman remarked. Then, referring to Japan's politicians, he added, "Whether that is right or not, they would not want to be in the line of fire when Congress gets angry."

HEADLINE: Belgrade TV Makes Serbs Furious At Albanians

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, March 10

 BODY:
With images of the widows of four Serbian policemen weeping inconsolably at the funerals of their husbands broadcast repeatedly on Government television, President Slobodan Milosevic has stirred the deep anti-Albanian feelings in Serbia.
The police, who were killed in an ambush set by ethnic Albanian guerrillas in Kosovo, have become the most potent symbol of the barrage of state propaganda that depicts Albanians in Kosovo as terrorists and scoffs at calls for respecting human rights in the province. 
 So far, the mounting television campaign appears to be having the effect that Mr. Milosevic apparently wants: Many ordinary Serbs are saying that the police action in Kosovo has been justified.
"How would the American people respond if Albanian terrorists started to shoot at American people?" asked Srdjan Savin, 26, a mechanical engineering student at Belgrade University as he relaxed after classes today at a cafe. "If the United States wasn't putting so much pressure, there wouldn't be so much trouble because then the Albanians would not be so bold."
Just as he used state-run television to drum up Serbian nationalist sentiment in the wars against Bosnia and Croatia, Mr. Milosevic is beginning to use the same techniques in the new drama in Kosovo, Serbian journalists said.
So far, television has failed to show pictures of the more than 70 Albanians who have been killed in Kosovo in the last 10 days.
A number of factors help Mr. Milosevic, who is not widely popular any more, in standing firm on Kosovo, Serbs said in interviews today.
First, Kosovo is the central pillar of Serbian national passion, the place where the holiest monasteries and monuments stand.
Second, the opposition parties that were able to mobilize tens of thousands of protesters against Mr. Milosevic 15 months ago have either joined forces with him or refrained from open criticism of his position on Kosovo.
And while economic sanctions imposed by the West during the war in Bosnia have severely damaged Serbian living standards, there seems to be little fear of more sanctions among a people who are sullen rather than angry about their plight.
"It can't get much worse," said Mr. Savin, who faces uncertain job prospects when he graduates in one year. Demonstrations organized by trade unions to protest the state's failure to pay wages for many months to civil servants have stopped in recent days.
In the current atmosphere, when Serbian police have been killed and the population feels under pressure from the outside world, protesters would feel like "traitors," a Serbian journalist said.
Mr. Milosevic also knows that Serbs have little tolerance for the Albanians, who make up 90 percent of the province of Kosovo. Until 1989, Kosovo was an autonomous region of Yugoslavia, a status granted by Tito.
"Tito's policy was too generous," said Mr. Savin. "The Albanians must adapt and accept Yugoslavia as their own state. They wouldn't get their own schools in Germany." He was referring to the separate school system set up by ethnic Albanian political leaders in Kosovo.
In an effort to stifle news about Kosovo that does not conform with the official view, prosecutors under Mr. Milosevic's control issued criminal charges on Monday against the editors of five independently owned newspapers.
The newspapers were accused of encouraging terrorism and depicting the actions of the Serbian police in Kosovo in a false light.
Gordana Logar, the editor of Danas, said that the authorities were angered that her newspaper had reported how the Serbian Assembly declared its respect for the dead Serbian policemen with a minute's silence but had failed to take note of the Albanians who died in the fighting. She said the Milosevic Government had also taken exception to her newspaper's referring to the dead Albanians as "victims" rather than "terrorists."
In contrast to the blackout in the Serbian media of news that shows sympathy for Albanians, the official Montenegro newspaper, Pobjeda, reported on its front page yesterday that 3,500 Albanian refugees had arrived in Montenegro. Together with Serbia, Montenegro, which is now led by Milo Djukanovic, a political opponent of Mr. Milosevic, makes up what is left of the former Yugoslavia.
The official Serbian press has paid little attention to the visit today of Robert Gelbard, the Clinton Administration's special envoy to the Balkans.
A State Department official described the encounter with Mr. Milosevic during which Mr. Gelbard outlined the new sanctions imposed on Serbia at a London meeting, as "very tough." "Not much was accomplished," the official said.

HEADLINE: Atlanta at Crossroads Of Gas Price Paradise

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, March 10

 BODY:
From a distance it seems a mirage, like the gauzy image of a Saharan oasis in one of those French Foreign Legion films. But as one drives closer, the letters and numbers on the sign at the Crown gas station near the intersection of Buford Highway and Interstate 285 sharpen into focus, making it clear that this is no illusion: "Regular -- .79 9//10 ."
In a land of cheap gas, Atlanta has the cheapest. When inflation is taken into account, the nation's gasoline prices have fallen to record levels this month because of an oversupply of crude oil. And they have been driven even lower in Atlanta by minimal gasoline taxes, intense competition among retailers and the convergence of two major pipelines. 
 It has become increasingly common in recent weeks to see gasoline prices break the 80-cents-a-gallon barrier, a breathtaking number to anyone who remembers the rampant inflation and gas rationing that followed the Iranian revolution in 1979. Some service station managers in Atlanta said they had seen prices as low as 75.9 cents, and anyone buying gas here for more than 87 cents a gallon is simply not trying.
In Atlanta, and everywhere across the country, gasoline prices have been in freefall since autumn. The average price for a gallon of regular self-serve gasoline here dropped from $1.09 on Sept. 5 to 87 cents on March 6, according to the Lundberg Letter, which regularly surveys prices at 10,000 gas stations nationwide. The national average fell from $1.22 on Sept. 5 to $1.04 on March 6.
Both Trilby Lundberg, the publisher of the newsletter, and the Energy Information Administration, a Federal agency, said that gasoline prices, when adjusted for inflation, were lower today than at any time since record-keeping began more than 40 years ago. Ms. Lundberg said the average price in Atlanta was the lowest in the country.
"It's just wild," Ms. Lundberg said. "With taxes up, with the quality of gasoline up, with the cost of environmental reformulations up, that this could even occur at all shows not only the resiliency but the daring of competitors to bring this benefit to our economy."
Indeed, many of the consumers filling up at the Crown station in the Atlanta suburb of Doraville said they viewed the price of gas as one of the most tangible signs of the country's economic health. For many, the ability to fill their tanks for just over $10 generates far more optimism than do the latest numbers on job creation and housing starts.
"It's great, I love it," said John R. Dempsey, a 42-year-old hardware store salesman who was happily filling the tank of his 1989 Lincoln Mark VII with 79.9 cent gas. "I do a little traveling on the weekend, and it's nice to be able to fill this thing up for a lot less than I used to. I wonder how long it's going to last."
The primary reason for declining gas prices, industry analysts say, is a worldwide oversupply of crude oil and, thus, of gasoline. The OPEC cartel nations increased production quotas in a meeting last November and those additional barrels are now flooding the market. New oil fields have started production recently in Africa, the North Sea and the Gulf of Mexico. If the United Nations eases sanctions on Iraq, even more oil could come to the market.
Meanwhile, economic turmoil in Asia has undercut demand for petroleum products in that part of the world, as has a warm winter throughout the northern hemisphere. The United States now has stockpiles of 327 million barrels of crude oil, 29 million barrels more than last year, said Joseph A. Lastelic, a spokesman for the American Petroleum Institute.
And as a result, West Texas intermediate crude, which is often used as a benchmark, closed on the New York Mercantile Exchange at $14.26 a barrel today, down from $21.28 a year ago.
In many places, retail gasoline prices, which typically rise in the summer and decline in the winter, have tracked the descent of crude. On Long Island, the average price of regular self-serve gasoline has fallen to $1.17 from $1.33 a year ago, according to the Lundberg Letter. In Newark, it has dropped to $1 from $1.17; in Hartford, to $1.20 from $1.44; in Los Angeles, to 98 cents from $1.29; in Chicago, to $1.11 from $1.33.
But in Atlanta, prices have declined far more. Georgia's gasoline tax, at 7.5 cents a gallon, is the lowest in the country, and its 4 percent state sales tax, which is applied to gasoline purchases, is modest compared with many other states. By contrast, Connecticut has a 36 cent gas tax, the nation's highest, and New York has a 30.38 cent gas tax. A Federal gasoline tax of 18.4 cents a gallon is applied in all states.
Another factor in Atlanta's pricing is the route of two major pipelines directly through the city, providing dramatically lower transportation costs than in cities where gas must travel by truck or barge. The world's largest oil and gas pipeline, the Colonial Pipeline, passes through Atlanta on its way from Houston to New York City, and the smaller Plantation Pipeline crosses Atlanta on its path from Baton Rouge, La., to the suburbs of Washington, D.C.
"The pipelines probably provide about a nickel a gallon price advantage," said Noel L. Griese, a spokesman for the Colonial Pipeline Company, which is based in Atlanta. "What the pipelines do is put the economies of scale of the Gulf Coast refining complex at the disposal of consumers in a place like Atlanta."
The final factor in Atlanta's pricing is competition. A driver's city that has taken slowly to mass transit, Atlanta is congested with gas stations, many of them price-cutting competitors like Quiktrip.
At the Crown station, the manager, Jewel Hossain, said that he took 8 to 10 trips a day up and down Buford Highway checking the prices of his half-dozen competitors. He has occasionally changed his prices as often as three times a day.
"This is the toughest market in the country," Mr. Hossain said. "Everybody's selling below their cost. But if we don't match them we lose our customers."
Although a competitive market may be beneficial to consumers, it is harmful to the city's already hazardous air quality, which has already incited sanctions from Federal environmental and transportation officials. On average, Atlantans drive more than residents of any other American city, nearly 35 miles a day.
In the 13-county metropolitan area, residents drive about 120 million vehicle miles a day -- 27 million miles longer than the distance to the sun -- and that figure is increasing at a rate of about 5 percent a year, said Joel F. Stone, director of planning for the Atlanta Regional Commission, a multicounty planning agency.
"We've been fighting a battle for years dealing with whether you can get people to do something other than drive in their cars by themselves," Mr. Stone said. "We've always felt it takes external forces to get them to take another mode or drive with someone else, and those are usually congestion or pricing. Cheap gasoline doesn't help us do that."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Trade Surplus Rises 212.8% in Japan

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, March 11

 BODY:
Japan's politically contentious trade surplus, as measured by the flow of goods and services, soared 212.8 percent in January from the corresponding month last year to 476.2 billion yen, the Finance Ministry said Wednesday.
The surplus in goods alone rose 136.6 percent to 538.8 billion yen. 
 At the Wednesday exchange rate of about 127 yen to the dollar, the current account surplus, the broadest measure of trade in goods and services, was $3.74 billion. It was the 10th straight month that the surplus had increased from a year earlier.
One reason for the enlarged surplus is that Japan's faltering economy has diminished the domestic demand for imports.
The burgeoning surplus is expected to increase calls from Japan's trading partners, particularly the United States, for Tokyo to do more to stimulate the economy so that Japanese consumers purchase more foreign goods.

HEADLINE: For Motorcycle Gang Without Motorcycles, Even More Bad News

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
These are hard times for the Harlem Cowboys motorcycle gang.
Most of the gang members don't have motorcycles. Rebel, the gang leader, lives in a motor home. And the headquarters are in a construction trailer. 
 Just when things seemed at their worst, police detectives kicked in the door and arrested them on suspicion of selling machine guns and related hardware. Now even prosecutors don't give them any respect.
"They were known on the street as the motorcycle gang without motorcycles," said Bridget G. Brennan, the city's acting special narcotics prosecutor. "I don't think we ever saw more than two or three motorcycles."
When they did roar down the avenue, Ms. Brennan noted, it tended to be on cheap, low-powered models. "Most of these guys were unemployed," she said, "and Harleys are kind of expensive."
Ms. Brennan said the Cowboys prefer to stalk the neighborhood around 111th Street and Third Avenue on foot, wearing jackets with their official colors: two bloody daggers above a cigar-smoking rack of teeth, and a "batlike object" in the foreground.
The police began investigating the group last year after officers started to suspect that the Cowboys were selling weapons, including military-style machine guns and other exotic firearms.
"We learned that anything you wanted, they could probably get their hands on," said Detective John Ragone of the Manhattan North narcotics major case squad. "They were talking at one point about getting hand grenades."
Seven members of the Cowboys were arraigned yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. Most were charged with criminal sale of a firearm. The president, Israel (Rebel) Jorge, 51, of Harlem, was also charged with selling drugs. Mr. Jorge's lawyer could not be reached for comment yesterday.
Police officials said detectives seized nine ounces of cocaine from the gang's headquarters during the last two weeks, as well as several guns, including TEC-9 automatic machine pistols, a MAC-11 machine pistol and an AR-15 machine gun with a silencer.
At one time, the Harlem Cowboys were a powerful gang. Founded 42 years ago, the gang is sanctioned by the Hell's Angels motorcycle gang, which gives members the right to attach the letters MC (for motorcycle club) to their colors without fear of reprisals from the Hell's Angels, police officials said.
"But their numbers have dwindled," Detective Ragone said. "They could not get anyone else to enlist."
There are 18 active members of the Cowboys, Detective Ragone said, and most are approaching middle age. But the detective said he believes that with the recent arrests, the gang is essentially out of business.
Several club members worked at jobs in the neighborhood. Police officials said Mr. Jorge provided night security for construction sites.
Doel Rivera, owner of E. J. York construction of Manhattan, said he did not know that Mr. Jorge's group was a motorcycle gang.

HEADLINE: Vallone, Attacking Pataki, Begins Race for Governor

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Peter F. Vallone, the Speaker of the New York City Council, declared his candidacy for governor yesterday, portraying Gov. George E. Pataki as an ambitious yet drifting chief executive who has overseen a stagnant economy, deteriorating schools and a troubled health care system.
Mr. Vallone, 62 and facing a forced end to his City Council career in 2001 because of term limits, laid out his candidacy at the beginning of a two-day series of rallies that took him to Long Island, Manhattan, Westchester and Albany. 
 The largely southern tilt of the first day's announcement, at venues where he was assured to draw a crowd, highlights what many Democrats believe is one of Mr. Vallone's main obstacles in winning his party's nomination: he is a Queens Democrat who is little known outside the southern part of New York.
Nevertheless, with New York's City Hall at his back, and surrounded by a thick clutch of political leaders who crowded around him as the cameras snapped, Mr. Vallone sought to do what many Democrats have chosen not to do this year. He offered a case for defeating Mr. Pataki during a time of relative prosperity and amid polls suggesting that the Republican Governor is well regarded by many voters.
Mr. Vallone asserted that New York's economy was lagging behind that of the rest of the nation. He condemned the partisan deadlock that had gripped much of Mr. Pataki's first term. And in fairly biting terms, he asserted that Mr. Pataki was nurturing his own potential national political ambitions at the expense of the state's health.
Mr. Vallone, a soft-spoken lawyer who sometimes had to struggle to make himself heard, declared that he would wage a campaign "that views the Governor's office as the seat of leadership and accountability for the state, not as an incubator for overheated personal ambition and oval-shaped flights of fancy -- a campaign that puts New York first for a change, first ahead of partisan wrangling and patronage and posturing, first ahead of excuses and delays and complacency, first ahead of personal ego and political ambition."
With yesterday's announcement, Mr. Vallone joins a crowded field, but most of his rivals are even less known than he is: James L. Larocca, a former state energy and transportation commissioner; Richard A. Kahan, a developer and former chairman of the State Urban Development Corporation, and Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn District Attorney.
The one well-known and well-financed candidate is Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross. She was elected as Mr. Pataki's running mate, but then changed her party registration and said she would seek the Democratic nomination and run against Mr. Pataki.
Mr. Vallone's aides said yesterday that they view Ms. McCaughey Ross as their biggest rival. She was the only Democrat Mr. Vallone criticized in his speech, challenging her political moorings without mentioning her name.
"The Democratic Party is much more than a convenient vehicle with which to advance a political career -- it is a sacred trust passed down from Jefferson, Jackson, Roosevelt, Truman and Kennedy," Mr. Vallone said, as his supporters shivered under the slate-gray skies that rolled over City Hall. "And to those who believe that a party or a person is merely a prop -- I serve notice here today that they will be called to task in this campaign."
Ms. McCaughey Ross, through a spokesman, declined to comment on the criticism. But, suggesting a reason for her political potency, she said: "New Yorkers are ready for fresh approaches and new ideas and they are ready to elect the first woman governor in New York State history."
Mr. Pataki also declined to respond to Mr. Vallone's criticism. "I'll respond to the Democratic candidate when the Democrats have a candidate, whenever that is," the Governor said in Albany.
Mr. Pataki's aides were not so reticent, taking issue in particular with Mr. Vallone's claim that Mr. Pataki was benefiting from a surge on Wall Street, and that in fact, New York economic performance trailed that of the rest of the nation.
"Throughout much of upstate New York, the national economy has been unable to pull communities out of a recession," Mr. Vallone said. "And the governor has been too out of touch -- and out of state -- to help. If this is the best we can do in the midst of a nationwide boom, where will we be when the boom fades?"
Stephen Kagann, Mr. Pataki's chief economist, disputed that claim, saying: "There's a very clear turnaround in the upstate economy. Again you can pick your numbers, but if you look realistically, you would find that most of the upstate economies or regions have turned the corner. Some of them are doing very, very well."
Mr. Vallone faces a number of problems in the months ahead. For one thing, several Democrats questioned whether he had the stomach for a contested statewide campaign. He is known in City Hall as someone who does not take to particularly long days, as he himself suggested in a 1996 interview in which he said he did not want to be mayor.
"I need a family life, and I don't know whether this city allows you to have one," Mr. Vallone said then. "I think you can as president. I think you can as governor. I don't think you can do it as mayor of the City of New York."
He also faces enormous challenges in raising money to match Mr. Pataki, who has already raised $12 million. At last report, Mr. Vallone had raised $2 million.

LENGTH: 1435 words

HEADLINE: High Schools Fear Telling Colleges All About Johnny

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER 

 BODY:
The reports are coming in piecemeal: parents threatening high school counselors with lawsuits if their children fail to gain college acceptance; counselors taking out liability insurance; admissions officers complaining that a student's disciplinary or criminal past is not being reported to them.
With college acceptances a month away, high school guidance counselors say fear of litigation by parents has made them more cautious in letters of recommendation and informal conversations with college admissions officials, threatening the longstanding system by which high school students are selected for cherished freshman class spots. 
 "Counselors are becoming afraid of telling the full truth," said Joyce E. Smith, executive director of the National Association for College Admission Counseling, a group that includes both high school counselors and college officials. "They'll write that Johnny took these courses and was a great student, but they won't tell you that Johnny burned down the gym. Whose job is it to tell admissions officers about that?"
Apart from the growing tendency everywhere to resort to legal action, the sources of these tensions are many.
Colleges increasingly are emphasizing campus safety and worry that if they admit a student with a criminal past who then becomes violent, university officials will be held liable. This makes them more determined than ever to know about students' pasts, especially following a 1995 case in which Harvard College unwittingly admitted a young woman who, as a juvenile, had killed her alcoholic and possibly abusive mother.
At the same time, parents worry that details of disciplinary problems will ruin their children's chances of admission.
And guidance counselors, hearing differing interpretations of state and Federal laws, are caught in the middle.
Past alcohol and drug use, widely reported to college admissions officers in an earlier era, is now shielded under the 1990 Americans With Disabilities Act. Further, the sharpened focus on the place of education in personal economic success seems to make parents more likely to calculate the financial impact of rejection from a top school.
Colleen Quint, a lawyer in Maine who advises colleges, said the atmosphere around admissions is changing dramatically.
"The stakes are so much higher now," she said. "By the time a student graduates from private school, parents have already put tens of thousands of dollars into guaranteeing a spot at a fancy college. Parents now see themselves as consumers with rights. They are making an investment. At the same time, there has been sociological change among students. Today, you have students who have been involved with some serious problems, and that concerns colleges.
"Twenty years ago, if a student had missed a portion of his senior year for alcoholism, counselors would have told admissions officers right away," she added. "The sense in the profession was to tell all, give a complete picture and put problems in perspective, saying now this applicant is back at the top of his game or some such.
"Today, there is a hesitation to do that. Under the Americans With Disabilities Act, you cannot make pre-admission inquiries about disabilities. Alcoholism and drug addiction are disabilities if you have had treatment for them and have moved on."
Many private preparatory academies have long had policies saying that all disciplinary actions against students will be reported to colleges. But some are now saying that they are reconsidering such policies under pressure from parents, as well as legal concerns.
Steven T. Syverson, dean of admissions at Lawrence University in Appleton, Wis., said he found out the hard way about the scope of the disabilities law.
Four years ago, Mr. Syverson received an application from a student who had suffered a psychological disorder and whose grades were weak following a breakdown. The university said it would withhold deciding on her application until the end of the year to see if her grades bounced back. They did not and her application was rejected.
The student's mother complained to the Office of Civil Rights at the Department of Education, which investigated and cleared Lawrence. But it did so on condition that its application form no longer include a question asking counselors whether there were "factors that might interfere with a student's performance, either from discipline, chronic illness or emotional stability."
A similar question exists on dozens of other college application forms.
"This problem of what we can ask and what counselors can report is now a topic at every workshop and conference I attend," Mr. Syverson said. "Counselors are worried about how not to get nailed. We worry about past criminal or disciplinary activity that could reappear on campus and that the college could have liability for. Everyone is getting squeezed on both sides.
"Over the years we had developed a candid relationship, and that is disappearing now. We are getting recommendations that clearly have to pass the test of parents having read them, meaning they are watered down and not very useful."
Although grades, standardized test scores, activities and essays form the basis for admission decisions, guidance counselors have traditionally been seen as important sources of straight information for admissions officers, with whom they have developed a relationship.
But guidance counselors express concerns over the deterioration of that relationship because they are no longer sure what protection they have to report unsavory details.
Scott White, a counselor at Montclair High School in New Jersey, offered a hypothetical case that he said bore parallels to a dilemma he faced in a previous counseling job: a senior who had already been accepted to a college was found distributing hate leaflets, and the principal asked that the college be informed.
"I know that if the college gets wind of this after the student starts attending, the admissions staff there will lose all faith in my honesty," he said. "But the student's parents say they don't want this information communicated. What am I to do?"
Mr. White's concern, he said, flows from a 1974 law known as the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act, or the Buckley Amendment, after James L. Buckley, the Senator from New York who sponsored it as an amendment to a 1965 education law.
Mr. White and many other counselors say they have been told that the act forbids sending student disciplinary records to colleges without express permission from the student's parents. Ms. Quint, the Maine education lawyer, says she knows lawyers who take that stand as well.
But LeRoy S. Rooker, director of the family policy compliance office of the Department of Education in Washington, said that interpretation is wrong.
"Congress clearly intended that you could transfer information of a non-academic nature to an institution where a student was going to enroll," he said.
He acknowledged that state regulations, like the Illinois School Student Records Act, and the Federal Americans With Disabilities Act do complicate the legal picture.
One factor driving the current debate is that crime on campus has become a widely recognized, if low-level, feature of college life, said Dorothy Siegel, director of the Campus Violence Prevention Center at Towson State University in Maryland, which tracks campus violence across the country.
She said that although crime has remained at the same low level for two decades, applicants and their parents routinely ask about crime and violence, often linked to alcohol. As a result, increasing numbers of universities are now asking students and their schools for any history of disciplinary troubles.
The increased use of such questions also stems from the publicity given the 1995 Harvard case, according to many counselors and admission officials. That case involved Gina Grant, an honors student in Boston granted admission. Ms. Grant had not revealed on her application that when she was a 14-year-old in South Carolina she had killed her mother, repeatedly striking her on the head with a lead-crystal candlestick. Harvard, which had asked about past criminal or disciplinary problems on the application, withdrew its acceptance when her past was revealed through anonymous mailings to the university.
Counselors say they are eager to prevent such embarrassments and often resort to coded language in their reports suggesting the college telephone them.
But now some say they have been warned that even that may be subject to legal action.

HEADLINE: Clinton Make Plea for Congress To Use Its (Short) Time Wisely

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

DATELINE: CINCINNATI, March 10

 BODY:
President Clinton took a poke at Congress today, noting seven times in a brief speech that in the schedule set by Republicans, legislators have just 70 working days left this year, even though it is only March.
But that is still enough time to pass landmark legislation on tobacco and child care, Mr. Clinton said, and he urged Congress to do so. 
 "We should not let the calendar get in the way of the urgent need for action," he said this morning in Bridgeport, Conn. The President spoke before attending two fund-raising events -- one over lunch in Connecticut, the other over dinner here -- that pulled in $850,000 for the Democratic National Committee.
"Do everything you can to send a clear and unambiguous signal that you do not want the election year to be a relaxation year," Mr. Clinton implored his audience in Bridgeport. "You want it to be a legislating year for the children of this country."
Increasingly, Democrats have cast the Republican-controlled Congress as "do nothing," and the President's call to action was intended to build on that theme. It had the added advantage of portraying Mr. Clinton as steeped in the nation's business, even though the independent counsel's investigation into his relationship with a former White House intern has tied up the White House.
The President's call for Congress to resolve the dispute over tobacco legislation dovetailed with his plea that Congress provide more money for child care. He has said that the proposed $368.5 billion settlement with the tobacco companies would help pay for his $21 billion child-care proposal. Mr. Clinton's importuning on tobacco also provided a way for him to deflect criticism for dining here tonight at the suburban home of a trial lawyer who stands to reap a windfall from the tobacco deal.
The lawyer, Stanley M. Chesley, who has represented smokers, helped negotiate the proposed settlement reached last June between 40 states and the tobacco companies. Mr. Chesley, who testified last week on Capitol Hill in favor of the deal, has said that tonight's cash cornucopia had nothing to do with tobacco.
Closure on the settlement would guarantee lawyers like Mr. Chesley a large but undetermined piece of the pie. Congress is still negotiating over whether to grant the tobacco companies immunity from further lawsuits and how to calculate lawyers' fees.
Ralph Nader and others have criticized Mr. Clinton's attendance at tonight's dinner, saying that it gives the appearance that the President would take Mr. Chesley's side in any tobacco deal because Mr. Chesley raised so much money for him.
Barry Toiv, a White House spokesman, said there was no connection between the fund-raiser and the tobacco legislation.
Mr. Clinton did not address the topic directly. When a reporter asked whether his appearance at the dinner was improper, he shook his head but said nothing.
Tickets to the sit-down dinner cost a minimum of $10,000 per person and $15,000 per corporation. About 100 people attended, bringing in more than $500,000 for the Democratic Party, which is still $9 million in debt from the 1996 Presidential campaign.
Earlier in the day, Mr. Clinton visited a child-care center at the Housatonic Community-Technical College in Bridgeport. He then spoke in a small auditorium to 200 people about child care, restating his proposal for $21 billion over the next five years so that 2 million families can receive subsidized child care.
The President said that the nation's low unemployment had come at a price -- working parents had to leave their children in child care. "We cannot have a country that asks people to make a choice between succeeding at home and succeeding at work," he said.

HEADLINE: House G.O.P. Content to Make Ripples

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
Three years after sweeping into office on their Contract With America, House Republicans are acting as if they now have a contract with their campaign consultants: to keep the revolution on hold.
In this election year, the House leadership has scheduled a mere 89 days when votes will be taken. And the Republicans, who once yearned to abolish whole Federal departments, are whiling away much of their time with the same kind of small-scale gestures and symbolic actions that President Clinton deployed in his re-election campaign. 
 So they have passed legislation to rename Washington National Airport for Ronald Reagan and moved to ban possession of machines that clone cell phone signals and to make it a Federal offense to cross a state border to intimidate a witness in a state criminal case. They have approved nonbinding resolutions, such as one proclaiming that Congress will not discriminate against stay-at-home moms.
The most radical idea on the horizon is an overhaul of the tax code. But for campaign purposes, the Republicans are working to stir up public opposition to the tax system without actually planning to bring a new code up for a vote this year.
All of this represents a strategic decision. Republican leaders believe their party will do best in the coming campaign by running on last summer's balanced budget agreement, adding some grace notes on education, crime and tax cuts and, most important, doing nothing to alarm the public.
"For the most part, this is going to be a year of don't make any waves," said Rich Galen, executive director of Gopac, the Republican political action committee. "Let's see what happens with the President and get out early and campaign hard at the end."
Even Newt Gingrich, the House Speaker, has become noticeably cautious. At news conferences the once freewheeling House Speaker has taken to checking his behavior with his press secretary, Christina Martin. He often catches her eye when he has delivered a well-crafted phrase or gives her a wary glance when he has failed to muzzle his biting humor.
He avoids some topics altogether. Asked about President Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky recently, he said, "I have no comment at all on that entire zone."
Some of the combative conservatives who went to Washington to remake it are starting to complain about a lack of will. Representative David M. McIntosh of Indiana told House Republican leaders recently that when Congress is in town, "we want real things on the agenda." He said the party leaders replied, "You need to spend more time at home."
On the other side of the aisle, Representative Barney Frank, a Massachusetts Democrat, has taken to joking that Congress has given up legislating for Lent.
Underlying the Republican strategy is the fact that in sharp contrast to the anti-Washington fury that shaped the 1992 and 1994 elections, pollsters this year are finding voters content with the booming economy, optimistic about the nation's future and with no dominant problem on their minds.
"The voters are not angry about anything," said Charles Cook, who puts out a nonpartisan political newsletter, The Cook Political Report.
Public approval of Congress is up and even Mr. Gingrich's approval ratings are inching higher. An internal poll by the Republican National Committee that is circulating among Congressional Republicans shows that in February Congress's own approval ratings reached an extraordinary high of 68 percent.
What all that means is that unless some new crisis rocks public life, it will be a good year for incumbents and a good year for the Republicans to hold on to their majority.
"I think the political decision has been made -- and it might be right -- that Congress right now is held in high regard," said Representative Peter T. King, a Long Island Republican, "that we've gotten the job done. We're a check on Clinton. He's a check on us, and the American people seem satisfied. The Republican leadership has made a decision not to upset that balance and equilibrium."
The question is whether rank-and-file party members and particularly those on the Republicans' conservative flank will follow the script.
For underneath the surface calm simmer profound Republican disagreements over the new fiscal era of budget surpluses, and how far to go in tax cutting and overhaul of the tax code. The Republicans in Congress are splintered over what to do about issues like tobacco and health care. And they are divided, too, over how hard to push a conservative social agenda.
The talk show host Rush Limbaugh recently complained on Fox television that it was getting harder to tell Mr. Clinton and the Republicans apart. And some Republicans are worried that they are not doing enough to energize their core supporters in November.
"A basketball team that tries not to lose invariably loses," said Representative Lindsey Graham, a Republican from South Carolina and a member of the landslide House class of '94.
A short Congressional session provides less time, however, for dissatisfied legislators to create waves like last year's abortive coup against Mr. Gingrich. And the leaders hope votes on such conservative issues as school vouchers or a planned attempt to override Mr. Clinton's veto of a ban on a form of abortion will be enough to placate those on the right.
Perhaps the greatest test of the leaders' ability to hold the party together will come as the House and Senate try to draft a new budget.
The party leaders want a plan that will provide enough new tax cuts to keep the party's imprint on the issue yet not go overboard and raise questions about whether Republicans are risking the fiscal stability they helped bring about.
One small group of Senators and Congressmen blasted their party at a news conference recently for missing an opportunity to push for further tax cutting. Senator John Ashcroft, a Missouri Republican, called for $600 billion to $1 trillion in tax cuts. Mr. McIntosh, who was at Mr. Ashcroft's side to complain of "the incredible shrinking leadership" in the party, said, "Our goal is to send a clear message to the leadership: We want tax cuts now."
Perhaps the most ambitious Republican idea on the horizon is radical revision of the tax code. Party leaders have been rousing their core voters and attempting to stir up new anti-Government fervor by touring the country debating the merits of a flat tax or a national sales tax.
Yet while the issue gives the party an election-year rallying cry, House and Senate leaders do not plan to take up any overhaul measures this year. Instead they plan a vote on legislation to have the tax code expire by Dec. 31, 2001, and trap the Democrats into defending the code.
As frustrating as the inactivity is for House conservatives, it is worse for Democrats, who are trying to win back control of the House, and need a net gain of 11 seats to do it. Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, has denounced "a do-nothing Congress" and a Republican Party "frozen in the ice of their special interests."
But that line of argument only goes so far as a campaign theme. As a minority party, the Democrats do not expect to pass much legislation this year. But they do need opportunities to win the war for public opinion. And it is harder to showcase their differences with the Republicans if debates showing the contrast between the two parties on issues like the tobacco settlement, or restraints on heath maintenance organizations or expansion of Medicare never take place on the House floor.
