HEADLINE: Man With Past Speculates on Future;
Without Renters in Place, Macklowe Plans a Manhattan Office Tower

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Two weeks after wrestling away a property on Madison Avenue near 42d Street from a pack of rival developers, Harry Macklowe was on his knees, poring over sketches for a new skyscraper.
He was thinking big. It would have a million square feet of space, he said last week as he unfurled maps and drawings in his office on 57th Street. It would cost $400 million. It would have a landscaped garden on the 10th floor. With an eye toward the newly electrified street life in Times Square, Mr. Macklowe said he would put the elevators behind glass walls, so that their up and down dance could be seen from the street. 
 Mr. Macklowe, the developer whom tenant activists love to hate, is back. His company, which became infamous in 1985 for tearing down two single-room-occupancy hotels in the middle of the night, had financial troubles in 1994 that forced him to shed his namesake hotel. Last summer, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and others criticized him for evicting tenants on the Upper East Side. And just a few months ago, one of his recent purchases rained bricks on Madison Avenue, forcing the street to be closed.
But now, he is building a 300-unit apartment house at Eighth Avenue and 50th Street and demolishing buildings at 53d Street and Second Avenue to make way for another apartment building. And he has hired Lehman Brothers to advise him on a possible initial public offering this summer for his company, which owns $1.5 billion worth of Manhattan properties.
Sure, a downturn in the economy could suck all the air out of the current real estate boom. But Mr. Macklowe is planning to build a new skyscraper at Madison and 42d Street that could put him back in the pantheon of New York developers. Still, it is risky because it would be the first speculative office building of the 1990's: built before anyone has expressed interest in renting there.
"It's the pre-eminent development site in the city," Mr. Macklowe said with a soft purr that belied his reputation as a fierce negotiator. "We feel a speculative building will meet with great success. We want to move forward because the market is now."
Mr. Macklowe also wants in on other deals. "He's been the high bid on more than six different transactions at the same time," said Peter Hauspurg, the chairman of Eastern Consolidated Properties. "He will take some big risks, and he goes after things in an aggressive, creative manner."
It adds up. Mr. Macklowe, 60, threw a party last night for 80 brokers, investment bankers and lawyers at Sammy's Romanian Steak House, a restaurant on the Lower East Side known for Jewish soul food and bad music, to celebrate the completion of $500 million in acquisitions and mortgage refinancings.
Half a billion dollars is not half bad for a son of a garment executive from Westchester. Mr. Macklowe dropped out of the University of Alabama, New York University and the School of Visual Arts before throwing himself into business in the 1960's.
He moved quickly from broker to builder, developing a keen interest in architecture and modern art that is reflected in his sleek modernistic buildings like Metropolitan Tower and his starkly white minimalist offices.
Mr. Macklowe's friends say his fiercely combative and obsessive nature plays out in both business and in sports. He took up golf and was on the links every day until he dropped it in favor of tennis. Now his vacation plans are stitched around tennis courts. But his personality is best expressed in sailing, they say. He owns a sleek, 70-foot custom racing sloop called the Unfurled.
And he wants to race. "It's typical of Harry, because he's so competitive," said Morton J. Schrader, a real estate broker and fellow sailor who has known Mr. Macklowe for longer than 30 years. "If he's sailing in the bay, he's looking for someone to face off with. He's always in the hunt."
His killer instinct was in evidence most recently in his pursuit of the Madison Avenue site. Last July, when he learned that Vornado Realty Trust was interested in the site, Mr. Macklowe quickly bought the mortgage after an all-night bargaining session. Then in February, he outmaneuvered both developer George Klein and the Amrock investment fund in bankruptcy court and took control of the properties.
In his own backyard, he has been in a three-year border war with Martha Stewart, the matriarch of style, whose waterfront mansion sits across from his on Georgica Pond in East Hampton. The two have spent tens of thousands of dollars in legal fees squabbling over the shrubs and bushes that separate their properties.
And when Mr. Macklowe began clearing a building site at Second Avenue and 53d Street last summer, people began to reopen old wounds. Mr. Giuliani accused Mr. Macklowe of taking unfair advantage of a change in the state's new rent laws that allowed him to evict 13 rent-controlled tenants, including an 82-year-old blind man who said his removal would be the equivalent of a death sentence.
"If you can think of anyone with a bad history of abusing his position as a landlord and a developer, it's Harry Macklowe," Mr. Giuliani said last June.
Even today Mr. Macklowe bristles at what he describes as the Mayor's politically irresponsible attack. He said he was merely the "windfall beneficiary" of a change in the rent laws. He will build around the few tenants who remain, though he said he expects the tenants "will shake us down for a considerable amount of money" and agree to leave.
More exasperating for Mr. Macklowe was the fact that the Mayor's attack prompted another round of articles about his association with the illegal, midnight demolition of two single-room-occupancy hotels on 44th Street in Times Square in 1985. His clashes with tenants and others had not been unusual compared with those of Donald Trump, Peter Kalikow and Leona Helmsley. But with the demolition, Mr. Macklowe came to epitomize the rapacious developer in the minds of many New Yorkers.
Without turning off the gas or electricity or obtaining permits, a contractor ripped down the two S.R.O.'s owned by Mr. Macklowe only days before a city moratorium would have blocked it. Mr. Macklowe was not indicted in the incident, but one of his executives pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges. The developer did pay the city $2 million to settle a civil suit and seethed as Mayor Edward I. Koch returned his $10,000 campaign contribution. Years later, Mr. Macklowe built the Hotel Macklowe on the site of the old hotels.
"I've done everything right except the hotel, and even then I didn't do anything wrong," he said. "The people who were indicted and convicted were at fault. It happened on my watch so I have to accept responsibility, but I personally was judged to have clean hands."
Stephen B. Siegel, the president of the Insignia/ESG Company, says that his friend is "shrewd and aggressive, absolutely, but I wouldn't characterize him as ruthless."
Mr. Macklowe is intimately involved in every detail of his projects, from the choice of china at the hotel to the art in the lobbies.
"Harry has been intimately involved in everything we've done," said T. J. Gottesdiener, the managing partner of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill who is designing the building at Madison and 42d Street. "He's very interested in the art of architecture, in the concept behind the design. The project is in its infancy, but I'm sure he will drive us crazy."
In the 1980's, Mr. Macklowe put up a quick succession of buildings, from Grand Central Tower to residential buildings like Rivertower, where he and his wife Linda have a duplex.
Mr. Macklowe was still buying properties in 1992 when Larry Silverstein, David Solomon and other developers ran into financial trouble. But two years later, Mr. Macklowe squared off with his lenders when he fell into default over $100 million in loans. He was pushed to sell several properties, including one of his most prized, the hotel. Hotel Macklowe became the Millennium Broadway.
"He loved that hotel," said Mr. Schrader, a fellow sailor and a friend of Mr. Macklowe's for 25 years. "He put his heart and soul into it. He never really looked me in the eye and said, 'I lost it.' He gets very attached about anything he puts his hand to."
It was not until 1996, when the New York real estate market began heating up, that Mr. Macklowe found new financial partners and resurfaced. He converted a loft building on Seventh Avenue into a luxury apartment house called Chelsea Atelier. He bought a tired-looking office building at 540 Madison in 1996 for $35 million, a price that even his banker thought was too high. Mr. Macklowe quickly renovated the building, installing more windows in the offices and expanding the retail space on a valuable stretch of Madison Avenue.
It looked like a huge success story until Dec. 7, when a section of the brick facade on the south side of the building crashed to the street, closing traffic on Madison Avenue for weeks. The city's building officials blamed the accident on shoddy workmanship when it was built in 1970.
Mr. Macklowe ruefully acknowledges that "trouble has a way of finding me." Though the repairs are costing about $5 million, he has been able to sign a new retail tenant for a remarkable $250 a square foot.
"We have made money with him," said William Adamski, co-director of the real estate group at Credit Suisse First Boston, which has backed many of Mr. Macklowe's deals in recent years. "This has been an extremely profitable relationship."

HEADLINE: At Pivotal Time, Suharto Gets a 7th Term

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Wednesday, March 11

 BODY:
With shouts of "Agree! Agree!" electoral delegates leapt from their seats on Tuesday and acclaimed President Suharto as their leader for a seventh term, after 32 years of near-absolute power here in the world's fourth-most-populous nation.
This morning, the President took his oath of office, calling on Indonesians to pull together in this time of hardship. 
 "We will never enjoy again an economic growth such as we have experienced for more than the past quarter of a century," Mr. Suharto said in a speech immediately after reciting the oath.
"As an individual, as a group, some of us may lead an affluent life," he added. "But as a nation, we can no longer afford to lead an extravagant life."
His carefully scripted re-election was unanimous, without even a murmur of dissent in the 1,000-member People's Consultative Assembly. But it comes at Mr. Suharto's moment of greatest crisis as the dramatic economic accomplishments of his presidency slip away under the pressure of Asia's economic slump.
Since the crisis hit hard in January, Mr. Suharto, 76, has produced an impressive display of political control, cowing his critics into silence, choking off demonstrations and cementing the backing of the powerful military and of all three officially sanctioned parties.
But he has failed to come to grips with the economic crisis and is now locked in a confrontation with the International Monetary Fund, which is demanding that he dismantle Indonesia's system of monopolies and favoritism in return for a $40 billion rescue package.
Though Thailand and South Korea have embraced the I.M.F. formula in return for billions of dollars in assistance, the fund's director general, Michel Camdessus, said on Monday, "We are not there yet by far in Indonesia."
Torn between a desire to force President Suharto to stick to its plan and fear of political instability and human suffering if it cuts off financial assistance, the I.M.F. expressed a willingness to be flexible, up to a point.
Last week the I.M.F. announced that it was delaying its second $3 billion disbursement of funds because of the slow pace of reforms, and Indonesian officials reacted with pugnacious nationalism.
Much to the annoyance of the United States and the I.M.F., President Suharto is continuing to float the idea of instituting what is known as a currency board, which would artificially raise the value of the Indonesian rupiah, a move that the I.M.F. has opposed. This possibility has slowed the deterioration in the value of the rupiah against the dollar.
In Washington, Stanley Fischer, the I.M.F.'s first deputy managing director, said at a news conference on Tuesday that the organization always looks at changing circumstances in deciding whether its programs need to be modified, and would probably do so in Indonesia.
In particular, Mr. Fischer said, the fund was "deeply mindful" of the "potentially tragic consequences of events now taking place in Indonesia" and would change its program if people were in danger of going hungry. But Mr. Fischer gave no indication that the fund was prepared to change its basic approach. And he said Indonesia needed to take tough action before he could realistically consider linking its currency to the dollar.
One of the President's sons, Bambang Trihatmodjo, asserted on Tuesday that Indonesia would go it alone rather than submit to foreign dictate. "If necessary, we can rebuild from ground zero," he said. The statement captured the grim mood on what should have been a day of triumph for Asia's longest-serving leader.
The President enters his new term facing a bleak economy not unlike the one he inherited in 1965 from his predecessor, Sukarno, with both inflation and unemployment soaring and with growing fears of food shortages and social unrest.
Mr. Suharto, then a little-known general, came to power after suppressing a coup attempt, apparently by Communists, which was followed by massacres that took as many as 500,000 lives.
The son of poor farmers, he provided schools, health care, roads and electricity to even the most remote areas of the archipelago. In addition, he secured decades of stability through a system of top-down military control and tight limits on press freedom and political activity.
But Indonesia's steady economic growth of 7 percent a year has collapsed into expectations of a deep recession. Mr. Suharto's associates say he is determined to conquer this final, greatest challenge of his presidency.
"He told us that he was already older than the Prophet Mohammed," a member of the electoral assembly said, "but that with a fighting spirit and adherence to the Indonesian soldiers' oath he was prepared to devote his soul, not to mention his possessions, to the country."
Mr. Suharto's possessions are an issue for his critics, who say the fortune amassed by the President and his six children amounts to $30 billion. One analysis of his reluctance to work with the I.M.F. is that he is seeking to protect this wealth.
Despite Mr. Suharto's uncontested re-election, there is a spreading sense among the middle class that the time has come for a change. "In our hearts, we know Suharto has to be replaced," Abdurrahman Wahid, the country's most influential Muslim leader, said in January. "But the problem is, there is a difference between our idealism and the reality of the situation."

HEADLINE: It's a Control Thing: Vermont vs. Cell Phone Towers

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: HARDWICK, Vt., March 9

 BODY:
As new towers for cellular phone traffic have cropped up by the thousands from coast to coast, so have the spats, the lawsuits and the local rebellions, from California to New Jersey to Florida.
But Vermont, with its sylvan sensibilities, is mounting an anti-tower offensive unlike any other these days, making itself the new national focal point for what until now has been a scattered guerrilla war. 
 "I don't want Vermont turned into a giant pincushion with 200-foot towers sticking out of every mountain and valley," declared the state's Democratic United States Senator, Patrick J. Leahy. "We're not asking that Vermont be left out of the telecommunications age. But we Vermonters want to be able to determine where the towers are located."
So hot is the tower issue in Vermont that Mr. Leahy and two Congressional colleagues, Senator James M. Jeffords, a Republican, and Representative Bernard Sanders, an independent, held a meeting today to discuss it in this North Country hamlet, where a 150-foot tower is planned for the top of Buffalo Mountain. Their special guest was William Kennard, the new chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, who traveled the state's muddy roads to hear Vermonters' concerns.
What Mr. Kennard heard was plaints that cell-phone towers ruin the scenery and reduce property values -- mixed with expressions of appreciation for the brave new wireless world.
That compote was the kind of jumble of opinions that has troubled hundreds of American towns like Hardwick in recent months as they contemplated their part in the construction of more than 100,000 antenna sites by 2005, more than a tenth of them requiring towers.
"It's a stark clash that is upon us," Mr. Kennard told the 200 or so Vermonters gathered in a high school auditorium.
The essence of the issue is that age-old political flash point, local control.
Congress decreed in 1996 that it was in the national interest to create a "seamless network" of cellular communications across the country, and few people in this nation of about 56 million cell phone users would object to that concept.
To make sure that this seamless network was created, Congress also decreed in effect that though local governments could exercise their usual zoning powers in deciding where towers went and how tall they were, they could not simply say no to cellular phone companies that wanted to put towers in their cities or towns. If localities resisted unreasonably, the Federal Telecommunications Act of 1996 said, the Federal Government could override them.
Around the country, scores of local groups have banded together to fight particular towers planned for particular spots. As tracked on a Cellular Tower Coalition Web site, they range from residents in North Barrington, Ill., trying to stop a 200-foot tower on their village hall to a Boca Raton, Fla., group fighting towers on school property. More than 600 towns have put moratoriums on new tower sitings at some point, cellular industry groups say, and some of the bans have lasted as long as two years.
But Vermont, its officials say, is leading the charge in the national political arena for local control over tower decisions.
Mr. Leahy, Mr. Jeffords and Mr. Sanders have combined forces to push bills in Congress that would restore full local control over tower-siting decisions. All three are vehement in their assertions that Vermont, with its love for its green hills and its New Englandy independent spirit, should be sovereign over its towers. And they have many allies in the populace.
"None of us are anti-technology," said Holly Fournier, an investment adviser who has been fighting for years to have a tower taken down in her Vermont town of Charlotte. "We just want to make sure the towers are appropriately sited."
But even in Vermont, the Hardwick discussion showed, opinions are deeply split. Most everybody likes the convenience and life-saving potential of cell phones. But they do not trust cellular phone giants backed by Federal clout.
"The natural landscapes of Vermont are our greatest economic resource," said Janet Newton, a resident of the Thistle Hill area of Cabot, which has been fighting a proposed cell tower. "We Vermonters claim the right to make land-use and quality of life decisions at the state and local level."
One resident said a study had shown that property values would drop 25 percent near a cell tower; several others commented that the long-term health effects of living near microwave-emitting towers were not yet known.
On the other side were residents who wanted to be able to dial 911 from anywhere, and those like Deb Moore, an emergency room nurse, who described how important it was to be able to sustain contact between an ambulance crew and the hospital preparing to treat its patient.
It is a problem in Vermont, "as wonderfully rural as it is, to hit a dead zone," Ms. Moore said. "We need to look at other issues for Vermont besides aesthetics and your property values."
Debate over tower siting has been heating up in recent months in part as a result of the 1996 Federal Telecommunications Act, which fostered telephone-industry competition and allowed many new players into the cellular phone market -- players who need towers. The rash of antenna building also stems from the swelling pool of cellular phone users, and from the advent of technology known as P.C.S., or personal communications systems. P.C.S. systems use digital transmissions rather than analog ones and need more antennas because their range is shorter.
Over all, said Tim Ayers, vice president for communications of the Cellular Telecommunications Industry Association, the largest association representing the wireless industry, it will take up to 125,000 antennas to build the cellular system authorized by the F.C.C., and the process will take until perhaps 2005.
The antennas are often easy to install in cities, where they can be stuck on existing tall buildings, steeples and roofs; in largely rural areas like Vermont, towers are often needed.
The cellular companies face pressures of their own, Mr. Ayers pointed out. To keep their licenses, he said, they must be able to say they are serving a substantial part of the population. They must also worry about paying off the cost of their licenses, which they got through Government auction.
To Vermonters, however, it can seem as if their towns are being invaded by corporate giants with only a bottom line in mind.
Some towns rush to pass ordinances limiting the towers' height and possible location. Others declare a tower-building moratorium to figure out what to do. But then they run the risk of legal challenges by the impatient cellular phone companies, and it is the law, as well as money, that cellular corporations have on their side. Court cases have generally been decided in favor of the cellular companies because the 1996 law so clearly states that they may not be turned down, Mr. Ayers said.
Ultimately, Mr. Kennard and others say, there will be solutions for all of this.
There are compromises gaining wider practice, from disguising towers as trees or steeples to agreements that allow several phone companies to "co-locate" on one tower, reducing the number of towers needed.
"This is not an intractable problem," Mr. Kennard told the gathered Vermonters, without specifying plans to solve it.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 18, 1998, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption on March 11 about a fight against cellular telephone towers in Vermont referred incompletely to a structure in the town of Charlotte. While the tower now includes a cellular antenna, it was built as a radio tower and also supports a radio antenna and an antenna for the local fire and rescue station. A cellular industry group reported the omission to The Times in March, but its request for a correction went astray through an editing lapse.

HEADLINE: Where Do Computers Go When They Die?;
Into the Attic, Under the Ping-Pong Table -- but Hardly Ever Into the Trash

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
IF Americans treated dead people the way they treat dead computers, their basements and closets would be cluttered with family corpses. Under many a desk, there would be a cadaver crammed into the arch meant for knees. Whole warehouses and offices would function as ad hoc mausoleums.
And only the diligent few, whether out of conscience or lack of space, would dispose of the departed properly. The rest, unable to let go or to find a proper resting place, would offer excuses like, "He cost me so much money in life. I can't accept that he's worthless now!" and, "She was a formative influence in my youth. How can I dump her?" 
 Of course, it makes about as much sense to do nothing with antiquated computers as it did for the eccentric family in John Irving's "Hotel New Hampshire" to stuff their dead little dog and keep him around the house long after his barking and fetching days were past.
Yet researchers believe that roughly 14 million to 20 million computers are retired each year in this country, and of those, a 1995 Tufts University thesis estimated, nearly 75 percent are simply stockpiled, taking their place on obscure shelves, under Ping-Pong tables, in unused offices, in hallways. Only 10 percent to 15 percent of them will be re-used or recycled, studies indicated, and 15 percent end up in landfills.
True, those numbers are changing, say many involved in the burgeoning businesses of giving old computers new life. In the last few years, thousands of computer reselling and recycling outfits have cropped up around the country, a recent Rand Corporation report said.
And the stream those resellers and recyclers depend on -- of functional but dull-edged castoffs -- has swollen as the typical active life span of a new computer in its original work setting has shrunk to as little as two or three years.
The companies that funnel older computers to schools and to the technologically needy have been multiplying and are becoming an increasingly national phenomenon, spurred by new tax incentives and the sheer volume of discards.
Whole directories on the Internet list groups that take old computers. One of the largest such funnelers, the Detwiler Foundation, based in San Diego, has already placed 37,000 computers in California schools and is branching out into at least nine other states. The Federal Government is running a program, Computers for Learning, to place hundreds of thousands of old Government computers in schools.
"When you're flushing a million computers out every year, they disappear like ink into blotting paper," said Clive Smith, chief executive officer of New Deal, a Cambridge, Mass., company specializing in software that lets older computers act like newer ones. "When you're flushing 10 million a year, the market mechanisms have to emerge to deal with it."
And emerging they are. But the juiciest mystery inherent in "closetware," as some call the squirreled-away old computers, is why it has taken so long, and why, even now, so few older computers are promptly resold or donated.
Certainly, those in the business say, owners' emotional attachment to old computers plays a role. At the East West Education Development Foundation, a Boston nonprofit company that refurbishes and supplies old computers to good causes, the president, Stephen Farrell, said that for donors who bring in their obsolete machines, "it's like bringing your dog to be euthanized -- it's really hard to part with."
Brigitte Jordan, a corporate anthropologist and principal scientist at Xerox's research center in Palo Alto, Calif., speculated that owners' attachments to their computers went beyond even the powerful attachments they can form to their cars, in part because computers are so much more interactive and in part because the machines can become repositories of parts of their owners' lives.
Of her own first computer, Ms. Jordan said: "It had not only my work on it but my poems and stories on it. It had on it a sort of snapshot of my life at that time, and when I got a new machine, not all of that got transferred. Somehow, in the transition from one machine to another, some piece of my life got lost. It's like losing a photo album."
Personal attachments to personal computers are one thing; professional ones are another. Love of machine can be so great that operators of early computers, like the room-size Univac, have been known to take them home when they were decommissioned, said Oliver Strimpel, director of the Computer Museum in Boston.
At the museum's Silicon Valley historical collection in Mountain View, Calif., he said, "I've seen people hugging disk drives and computers like long-lost friends they've spent big parts of their lives with."
Also seemingly at work in owners' clinging to their computers is a certain inability to accept the harsh economic reality of computer depreciation -- the fact that a machine that cost $3,000 just four years ago is now worth less than $100.
In 1991, H. Scott Matthews, then an undergraduate student at Carnegie Mellon University, helped produce a study that predicted that by 2005, 150 million computers would be cluttering the country's landfills. Last year, Mr. Matthews returned to the much-quoted study, re-evaluated its predictions based on updated figures and lowered that projection, to 55 million.
He and his co-authors cited the "second life" given computers by newly established markets for recycled electronic goods as a central reason for the revised estimate. But the biggest reason for the change, he said, was something else: "I think the fundamental behavioral issue we did not consider in the first paper, that we do now, is that people don't want to throw away anything that they think has value. If you have something you paid a couple of thousand of dollars for, you're going to have a hard time throwing it away, even if you don't use it anymore."
Especially if it still works fine. But aren't Americans supposed to be experts at throwing things away?
"This is the opposite of the disposable society," said Mr. Matthews, now a doctoral candidate in economics at Carnegie Mellon's Green Design Initiative. "This is the attic society."
Robert Dangelmeyer, a service manager for the Digital Equipment Corporation, said that according to four computer-price databases he had examined, computers tended to lose 80 percent of their market value in the first year after purchase. Then their worth levels out for a year or so, he said, before plunging practically to zero.
That hurts both individuals and institutions or businesses. In 1993, said Kenneth D. Campbell, a spokesman for the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the university bought a supercomputer for its Laboratory for Computer Science that at that point was the 17th-most-powerful computer in the world. It cost $3.8 million.
When the computer, the CM5, was shut down four years later, still the 497th-most-powerful computer in the world, he said, the best offer the university could get for it was $750. It decided to donate it to the Computer Museum instead.
Museums and collectors, however, generally seek only rare and historically valuable computers. Dr. Strimpel, of the Computer Museum, said that any machine produced before 1960 was generally worth preserving; some from the 1960's, like the I.B.M. System 360 series, are and some aren't. From TRS-80's on up, there is usually little collecting interest in garden-variety computers.
That means most of the tens of millions of computers in America that have been retired from their primary functions have no obvious monetary value.
Some creative types come up with novel uses for their old machines. Clifford Stoll, a notoriously skeptical computer commentator, turned his Mac Plus into a Macquarium, using plans posted on the Internet, and used a gutted 286 computer as a cat litter box for a couple of years.
"It was flat, squat, pancake-shaped -- it worked well," Mr. Stoll said. "But it got too stinky after a while, and it was cheaper to toss it out than clean it. A 286 computer costs about the same as a kitty-litter box anyway -- about $5. My cats liked it, though."
Whimsy aside, there do seem to be sensible answers to the riddle of what to do with an obsolete computer, economists and computer professionals say.
One answer for individual users decommissioning computers -- and for businesses -- is that whatever owners do, they should do quickly, said Mr. Dangelmeyer, of Digital, who has often encountered hallways full of computers at companies he has serviced.
"My perspective is, if it's in the hallway, you've already made a mistake," he said. "If it's in the hallway, now what do you do? People are ripping off memory boards, saying, this is junk, and I need an extra keyboard or a new mouse -- so all of a sudden, it's not a working system anymore; it's been cannibalized.
"So now you need labor at between $40 and $230 an hour for a skilled technician just to get them back in working order, and they're only worth $100 -- so you turned something worth something into a liability," he said. And there is the issue of further potential liability from sending a lot of computers, including lead-containing monitors, to the dump.
Rather, Mr. Dangelmeyer recommended, computer buyers should pack up their old computers in the boxes that come from the new ones and have a technician certify that they are in good working order. Then they can either be sold to used-computer dealers or recyclers or given to an organization like East West.
Only a handful of areas around the country -- including Somerville, Mass., and Hennepin County, Minn., home to Minneapolis -- have special recycling programs for computers, said Dawn Amore, senior program leader at the National Safety Council's Environmental Health Center, which has a program to foster computer re-use and recycling. But more are exploring the idea, she said, and computer manufacturers, too, are exploring ways to design computers so they are easier to re-use and recycle. Many also accept their old computers back from buyers for recycling, notably I.B.M., which also has a program in environmentally friendly design.
But economically,recycling is still of limited appeal.
"There's no economic incentive to empty out the closet," said Joe Pucciarelli, research director for the Gartner Group. "Computers sell for 3 1/2 cents a pound for mixed electronics, and it costs more money to drive it to the recycler than it's worth."
Indeed, at the Electronic Product Recovery and Recycling Conference last year, run by the National Safety Council, participants noted that a typical 386-based computer had a resale value of $10 to $20, a component value of $5 and a zero net value for plastics and glass.
But there can still be life in them there silicon-based bones, and good-deed points for those who pass them on.
Mr. Smith, of New Deal, offered this simple arithmetic: There are fewer than 7 million computers in American schools for a total of 51 million students. Analysts say there are 33 million older 286 and 386 computers around, not to mention millions of 486's that many people are now discarding in favor of Pentium machines.
If most people donated their older computers -- and schools could be convinced that with souped-up, point-and-click software, they were more than adequate for teaching computer literacy, Internet browsing and school subjects -- the United States could approach a one-to-one student-computer ratio much faster, he said.
"And there are 14 million kids in 8 million households below the poverty line," Mr. Smith said. "Do you think they're going to get a trickle-down Pentium any time soon?"
 
If You Can Bring Yourself to Part With It...
 
Giving It Away
 If you have decided to donate your old computer, here are some pointers:
Some schools and organizations will not accept anything older than a 486-based machine, but many will.
 The sooner you donate it, the more value it will hold for the recipient -- and, though admittedly piddling in any case, the greater your tax write-off.
The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 took effect in January and gives special tax breaks to companies that donate personal computers less than two years old to schools. For all tax implications, check with your accountant.
These Web site lists groups by state that arrange computer donations to schools and nonprofit organizations:
www.microweb.com/pepsite/Recycle/
recycleindex.html and www.learner.org/ sami/computer-recycle.shtml
On paper, the Institute for Local Self-Reliance in Washington, (202) 232-4108, or in Minneapolis, (612) 379-3815, has a far-reaching list of recyclers and re-users in the back of its 1997 report, "Plug Into Electronics Re-use," by Brenda Platt and Jennifer Hyde.
Also possibly helpful:
The participant list from the first Electronic Product Recovery and Recycling Conference:
www.nsc.org/ehc/epr2/epr2part.htm
The Federal Government's Computers for Learning Home Page:
www.computers.fed.gov
Many Goodwill stores will take computer donations, officials say.
 
Selling It
You'd rather sell it? You may be shocked at how little it will pay you to do so. If you want to do it, here are some tips:
On-line auction houses like ebay.com and www.onsale.com allow you to solicit bids on items like hardware and software.
Exchanges ease the match between buyer and seller. The seller ships the computer to the exchange, the exchange makes sure it works, and the buyer sends in the money:
The Online Exchange (the United Computer Exchange): www.uce.com/exchange
Advantage Computer Exchange: www.computerpricing.com/selling.html
American Computer Exchange (publishes the AmCoEx Index of Used Computer Prices): www.amcoex.com
Yahoo's Internet Directory has a large collection of places that will buy used computers or help you find a buyer:
www.yahoo.com/businessand
economy/companies/computers/retailers/ used/index.html
The Used Computer Mall offers free on-line classifieds and other features:
www.usedcomputer.com
Affiliated Remarketing Web Inc. tracks down refurbished computer products from 185 dealers. Type in the equipment you want, and it gives a list of dealers who have it: www.remarketing.com
Of course, plenty of local stores buy used computers, and there are no shipping charges. Computer Renaissance is a chain of 187 stores in 44 states: www.cr1.com
Leasing a computer works for some people. A lease means you don't have to worry about getting rid of it when you're done: Just turn it in.
 
Wipe It Before You Dump It
If you are worried about leaving privateinformation on a computer, don't forget: reformatting the hard drive won't erase all the data. People who want to insure that there's absolutely nothing left should try a disk utility program designed to wipe clean the disk, programs available for sale or as free software or "shareware" on the web.

Chart: "10 Uses for a Dead Computer"
 
1. Fish tank. But it's a lot of work to make it waterproof.
2. Litter box. If your kitty isn't too picky.
3. Decoration. Chips and circuit boards can be made into earrings and clipboards.
4. Gold mine. Many 60's units used a fair amount of gold.
5. Furniture. Use it as doorstop or high-tech hassock.
6. Reincarnation. Use it to play old games or upgrade it to use as a backup device or personal Web server.
7. Planet saver. Recycle it and feel noble.
8. Source of cash. But not much. Sell it to a secondhand-computer shop.
9. Gift. If it's still breathing, donate it to a good cause or give it to a friend or relative.
10. Boat anchor.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Amex and Nasdaq Reported To Be Discussing Merger
The American Stock Exchange and the National Association of Securities Dealers are discussing a combination that would give them enough heft to seriously challenge the giant New York Stock Exchange, according to several people close to the talks.
Details about the planned combination are sketchy, in part because they are still being worked out, and exchange members had not been fully informed last night. Page A1. 

Japan's Central Bank Raided
Prosecutors raided Japan's central bank and arrested Yasuyuki Yoshizawa, who runs its capital markets division. He was suspected of leaking secrets to Japanese banks. Within hours the governor of the Bank of Japan, Yasuo Matsushita, left, offered to resign. Credibility is critical to the central bank's monetary effectiveness. A1.
 
Judge Opposes Agreement
An administrative law judge in Manhattan said that an agreement between officials of the New York Mercantile Exchange and a Manhattan lawyer who was suing the exchange was "certainly unethical" and violated Federal regulations. D4.
 
Investors Continue a Buying Spree
Stock investors, apparently having overcome their anxiety about Asia and corporate earnings, went on another buying spree, sending the indexes farther into record territory. The Dow industrials rose 32.63 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, to 8,675.75. That put the average up 9.8 percent for the year -- surpassing the 6 to 8 percent rise analysts had foreseen for the entire year. D7.
 
The World Bank priced its largest dollar-denominated global bond issue ever, $4 billion, and it was oversubscribed. It was priced to yield 5.703 percent for a bond due 2003. D7.
 
Europeans Irked Over Air Deals
The European Commission, seeking to negotiate as a bloc, warned eight European Union member countries that have open skies aviation deals with the United States that it would go to court against them if they did not shift within two months. D3.
 
Commercial aviation grew strongly last year, the F.A.A. said. Carriers had operating profits of $7.9 billion, up from $4.3 billion in 1996. It sees more growth this year. D4.
 
Who Invented the V-Chip?
The F.C.C. will formally approve the much-debated television rating codes today, and will issue technical standards for the microchip inside new television sets, known as a V-chip, that will let parents block programs with violence, sex or vulgar language from screens. Three competitors claim to have invented the chip. If one prevails it could mean millions of dollars in licensing fees, but it may be too late. D2.
 
Apple Hires Compaq Executive
Apple Computer named Timothy D. Cook, Compaq's No. 2 manufacturing executive, as its senior vice president for worldwide manufacturing operations. D4.
 
I.M.F. Financing at Issue
House Republican leaders threatened to hold hostage $18 billion for the I.M.F. and nearly $1 billion in back dues the United States owes the United Nations unless the White House agreed to an anti-abortion provision. The White House suggested that Mr. Clinton would not buckle to the demands. A10.
 
Suharto Calls for Belt-Tightening
President Suharto, taking his oath of office for a seventh five-year term, called on Indonesians to tighten their belts in response to the economic shock that has made almost all of Indonesia's 200 million people suddenly poorer. A8.

HEADLINE: Installation of E-Z Pass System on Turnpike and Parkway Is Expected to Take 2 Years

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 11

 BODY:
State transportation officials said today that the E-Z Pass toll system would be in operation on the Garden State Parkway and the New Jersey Turnpike in about two years. They said they would finance the system by fining motorists who speed through the tolls without paying.
The officials detailed their plan as they announced a $488 million, 10-year contract to install and operate the electronic toll collection system that will let motorists glide through the toll lanes on both highways and the Atlantic City Expressway. 
 The new E-Z Pass system in New Jersey will cost eight times more than the system now operating on New York City's bridges and tunnels. State officials said they would cover much of the cost by imposing $25 fines on motorists who try to cruise through E-Z Pass lanes without paying.
State officials said that cameras, set up at toll lanes, would photograph license plates of toll violators.
Some lawmakers say that transportation officials have set unrealistic goals for the amount of fines that are expected to be collected each year.
But Edward Gross, executive director of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority, said the revenue estimates were "conservative." He also said that almost all of the revenue would be new because few fines were collected from scofflaws on toll roads now. He conceded, however, that if the fines did not meet the projections at the end of 10 years, toll revenues would have to cover the cost.
The installation of the E-Z Pass system on New Jersey toll roads will complete one of the last links in an automated toll collection system that will eventually stretch from Washington to Buffalo. Instead of handing over tokens or change, motorists will be able to pay their tolls in advance. They will be able to pass through toll lanes without stopping because an electronic tag posted on their windshield or car door will deduct their toll charges from their prepaid account.
E-Z Pass is already up and running on the Hudson River crossings as well as on New York City's bridges and tunnels and the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway. After some initial glitches, the system has proved popular with commuters. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which has installed the system on seven bridges and two tunnels, has far exceeded its sales projections, officials said.
New Jersey lawmakers gave final approval last year to set up an automatic toll collection system. But there were delays in awarding the lucrative contract because one of the losing bidders, Lockheed Martin IMS, had filed a lawsuit.
Lockheed officials unsuccessfully argued in court that the bidding process should be reopened because the former state transportation commissioner had talked about his own job prospects with two companies that stood to benefit from the deal.
State transportation officials awarded the $488 million contract to MFS Network Technologies of Omaha, Neb., to install and operate the system over the next 10 years on 700 toll lanes.
Although it will take as long as two years to open E-Z Pass toll lanes on the Garden State Parkway and the New Jersey Turnpike, state transportation officials said that they expected the new technology would be available on the Atlantic City Expressway within a year. Under the contract, MFS Network will also install a fiber-optic cable network along more than 400 miles of roadways owned by the state's various transportation authorities.
New Jersey transportation officials said that $450 million of the cost of the project would come from toll violators. They estimated that they would generate another $118.5 million from telecommunications companies seeking to lease access to new fiber-optic cables over the next 10 years.
In New York, transportation officials have paid for the installation and operation of the E-Z Pass system with toll revenues.
New Jersey's Transportation Commissioner, John J. Haley Jr., billed the new electronic toll system as a major "customer service initiative."
"Because transportation is New Jersey's lifeblood, E-Z Pass will help insure that our toll roads and bridges are not an impediment to a strong and vibrant economy," Mr. Haley said. "It will improve the movement of goods, reduce congestion and pollution at the toll plazas and provide a level of convenience and efficiency that drivers demand and deserve."
But when asked whether a more appealing "customer service initiative" for motorists would be to remove tolls on some roadways, like the Garden State Parkway, Mr. Haley laughed. He said that the new electronic toll system would allow the state to examine toll prices more closely and make "unified toll decisions." Now, decisions about toll increases are made by the individual state authorities that oversee the different roadways.
"We ought to begin thinking of some toll relief," Mr. Haley said.
Under the contract, the state and MFS Network would share in revenue generated above the estimated $488 million cost of the project. After the project is paid for with the revenues from the fiber-optic network and toll violators, Mr. Haley said that the state's transportation authorities would keep 85 percent of the revenues, and MFS Network would keep 15 percent.
Once the E-Z Pass system is installed, he said, New Jersey motorists will be able to use their prepaid toll accounts at the Hudson River crossings, operated by the Port Authority, and on bridges and tunnels in New York City and throughout the region.

HEADLINE: CLINTON MOVES UP HIS TRIP TO CHINA TO LATE IN JUNE

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET with SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
Eager to prevent any deterioration of relations between the United States and China over human rights and other issues, the Clinton Administration has decided to move up this year's Presidential trip to Beijing to late June, from November, senior Administration officials said today.
Chinese officials, who are anxious to showcase the first visit of an American President to China since the massacre of unarmed civilians near Tiananmen Square in 1989, leapt at the Administration's proposal for an earlier meeting, said Administration officials here and in Beijing. 
 "It is pretty much a done deal," one senior Administration official said today.
The rescheduled trip is likely to follow on the heels of the Paula Jones sexual misconduct trial against the President, which is to start on May 27 in Little Rock. Indeed, the trial will now be bracketed by high-profile foreign trips, since Mr. Clinton is scheduled to return from a visit to Europe on May 19.
Mr. Clinton does not have to appear at the trial, and will not attend as an observer. But some of his advisers want to hold open the option for him to appear to testify in his own defense, if necessary.
Administration officials have been at pains to deny that the charges against Mr. Clinton have had any impact on how he governs and today said that the Jones trial had nothing to do with rescheduling the China trip. But planners have left Mr. Clinton enough time in June to go to Little Rock if he chooses to. Aides to Mr. Clinton predicted that the trial will be over before he leaves for China.
Because appearances with foreign leaders provide a great opportunity for Presidents to appear Presidential, Mr. Clinton may reap political benefits from the trip. In conducting a summit meeting with leaders of the world's most populous nation immediately after the Paula Jones trial, Mr. Clinton will be able to demonstrate that he is absorbed in his official duties, which has been the White House strategy for deflecting charges about his personal life.
Senior officials offered slightly varying reasons today for rescheduling the 10-day China trip, now set for the last week of June and the first week of July. One official said that the White House was eager to build on progress made during the visit by President Jiang Zemin of China to the United States last October.
"There's tremendous positive feeling over there about the relationship," this official said.
But another senior official said that the President's advisers were concerned that relations with China had deteriorated recently. "It feels like some of that momentum has stalled," he said. He cited repeated disagreements in the United Nations Security Council over policy toward Iraq.
Some Administration officials are anticipating further tension with China over the meeting of the United Nations Human Rights Commission in Geneva next week. Applying pressure on the Administration to forcefully criticize Beijing's human rights record, House and Senate committees today approved non-binding resolutions urging the Administration to denounce China's abuses in Geneva. The Administration has not decided what approach to take in Geneva.
Officials here said that the idea to go to China earlier in the year originated with the American Ambassador to Beijing, James Sasser, who broached it with the President's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, during a recent visit here. Mr. Sasser was said to have wanted to hold the summit meeting in April.
But Mr. Clinton had conflicting trips already scheduled for April and May. And he could not go to China in early June, one official said, because there would not be enough recovery time after the European trip. Another official offered an additional reason, saying that the White House did not want Mr. Clinton to appear in China near the June 4 anniversary of the Tiananmen violence.
"It's probably dicey enough that we're in the same month," one official said.
As today's Congressional resolutions indicate, Mr. Clinton is in some ways taking a political risk in going to China. But he has committed his Administration to increasing economic ties with China in hopes of encouraging democracy and political freedom there.
Even before the accusations regarding Monica S. Lewinsky were disclosed in January, Mr. Clinton's aides had planned the busiest year of foreign travel of his Presidency, and they are still adding to it.
Later this month, Mr. Clinton plans a two-week trip to Africa, his first trip there as President. The White House today added Rwanda to his itinerary; he is also to visit Botswana, Ghana, Senegal, South Africa and Uganda.
In April, he is scheduled to spend almost a week in South America. And his aides have been tentatively tacking stops on to the May trip to the economic summit meeting in Birmingham, England. Mr. Clinton is planning to stop first in Berlin, and he may also stop in Moscow and Dublin, aides said.
Later this year, Mr. Clinton plans a visit to India, Pakistan and Bangladesh, and a separate trip to Malaysia. He had originally planned to stop in China as part of the Malaysia trip, but the Administration learned that for the Chinese "connecting this trip with another trip devalued it in their eyes," one official said. By making the China visit a stand-alone trip, the Administration believed it would wring more gains from the talks.
A senior American diplomat in Beijing said: "Since the Jiang visit, everything has gone more smoothly." He said that the Chinese were so eager for Mr. Clinton's visit that they indicated a willingness to alter plans for visits by leaders from other countries to accommodate him.
China's leaders, the diplomat said, are mystified by the crisis surrounding Monica Lewinsky, and are unlikely to understand how it might affect Mr. Clinton's travel plans.
Chinese diplomats clearly hope that a visit by Mr. Clinton will put the memory of Tiananmen Square behind them and cement a more cooperative relationship.
"There is a strong desire on both sides for friendly cooperation, not for confrontation," Yang Jiechi, assistant foreign minister, said in an interview. "Both sides see a common good in a better relationship."

HEADLINE: Saturn Union Votes to Retain Its Cooperative Company Pact

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: SPRING HILL, Tenn., March 11

 BODY:
After weeks of dissension in a workplace known for harmony, two-thirds of the workers at the Saturn car factory here voted down a measure that would have asked the company to jettison their current union contract, corporate America's most prominent continuing experiment in labor-management cooperation.
A General Motors Corporation executive hailed the vote. "The membership has spoken," said Donald W. Hudler, president and chairman of the board of Saturn, which is owned by G.M. 
 Local union officials, who had urged their membership to endorse the contract by voting down the ballot measure, nonetheless criticized G.M.
"You cannot take for granted that this membership will continue with this partnership forever without some visible commitment in return," Michael E. Bennett, chairman of Local 1853 of the United Automobile Workers, said. "It is time for General Motors to explain to all of us whether the Saturn success story and the U.A.W. partnership has any value for General Motors as it moves into the new millennium."
In two days of polling, 4,052 union members voted to keep the current labor agreement, which calls for the company and union members to cooperate in running the Saturn plant and encourages teamwork on the factory floor. In opposition were 2,120 who voted to jettison the unique contract and instead return to the industrywide U.A.W. contract, which would have provided explicit pay guarantees in the event of layoffs.
Job cuts are prohibited at Saturn under the current agreement except under "catastrophic events or severe economic conditions." Plagued by a declining small-car market, Saturn's sales have plummeted, and many workers said that they feared layoffs in the coming months. Last year, Saturn sales fell 9.9 percent and in the first two months of this year, they have fallen 20.2 percent.
Until the small-car slump began two years ago, Saturn, G.M.'s newest brand, had enjoyed a series of successes. Propelled by folksy advertising that showed teams of Saturn workers cheerfully building cars, Saturn attracted what for General Motors was a new breed of buyer -- those accustomed to buying fuel-efficient Japanese cars.
In addition, Saturn broke new ground with its no-haggle sales strategy in car dealerships. Customers loved the low-pressure sales tactics at Saturn, where the price on the window sticker was what buyers actually paid. Current prices range from $10,600 to $14,800 and Saturns can be leased for as little as $129 a month.
While it is unclear how the union contract would have changed had it been rejected in the referendum, both the company and the union said they would have entered into negotiations to resolve the issue.
Workers on both sides said they expected changes at Saturn, including explicit provisions detailing what would happen in the event of layoffs. Many also called for greater worker influence over Saturn's business decisions. Saturn workers have been clamoring for G.M. to expand Saturn's lineup for years to include a midsize car and a sport utility vehicle. The workers were disconcerted when G.M. decided several years ago to build a midsize Saturn in an existing factory in Wilmington, Del., instead of here in Tennessee.
"There's a heck of a fire going down here in Spring Hill," said Thomas W. Hopp, 39, who helped organize a group called Concerned Brothers and Sisters of Local 1853, which forced the referendum. "I believe every single one of our issues will be addressed" in future talks prompted by this week's vote, he said.
"We've won because we got our point across and Saturn will never be the same," Mr. Hopp said.
Mr. Bennett, the local union leader, said it was now up to G.M. to improve the situation at Saturn. "The vote today represents the fact that this local union membership is as dedicated and committed to the original Saturn idea as it was in 1985," he said. "The question, as yet to be answered, is whether or not it's alive and appreciated in Detroit."
Mr. Hudler, the Saturn executive, said General Motors was well aware of the workers' concerns.
"We're going to work very hard to resolve that," Mr. Hudler said. "We need to re-vision where we go from here and we're doing that internally."
Rank-and-file members who voted to keep the current labor contract said they hoped the vote would spark reforms. "It will be a wake-up call for all of us to look at our contract," Lee G. Swegles, 31, said. "I hope it sends a message to G.M. that we need to be unique."
Barbara D. Jennings, 41, who voted to reject the current agreement and return to the traditional contract used by all other G.M. workers, said she was concerned that slow sales would prompt layoffs. "I like Saturn -- I like what it stands for," Ms. Jennings said. "Most of us are just looking for job security."
Saturn is the latest company to see its worker-management cooperation experiment hit turbulence on encountering rough market conditions.
"Many of the most innovative approaches to labor-management relations have hit the rocks when times have turned bad," said Harley S. Shaiken, a professor specializing in labor issues at the University of California at Berkeley. "It is really difficult to talk about cooperation if you're laying people off or if they fear being laid off."
Levi Strauss & Company has for years been a model of cooperation between workers and management. But tensions grew last fall, after it announced it would close 11 factories this year, leaving 6,395 workers jobless. And tensions ran high in the early 1990's when the Xerox Corporation announced huge layoffs despite its attempts at worker empowerment over the last two decades.
"The partnerships are easy when times are good and there's not much controversy," said Bruce S. Raynor, secretary-treasurer of the Union of Needle Trades, Industrial and Textile Employees, which represents workers at both Levi Strauss and Xerox. "Those two are ones I think have weathered the bad times."
Of course most labor-management cooperation pacts were born in bad times -- often when a company faced going out of business or a union faced factory closings. Under such circumstances, companies and workers sometimes have little choice but to agree to the power-sharing arrangements. "You could argue they weren't freely entered into," said Douglas A. Fraser, a labor professor at Wayne State University in Detroit and a former president of the United Automobile Workers union.
The cooperative agreements are particularly fragile. "A lot of times when they break down it's not because of new economic circumstances," Mr. Fraser said. "An individual can make a difference -- a new plant manager, a new local union president."
Despite the volatility of such partnerships, unions expect more in the future. "There are lots of partnerships that haven't survived," said Nancy F. Mills, director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s Center for Workplace Democracy. "The trend is still in the direction of workers taking on more and more responsibility."
"This may be a slip in the road, but I don't think it is a setback to the general trend," she said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Chinese way: spend out of trouble like Keynesians.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
JOHN MAYNARD KEYNES may be out of fashion in the West. But in one of the odder twists to the unfolding Asian crisis, his prophets have resurfaced in Beijing.
To keep the Chinese economy out of recession -- and to prevent the urban proletariat from taking to the barricades -- China's pragmatic Communist leadership is calling for a heady dose of fiscal stimulus that would have made Keynes proud. 
 Acknowledging that fiscal intervention is needed to sustain annual growth of more than 8 percent is one thing; delivering on that promise is quite another for the Chinese Government. For even if the early reports have exaggerated the amount that China will spend on roads, housing and other public works, any significant increase in outlays is bound to complicate its plans to modernize the half-socialist, half-capitalist economy.
"There's just no easy way out of their predicament," said Nicholas Lardy, a specialist in the Chinese economy at the Brookings Institution.
At first glance, the case for spending is strong. China's ability to modernize has been constrained in recent years by electricity and transportation bottlenecks. And the timing is propitious, since spending could offset economic pain. The combination of currency depreciation and falling output in the rest of Asia is widely expected to reduce the demand for Chinese exports by about $20 billion this year. Meanwhile, the continuing effort to trim China's bloated state enterprises is expected to push several million people out of jobs.
Rather than accept a sharp drop in employment and growth, Chinese leaders have said they will increase spending, with $750 billion to $1 trillion devoted to new construction over three years. Even by the widest definition of infrastructure spending, the Government would have to increase outlays by 60 percent to hit the $750 billion mark -- virtually impossible short of a total mobilization of the economy in the manner of Chairman Mao's Great Leap Forward.
But even a 10 to 20 percent increase, as is deemed plausible by Wing Thye Woo, an economist at the University of California at Davis, would conflict with China's other policy goals. The only practical way to increase spending rapidly is to funnel the cash to state enterprises -- many of which are industrial dinosaurs with a long history of wasting resources. "All the politics says the Government will give the money to China's equivalent of the Korean chaebols," Mr. Woo said.
Moreover, new public spending is likely to displace money that would have been used to recapitalize China's insolvent state banks. Bank reform can wait. The banks can easily meet their current obligations to foreigners, and domestic depositors have no place else to go with their money. But the longer the delay, the longer it will take to create the disciplined, efficient market for capital that the economy desperately needs to sustain growth.
China could try to both recapitalize the banks and prime the fiscal pump by opting to run a big deficit. On paper, the risks would be modest: With the cost of living actually falling in recent months, inflation is not a major worry. And with a very small Government debt, China would have little difficulty selling bonds to finance spending. But Jeffrey Sachs, the director of Harvard's Institute for International Development, warns that China's finances are more precarious than the official numbers suggest.
The state banks' bad debts, which may be the equivalent of several hundred billion dollars, are effectively part of the national debt. Worse, what appears to be a nearly balanced budget is actually deeply in the red because the official expenditures do not include subsidies to state enterprises disguised as bank loans. "China is sitting on a mountain of fiscal problems already," Mr. Sachs concluded.
All this points toward a strategy of big talk and modest action. China's leaders, whose political legitimacy is tightly linked to their competence as economic managers, cannot afford to look as if they are ignoring rising unemployment and insolvent banks. By the same token, they cannot afford to risk China's hard-won reputation as fiscally conservative -- a reputation that has prevented capital flight from Hong Kong and allowed the newly installed Government to hold the line on exchange rates.
Beijing appears to have undertaken the delicate task of having it both ways. "These guys know what they're doing," argued Lawrence Kreicher, chief economist for Alliance Capital.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Saying No in the Land of Yes;
Japanese Rail Executive Stands Up for Shareholders

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 11

 BODY:
Never in his wildest dreams did Masatake Matsuda imagine he would tell the Prime Minister no.
Formerly a top-ranking bureaucrat at the Ministry of Transportation, Mr. Matsuda is well versed in the painstaking consensus-building process that banishes "no" from the lexicon of Japanese business and politics. 
 But last month, Mr. Matsuda, now president of the East Japan Railway Company, uttered the forbidden word to Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, and so did the heads of the six other railway companies that were formed when the national rail system was privatized more than a decade ago.
Mr. Hashimoto was trying to persuade the seven executives, recently dubbed the Seven Samurai by the Japanese press after the heroes of Akira Kurosawa's film of the same name, to absorb an additional $2.85 billion in unfunded pension liabilities that had come to light after the privatization.
"He pleaded with us to rethink our stance, but we rejected his plea right there in front of him," Mr. Matsuda said, obviously still somewhat awed by his own moxie.
Even more astounding, the railroad chiefs risked offending the Prime Minister for a cause regarded as heretical by the Japanese establishment -- their shareholders' rights.
With Mr. Matsuda as ring leader, the seven railway executives contend that the Government is trying to change the terms under which shareholders bought their stock after the privatization. The showdown highlights the growing conflict between the broad social obligations that Japanese companies have shouldered since World War II and their new-found need to attract foreign investors, who naturally think their interests should take priority.
"This whole debate shows a shocking ignorance of the rights of shareholders by government officials and politicians," said Clifford J. Shaw, president of Mercury Asset Management Japan Ltd., a unit of Merrill Lynch & Company, which owns shares in East Japan Railway, known here as JR East. "Such little regard for honoring previous commitments is really disheartening."
The Government's effort to squeeze a billion dollars more from the railroads -- contained in a bill now before the Japanese Parliament, or Diet -- has cast a pall over its plan to sell a second slice of stock in three of the companies for an originally projected $7.8 billion. But the economic impact could be much more damaging, critics warn.
They say the arm-twisting could undermine what little faith investors have in the Government's stated intention to stop interfering so much in the workings of the private sector. And that could curb the market's appetite for future privatizations, which the Government needs to raise money to close a yawning budget deficit and shore up the nation's rickety financial system.
"If the Government decides to ignore market principles in this way, we believe the impact will spread far beyond merely devaluing the companies' shares," Naoko Matsumoto, a transport analyst at Merrill Lynch, wrote in a report earlier this year. "We believe it would change the entire perception of the Japanese market."
Not that Japan has ever been mistaken for a land of swashbuckling capitalists. In the United States these days, and to a lesser extent in Europe, shareholders are treated as a company's ultimate masters. In Japan, by contrast, the welfare of the employees and the designs of management hold sway.
Moreover, some 70 percent of the shares of the average company are held by friendly affiliate companies to create a web of long-term cross-holdings that become a reliable rubber stamp for management. The system is slowly breaking down, but until recently cross-shareholdings were so durable that the Japanese referred to them as "shiozuke," or pickled.
Legal reforms passed in 1993 made it easier for individual shareholders to sue companies, and the number of shareholder cases has more than doubled since then.
But the Keidanren, Japan's powerful big business association, is currently lobbying to limit such suits once again. "There is no real market control of management of corporations here," said Koji Morioka, a professor at Kansai University and the head of Shareholder Ombudsman, a shareholder advocacy group.
That why Mr. Matsuda's crusade is so remarkable, although he doesn't see it that way. "As president of this company, which is a public company and has to observe market rules," he said, "I can't just decide to violate the shareholders' rights in order to give charity to the Government,"
Indeed, to Japanese shareholders' ears, Mr. Matsuda sounds almost too good to be true. When other Japanese executives argue on behalf of shareholder rights, it is usually more a matter of convenience than conviction.
But the fact that Mr. Matsuda and his fellow executives did agree to pay what they regarded as a fair portion of the pension shortage suggests that they are not simply trying to avoid additional debt. "Mr. Matsuda is rather unique among Japanese business executives, but I think he's sincere in what he's saying," said Naoto Hashimoto, a transportation analyst at Nomura Securities and an expert on the rail system's privatization.
Under the terms of the privatization, the companies assumed a staggering $113.7 billion of the debt accumulated by the Japan National Railway, while the Government-backed JNR Settlement Corporation picked up $173 billion. Then, in 1996, when the privatized companies went to merge their pension funds with the public pension fund, $7.4 billion in previously undetected pension liabilities came to light, and the companies agreed to pay what they considered their fair share, or $1.35 billion. The Parliament approved a law for the Settlement Corporation to handle the rest.
Now the Government is disbanding the Settlement Corporation, and it wants the railroad companies to pick up more -- $2.85 billion more -- of the pension tab, which they are determinedly resisting. "Adding on to our debt is a breach of a promise," Mr. Matsuda said. "This was a contract between the state of Japan and the companies, and the Government should not go back on its promises."
Such a frontal attack on the Government's integrity by a corporate executive is highly unusual in Japan. But Mr. Matsuda is not afraid of a little adversity. His conference room prominently features a calligraphy of a 3,000-year-old Chinese character that combines the symbols for hand and stone and means opening the frontier. And after all, he says, his motives are patriotic.
"I'm really a quiet, gentle man," he insists. "But I believe we have to fight things out in the open. Japan can no longer afford to do things the old way of kowtowing to politicians and making decisions in a black box."
His stance has touched off a minor revolt in the ruling Liberal Democratic Party. Concerned about the negative publicity, several senior party members refused to support proposed legislation that would force the seven railroad companies to pony up the extra money.
"I cannot accept the bill because it will hurt international confidence in Japan," said Yohei Kono, a former party president. It was the first time in as long as anyone can remember that a bill ended up in the Parliament without the unanimous approval of the party leaders.
The bill is expected to pass, in which case JR East has threatened to embarrass the Government further by suing it. Any lawsuit would risk throwing an unwelcome spotlight on the Government's history of mismanagement of the railways. And even though it raised $70.6 billion through the sale of their assets and stock, it did not use the proceeds to pay down Government debt, which has mushroomed to $220 billion from $173 billion.
In contrast, the privatized companies have shrunk their inherited debt of $113.7 billion to $100 billion while cutting costs and increasing revenues through new station developments that encompass retailing, hotel management and even credit services.
The Government plans to use tax revenues, including a new tax on cigarettes, to pay off the debt. Taxpayers are incensed that their money is being used to bail out yet another business that the Government mismanaged, and smokers question why they should bear an additional burden when smoking is restricted to a handful of railway cars.
"The Ministry of Finance is responsible for the negligence that put us in this position," said Katsutsugu Sekiya, a member of Parliament who heads a special committee on the Japan National Railway's long-term debt. "Also the politicians, who allocated the budget of the national railroad to bullet trains and local lines in order to create employment in their districts."
Mr. Sekiya himself is one of those politicians, as he happily pointed out during a recent interview, having ordered up the Uchiko Line on Shikoku Island to bring jobs to his constituents. Not that it did him much good, since shortly after the project began, his district was gerrymandered so that the line no longer runs through it.
But while he accepts responsibility for the problem, Mr. Sekiya is determined that the privatized rail companies and their shareholders will pay part of the cost of solving it. "If the stockholders think that is unfair, they should sell their stocks," he said.
The Government acknowledges that the pension shift will impose an additional burden on shareholders in the railroads but argues that it will save them money in the long run. The newly discovered money shortgage, said Katsuhito Nawano, senior deputy director general of the railway bureau of the Ministry of Transportation and one of the chief architects of the proposed legislation, was the result of merging the railroads' pension funds with the national pension system. Thus, he maintained, shareholders should be happy to assume that burden because otherwise their companies would be grappling with bankrupt pension systems.
But because the shortfall relates to the pensions of those employees who have worked for the rail system both before and after privatization, the companies insist the Government is partly responsible.
"We have paid our fair share in full," Mr. Matsuda said. He chalks up his outspoken defiance to a "frontier spirit" that imbues natives of Hokkaido, the cold, harsh northernmost island in the Japanese archipelago, and to entering the bureaucracy at a time when American management philosophy was wildly popular in theory but not in practice. "I told myself then it would be a revolutionary change to adopt those principles," he said. "But there was never any effort to cause a revolution."
Until now.
