HEADLINE: Many Serbs Would Just Rather Not Fight to Keep Kosovo

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, March 11

 BODY:
Few Serbs announce any qualms in the first moments of conversation, but not far beneath the surface outrage over the turmoil in Kosovo lurks opposition to any notion of fighting to keep the southern province.
If President Slobodan Milosevic wanted to rally the Serbs to fight against Kosovo's ethnic Albanians -- as he did against the Croats and then the Bosnians -- he would be unable to do so, Serbian nationalists and political analysts said. 
 Struggling to stay afloat in an economy crippled by war, sanctions and pervasive government corruption, many Serbs say they feel betrayed by Mr. Milosevic's failed promise of a greater Serbia. They want no part of an effort to hang on to the last morsel of it.
"I personally feel apathetic even though I can understand the issue intellectually," said Ljubomir Tadic, 73, a professor of philosophy at the Academy of Sciences and a Serbian nationalist who is angered that ethnic Albanians outnumber Serbs so dramatically in Kosovo. "People don't have pensions. The Americans have frozen our money. It is hard to get passionate about it."
Mr. Tadic said Mr. Milosevic should start "immediate" negotiations with the Albanians in Kosovo and work toward granting the province more autonomy. Mr. Tadic -- like the American policy makers he says he despises -- is opposed to the ethnic Albanian demands for independence.
On Tuesday the Serbian Government made an appeal for a dialogue with the Kosovo Albanians, but many Albanians said they were not taking the gesture seriously.
In many ways, the repression of Albanians in Kosovo by Serbian forces is a last chapter in the conflicts that Mr. Milosevic used to try and create a greater Serbia but which only tore the former Yugoslavia apart.
But seven years after the start of those wars, Mr. Milosevic, now the isolated leader of an economic backwater, has spent the good will of his people.
A poll published today in the independent newspaper Nedeljeni Telegraf showed that more than 70 percent of those asked said they were against close relatives' being sent to fight in Kosovo.
To many here, Kosovo, where fewer than 200,000 Serbs live, seems a historical outpost. It hardly seems worth the expensive upkeep, they say. Unlike most civil servants in Serbia, the police who are stationed in Kosovo to control the Albanians are paid their salaries by the Milosevic Government on a regular basis.
A Serbian writer referred to Kosovo today as "dead history," a place where beautiful Orthodox monasteries were revered but were not worth spilling blood over.
"What is important is how to live better," said the writer, Slobodan Reljic. "Our biggest problem is the threat of sanctions. Only a few people have relatives there."
Rather than seeing the chance for greater glory in Kosovo, many Serbs now see a lost cause, said Bratislav Grubavic, the editor of an influential newsletter VIP, which is distributed in diplomatic circles.
"Emotionally they care about it, but not to the extent of fighting for it," said Mr. Grubavic. "They are sad that it is a lost cause and it can't be under Serb control. Consciously or subconsciously they know Serbs have lost wars, and they know Kosovo will be a final act in this show."
But such realism does not mean that Mr. Milosevic will respond to popular feeling or give in quickly to Western demands for serious negotiations, Mr. Grubavic said.
Serbian police action against the Albanians will probably not end any time soon, he said. Part of Mr. Milosevic's strategy in using the police to pummel the Albanians in Kosovo, he said, was to weaken Ibrahim Rugova, their leader, whom Washington has encouraged to open talks with Mr. Milosevic.
While many Serbs said they were prepared to grant Kosovo autonomy, some Serbian nationalists have said that in order to maintain the "purest" Serbia, Kosovo should be allowed to secede.
This theory was put forward a year ago by members of the Serbian Academy of Sciences who argued that because of the high birth rate among Albanians in Kosovo, Serbs would be outnumbered by other groups in Serbia within a decade.
At present, demographers estimate that Serbs make up about 62 percent of the 11 million population of Serbia and that non-Serbs, including Albanians, Hungarians and Bulgarians, make up 38 percent.
Even in Mr. Milosevic's hometown of Pozarevac, 50 miles south of Belgrade, the passion for war has long evaporated, said Dragoslav Cvetic, an editor at Radio Bum, an independent station there.
Indeed, Mr. Milosevic is so unpopular that he can no longer resort to the nationalist argument to resurrect his image. "People don't have money, and they are very concerned about that," Mr. Cvetic said. "Milosevic is very afraid that the Americans are like demons. He doesn't have the courage to defy them, and he wouldn't have any support from the Serbs if he did."
Contrasting the atmosphere in the early 1990's, when Mr. Milosevic whipped the Serbs into a frenzy of war and the fatigue today, Milorad Tadic, a Belgrade truck driver, said: "Then we were fighting for Serbia. Now we would be fighting for Milosevic's throne. I wouldn't give one hair for Kosovo or for Milosevic."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: House G.O.P. Puts Brakes on I.M.F. Funds

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
House Republican leaders said today that they would hold up financing for the International Monetary Fund and back dues owed to the United Nations until the White House agreed to an anti-abortion provision.
Republican leaders said they would attach a ban on financing international groups that promote abortions overseas to an emergency spending bill that includes $18 billion for the I.M.F. and nearly $1 billion that the United States owes the United Nations. 
 The White House and its Democratic allies on Capitol Hill rejected the Republican proposal. They suggested that President Clinton would veto the spending bill, despite furious lobbying by his foreign policy advisers to secure the funding it contains, rather than buckle to Republican demands.
"We're certainly moving in that direction if Congress continues to move in the direction it is moving," said the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry. "What Congress is trying to do is to prevent recipients of some of this funding from doing what they would be protected in the United States from doing under the First Amendment."
The impasse threatens to derail financing that the Administration says the I.M.F. badly needs to cope with the financial crisis in Asia, and that the United Nations has been demanding from Washington at a time when Secretary General Kofi Annan has played a central role in calming the latest crisis with Iraq.
Last year Republicans blocked financing to the I.M.F. by linking it to the abortion provision. But that was before the financial problems in Asia. If they pursue the same course now, Republicans will risk the wrath of Wall Street and corporate America, which last month began a lobbying campaign for approval of the I.M.F. financing.
"If we fail to act, we'll be sending a message that we're not interested in those markets," Thomas J. Donohue, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, said in a telephone interview. "That would come under the heading of stupid."
Neither side shows any sign of softening its position; each believes it holds the best political cards. But the risk of not acting during the Asian crisis and of offending women also bring perils to both sides.
Even though the Administration has been urging prompt action on the I.M.F. refunding, the House and Senate may not vote on the money until after their April recess.
Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the Republican whip, said in an interview when told of the veto threat: "The President's really not interested in getting I.M.F. funding, is he? Our members aren't too thrilled about I.M.F. in the first place."
But Senator Thomas A. Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, said, "We're just not going to be blackmailed into accepting language that is totally unacceptable."
The standoff reprises a similar showdown between the White House and the Republican-controlled Congress last November. At that time it appeared that an assiduous yearlong effort by the White House to win approval for the I.M.F. and United Nations payments had paid off.
But conservative House Republicans insisted on the abortion provision. After Mr. Clinton threatened to veto the foreign operations spending bill, the abortion language was dropped, but so were United Nations and I.M.F. payments, as well as a State Department reorganization plan.
From the ashes of that defeat, the White House has urged Congressional leaders in recent weeks to resurrect the financing for the I.M.F. -- a $3.5 billion contribution to a new line of emergency credit and $14.5 billion to replenish the Fund's capital base -- and to the United Nations in an emergency-spending bill.
The Senate appears willing to approve the payments and opposes the abortion restrictions. But conservative House Republicans, led by Representative Christopher H. Smith of New Jersey, have held the Speaker, Newt Gingrich, to his pledge to link the abortion provisions to the foreign-policy initiatives.
"Killing babies is a very serious matter," Mr. Smith said in an interview. "This Administration is promoting abortion overseas."
International organizations like the United Nations and the I.M.F. are frequent political targets of conservative Republicans. But the current fight has put many Republicans in the awkward position of choosing between two key constituencies: big business and opponents of abortion.
Last month an array of powerful business groups began a lobbying campaign in support of the I.M.F. payments. Business leaders and their Congressional allies are concerned that American companies could lose billions of dollars in exports because of the Asian currency crisis.
Moreover, the stakes in Asia are much greater than they were last fall. "This could have a very serious impact on the finances of many countries," said Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, a New York Republican who heads the House International Relations Committee. "There's a real interest on our part to resolve this."
But abortion opponents carry influence with many conservative Republicans. "If there's someone who worries more about a foreign economic crisis than the principle of U.S. taxpayer money going to repeal right-to-life laws, I haven't met them," said Representative John Shadegg, an Arizona Republican.
The abortion provision is also attached to a separate bill that reauthorizes the activities of the State Department and the agency's reorganization plan. The bill, which the House may vote on as early as Thursday, would also authorize the $921 million in arrears the United States owes the United Nations. Because of the abortion provision, this bill is also likely to draw Mr. Clinton's veto.
A third spending bill is likely to emerge unscathed before Congress adjourns for its spring recess in early April. That emergency spending bill for the fiscal year that began last October would appropriate $1.4 billion for military operations in the Persian Gulf, $487 million for operations in Bosnia and $642 million in disaster relief to states like California that have suffered severe storm damage.
One provision of the Senate version of this bill may draw objections. It would bar the Federal Communications Commission from spending money to enforce a policy requiring television networks to give political candidates free commercial time.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
California, taking a cue from other regions, plans a specialized promotion for cultural tourism.

BYLINE: By Andrea Adelson 

 BODY:
A NEW campaign promoting California as a destination for cultural tourism goes beyond the obvious beacons like the Getty Center in Los Angeles. One suggested stop is the Thai Plaza on Hollywood Boulevard, where a Thai Elvis performs on Tuesday nights for throngs of Asian regulars.
The Thai Plaza is listed in "On the Edge," one of 13 itineraries included in a 32-page advertising insert that is the foundation of a $3 million promotion by the year-old California Cultural Tourism Coalition. Last year, the group received a $150,000 grant from the National Endowment for the Arts, which supported the project as a national model. 
 The insert's brightly inked pages, designed by the Garza Group in Pasadena, Calif., use a montage of photos and text to describe highlights of the itineraries. Each one suggests a themed cultural trail that can be followed in Los Angeles, San Francisco or San Diego.
The insert is appearing in the March issue of the American Express Company's Travel and Leisure magazine. It is also to appear in two travel industry trade publications in March and is being sent to 200,000 customers of American Express, which is a corporate underwriter of the effort. The insert is expected to reach a combined audience of one million.
Along with highlights like the new Getty Center, the insert's pages sketch out a road map to less prominent cultural outposts. Besides kitsch and camp sites from "On the Edge," an adventurous tourist could sample contemporary music in "Jazz and Blues," feel the fusion of Latino cultures at "Fiesta" locations, explore lesbian and gay culture in "Pride," absorb architectural contrasts in "Art to Architecture" or retrace state history along the "Mission Trail."
Readers of the insert are urged to obtain more detailed descriptions from "California: Culture's Edge," a 120-page guide created by the coalition that is being distributed free to 50,000 travel agents around the country. The compendium will be on line at www.californiasedge.com.
"For a lot of years, people thought California culture meant yogurt," said John R. Poimiroo, director of the state's Division of Tourism, which contributed $70,000 to the effort. The stereotype persists even though the state has museums devoted to subjects that range from steam engines to underwear. "We've taken them for granted and never seen them as tourism treasures," Mr. Poimiroo said.
By making culture more accessible, the campaign aims to show out-of-state visitors that there is more to California than Yosemite and Disneyland and gives them reasons to linger longer. The average stay in California is three days, down from five days a decade ago. That was before other Western destinations, such as Las Vegas, Nev.; Phoenix, and Santa Fe, N.M., stepped up their own tourism promotions.
"We're making a big effort to change the erroneous perception in the front line that there's no culture," said Robert Barrett, an executive at the Los Angeles Visitors and Convention Bureau and a coalition leader.
California's emphasis on travel for cultural reasons reflects the success of similar efforts -- emphasizing concepts like eco-tourism and heritage tourism, which focuses on history -- in other regions.
"We can prove it," said Becky C. Anderson, executive director of Handmade in America, a nonprofit group in Asheville, N.C., that created a self-guided tour to North Carolina's crafts community in 1996. California used Handmade as its model.
Now more artisans are opening their backwoods studios to the public. And shops like the Weaving Room in remote Crossmore, N.C., are seeing revenue increase. "They credit it every bit to the guidebook," said Ms. Anderson, who envisions tours focusing on the region's Cherokee heritage and music.
In a different twist, City Pass Inc. in Napa, Calif., last June began selling to tour operators and visitors a discounted package of tickets to San Francisco and Seattle cultural sites. This summer, City Pass will get a tryout in Boston and New York. Locations in New York will include four museums and the observation decks at the Empire State Building and the World Trade Center.
With programs like City Pass and California's cultural tours, travelers are more likely to make extra stops that they would normally have overlooked, said Michael B. Gallagher, the founder of City Pass. "People travel to see culture, but the cultural community gets the least amount of economic benefit," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
A $4 Billion Global Issue by the World Bank Sells Quickly

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The World Bank priced its largest dollar-denominated global bond issue ever yesterday, as solid demand from investors insured its quick sale and oversubscription.
While the recent cascade of corporate financings scheduled to be priced has weighed on the Treasury market, the World Bank deal did not because it was completed quickly. 
 The World Bank, which lends money to developing countries, sold $4 billion in global bonds through underwriters led by Goldman Sachs International, J. P. Morgan and SBC Warburg Dillon Read. The issue was triple-A rated and priced to yield 5.703 percent for a bond due 2003, or about 14 basis points above a Treasury security with a similar maturity. (A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.)
Randy C. Snook, managing director of corporate new issues at Goldman, Sachs, said the pricing was in line with expectations, with Europe accounting for 45 percent of subscribers, the United States for 35 percent and Asia for 20 percent. He said it was largest of the 14 dollar-denominated bond issues the World Bank has sold since 1989.
Another global issuer yesterday was the Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, which sold $3 billion in bonds backed by student loans in three parts through Merrill Lynch & Company.
Sold through a SLM Student Loan Trust 1998-1, the bonds pay a floating interest rate. The first part consisted of $1.7 billion with an average maturity of 2.49 years priced at par to yield 71 basis points more than a three-month Treasury bill, while the second part consisted of $1.2 billion in bonds with an average maturity of 7.29 years, priced to yield 76 basis points more than a three-month bill. The third part included $106 million of bonds with an average life of 9.35 years that were priced to yield 97 basis points above a three-month bill.
Treasury securities got an early lift from a surge in the dollar to a seven-week high against the Japanese yen, following news that prosecutors had raided the Bank of Japan and arrested a senior official. A strong dollar makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities more attractive to foreign investors.
The 30-year bond rose 1/4, to 102 20/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction fell, to 5.94 percent from 5.95 percent.
Market participants showed some jitters over today's release of retail sales for last month, which are expected to be strong, but appeared less worried about tomorrow's report on the Producer Price Index, which is expected to show benign inflation at the manufacturing level.
The Commerce Department reported yesterday that inventories of goods at wholesale merchants declined half of a percent in January for the first time in six months.

HEADLINE: Tighten Belts, Suharto Tells His People, It's All Over

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 11

 BODY:
President Suharto called on Indonesians today to tighten their belts, saying the rapid growth in prosperity they had enjoyed over the last 25 years was gone for good.
"We will never enjoy again an economic growth such as we have experienced for more than the past quarter of a century," he said after taking his oath of office for a seventh five-year term. It was his strongest public statement yet about the economic shock that has made almost all of Indonesia's 200 million people suddenly poorer. 
 "As an individual, as a group, some of us may lead an affluent life," said the President, whose family controls much of the nation's wealth. "But as a nation, we can no longer afford to lead an extravagant life."
As low-key and expressionless as ever, Mr. Suharto peered through his glasses at a sheaf of notes as he spoke, displaying the seemingly effortless command he has exercised over the world's fourth most-populous country for the last 32 years.
There was no inflection in his voice as he raised a rallying cry: "Let us carry the heavy burdens together on our shoulders. Let us carry the easy loads together in our hands."
Mr. Suharto told the 1,000-member People's Consultative Assembly that he fully intended to serve out his five-year term, which will end when he is 81.
"In five years' time, God willing, I shall stand on this rostrum to present the accountability of my leadership before the Indonesian people's representatives," he said.
The economic crisis of the last few months has led to unparalleled calls for change at the top. Some members of the country's fragmented and timid political opposition have raised their voices to call for his removal. In the last two weeks, demonstrations have spread through at least 30 colleges, although the students have obeyed orders to confine their marches to their campuses.
By his side as he embarks on a new term as Asia's longest-serving leader will be his longtime confidant, B. J. Habibie, who was endorsed today by the assembly as the new Vice President, in obedience to Mr. Suharto's wish.
Mr. Habibie rose from his seat, shook hands with the departing Vice President, Try Sutrisno, and switched chairs with him. Unlike the dour President, he smiled.
A man who might be described in the United States as a technology wonk, Mr. Habibie, 61, is an aeronautical engineer who has served for years as Minister of Research and Technology.
Sometimes described here as the President's seventh child, Mr. Habibie has never devoted himself to politics and does not have a significant power base of his own. Many analysts here suspect that if Mr. Suharto does not complete his term, there will be a power struggle over the succession.
The 11-day electoral session ended with an expression of nationalism by the Speaker of the House, Harmoko, who said, "International support is very important, but our dignity is more important."
This is the battle cry of the moment as Indonesia wrestles with the International Monetary Fund over the terms of its $40 billion economic restructuring plan.
A Government delegation is set to travel to Washington to meet with officials of the Fund and the United States Government. Mr. Suharto has complained that the restructuring plan he signed in January demands an open economy that is not right for Indonesia. And he still appears determined to bet the health of the economy on a risky plan to raise the value of the currency artificially by pegging it to the dollar.
As the electoral assembly doggedly performed its political ritual today, the ritual approached self-parody at times. After obeying the President's wishes in nominating Mr. Habibie, for instance, assembly leaders then formally presented Mr. Habibie's name to the President for approval.
According to the ritual, the President himself had to be vetted as fit for office. This is how The Jakarta Post described that procedure:
"Background checks by all factions found Suharto conformed to fundamental requirements of the presidential candidate. He possess an I.D. card signed by Jakarta Governor Sutiyoso, letter of good conduct from National Police Chief Gen. Dibyo Widodo, letter confirming noninvolvement in the banned Indonesian Communist Party, also from Dibyo, letter of ideological screening by the internal security agency chief from Gen. Wiranto, a letter stating he is not serving a sentence or under investigation from Chief Justice Sarwata, and a health certificate from the chief of presidential medical team, Bondan Haryono."
The report concluded, "The administrative proceedings ended with Afif stating that Suharto agreed to be renominated."

HEADLINE: Florida Appeals Court Returns Defeated Mayor of Miami to Post

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, March 11

 BODY:
A state appeals court today returned Joe Carollo to the mayor's post he lost in contested balloting four months ago and ruled there was no need to rerun the mayoral election that a judge overturned last week.
Mr. Carollo won a majority of votes from polling places in a Nov. 4 election, but Xavier L. Suarez's overwhelming advantage among absentee ballots forced a runoff between the two men, which Mr. Suarez won on Nov. 13. Mr. Carollo sued to overturn the Nov. 4 vote, claiming there had been widespread fraud among the absentee ballots. 
 Judge Thomas S. Wilson Jr. of State Circuit Court agreed and ordered a new election, leaving the city without a mayor in the meantime.
But a three-judge panel of the State Court of Appeal for the Third District threw out the absentee ballots today and said the election should be decided by the votes at polling places.
"Were we to approve a new election as the proper remedy following extensive voting fraud," the judges wrote, "we would be sending out the message that the worst that would happen in the face of voter fraud would be another election.
"We refuse to disenfranchise the more than 40,000 voters who, on Nov. 4, 1997, exercised their constitutionally guaranteed right to vote in the polling places of Miami. Unlike the right to vote, which is assured every citizen by the United States Constitution, the ability to vote by absentee ballot is a privilege."
Whether this ends the fight over the election results is unclear. After his aides cleaned out his office this afternoon, Mr. Suarez held a news conference at which he said he would sue in Federal Court, under the Voting Rights Act, in an effort to be returned to office. He also said he would seek a change in the city charter to shorten Mr. Carollo's term.
"I wanted our city to move forward," Mr. Suarez said, "I wanted our city to progress. I wanted our city to be clean and have a balanced budget."
Mr. Carollo, who could be sworn in as early as Thursday, pledged to return stability to a city that has been in turmoil for more than 18 months, struggling with a financial crisis, criminal indictments of city officials, several changes of city manager and a four-month fight over the election.
An elated Mr. Carollo met with reporters outside City Hall within an hour of the ruling.
"This is what a democracy is all about," he said exultantly. "This is why America is the greatest country in the world."
In a reference to contentious changes brought about by Mr. Suarez during his four months as mayor, Mr. Carollo said in an interview, "I will be taking cautious steps. You're not going to have the rest of the world laughing at the position of the mayor of Miami."
Mr. Carollo, a businessman who will be 43 on Thursday, was noncommittal when asked if he would retain City Manager Jose Garcia-Pedrosa, appointed two months ago by Mr. Suarez.
Mr. Suarez's lawyers had argued that the court should be bound by the will of the people, and that Mr. Suarez had won the mayoralty in the runoff.
But it was clear from the questions the judges asked at a hearing on Wednesday that they were skeptical about that argument, even though they agreed that Mr. Suarez himself had not been implicated in the fraud.

HEADLINE: Turf;
When Banks Step Back, Middlemen Rush In

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
WHEN Lorraine Altman arrived for her first meeting with a mortgage broker, she came armed. From her perusal of the Internet the night before, she knew the current interest rates. From discussions with her real estate agent, she knew what type of loan she wanted. And from talking with her accountant, she knew exactly how much she wanted to spend on the monthly mortgage payment for the new $165,000 Upper East Side one-bedroom apartment she had picked out.
The only thing this savvy 52-year-old Long Islander didn't know -- and was relying on the mortgage broker to tell her -- was where her mortgage would be coming from: a bank, a small investment group, an insurance company or a giant mortgage conglomerate. 
 Ms. Altman, a job-training executive in Manhattan, found that getting a mortgage these days is a lot different from the way it was 17 years ago, when she bought a co-op in Great Neck, N.Y. "I never even heard of a mortgage broker when I bought my last co-op," she said. "I just walked into the Dime Savings around the corner."
Times have changed. Real estate agents, brokers and bankers say that these days, home buyers are more inquiring, the old-line banks are more reluctant to lend and the mortgage brokers are a lot more reputable. In a decade, the number of mortgage brokers has tripled; the use of mortgage brokers has soared, from less than 20 percent to 52 percent. In Manhattan, the percentage is probably higher; experts estimate that mortgage brokers handle as much as 75 percent of all co-op loans.
"Ten years ago, all top 10 lenders in the country were banks," said Neil Bader, the chief executive of Skyscraper Mortgage, one of the largest mortgage brokerage companies in New York City. "Now, there's only two or three."
Not only that, but customers are also more technologically plugged in. "Consumers are more adept at using the Internet, and bankers and mortgage brokers are, too," said Barbara Kent, a lawyer at the New York State Banking Department. In response to dozens of requests from buyers, lawyers and brokers, she said, the state has proposed a new rule to allow mortgage applications to be filed over the World Wide Web. "New York is the first state to address using the Internet to get a mortgage," she said.
The Banking Department is currently gathering comments on the rule -- which contains the same protections for consumers as the old-fashioned transactions -- and said it might release the new rule sometime in April or May.
It used to be a lot simpler. In the early 1980's, when Ms. Altman was getting her first mortgage, the prospective home buyer would stroll into a bank, brandishing a contract to buy a house. The banker might even know the place. There wouldn't be too much discussion about rates -- the percentage the bank charges to make the loan. There would be lots of forms, lots of hand-shaking, an appraisal and, finally, at the closing, the bank officer would appear with a check.
The idea of a mortgage broker -- a middleman who would scout the market, find the best rate (even if it was from a lender in San Diego or Dallas), counsel and advise, and then do all the paperwork -- was almost unheard of.
In the past, mortgage brokers often took their fees from the customer -- occasionally opening themselves to criticism that they were gouging the home buyer. Now, they increasingly take their commissions from the lender. In effect, the lender offers the broker a discount to do what the bank officers once did: things like filling out applications, scanning credit reports and arranging appraisals. For his fee, the broker takes the difference between the discount rate for the loan and the retail rate. (Regardless of how the fee is figured, reputable brokers say a customer should never pay more than if he walked into a bank.)
Most of these changes have occurred since the mid-80's, when the states started registering mortgage brokers and many banks switched their focus away from residential mortgage lending. Now, customers complain that the banks have abandoned the off-the-street mortgage customer.
The change, New York Banking Department officials say, may be most noticeable in the savings banks. "Savings and loans did a tremendous mortgage business, and that definitely has lessened after the S.& L. crisis of the 80's," Mrs. Kent said. "They were encouraged to diversify, and the business that has left the savings banks has gone to mortgage brokers." (In 1987, those banks did 41 percent of the country's mortgage business; two years ago, they were down to 19 percent.)
Banks still give mortgages, but many would rather let the mortgage broker stand between them and the customer. Even if a loyal bank customer gets a mortgage through his bank, he may find that his mortgage is sold shortly afterward to a different bank or a large consolidator.
The March 2 issue of The National Mortgage News lists the top 50 mortgage lenders; only a handful can be considered old-fashioned banks in the sense that they have branches. Norwest Mortgage, based in Des Moines, is first, followed by Countrywide Home Loans of Pasadena, Calif. Chase Manhattan Mortgage of Edison, N.J., is third. In the New York region, the only old-fashioned banks listed are Marine Midland (No. 29), in Depew, N.Y., and the Long Island Savings Bank (No. 45). To tie in to the big, out-of-state lenders, a customer probably needs a broker.
"You can usually get a better deal from the mortgage brokers than from the banks; they'll generally write the business faster because they'll draw on all those sources," said R. Marshall Kneeland, a building contractor from Winsted, Conn., who used to be a real estate agent. Five years ago, when he was selling houses, he said, many people thought of mortgage brokers as "kind of slimy specimens who took out small ads in the classifieds, like: 'Refused by your bank? Come see us.' "
Now, he said, mortgage brokers are "taking out giant billboards on I-91."
Mr. Kneeland, who is currently using a mortgage broker to help him shop for his own mortgage, pointed out that many borrowers don't keep track of who holds their mortgages. "It might be the bank you signed up with -- or it might be the ABC Finance Company in Albuquerque," he said. "You might as well go for the best deal."
Getting the best deal has become an obsession for many of today's home buyers, some of whom are comparison shopping on the Internet, a tool that wasn't even available 10 years ago. Refinancing, which allows borrowers to better the interest rates they got in the past, now makes up 55 percent of today's mortgage business.
All of this points to an increasingly investigative shopper. Yet, even the best informed home buyer may need help with the paperwork involved in applying. That's where a broker -- or even the Internet -- can help.
Richard Hodos, a commercial real estate broker, figured there would be no snags in applying for a $300,000 loan to buy a huge 1,000-square-foot one-bedroom apartment in an elegant prewar co-op building in Greenwich Village. After all, he was putting up 40 percent of the $499,000 price.
But despite Mr. Hodos's sterling credit report, Bruce G. Maasbach, the broker at Skyscraper Mortgage, was concerned about two recent credit inquiries from banks. "They want to make sure you're not taking out any other mortgages on different properties," he explained. So Mr. Hodos, an enthusiastic and affable man of 37, gave reasons for the credit inquiries, including his request to one credit card company for an increased limit this past Christmas.
AT their first face-to-face meeting, Mr. Maasbach -- who had drafted a pile of forms after a brief telephone interview -- laid out for Mr. Hodos what he would be charged, above and beyond the monthly payment and the up-front money that would be required, including an application fee of $290, a credit check for $10 and the appraisal fee of $275.
By the end of the session, Mr. Hodos had filled out all the paperwork and had a tentative rate -- 7 3/8 percent, from the Astoria Federal Savings and Loan Association in Lake Success, N.Y. -- and a tentative monthly payment: $2,072.
These days, the banks rely on brokers like Mr. Maasbach and Elise Leve Wittenberg at Manhattan Mortgage, who met with Ms. Altman, to funnel clients and paperwork to them. But it wasn't always that way. In fact, before the mid-1980's, the banks didn't usually deal with mortgage brokers at all.
When the business of mortgage brokering began, "we were the lender of the last resort," said Tuck Marshall, who will become the president of the National Association of Mortgage Brokers in June. He continued: "The mortgage broker helped you clean up your credit and found you a loan -- but not through a bank. It was seen as slightly shady business."
From 1990 to the present, there was an even greater shift, away from commercial and savings banks to mega-lenders like Countrywide, which last year lent $45 billion. "No one knows these big mortgage conglomerates' names -- they don't even have branches," Mr. Bader said. "They're using the mortgage brokers as conduits."
This all gets a bit heady for a consumer who wants to research the rates on his own, and confusing for those who are not yet ready to spend their spare time hunkered down over a computer keyboard, trying to surf the Web.
L. Daniel Rawitch is the chief executive of Finet, the parent company of I Qualify, a mortgage brokerage company on the Internet. Mr. Rawitch says his company (at www.iqualify.com) will give a preliminary approval in six minutes, based on a quick, fill-in-the blanks application, to prospective homeowners for only $39. If the applicant gets the preliminary approval, he or she can take the results to any lender, the company says, or use Monument Mortgage, the mortgage company Finet also owns.
The Web site may be helpful in spotting weak areas; applicants may be told to explain late payments on credit cards, for instance. After a client pays a fee, I Qualify will also mail him the current percentage rate for a mortgage and the monthly payment. But Manhattanites beware: the company does not handle loans on co-ops. And, as it states in bold type, "This is not a commitment to lend."
To Mr. Rawitch and his competitors, the Internet is the wave of the future. Others are not so sure.
"The Internet isn't there yet," said Mark E. Zimmerman, a real estate lawyer in Manhattan. "People want personal service, plain and simple. The banks are really missing the boat."
Mr. Bader, whose mortgage brokerage company has three Web sites, grumbled, "The Internet will be there for my children."
Still, there are plenty of people already betting that Mr. Zimmerman and Mr. Bader are wrong.
 
Defining the Terms
FOR the novice searching for a mortgage, here are a few terms to throw around so you can sound like a pro.
ADJUSTABLE RATE MORTGAGE -- Often called an ARM in the ads, it means that the interest rate changes at specified intervals; for example, "10/1" means the rate will stay fixed for 10 years, then will change each year for the duration of the mortgage.
LIFE CAP -- The limit on the interest rate on an adjustable rate loan.
POINTS -- A one-time charge by a lender: each point equals 1 percent of the loan amount.
CLOSING COSTS -- Costs incurred in buying real estate, which can include points, attorney's fees, the cost of a lien search, filing fees and more.
LOAN COMMITMENT -- An agreement to lend. Synonym: Loan approval.
REFINANCE, OR REFI -- Money borrowed by the owner of real estate to replace an existing loan on the same real estate. TRACIE ROZHON
 
Proceed With Caution
 ALTHOUGH a lot of the uncertainty when dealing with a mortgage broker is gone -- New York State and the surrounding states have some of the toughest rules around -- the smart home buyer always comes to the first meeting well prepared.
Get a recommendation from a friend or colleague who has used a good broker in the past. Failing that, get several names from your real estate broker.
Check newspapers or the Internet to learn the most current rates for the kind of mortgage you want. Last month, the New York State Banking Department began posting the latest interest rates for mortgages on the World Wide Web, at www.banking.state.ny.us. (Look under the section called Interest Rate Surveys.) For the Web-challenged, hard copies of the reports can be obtained from (800) 518-8866.
Remember to ask the mortgage broker to go over every one of the charges you will have to pay. You shouldn't pay more for a mortgage through a broker -- including all preparation costs -- than you would pay if you walked in to a bank. (Brokers say you will often pay less, because of their ability to comparison shop.) TRACIE ROZHON

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
Trenton Gets Grant For Urban Renewal

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Federal housing officials awarded a $3.8 million grant to Trenton yesterday to help turn a 212-acre area of abandoned buildings and deteriorating homes into a residential neighborhood of single-family houses. 
 The grant, from the Department of Housing and Urban Development, will be used to buy land and improve housing stock in Trenton's Canal Banks section, a half-mile north of downtown, said Christine Soucy, a spokeswoman for the department's Newark office. About 250 homes will be built or renovated in the neighborhood and half will be set aside for low-income residents, Ms. Soucy said. She added that the construction was expected to increase the rate of homeownership in the area to 50 percent from 30 percent.

HEADLINE: What's Trendy on Campus? Adjunct Faculty and Easy A's

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Why Colleges Shower Students With A's," Brent Staples's March 8 Editorial Observer: While grade inflation may de-emphasize grade point averages, it certainly does not devalue diplomas themselves. It has only changed the emphasis of the college experience. 
 At Yale, a generous grading policy has encouraged students to take academic risks and to devote themselves to real-world activities outside the classroom. A demonstrated commitment to public health in New Haven is now more important to medical school admissions officers than earning high scores in the cutthroat memorization game in organic chemistry class.
 
HERB ALLEN
Bloomsburg, Pa., March 8, 1998

HEADLINE: What's Trendy on Campus? Adjunct Faculty and Easy A's;
Quality Over Quantity

 BODY:

To the Editor;
Having just finished my midterm grading, issuing 24 D's and F's out of a class of 50 in a music appreciation course, I read with interest Brent Staples's March 8 Editorial Observer on grade inflation. It seems that higher education has become an entitlement rather than a privilege. Universities cater to this notion, seeking to boost admissions numbers with little regard to the quality of the students. If universities wish to adopt the practices of the business world, they cannot do it by half measures; they must concern themselves with quality as well as quantity.
 
DAVID CURTIN
Platteville, Wis., March 8, 1998
 
The writer is professor of piano, University of Wisconsin at Platteville.

HEADLINE: What's Trendy on Campus? Adjunct Faculty and Easy A's;
Grades and Ratings

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I take exception to a number of statements Brent Staples makes in his March 8 Editorial Observer on grade inflation. As an associate dean for three years, I was responsible for all course-related issues, including grades. Rather than "hound" faculty to give high grades, we regularly told faculty with inflated grade distributions to lower them in the future. Grade inflation was more of a problem with full-time faculty than with adjuncts. I have never heard of an instance where a student "threatened" a faculty member for being given a low grade. High teacher ratings and easy grades did not necessarily correlate.
 
SHELDON EPSTEIN
South Orange, N.J., March 9, 1998
 
The writer is interim dean of the School of Business, Seton Hall University.

HEADLINE: What's Trendy on Campus? Adjunct Faculty and Easy A's;
Report the Median

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Brent Staples, in his March 8 Editorial Observer, ignores a simple solution to grade inflation. Posting the median grade received in every class right next to the grade received shows the relative worth of an A in any given class. Dartmouth College, which I attend, does this. A prudent next step would be computing for every student a "difficulty grade point average," which would be computed the same way G.P.A.'s are, except using median grades.
 
DAVID SCHLEICHER
Hanover, N.H., March 8, 1998

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 32; Column 3; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 921 words

HEADLINE: INSIDE ART

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:

Economic Projection
 As the different branches of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum develop, so do their collections.
On Saturday, the Deutsche Guggenheim Berlin, the museum's 7,000-square-foot space on the ground floor of the newly restored Berlin headquarters of Deutsche Bank, unveiled "The Swimmer in the Econo-mist," a major new work by the Pop artist James Rosenquist. It is the museum's first site-specific commission and will be on view there through June 14. 
 "The Swimmer" is a monumental, billboardlike suite of three paintings; each canvas is 11 1/2 feet high, with one 20 feet wide, another 48 feet wide and the third 90 feet wide.
The work has been compared to the artist's monumental "F-111" (1964-65), a 10-by-86-foot painting that was conceived as a reaction against military power and consumer culture. It was acquired by the Museum of Modern Art two years ago.
"The Swimmer in Econo-mist" refers specifically to industry and consumerism as well as to the turbulent nature of today's economy. The work was financed by Deutsche Bank, but the bank and the museum still haven't determined who owns it, said Lisa Dennison, the Guggenheim's deputy director and chief curator. When the Berlin branch opened, with financial backing from Deutsche Bank, the Guggenheim said that artworks purchased on commission would be jointly owned by the museum and the bank.
Ms. Dennison said that the museum had chosen the artist, and that one panel of the work had been exhibited in October at the opening of the Guggenheim branch in Bilbao, Spain. The Berlin branch opened in November on the Unter den Linden near the Brandenburg Gate.
"Rosenquist is a major artist of the 1960's who doesn't have a large presence in our collection," she said, adding that the Guggenheim had bought another painting by Mr. Rosenquist, "Flamingo Capsule." This brightly colored work from 1970, a meditation on space exploration, was purchased specifically for the collection at Bilbao, where crowds are still waiting hours to visit the five-month-old building.
 
The Short List
The acquisition wasn't the only announcement from the Guggenheim this week. It has also released the short list for its Hugo Boss Prize.
This prize, a $50,000 award named after its sponsor, the German menswear company, is given every two years in recognition of an artist's entire body of work that represents "either a major achievement or a significant development in contemporary art," Ms. Dennison said.
The Hugo Boss Award does not stipulate the artist's nationality, unlike the Turner Prize, given by the Tate Gallery in London only to British artists. Two years ago, Matthew Barney, the American installation artist, was the first Boss winner.
Artists are chosen by an international jury that spends days reviewing slides, videos and other documentation.
This year the short list includes several installation and performance artists but no painters. It is noticeably balanced between men and women, with several nationalities and different stages of careers represented. By far the best known is Douglas Gordon, the Conceptual artist who was the 1996 Turner winner. Another recognizable name, especially in this country, is Lorna Simpson, the American photographer and filmmaker who has had solo shows at the Museum of Modern Art, the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago and the Contemporary Arts Museum in Houston.
Other nominees are Huang Yong Ping, a Chinese installation artist whose work has been exhibited throughout Japan and at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo; William Kentridge, a South African filmmaker who received much attention at Documenta X in Kassel, Germany, last summer and whose work has just been seen at the Drawing Center in SoHo; Lee Bul, a South Korean installation and performance artist whose work was on view at the Museum of Modern Art, and Pipilotti Rist, a Swiss video artist whose work has been shown throughout Europe and at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago.
An exhibition of works by these artists will be on view at the Guggenheim's branch in SoHo from June 24 through Sept. 20. The winner will be announced in July.
 
Cincinnati Choice
Zaha Hadid, the Iraqi-born London architect, will become the first woman to design an American museum.
Ms. Hadid was selected to design a 65,000-square-foot, $25 million building for the Contemporary Arts Center in Cincinnati. She has designed buildings in Japan and Germany.
The new building will be on the northwest corner of Sixth and Walnut Streets in the heart of Cincinnati's Backstage Entertainment District and will be more than three times the size of the center's current site at 115 East Fifth Street. Ms. Hadid was chosen from 97 architects from 4 continents by a jury of trustees and architects.
The other finalists were Bernard Tschumi, the dean of the Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation at Columbia University, and Daniel Libeskind, the Polish-born architect who received much attention for his design of an ultra-modern building, resembling a series of tumbling boxes, that is to be constructed between two ornate Victorian palaces that make up the Victoria and Albert Museum in London.
Charles Desmarais, director of the Contemporary Arts Center, said it had not decided what it would do with the old site, which it leases. It may rent it out or may use it as an auxiliary space. The center said it was hoping to have its new building completed by late 2001 or early 2002.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A detail from James Rosenquist's "Swimmer in the Econo-mist," at the Deutsche Guggenheim Berlin. (Lee Ewing/Deutsche Guggenheim Berlin)

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 33; Column 5; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 768 words

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
The Puzzling Road Maps Of a Philosopher's Mind

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:
Among many art trends hovering in the air is an interest in visual systems, from the exhaustive cosmologies of the Buddhist mandalas seen at the Asia Society last fall, to the computer-generated flow charts with which Peter Halley recently papered a gallery at the Museum of Modern Art. A gallery show in SoHo by Matt Mullican (at Brooke Alexander through March 28) follows a similar thread.
Within this context, the exhibition titled "Rudolf Steiner: Blackboard Drawings, 1919-1924," at Peter Blum Gallery, makes sense. Steiner, who died in 1925, was a social philosopher, mystic and educator. He helped establish the Theosophical movement in Germany but later developed his own "spiritual science," which explained the material and spiritual worlds as an array of interactive links and correspondences. 
 Steiner wasn't a professional artist; he dabbled in painting, to insipid effect. But he was a tireless lecturer and drew diagrams in colored chalk on slate blackboards as he talked. In 1919, one of his followers, Emma Stolle, hit on the idea of preserving the drawings by covering the slate with sheets of black paper before lectures began. She then dated the sheets and stored them away.
The results were rarely seen publicly until 1990. The show of 38 works at Blum, on loan from the Rudolf Steiner archive in Dornach, Switzerland, and originally organized by Lawrence Rindler for an exhibition at the Berkeley Museum of Art in California, is the first appearance of the work in the United States.
What Steiner would have thought of submitting his pedagogical aids to sustained scrutiny is a question. Seen apart from his lectures, their near-abstract forms, symbolic colors (which Steiner viewed as emanations of spiritual beings of an earlier age), often ponderous titles ("Evil," "Why we are on earth," "Hegel and Schopenhauer") and jottings on such diverse subjects as medicine and economics, look hopelessly arcane.
Yet even for the noninitiate, which means most of us, the drawings hold attractions. Some appear straightforwardly illustrative. In a lecture dated Dec. 4, 1920, for example, Steiner spoke of Hegel's vision of the cosmos as a "spider's web of concepts," and he underscored the idea with a fleet, improvised sketch of a connect-the-dots constellation of white chalk lines set against scribbled orange strokes.
In other cases the relation of image to text seems more oblique. In one lecture, Steiner's reference to what he calls reflective elements in the human organism is accompanied by two ovoid forms, executed with the flat side of the chalk, suggesting luminous curtainlike parachutes. Elsewhere, the phrase "a kind of breathing in the light" finds its visual equivalent in a nebulous burst of hair-fine strokes in coral and gold.
Some of the sparest images are the most evocative. The drawing titled "Devoted Attention to the Least Thing" consists of nothing more than a tidy lineup of two circles, a cube, an upright pole and a mantra-like inscription ("In me is God, I am in God"). And another, titled "The Realm of Angels," is just a small white circle intersected by a curving two-toned line whose yellow half points up and green half points down.
Occult stuff-and-nonsense? Mondrian, Kandinsky and a host of other early modernist artists apparently didn't think so. Nor did a more recent figure like Joseph Beuys, who produced his own blackboard drawings on the Steiner model and was particularly absorbed in the social and ethical implications of Steiner's thought. (Drawings by Beuys are on view at CRG Gallery in SoHo through tomorrow.)
But these days any talk about "the spiritual in art" tends to make everyone squirm a little. And Beuys, with his roots deep in German Romanticism, has always met with an uneasy reception in this country. (A panel discussion titled "Beuys and Spirituality" held at the New School three years ago elicited some virulent anti-Beuysian sentiments from its American participants.)
And yet the impulse to seek a content in art that amounts to something beyond yet another new twist on yesterday's new twist continues to find adherents. The programmatic philosophy that spawned Steiner's blackboard drawings may attract a limited audience. But the drawings themselves, with their modest formal beauties tied to an ambitious vision, offer a kind of art -- an uncool, un-Duchampian esthetic, let's call it, one often associated with "outsider art" today -- that will have its appeal.
"Rudolf Steiner: Blackboard Drawings, 1919-1924" remains at the Peter Blum Gallery, 99 Wooster Street, SoHo, through March 21.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A 1923 blackboard drawing by Rudolf Steiner, at Peter Blum Gallery. (Peter Blum Gallery)

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 14; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 1533 words

HEADLINE: AT THE MOVIES

BYLINE: By Bernard Weinraub 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, March 12

 BODY:

From Fantasy To Opening Day
Eight years ago, Richard Kwietniowski, a British filmmaker, visited a bookstore and bought a new novel, "Love and Death on Long Island," by Gilbert Adair.
"I read a review that said it was at a certain level about the power of cinema, and I was drawn to it immediately," said Mr. Kwietniowski (kuh-SEE-et-nee-ahv-skee). "That night I gave it a little glance and didn't put it down until the last page. I was already fantasizing about turning it into a film." 
 The fantasy has turned into a highly acclaimed reality. The film, written and directed by Mr. Kwietniowski (above), a 40-year-old television director and independent filmmaker, opened in New York and Los Angeles last Friday to some of the best reviews in months; it is opening in other cities today. It stars John Hurt, the veteran British actor, as a reclusive widower and "man of letters" who sees an American teen-age movie by accident and becomes obsessed with the star of the film, played by Jason Priestley, best known for the Fox television series "Beverly Hills 90210." The Hurt character flies to Long Island to meet the teen-age star.
Although the comedy, which cost about $4 million, may have overtones of "Death in Venice" and "Lolita," it's also about the power of film. "I loved the idea of someone like the John Hurt character going to the cinema for the first time in 20 years and being completely struck by a bolt from the blue which will drastically alter everything about his existence," Mr. Kwietniowski said. "I have a certain investment in believing that can and does happen."
The film is also about obsession. "It's about someone who's obsessed with probably the least appropriate person in the world," he said.
Although Mr. Kwietniowski spent several weeks traveling around Long Island for the film, the movie's beach scenes, set in the Hamptons, were shot in Nova Scotia, Canada, because it was cheaper. "I took a lot of photos of Nova Scotia and showed it to Long Islanders, and they gave me license," he said. "I was also challenged by the idea of creating a Long Island rather than remaining enslaved to the real one. I'm not showing a definitive version of Long Island. I'm showing a Long Island that's a little quirky."
Although he's unknown in the United States, Mr. Kwietniowksi got his first choices as stars of the film, which received financing from companies in Britain, Canada and Italy. After reading the script, Mr. Hurt immediately agreed to appear. To Mr. Hurt, the film is about "the passionate pursuit of beauty, in a place where one would not expect to find it, leading to a discovery of love and life."
Mr. Kwietniowski flew to Los Angeles to seek out Mr. Priestley, who took the part largely because the script was so different from formulaic movies he is offered. "We're using Jason's status as a heartthrob, Mr. Kwietniowksi said, but the film allows him to be playful with that image. He's a very good sport."
The filmmaker said he had been receiving new scripts from Hollywood but was unsure about his next project. "Nobody is terribly interested in me in Britain," he said. "I'm a bit of a square peg in a round hole. When we tried to get the film off the ground, we were told it was too ambitious. The British are a bit nervous about obsession and desire. Most British films look inward towards the past or are about some economic situation. They don't build bridges across oceans and engage other cultures."
His outsider status in Britain, Mr. Kwietniowski said, is partly because of his upbringing. Although he was born in London, his father, Leszek, a violinist, was Polish-born.
"I grew up with a slightly detached relationship to British culture," Mr. Kwietniowksi said. "I still don't play cricket."
 
Obsession, Again
 Wendy Wasserstein has spent her career in the theater, but this Pulitzer Prize-winning author of "The Heidi Chronicles" and other plays has long had a not-so-secret obsession: the screenplay adaptation of the Stephen McAuley novel "The Object of My Affection."
"I've been working on it for the last 10 years, off and on; I've gone back to it again 10 times," Ms. Wasserstein (above) said. "Barry Diller a few years ago said that someday someone will make that movie, and I'll have nothing to do for the rest of my life."
Someone finally made the movie.
The comedy-drama, to be released on April 17 by 20th Century Fox, was directed by Nicholas Hytner ("The Madness of King George" and "The Crucible") and is set in New York. The film is a contemporary love story about the blurred lines separating love, sex and friendship, starring Jennifer Aniston as a social worker who falls in love with a gay teacher played by Paul Rudd.
What consumed Ms. Wasserstein about the story? "It was actually in a way a girl falling in love with the wrong guy," she said. And then she laughed. "It had nothing to do with my own experience."
Ms. Wasserstein said: "Falling in love with the wrong guy is a habit of mine. And what really moved me about this story was that it was ultimately about friendship and the nature of friendship as well as romantic friendship. The love between a straight woman and a gay man also interested me."
Ms. Wasserstein has written several unproduced screenplays, and adapted "The Heidi Chronicles" as a made-for-television movie starring Jamie Curtis. She has also written for PBS. But her foray into making a studio film took some adjustment.
"The big difference is you can always fix a play, especially a comedy that's playing before an audience," she said. "You're trained to go home and rewrite. You figure out the texture of what's comedic in front of an audience. In films, you have no audience response."
But Ms. Wasserstein said that the experience of writing the script was almost more Broadway than Hollywood. She worked closely on revisions with Laurence Mark, the producer, and with Mr. Hytner, the British theatrical director who staged "Miss Saigon" and the National Theater production of "Carousel," which won five Tony Awards in 1994. "It was very much a collaboration, very much like putting on a play," she said. But still, she said, "screenwriting is very spare."
"In a play two people can sit down and say how unhappy they are, and they can talk for two hours with each one saying, 'I'm more unhappy than you,' and the other saying, 'Yeah, but let me tell you about my mother' " she said. "In a film, you literally have to move from scene to scene, you have to pare everything down. The emphasis is on telling the story, moving it forward."
"What I learned is that you can learn something about a character in a film by going in on them with a camera," she said. "Nick would always say, 'We can show this; you don't have to say it.' I tend to get too chatty." (She is now starting work on a new play.)
Ms. Wasserstein said the Hollywood system of hiring writers to rewrite each other -- which did not happen with this movie -- puzzled her. "It happens all the time: they bring in one writer because he's funny and another writer because she's good on character and a third writer because the star wants him," Ms. Wasserstein said. "In a play, there's the voice of one author. You don't bring in Edward Albee to fix an Arthur Miller play."
 
Best Supporting Joke
Bruce Vilanch is happy. A top comedy writer who helps write the Oscar show, Mr. Vilanch says this year's 70th Annual Academy Awards, on March 23 at 9 P.M. on ABC, will inevitably lure a bigger television audience than last year's show.
"Last year it was, let's face it, Tom Cruise and a bunch of other people," said Mr. Vilanch (above), a cherubic fellow who wears pink-rimmed spectacles and has a perennial halo of out-of-control hair. "People hadn't heard of Brenda Blethyn or Geoffrey Rush. These were not box office names and their faces were unrecognizable. Many people hadn't seen the movies that were nominated. This year, who hasn't seen 'Titanic'? And all the other films are big hits. And you have stars who were nominated -- Nicholson, Hoffman, Robin Williams, Duvall, Helen Hunt, Julie Christie, Burt Reynolds. It's just much more fun."
The jokes by the master of ceremonies, Billy Crystal, as well as the patter by the presenters -- often the most laborious moments at the Oscars -- are, of course, carefully written by about a dozen writers.
Few subjects are considered off-limits for the Oscar show, Mr. Vilanch said. But he added: "There's stuff that you can do on Leno or Letterman that's inappropriate for the Oscars. It is, after all, an awards ceremony, and for many people the pinnacle of their careers. What you say at the Academy Awards can stay with you for the rest of your life. It never leaves you. Just ask Sally Field." (When Ms. Field picked up her Oscar in 1984 as best actress for "Places in the Heart," her acceptance speech included these lines: "I can't deny the fact you like me. Right now, you like me!")
During the show, Mr. Vilanch said, the writers are busily revising material, largely because the unpredictable -- remember Jack Palance's push-ups? -- often takes place. "We try to stay sober until the show is over," he said.

HEADLINE: Indian Success Story

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your March 8 front-page article "New Prosperity Brings New Conflict to Indian Country" implies that every gain by Indians is a non-Indian loss. For an example of how Indians and other Americans can prosper together, consider the Mississippi Band of Choctaws. 
 During two decades of solid business growth (the Silver Star Resort and Casino is their latest success), the Choctaws have transformed Neshoba County, once infamous for poverty and racial violence, into an economic hothouse and model of interracial accord. Now one of the five largest employers in Mississippi, the Choctaws have created more jobs for non-Indians than for themselves. The tribe's members believe that economic progress has helped, rather than hurt, their cultural integrity.
 
ROBERT H. WHITE
Lawrenceville, N.J., March 9, 1998

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Hoechst Predicts No Gain in Profits

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, March 12

 BODY:
The chairman of Hoechst A.G., the German chemical company, said today that the company does not expect profits to increase this year, partly because of the Asian financial crisis.
Hoechst, which has seen business slow down during the first two months, faces a difficult year and foresees operating profits at "the same level as last year," said its chairman, Jurgen Dormann. 
 Last month, Hoechst reported an operating profit of 3.65 billion marks ($2.03 billion) for last year, down from 4.01 billion marks in 1996.
Hoechst will continue a reorganization, spinning off industrial chemical units into subsidiaries, Mr. Dormann said. It will also focus on such growing markets as pharmaceuticals, fertilizers, herbicides and immunizations, he said.
Ten percent of Hoechst shares are now owned by North Americans, up from 6 percent in September 1997, the company said. Hoechst made its debut on the New York Stock Exchange six months ago. The American depository receipts fell $2.1875 each today, to $38.6875.

HEADLINE: Consumers Lived It Up In January And February

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
Consumer spending began the year at a healthy pace after a disappointing holiday shopping season, the Government's latest data indicated today.
The Commerce Department said that retail sales rose half a percent in February, as unseasonably warm weather brought shoppers out early to buy spring clothes and garden supplies. And it revised January's sales data upward to show a gain of 1 percent, not the increase of only one-tenth of 1 percent that had been reported originally. 
 The January gain was the biggest in six months.
"It's a very strong report that says consumers are feeling pretty good," said Cynthia Latta, an economist with DRI-McGraw Hill of Lexington, Mass.
Most economists believe economic growth will slow significantly this year because of the effect of the Asian economic crisis. That expected weakness has not yet been felt widely, however. The Government reported last week, for instance, that the unemployment rate fell in February to 4.6 percent, returning to a 24-year low.
In a separate report today, the Labor Department said that new claims for unemployment benefits fell by 7,000 last week, to 298,000, a sign of continued strength in the labor market. The four-week average of claims, a less volatile measure, was 308,000, down 1,000 from the week earlier.
The February retail sales report showed that sales outside the auto sector rose six-tenths of 1 percent. That followed a revised 1.3 percent surge in January, the biggest gain in almost two years.
Auto sales alone grew one-tenth of 1 percent in February after having declined two-tenths of 1 percent in January.
The warm weather in most parts of the country, caused by the climate-altering phenomenon El Nino, spurred strong demand for spring clothing, garden supplies and other hardware products. Sales at department stores and specialty stores rose a strong 1.3 percent on the heels of a 2.1 percent increase in January.Sales at service stations were down 1.1 percent, the biggest decline for any major category last month, reflecting a drop in gasoline prices because of an abundant world oil supply.

HEADLINE: '97 Current-Account Deficit Took a Jump

BYLINE: Bridge News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
The deficit in the United States current account, the broadest measure of foreign trade, jumped to its highest level in 10 years in 1997, the Commerce Department reported today.
The department said the gap in the current account widened to $166.4 billion, from $148.2 billion in 1996. The 1997 deficit, which amounted to 2.1 percent of gross domestic product, was the highest since the record deficit of $168.1 billion in 1987. 
 In the fourth quarter, the deficit widened to a record $45.6 billion from $43.1 billion in the third quarter.
The current account is the most important trade statistic because it measures investment flows as well as trade in goods and services. The trade reports that the Commerce Department issues monthly measure trade in goods and services only.
Economists have been forecasting that the nation's merchandise trade and current account deficits will rise in 1998 because the sharp currency devaluations in Asia will cut the cost of Asian imports while making it much more difficult for Asian economies to absorb exports from the United States.
At the same time, they expect that less expensive Asian imports, as well as low energy prices, will hold down inflationary pressures. Indeed, the Labor Department said in a separate report today that prices of American imports, excluding fuel, continued to decline in February -- the eighth consecutive month without a rise.
The price of imported goods apart from petroleum dropped three-tenths of 1 percent in the month.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Prices Up Sharply Despite 2 Strong Reports

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose sharply yesterday as investors apparently shrugged off concerns of inflation after several Government reports of economic strength.
Market participants said the buying was led by hedge funds and by central banks. The 30-year bond gained 12/32, to a price of 103 22/32, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 5.86 percent, from 5.94 percent on Wednesday and its lowest level in more than three weeks. 
 Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Asset Management, said that while the bond market continued to rally in part because it focused on the broader lack of inflationary pressure in the economy, looking beyond the strong reports yesterday on retail sales and jobless claims.
Retail sales rose half a percent in February, in line with expectations, but sales for January were revised upward strongly. And in the week ended March 7, initial claims for unemployment benefits fell to 298,000 from a revised 305,000 the week before.
Mr. Fine cited unusual weather conditions around the country, along with substantial tax refunds, as two possible reasons for the strength in consumption spending in the first quarter.
"More importantly," Mr. Fine said, "the buoyant consumer's robust spending has yet to produce an uplift in inflation."
The February Producer Price Index, to be released today, is expected to fall for the fourth consecutive month, and the Consumer Price Index, to be reported next week, is again expected to show little or no change.
In addition, Mr. Fine noted, both import and export prices continued to drop in February, and import prices are below those of a year ago, which puts downward pressure on prices of domestic goods. "Furthermore, given the adversity in Asia, this trend is not likely to reverse anytime soon, and that should keep the bond bulls bubbly," he said.
Edward S. Hyman and Nancy Lazar of the International Strategy and Investment Group, a money management firm, have told clients: "With oil down and the dollar up, U.S. inflation readings over the next few months are strongly biased to show improvements. We estimate March C.P.I. to have slowed to just a 1.3 percent year-over-year increase. Foreign C.P.I.'s already reported for February suggest a low U.S. reading for that month."

HEADLINE: Public Schools, Redefined

BYLINE: By Sue Halpern; Sue Halpern is the director of the Wilderness Community School and the author, most recently, of "Migrations to Solitude."

DATELINE: JOHNSBURG, N.Y.

 BODY:
There are days when, tired of arguing in favor of Gov. George Pataki's proposed charter-school legislation, I fantasize about moving to Scarsdale. How uncomplicated it would be to send my daughter off to a well-financed, energetic, successful local school while I, in good conscience, talked up the benefits of her public school education.
But I live in the Adirondacks, at the intersection of New York State's three poorest counties. Children are bused to a centralized K-12 public school with limited resources that is strained by state mandates dictating how those resources are spent. Until this year, school choice came down to sending our children to the central school or educating them at home. 
 This year, though, there was a third choice, a small, independent school that a few of us here made -- it feels like -- out of paper and glue. It, too, has limited resources: a tiny budget, no art or music teacher, no gym, no computer. We wanted to create a school where community service and hands-on experience in the natural world were integrated into a solid elementary curriculum.
It was not our intention to start a private school. All of us involved in this effort value public education. But public education did not value us; there was not enough room for our ideas within the public system, so we felt compelled to work outside it. Having done so, we have been gratified that many local teachers and administrators see us not as a threat but as a complement to their efforts in the public school.
The problem is that private schools charge admission. So in poor places like the Adirondacks, or like Ocean Hill or Bedford-Stuyvesant, nondenominational independent schools are beyond the reach of almost everyone. That's why they almost never exist in such neighborhoods.
We were lucky. A few foundations gave us enough money to ease the burden of tuition for a year. Most of our seven students receive substantial financial aid; if we had more money to give out, we would have more students.
It is unlikely that our luck will hold, and just as unlikely that others with good ideas, in other economically disenfranchised areas, will be so fortunate in the first place. That is why many people in rural areas and in inner-city neighborhoods like Brownsville and the South Bronx support Governor Pataki's efforts to charter independent schools.
It is also why Democratic state legislators from poor and minority districts are beginning to break ranks with their party to support the Governor's plan. Under his legislation, students would bring the average per-pupil expenditure of the school district with them to the school they wanted to attend.
Unlike vouchers, which are usually intended to allow students to apply public school money to private or parochial schools, this legislation would enable students to attend institutions that have been chartered by the Board of Regents, or perhaps a state chartering authority. The overseers would be able to insure that only schools with legitimate academic missions were approved. The effect would be to democratize educational opportunities in the state, which can only benefit children in underserved neighborhoods.
In my own underserved neighborhood, our Wilderness Community School was able -- because it is not a public school -- to hire two remarkable but uncertified teachers, both of them alumni of Teach for America, which sends recent college graduates to neglected areas. Governor Pataki's proposed legislation would allow teachers like ours and ideas like ours into state-financed classrooms. If traditional public schools then find themselves losing students, perhaps they will have the incentive and institutional support to reform. Chartering, rather than diminishing the public school system, promises to improve and expand it.
Last week, the Wilderness Community School had its end-of-the term open house, and all the students gave presentations. There was one on horses, one on George Washington Carver, one on a rare variety of ladyslipper. Afterward, I reminded my daughter that school would be on break for two weeks. "It's just not fair," she complained.
In a different way, I share her concern about fairness. On days when I don't dream of moving to Scarsdale, I allow myself to imagine a time when any child can choose to attend a school like ours. I hope that choice will still be available next year, and the year after -- all the way to the year when New York State has a strong school-charter law.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Quarterly Profit Falls Short At National Semiconductor

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, March 12

 BODY:
The National Semiconductor Corporation today reported earnings slightly below analysts' estimates for its most recent quarter, after warning last month that results would fall short of expectations. National said it expected a loss for the current quarter, after a further decline in revenue.
National's warning last month presaged a round of bad news for chip companies and their customers. Though different factors affected each company, bellwethers like the Intel Corporation, Motorola Inc., and the Compaq Computer Corporation subsequently reporting or warning of weaker-than-expected quarters. 
 National attributed its disappointing results to the Asian economic crisis and difficulties in increasing production of microprocessors at the Cyrix Corporation, which it acquired last year for about $550 million. Cyrix and its manufacturing partner, the International Business Machines Corporation, have not been able to meet demand for higher-speed versions of its chips, but National said today that it had begun its own production of these products at a plant in Portland, Me.
National shares closed today at $20.25, down 50 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. National reported the results after the close of the market.
For the fiscal third quarter, which ended on March 1, National reported earnings of $22.3 million, or 13 cents a share on a fully diluted basis, down from $200.2 million, or $1.02 a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. Revenues fell 9 percent, to $650.1 million, from $712.0 million in the third quarter of the 1997 fiscal year.
The results for the previous year's quarter include a one-time gain of $202 million from the sale of Fairchild Semiconductor in March 1997. Third-quarter 1998 results include a one-time charge of $5.2 million related to the acquisition of audio compression technology from the Gulbransen Corporation. Without the charge, National would have earned 16 cents a share; analysts expected the company to earn 17 cents a share, according to First Call.
National said that although overall orders recovered in February from their January levels, third-quarter orders still reflected uncertainty in some markets. Because orders in networking, wireless communications and personal computers remained weak, National said it now expected revenue to decline, and said a loss was likely for the fourth quarter.
"As a result of this uncertain business environment we are aggressively pursing cost reduction actions and obviously continuing to drive revenue growth for the future," Brian L. Halla, National's president and chief executive officer, said in a statement.
