HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Greenwich Condo Resuming Sales

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Originally designed as luxury condominiums, Old Greenwich Gables became a rental complex when the building boom of the 80's soured. Now the 167-unit development named for its area of Greenwich, Conn., has come full circle.
Sales of units resumed last month after the developer, Collins Enterprises of Old Greenwich, acquired the mortgage on the complex at 51 Forest Avenue for $23.5 million from the lender. YTB Leasing (America) Inc., a subsidiary of the Yasuda Trust and Banking Company of Tokyo, held a $70 million loan on the 12-building 7.6-acre project. 
 Construction began in 1989. Over the next three years, 50 apartments were built, with 40 being sold. The remaining 10 were rented. All but 17 of the 117 units built through 1995 were also rented.
That completed the 7.6-acre complex next to the Metro-North Commuter Railroad station in an area of narrow streets and tightly packed turn-of-the-century houses.
The president of Collins Enterprises, Arthur Collins 2d, said that with the lower mortgage, selling at competitive prices was "now doable." That, along with a strong market, supported the decision to resume sales, Mr. Collins said.
His company negotiated with YTB Leasing for nearly two years. The sale indicates that since 1996, the Yasuda Bank has been trying to leave such loans by this month. The policy is related to the financial difficulties of Japanese banks.
A YTB executive who spoke on condition of anonymity confirmed the reason for the sale, one of 40 such loans that the bank has sold in two years.
The financing to buy the mortgage is from an $18.2 million loan from the Manhattan office of Helaba Landesbank Hessen-Thuringen of Frankfurt, Germany. The rest came from the Apollo Fund, which invests in real estate worldwide, and Collins's equity.
"In securing new low-cost capital, Collins will be able to maintain an economic interest in and benefit from the sale of the units," said Steven A. Kohn, managing director at the Sonnenblick-Goldman Company, the real estate investment banking firm in Manhattan that arranged the bank financing for the Old Greenwich Gables loan.
Mr. Kohn said a steady flow of such loan sales would continue for at least two years as Japanese banks and other Asian lenders liquidated their real estate assets in the United States.
At Old Greenwich Gables, Mr. Collins said, his company plans a $1.5 million renovation, including $5,000 to $15,000 to refurbish each of the unsold one- to three-bedroom units as they become available. The units, with 911 to 2,400 square feet on one or two floors, are in three-story buildings grouped around courtyards and brick walkways.
The company also plans to improve common areas like the 229-car underground garage and the walkways at the complex, whose amenities include a health club and an outdoor pool. Monthly maintenance is $200 to $515.
In the month since the purchase, 10 vacant units have been sold, for $250,000 to $575,000, Mr. Collins said, noting that the prices are about the same as the original prices.
Gary and Judy Miller recently sold a one-bedroom unit with a loft that they had owned at the complex since 1994 and are buying a larger unit that they have been renting elsewhere in the complex. The Millers plan to close on their unit at the end of the month.
"We always believed that the condominium because of its location would hold its value," Mr. Miller, a member of the condo association, said. "We are not looking for the same appreciation single-family detached homes are achieving. But values are moving north, and we are very comfortable with that."
Robert S. Curtis, who runs a real estate firm with his name in Greenwich, said the local market was benefiting from the improvement in the New York metropolitan region market and renewed interest from buyers like professional couples and those with "empty nests" who want the maintenance-free living.
According to the Residential Data Base Reference, which reports on housing sales in Greenwich, the average sales price of the 212 condominiums sold last year was $385,000. By comparison, the average for the 171 units sold in 1996 was $344,800. In 1989, the average was $382,300.
The market for single-family housing, including condominiums "is active and edging toward a seller's market," said Laurel A. Dove, manager of the Greenwich office of Coldwell Banker, the realty company.

HEADLINE: I.R.S. Has Sent Out More in Tax Refunds

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
The Treasury Department has sent out 11.3 percent more in tax refunds this year than in the corresponding time last year, providing a potential push for the economy in the first quarter.
The Internal Revenue Service reported today that it sent taxpayers $45.02 billion in refunds through last Friday, up from $40.46 billion in the corresponding period last year. 
 The rise could lead to increased consumer spending, which makes up about two-thirds of the overall economy, during the first three months of 1998, analysts said. "It might explain in part the strength that took place in retail sales activity" in February, said Lynn Reaser, an economist at Nationsbank in Jacksonville, Fla.
The faster consumers get their refund money, the more likely they are to spend it, which suggests growth in the second quarter could slow, analysts said.
Consumers are speeding up the tax-refund process by filing their taxes over the telephone and through computers. The number of individuals using the phone to file their taxes has risen 25.2 percent so far this tax season to 4.38 million from 3.5 million in the similar period in 1997.
The number of taxpayers sending their tax forms by computer has risen 21.8 percent in 1998 to 13.31 million from 10.92 million. The I.R.S. is also sending out slightly larger refund checks. The average refund is $1,450 so far this year, up from $1,418.

HEADLINE: Thais Expected to End $392 Million Boeing Deal

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
The United States has agreed to allow Thailand to cancel its purchase of eight F/A-18 fighter jets because of Thailand's economic crisis, Administration officials said today.
The decision to cancel the $392 million deal is to be announced on Friday, when Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai is to meet President Clinton here, the officials said. 
 Thailand, which has already paid $72 million, faces another $100 million payment by the end of the month to the planes' manufacturer, the Boeing Company. It is not clear what effect cancellation of the sale will have on Boeing, but one official said the Administration hoped Thailand would resume purchases once its economy recovers its footing.
Thailand's inability to pay for the planes underscored the extent to which the economic crises that have swept southeast Asia have curbed a budding regional arms buildup, which has pitted American arms makers against European and Russian companies. Malaysia, Indonesia and South Korea have all announced cuts in military spending, including purchases from the United States.
Thailand is one of the oldest American allies in southeast Asia, and the decision to allow it to break a contract showed the Administration's desire to maintain good ties. Relations have been strained somewhat by Thai perceptions that Washington was slow to respond to its economic crisis.
Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen was in Thailand in January and, after meeting Mr. Chuan and other officials, pledged to help Thailand renegotiate the purchase. Although Boeing makes the planes, Thailand bought them directly from the Pentagon. They were due to be delivered next year.
At their meeting in January, Mr. Chuan asked the United States either to keep the F/A-18's or to find another country willing to buy them. American forces cannot use the planes because they are an export model incompatible with those in the American arsenal.

HEADLINE: U.S. Says It Might Consider Attacking Serbs

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
Clinton Administration officials raised the possibility today that the United States would consider a military attack on Serbian forces if diplomatic efforts failed to stop human rights abuses in the province of Kosovo.
The Administration announced that it was also weighing whether to enlarge an American-led United Nations peacekeeping force in Macedonia because of fears that the crisis in neighboring Kosovo could spin out of control. 
 "We want to use every appropriate instrument at hand," Robert Gelbard, President Clinton's special envoy to the Balkans, said when asked at a Congressional hearing whether the United States might consider military strikes against Serbian police and paramilitary units that have been blamed for dozens of killings in Kosovo in the last 10 days.
Mr. Gelbard said the United States would first try to end human rights abuses against the ethnic Albanian majority in Kosovo through "every possible economic sanction or other kind of tool we have diplomatically, but we're not ruling anything out."
Another senior official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said a military attack on Serbian forces involved in the Kosovo crackdown was a distinct possibility, although "not likely." He added, "It's a useful threat to have out there."
Officials said the State Department and the Pentagon were considering whether to update a diplomatic warning that was first issued by President Bush in December 1992.
In a letter then to President Slobodan Milosevic, Mr. Bush said the United States was prepared to use force against the Serbs if they tried to drive ethnic Albanians from Kosovo, a province in which Serbs are a small minority.
An Administration official involved in American policy in the Balkans said that while the United States had not drawn up any contingency plans for an attack on the Serbs, "the United States view remains the same as it was in December 1992 -- that we're not going to sit back and accept a major Serb military operation in Kosovo."
The State Department charged this week that Mr. Milosevic's Government was engaging in "ethnic cleansing" in Kosovo and said today that a Serbian overture to negotiate with the ethnic Albanians there was a "propaganda exercise."
"It seems like the Belgrade authorities are proposing things that are designed to fail," James P. Rubin, the department's spokesman, said after Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright met with her senior advisers to discuss Kosovo.
Mr. Rubin said the Serbian offer for talks "consisted in large part of a justification for the use of force in Kosovo and contained no hint of remorse for the deaths of innocent Albanian victims."
The State Department also said today that the United Nations force of 700 American and Scandinavian peacekeeping soldiers in the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia might be enlarged. Ethnic Albanians in Macedonia have vowed to back Kosovo's struggle for independence.
The State Department also announced that Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott would travel next week to Macedonia, Albania, Slovenia and other neighbors of Kosovo to discuss responses to Mr. Milosevic's actions in the province.
Mr. Gelbard, in his appearance today before the House International Relations Committee, was asked to explain remarks he made in Belgrade, only days before the first Serbian attacks on Kosovo. At that time Mr. Gelbard described the outlawed Kosovo Liberation Army, which was the target of Serbian paramilitary forces during the recent turmoil, as a terrorist organization.
In his comments on Feb. 23, Mr. Gelbard said that the Kosovo Liberation Army "is, without any questions, a terrorist group" and that "we condemn very strongly terrorist activities in Kosovo." Spokesmen for the Serbian Government have seized upon his remarks as a justification for the crackdown in Kosovo.
Questioned by lawmakers today on whether he still considered the group a terrorist organization, Mr. Gelbard said that while it has "committed terrorist acts," it has "not been classified legally by the U.S. Government as a terrorist organization."
And whatever the activities of the separatists, who have claimed responsibility for a series of attacks on Serbian targets, Mr. Gelbard said the blame for the violence in Kosovo rested squarely with the Government of Mr. Milosevic.
"Unfortunately and tragically, terrorist acts have occurred, and they have provided an excuse for Milosevic here," he said. "But, as I said, there is no question at all that the overwhelming, brutal, repressive, despicable violence -- the criminal actions, I believe, committed by the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia here -- are responsible for the tragedy we have at hand right now."

HEADLINE: 2 Polk Awards for Journalism To New York Times Reporters

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

 BODY:
Reporters for The New York Times have won two 1997 George Polk Awards for excellence in journalism for their articles on allegations of corruption at the nation's largest private hospital chain and safety concerns surrounding light trucks and sport utility vehicles.
Kurt Eichenwald and Martin Gottlieb of The Times won the award for business reporting for their series of articles on allegations of fraud, overcharging, conflicts of interest and other practices at Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation. 
 With the aid of computer analyses, Mr. Eichenwald and Mr. Gottlieb raised questions about the company and how it purchased hospitals and charged the Government for its Medicare patients. Their reports prompted indictments, lawsuits and a corporate reorganization.
Keith Bradsher, Detroit bureau chief for The Times, won the Polk Award for national reporting for his investigation into the human and financial toll sport utility vehicles and light trucks take on the nation's roadways. Mr. Bradsher linked an increase in air pollution to the vehicles, which were exempt from federal emissions standards, and documented the inordinate amount of deaths related to the vehicles.
In all, journalists from 13 American news organizations were recipients of the awards, established in 1949 in memory of George W. Polk, a CBS News correspondent who was killed 50 years ago while covering the civil war in Greece. Formal presentation of the awards, which are administered by Long Island University, will be on April 15 in Manhattan.
A career award was given to The Pittsburgh Courier, a prominent newspaper that for nearly 50 years has been covering affairs of special interest to African Americans. It is the first time in the history of the Polk Awards that the career award is being presented to a publication rather than an individual.
The award for foreign reporting went to Laurie Garrett of Newsday for her 25-part series on rampant tuberculosis and AIDS in the former Soviet Union. She showed how a nearly bankrupt economy and poor environmental decisions have led to hundreds of thousands of deaths.
The other categories and winners:
INTERNATIONAL Michael Dobbs of The Washington Post for documenting the Jewish roots of Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, whose parents hid her past from her even though much of the family died in Nazi concentration camps.
MAGAZINE Adam Gopnik of The New Yorker for his dispatches from Paris.
SPORTS The Kansas City Star for its reports of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's poor enforcement record and its executives' expensive taste for perks.
BOOK AWARD Horst Faas and Tim Page for "Requiem," a tribute to 135 photographers who died covering wars in Southeast Asia from 1950 to 1975. It is Mr. Faas's third Polk Award.
ENVIRONMENTAL Will Englund, Gary Cohn and Perry Thorsvik of The Baltimore Sun for "Shipbreakers," their series on the safety hazards faced by poorly trained ship workers.
LOCAL REPORTING The Pensacola News Journal for "Pensacola's Brownsville Revival: The money and the Myths," which exposed skullduggery at a local revival.
MEDICAL The Wall Street Journal for its report linking over-the-counter diet drugs to lethal side effects.
MILITARY AFFAIRS The Dayton Daily News for "Unnecessary Danger," a series about the military's protection of incompetent physicians.
NETWORK TELEVISION ABC News's "Prime Time Live" for "Blood Money," an expose on black-market trafficking in human body parts from Chinese prisoners and sold in the United States.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Some Stock Indexes Set Records, but Dow Slips
After most major stock gauges stumbled at the start of the trading day yesterday, they reversed course with help from strong economic news and indications that the robust demand for shares seems to be continuing. Those factors helped send the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index up another 1.45 points, to 1,069.92, its third consecutive record high. 
 Smaller stocks participated, too. The Russell 2000 index of smaller-company stocks also set a record, gaining 0.65 point, to close at 467.77, its second consecutive high. But the Dow Jones industrial average fell 16.19 points, to 8,659.56. Page D8.
 
Prices of Treasury securities increased, sending the yield on the 30-year bond plummeting to 5.86 percent, its lowest level in more than three weeks. D8.
 
Money Rolled Into Funds in February
Stock mutual funds attracted an estimated net $19.5 billion last month, exceeding the net $14.6 billion put into them in January. But the story was different for bond funds, which lured an estimated net $8.5 billion in February, down from $11.3 billion in January. D8.
 
Gates Working on a Second Book
William H. Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, has quietly approached several New York publishers about writing a new book intended to showcase his talents as a technologist and counter the image that his company is a monopolistic predator. Unlike his first book, "The Road Ahead," which was aimed at general readers, the new book would be intended for the company's millions of business customers. D4.
 
Retail Sales Rise
Retail sales rose half a percent in February, as warm weather brought shoppers out. January's sales data were also revised upward to show a gain of 1 percent. D4.
 
F.C.C. Approves Ratings System
The Federal Communications Commission has approved the ratings system agreed to last year by broadcasters, parent advocacy groups and the Motion Picture Association of America. Now television manufacturers must begin making sets with the V-chip, which provides the ability to block programs according to the ratings codes. A16.
 
Korea's Liquidity Crisis Eases
South Korea and international banks successfully have converted enough of the country's short-term foreign debt into long-term debt to ease a liquidity crisis. D2.
 
A Big Turnaround at Oracle
Oracle reported a sharp gain in its quarterly earnings, exceeding analysts' estimates. The performance was a sharp turnaround from weak results reported in December. D4.
 
National Semiconductor reported quarterly earnings slightly below analysts' estimates and said it expected a loss in the current quarter. D4.
 
Japanese Pump Money Into Banks
The Japanese Government agreed to put 1.42 trillion yen, or nearly $11 billion, into 17 banks in an effort to restore confidence in the debt-burdened financial system. D2.
 
The Return of the Bug
The campaign for the original version of the Volkswagen Beetle, sold in the United States from 1949 to 1979, is widely considered the best ever created for a consumer product. With the Bug's return, can lightning strike twice? Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D6.
 
Nicotine Tinkering at Reynolds
A former top manager at R. J. Reynolds Tobacco secretly told Federal regulators in 1994 that the company manipulated nicotine levels in some products to give them more "oomph" and "pizazz." A13.

HEADLINE: Experiment in Private Fire Protection Fails for a Westchester Village

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

DATELINE: RYE BROOK, N.Y., March 12

 BODY:
Two years ago, this prosperous village in Westchester County drew national attention when it became the first municipality in the heavily unionized Northeast to hire a private company to provide fire protection.
This week, three months after a $1 million home was destroyed by a fire, there was a verdict of sorts on privatization: Rye Brook decided to part with the private company and hire its own firefighters. "It was not a success," the Mayor, Salvatore M. Cresenzi, said in an interview today. 
 The story of Rye Brook's experiment with privatization, officials here say, is full of lessons for other communities attracted to businesses that promise efficiency in the delivery of essential services.
"I think people are going to tread very carefully on the privatization of public safety," said the Westchester County Executive, Andrew Spano. "You have a responsibility to protect the citizens of your jurisdiction."
In recent years, privatization -- the hiring of profit-making enterprises to run public services -- has been the most talked-about idea in local governments. There have been some successes, like the management of municipal sports arenas and convention centers. And there have been some notable failures, like the cancellation of contracts with a private company to run the public schools in Hartford and Baltimore.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York City has talked about privatization, but he has yet to bring about any large-scale change in this area.
With municipalities everywhere struggling to contain costs, business executives who have promised to show political leaders how to manage such core services as fire protection have drawn special notice. When Rye Brook decided in 1996 to hire Rural Metro Corporation of Scottsdale, Ariz., to provide fire protection, the deal was presented as a test of whether the idea could work in the densely populated Northeast.
For decades, some Western cities and suburbs have used privately owned fire departments. But those areas often lack the firefighter unions and the long traditions of professional and volunteer fire departments that exist in the New York region.
Executives of Rural Metro, a publicly traded company that is the largest of a dozen private providers of fire protection in the country, had described the deal here as an experiment with national import. In a 1996 interview, Martin A. Yenawine, a company vice president, was quoted in the Central New York Business Journal as saying, "If it can happen in the New York City area, it can happen anywhere."
But from the start, the arrival of the profit-making company encountered resistance that sometimes included protests, threats and vandalism.
Officials here say there were many causes of Rural Metro's problems, including hostility from unionized firefighters across the New York region who conducted a campaign intended to make residents of Rye Brook fear that they were being inadequately protected by the company. There was also hostility from volunteer firefighters who saw the company as a threat to old social traditions in many small towns.
For firefighters everywhere, the arrival of the company was a fundamental threat, said Anthony Pagano, president of the Yonkers chapter of the International Association of Firefighters, a union. "People might say, 'Maybe it's better that we go cheaper,' " Mr. Pagano said today. "But, you know, bean counters are counting beans, while we are fighting fires. That's dangerous to firefighters."
Perhaps the biggest challenge to the privatization experiment was the bitter dispute that the arrangement set off between Rye Brook and the neighboring village of Port Chester. The feud aggravated old divisions between the wealthy village of Rye Brook, most of whose residents are white, and Port Chester, with its more racially diverse and blue-collar population.
Before Rye Brook decided to hire a private company, it paid Port Chester $725,000 a year to provide fire protection. The amount was almost half of Port Chester's fire budget.
Although Rye Brook officials had not expected any short-term savings with Rural Metro, they had hoped to gain a more effective firefighting service by acquiring control of firefighters and having firefighting equipment within the village.
 In what Mayor Cresenzi said was an effort to sabotage the experiment here, Port Chester said it would not to respond to calls for help from the private Rye Brook firefighters.
Mayor Cresenzi said that the resistance from firefighters and the difficulties with Port Chester were obstacles to making privatization work. "We thought it was the best for Rye Brook," he said bitterly. "Other jurisdictions said, 'No way,' and they tried to undermine it and make sure it failed. That's what we were up against."
The Port Chester fire chief, William M. Barnes, acknowledged that he was ordered by village officials not to respond to calls from Rye Brook. He said there were safety and financial reasons, but he declined to comment further. Port Chester's Mayor, Christine A. Korff, did not respond to telephone messages that were left with her secretary.
Kurt M. Krumperman, Rural Metro's regional president for the Northeast, said one effect of the debate was that the company had difficulty keeping the on-call reserve firefighters that it relied on to supplement the nine full-time firefighters.
He said people who took the $5.50-an-hour reserve jobs were subjected to pressure from opponents. "The fact is that we are a for-profit company," Mr. Krumperman said, "and that was just not well-received in the communities surrounding Rye Brook."
The reserve firefighters living near Rye Brook kept resigning because of the pressure, Mr. Krumperman said, and the company was forced to look farther and farther away to maintain adequate staffing.
Mayor Cresenzi said Rural Metro had promised that at least 25 reserve firefighters would respond to emergencies.
These nagging problems turned into a crisis during the fire at the $1 million house on Rocking Horse Trail last December. Six full-time firefighters responded. But instead of the 25 reserve firefighters, there were only three. Port Chester did not respond to calls for help.
Mayor Cresenzi said that a crowd gathered at the fire, and that its members seemed to include firefighters from neighboring communities who were willing to let the fire burn to prove a point. He said he heard someone in the crowd say, "Let the Jews burn," which he took to be a sign of the generalized animosities between the village and some of its neighbors. The residents of the house were not Jewish.
No people were injured, but the contract with Rural Metro was fatally injured.
The owner of the house filed papers indicating an intention to sueRye Brook, Rural Metro and Port Chester, accusing them of inadequate fire protection. The company and village officials say that even a fully staffed department could not have prevented the damage because the 911 call was made when the fire was already well under way.
But with anxieties here rising, the village trustees quickly gave the company 60 days to provide adequate reserve staffing. Last Monday, the company notified the board that it could no longer promise to supply the required firefighters and recommended that the village return to a municipal department.
On Tuesday, Rye Brook announced that it would move toward a village fire department over the next six months.
Mr. Krumperman of Rural Metro said the experience had taught his company a lesson about private fire protection in this area of the country, where hostility to privatization is high. "You have to pay attention to those kinds of acceptance issues," he said, "and how surrounding communities will relate."
Instead of the ambitious plans it talked about a few years ago, he said, Rural Metro is now concentrating in this part of the country on supplying for-profit fire protection merely as a supplement to government-run fire departments.
To some experts on privatization, Rye Brook's experience is an example of how economic efficiency may not always be all that people want from their government services.
Robert W. Bailey, a professor of public policy at Rutgers University in Camden, said that in many community fire departments, there are social and union traditions that may be considered valuable, but that a corporate vendor may not understand. Officials should be skeptical of privatization of services like fire protection, Mr. Bailey said. Basic municipal services, he said, "are associated with cultural and political values."

HEADLINE: Where Landlords Learn;
Some Property Owners Choose School Over Fines

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
The teacher raised his hands and pleaded for calm: "Hold on! Let's catch our breath here, people!"
But the student in front was determined to finish his account of being menaced with a kitchen knife. Two classmates were laughing at him. A fourth student launched into a full-throated attack against human nature and the evils of bureaucracy and marched angrily out of the room. "I have a bad heart," she yelled from the hallway. "I've got to cool down." 
 In almost any other classroom, someone would have been in big trouble. But this was Landlord School, and the 25 New York City landlords who had gathered in the basement of a Brooklyn bank were already in big trouble.
Sometime this winter, city housing inspectors found that they were not providing their tenants with heat or hot water or both, one of the most serious violations of city housing law. Instead of paying a fine, though, the landlords had chosen an unusual out: they were going to school and learning to be better landlords.
In a city of more than four million renters, it might sound like the stuff of fantasy, a tenement morality tale from the pages of Bernard Malamud.
But the experimental program, begun in January 1997 and confined for now to Brooklyn, has produced real results: None of the 100 landlords who took the nine-hour course last winter have been cited for denying tenants heat or hot water so far this winter.
"They're not the people you think of when you think of a slumlord," said Anne Pasmanick, who runs the Community Training and Resource Center, a tenant advocacy group that created the program with the help of the courts, landlord groups and the city. "These are people, for the most part, who are not malicious, but just ignorant and struggling themselves. And when they get fined, they usually just get mad. The fines don't make them say, 'What can I do to solve the problem?' "
Those who have passed through the class, officially known as the Landlord Training Program, are certainly not a casting agent's idea of slick New York City landlords. Most have full-time jobs apart from real estate and spend nights and weekends attending to the intricacies of boilers, breaker switches, clogged toilets and leaky roofs.
Nearly two-thirds of the landlords were born outside the United States and many are recent immigrants who have a hard time with English. Their tenants tend to be recent immigrants themselves, many of them working class or poor.
Also, the class is open only to small-time landlords who own fewer than 20 apartments, a group that has long been on the economic ropes, struggling with worn-down buildings, low rents and what they contend are crushing taxes and regulations. Citywide, the group is essential to the affordable housing market: according to 1996 Census Bureau figures, perhaps as many as half a million people live in buildings of this size.
But when asked, almost all the landlords in the class swear that if they were given a chance to go back and invest the money elsewhere residential real estate would be nowhere on the list. "Are you kidding?" asked Kwei Yang, a nurse in her late 40's who owns two buildings on tough streets in East New York. "I had no idea what I was getting into. It has turned my hair gray."
That is not to say, however, that the landlords are the innocent victims they often portray themselves to be. While they are all first-time offenders of the heat and hot water laws, a survey of last winter's class of 100 landlords found that more than half the owners had at least 30 violations recorded against their buildings, ranging from faulty wiring to broken windows to roach and mice infestations.
And there is a good chance that many of the landlords have not fixed these problems. In spot checks of repairs, the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development has found that landlords lie about correcting violations in about 35 percent of the cases.
Many owners also readily admit to being active participants in the landlord-tenant duels that have become as ritualized in New York City as Kabuki theater. "There was this one guy who came up to me and said, 'I turned off the heat and hot water,' " Ms. Pasmanick of the tenant advocacy group recalled. "He said, 'I wanted to get these people out of there, and this is how I did it.' No qualms about doing it. Or saying it."
More often, though, the owners simply do not know how to run their buildings, a fact that led the city's largest landlords' group, the Rent Stabilization Association, into a rare alliance with the tenant advocates to promote the program.
"Everybody thinks you're an automatic maven, an expert, when you buy a building," said Joseph Strasburg, president of the landlord group. "It's just not the case."
On a recent night in landlord class, the students were amazed, for example, to hear that apartments consume almost twice as much energy as the average American house, because they are generally overheated. Many had never considered that when their fuel-oil salesman is also their boiler repairman the potential for finagling exists, or that many of their shower heads still spout 6 gallons of water a minute instead of 2.5 gallons, the Federal standard.
"This item alone could cut your fuel bill for hot water in half," said Andrew Padian, an energy efficiency expert who addressed the class.
The landlords listened with rapt attention until the discussion turned to their relationships with tenants, at which point they angrily insisted that they could teach the tenant advocates a thing or two.
Kevin Ryan, an advocate who taught the class, tried to head off the barrage of horror stories. "I've heard them all; every story you could think of," he said. "I heard about the tenant who put cement in the toilet to stop it up; the landlord who deliberately put rats in the apartment to drive the tenant out. There's nothing you can tell me I haven't heard."
But it did not stop his students from trying. Throughout the class, Daniel Sigueacia, an Ecuadorean immigrant who owns a six-family building in Ridgewood, Brooklyn, recounted how he had been attacked by tenants with knives and how he had offered one particularly troublesome tenant $1,800 to move out.
Ms. Yang, the nurse, told of the ex-convict tenant who broke into a vacant building and stole every inch of copper pipe.
When the subject of heating bills came up, Emmanuel Wu, an immigrant from Taiwan who owns buildings in Williamsburg, shouted: "The tenants want it like a nursery in the building! They want to burn up your money one way or the other."
The class briefly threatened to devolve into "The Jerry Springer Show" when Shirley White, a grandmother who owns a six-family building in East Flatbush, began castigating the people who landed her in the class: the tenants who reported her and the housing inspectors who cited her building.
"I've been there since 1970, and nobody has ever called the inspector on me," said Ms. White, flailing her arms and trembling. "I have four generations living in that building who are my family. We don't freeze. You walk into my building -- everybody's got shorts on."
After the class, Mr. Ryan pressed his fingers to his temples and said, "They don't learn much when everybody's yelling, but I think it helps -- kind of like group therapy."
While the class has been praised by housing advocates, landlords and those who oversee the chaotic housing courts, its future is uncertain. So far, three private philanthropies -- the Edna McConnell Clark Foundation, the Uris Brothers Foundation and the Banker's Trust Company Foundation -- have paid for the pilot program. The program has cost about $46,000 a year and has trained 125 landlords with the help of the Cornell University Cooperative Extension Program, which advises building managers in low-income neighborhoods.
But the philanthropies say it should be the role of city government to continue the classes, and they have not pledged support beyond this year.
Officials with the Department of Housing Preservation and Development -- who have run a similar but less intensive landlord class for the last three years -- have spoken favorably about the program. But they declined to say whether they would pay to continue it.
Justice Fern Fisher-Brandveen, administrative judge of the city's Civil Court, which oversees housing cases, said she would like to see the program expanded into Queens "because we have so many small owners and so many immigrants there who need it." At the very least, she said, it should be continued in Brooklyn, where its results have been encouraging. "It would be a real shame if it just went away."

HEADLINE: Balky Conservatives Block House Vote on Republican Anti-Abortion Measure

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
Fighting dissension in their own ranks, House Republican leaders today abruptly postponed a vote on legislation that was designed to display their resolve to link an anti-abortion provision to some of the President's chief foreign policy priorities.
Senior Republicans said the delay on a measure authorizing an array of State Department programs as well as nearly $1 billion in back dues to the United Nations did not represent second thoughts on abortion strategy. Instead it was triggered by a rebellion from a sizable band of conservatives who were unwilling to vote for payment of the dues owed to the United Nations. 
 "I've been amazed at the angst at the United Nations," said Representative Christopher H. Smith, the New Jersey Republican who is the author of the abortion restrictions.
Senior Republican aides said that the leadership would try to persuade the balky conservatives by next week to swallow their misgivings on the United Nations in favor of the anti-abortion cause. Anti-abortion groups were also lobbying for the legislation. "We're going to keep working it," Mr. Smith said.
Unless the conservatives drop their opposition, the State Department measure could prove impossible to pass in the House. Democrats are opposing it, as are Republicans who support abortion rights.
Republican leaders also faced problems on what had seemed like a simple, politically attractive bill to pay for troops in Bosnia and the Persian Gulf as well as storm damage at home. An array of Republicans lawmakers were demanding that other domestic programs be cut to offset the emergency spending.
Such a move would most likely provoke a confrontation with President Clinton. But Republican stalwarts said this would test of their seriousness about preserving fiscal discipline. "This, I believe, is the first test of our majority in the new age of balanced budgets," said Representative Jim Nussle, an Iowa Republican.
The abortion battle, too, appeared to be moving the Republicans and the President toward a high-stakes game of political brinksmanship.
Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, today implied that the President would veto any measure with the abortion restrictions even if he lost the money for United Nations dues or for the International Monetary Fund. Democratic leaders in both the House and Senate predicted there would be enough votes to sustain the veto.
Mr. Clinton has won politically in two similar showdowns when the Republicans forced a Government shutdown in 1995 and delayed disaster assistance to flood victims in 1997. But the public might be slower to rally to the President's side over financing for the I.M.F. to contain economic turmoil in Asia or over United Nations dues.
Each side today was gearing up to blame the other if the United States appeared crippled in its ability to play a world leadership role.
Mr. McCurry accused Republicans of looking to "play politics and to gum up the works" on urgent foreign policy needs. And Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said, "The I.M.F. is critical in terms of the world financial stability."
Congressional Democratic leaders also rallied to Mr. Clinton's side. Senator Tom Daschle, the minority leader, said it is "very difficult for us to ask the United Nations to follow our leadership when we're not willing to pay our dues."
And Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader, said Republicans were engaging in "an irresponsible act" by linking anti-abortion provisions to United Nations debt payment and aid to the I.M.F.
For their part, Republicans moved to portray Mr. Clinton as more committed to abortion than to critical elements of his foreign policy. "This should be a no-brainer for the President," said Representative Dick Armey, the House majority leader. "Is he really going to sacrifice his United Nations policy to continue a pro-abortion campaign abroad?"
The standoff is a replay of what happened last November when conservative Republicans insisted on tying a crucial spending bill for foreign affairs programs to a ban on providing money to international family-planning organizations that lobby against abortion restrictions.
When Mr. Clinton threatened to veto the spending bill, Republican leaders dropped the abortion language but also dropped the payments for the United Nations and the I.M.F. in order to placate Mr. Smith and other conservatives.
But that was before the financial crisis in Asia. Senior Administration officials had been lobbying hard in recent months to try to persuade the Republicans to move forward with at least the money for the I.M.F.

HEADLINE: SENATE'S MEASURE OFFERS COMMUTERS A BREAK IN TAXES

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
A little-noticed provision of a sweeping transportation bill adopted by the United States Senate yesterday would let employers give workers up to $65 a month in tax-free mass-transit benefits instead of salary. Experts said the plan could sharply cut the cost of train, bus and subway travel in the New York metropolitan region and across the country and possibly bring new surges in ridership and transit revenues.
The provision was part of a $214 billion measure to upgrade the nation's highways and transit systems over the next six years, one of the largest public works plans ever. Overcoming weeks of regional conflicts by expanding every state's financing -- and creating huge headaches for budget balancers -- the Senate voted overwhelmingly, 96 to 4, for the bill. 
 The measure calls for spending $171 billion on highway construction programs through 2003, $2 billion on transportation safety programs and $41.3 billion on mass transit. It would raise overall Federal transportation spending by nearly 40 percent, or $60 billion, compared with the previous six-year plan, which expired last year.
The House, which is considering an even more expensive bill, was expected to pass it in some form and send it to President Clinton before May 1, when the current spending law expires.
While the size and sweep of the legislation obscured much of its minutiae, advocates of mass transit in New York applauded the measure as holding out the promise of something for almost everybody: tax breaks and lower commuting costs for employees, tax savings and other incentives for employers, ridership and revenue increases for transit agencies, and yet more reasons for commuters to leave cars at home. Even car poolers could take advantage of the benefits.
The benefits would be made available through a program known in the New York area as Transitchek, a system of vouchers that employers can buy and make available to employees, who redeem them at token booths or ticket windows for commutation tickets, Metrocards or other fare-paying systems. While Transitcheks have been available for years, only 7,000 companies and 150,000 workers now participate.
Experts say the Transitchek program never caught on because employers by law could offer the vouchers only as part of a salary increase and because of limitations on the tax-free benefits.
The measure adopted yesterday contained provisions, largely shepherded by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, to rectify what he called the inequities. It would authorize employers to give any worker transit benefits in lieu of regular pay, and provided for full tax-free treatment of the mass-transit benefits.
Thus, an employee who took $65 a month in such benefits, would obtain $780 a year in vouchers, but would not see those sums on annual income tax statements and thus pay no Federal, state or city taxes on the $780.
Depending on one's tax bracket, that could save $300 or more a year. Under the bill passed yesterday, the $65 monthly limit on transit benefits would be raised to $100 in 2002.
If the bill passes the House and becomes law by next July, riders in New York could combine the Federally subsidized vouchers with the advantages of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's monthly passes for unlimited riding. A $63 monthly pass could thus cost as little as $35 after the savings in Federal, state and city income taxes.
"With the new flexibility added by adoption of today's legislation," Senator Moynihan said, "coupled with New York City Transit's introduction of new monthly and weekly unlimited-ride commuter passes later this year, New Yorkers will have the most flexible and comprehensive mass-transit program in the city's history."
Only the Federal Government would lose substantial money on the arrangement. While the program's cost would depend largely on how widely it was used, an official in Senator Moynihan's office said the bulk of the cost would be the loss of employee income-tax revenues, and he said that might be as little as $31 million over 10 years.
Transit advocates were elated by the provision.
"The bottom line is that this will mean substantially lower fares for hundreds of thousands of riders in the metropolitan area and for transit riders across the country," said Gene Russianoff, a lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, a riders' advocacy group.
If all goes well, Mr. Russianoff said, as many as 500,000 transit riders across the metropolitan area would be participating in the voucher program in a year or two, three to five times as many as currently particpate in Transitchek programs.
He said the city of New York had not offered transit vouchers to its 200,000 employees because it would have to give all a raise to do so and the municipal unions have opposed the program because many city workers who do not use mass transit would have been left out. Mr. Russianoff said the city and the unions might reconsider if the measure became law.
Besides tax benefits and lower fares for employees who choose to participate, employers will see their payrolls cut and their own taxes reduced. Employers pay Social Security taxes and make payments for unemployment insurance and to disability and retirement funds, all based on salary outlays, and these would be reduced accordingly, said Larry Filler, executive director of TransitCenter, which administers the Transitchek program. The savings would be somewhat offset by the costs of administering the program, he noted.
Chris Boylan, deputy executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, also applauded the transit benefits provision of the measure, calling it "terrific" and "wonderful." He said it was as yet unclear what it might mean for transit ridership and revenues, though he said it "certainly will be a positive."
While pleased with the provision, Mr. Boylan said the M.T.A. was greatly encouraged by the overall bill's sharply higher spending for mass transit: $5 billion more than was proposed in committee last fall. The authority currently receives more than $700 million a year in Federal funds for capital projects, including construction and the purchase of subway cars and buses, he said.
Under the bill adopted yesterday, he estimated that the agency would get an additional $150 million to $200 million, and he lavished praise on Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York for helping to engineer the increases. "He was very much alone in his battle," Mr. Boylan said. "This will mean tremendous things for New York and the transit industry in general. We're talking about hundreds of millions of dollars for New York."
In two weeks of spirited horse-trading, it was not only New York's senators who sought and won money for home-state highways, bridges, bus and rail systems. Many senators, especially those representing the South and the West, succeeded, shifting spending away from the Northeast, and pushing costs well above the strict spending limits set by last year's balanced-budget agreement.
Now, Senate budget negotiators will begin searching for ways to offset some of the $31 billion in new spending in the bill. It is unclear where the money might come from, but proposals to expand social programs, cut taxes or reduce the national debt might have to be scaled back to pay for the transportation program. The House faces the same quandary; its version earmarks $4 billion more than the Senate bill.
But the Transportation Secretary, Rodney E. Slater, who watched the Senate vote from the gallery, said afterward that he thought President Clinton would support the expanded transportation spending. "It will be difficult with the budget constraints," he said, "but we can get there."
With spring and the annual return of the construction season about to bloom, governors have warned that Congressional procrastination could delay important highway projects. Representative Bud Shuster, the Pennsylvania Republican who heads the House Transportation Committee, is expected to bring the bill to the floor in early April so negotiations with the Senate can begin well before May 1, when a six-month extension of the last law expires.
The Senate bill was a patchwork of pork-barrel spending intended to silence opposition and win the broadest support. It included $450 million for projects in so-called trade corridors, a favorite of Senator Phil Gramm of Texas; $1.8 billion for the Appalachian Highway that Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia advocates, and, at the behest of Senator John W. Warner of Virginia, $900 million for replacing the Woodrow Wilson Bridge over the Potomac.

HEADLINE: Canada No Safe Haven for Birds or Bears

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: DESOLATION SOUND, British Columbia

 BODY:
The venerable yellow cedars near here hold one of the world's great concentrations of nesting sites for the marbled murrelet, a secretive bird equally at home in the old-growth forest and on the sea.
The robin-sized murrelet is on the endangered-species lists in both Canada and the United States, primarily because logging is destroying its habitat. 
 South of the border, the giant trees where the bird makes its home in moss-covered branches high off the ground are strictly guarded. But in British Columbia they are often fair game to logging operations. Last spring, despite the efforts of environmental officials, crews cleared a mountaintop here that held several nesting sites.
The loggers did leave a 100-foot cedar that held a nest designated by scientists No. 17, and a younger tree alongside. The trees stand like sentinels now on an otherwise bare knob, and they are so exposed that researchers doubt the murrelets will return.
The failed attempt to save the cedars underscores the state of endangered-species protection in Canada. While the Government has assembled a list of 291 species of animals, birds, insects and plants that are endangered, it has not so far passed legislation that protects them.
"It's like a hospital that registers its patients but doesn't treat them," said Stewart A. G. Elgie, managing lawyer for the Sierra Legal Defense Fund in Toronto. "We identify the species at risk, diagnose what's wrong, but then we don't treat them. It's absurd."
Environmentalists say that Canada's lack of endangered-species legislation jeopardizes longstanding efforts in the United States to shield animals that cross the border. For instance, grizzly bears in the Western United States are protected, but they can be hunted if they cross into the Canadian provinces of Alberta and British Columbia.
"I have had bears that range into Alberta and have been lost," said Michael J. Madel, who runs the Grizzly Bear Management Program for the Montana Department of Fish, Wildlife and Parks. The radio collar signals "just disappear," he said. "It's not a good sign."
Environmental groups in Mexico and the United States filed a complaint in January with the environmental commission of the North American Free Trade Agreement charging Canada with failing to protect its endangered species.
And in February 1997, 130 American environmental organizations signed a letter asking Vice President Al Gore to encourage the Canadian Government to pass an endangered-species bill then being considered by the Canadian Parliament.
But when Prime Minister Jean Chretien called an election last spring, all pending legislation effectively died. To be considered again, the bill would have to be reintroduced in the new Parliament.
So far, with a new Environment Minister in place, the Government has moved slowly. Although officials at one point said legislation would be ready for consideration in June, they now say they have no idea when a new version of the endangered species act will be introduced.
Such hesitation can seem strange in a country with a reputation for environmental awareness. Opinion polls show that 94 percent of Canadians support laws to protect endangered wildlife. But the problem lies in a more traditional dispute over where power lies.
Canada's 10 provinces dig in their heels any time the Federal Government in Ottawa tries to exercise its power. All provinces have gained strength over the last 30 years as Ottawa has tried to soothe separatists in Quebec by keeping decision-making local.
Environmentalists saw last year's endangered-species legislation as weak and only minimally effective. They said it would have protected the habitat of endangered species only on federal lands, and would have applied only to those species that do not cross any borders. Still, the provinces strenuously objected to it and rejected any Federal attempt to control local land use -- for instance, protecting the areas where endangered species live.
Hovering like a black cloud over the debate are perceptions of the American experience over the 25 years since Washington passed the Endangered Species Act.
Jack Munro, chairman of the Forest Alliance of British Columbia, a logging trade group, wrote, "British Columbians only have to look across the border to see the kind of human devastation that can result from poorly reasoned actions considered necessary to protect endangered species." In newspaper columns opposing the Canadian proposal last year, Mr. Munro said the American legislation had produced only modest conservation benefits, while costing thousands of logging jobs to save species like the spotted owl.
Environmentalists say that one reason endangered-species legislation has not passed is that Canadians find it hard to believe that with so much open space, and so few people, species could be in trouble.
As David R. Boyd, head of the Sierra Legal Defense Fund in Vancouver, put it: "The general perception among a majority of the population is just one of, 'How can there be environmental problems?' "
A group of scientists on the Committee on the Status of Endangered Wildlife in Canada put together and updates the list, which now includes 291 endangered or threatened species, with another 23 already extinct.
Without clear information on nesting, it has been hard to estimate the population of marbled murrelets. Biologists generally believe there are around 30,000 in British Columbia. But the Committee on the Status of Wildlife in Canada found that if logging continued at the current rate, the marbled murrelet could be extinct in "a matter of decades."
Ontario, Quebec, New Brunswick and Manitoba have their own endangered-species legislation, though environmentalists consider them inadequate. In British Columbia, officials rely on an overlapping network of laws, and the Forestry Practices Code that governs the logging industry, to protect species and habitat.
"The position of the B.C. government is that we will not have stand-alone endangered-species legislation," said James H. Walker, senior land use adviser to the British Columbia ministry of environment. "But the other laws and acts, taken together, provide as much as or more protection than any single piece of legislation."
Mr. Walker said British Columbia listed only 4 of more than 700 vertebrate species in the province as endangered and another 41, including the marbled murrelet, as at risk.
But environmentalists say the loss of habitat accounts for 80 percent of species decline. Thus conservation often becomes an economic issue, especially in resource-rich provinces like British Columbia, where logging is one of the most important industries. Experts say species protection cannot stand up to economic interests, as shown by what happened at Desolation Sound last spring.
"The province depends on revenues from lumber to balance its budget," said Fred Cooke, a biology professor at Simon Fraser University who studies bird population and wildlife ecology. One of his projects, a three-year effort at Desolation Sound, was interrupted last year by the logging.
The province's ministry of environment tried to protect the forest tracts near Desolation Sound because the 32 nests found in the area were a surprisingly rich research site. Until 1990 no murrelet nests had been found in Canada.
Despite the ministry's efforts, the ministry of forests had already granted logging permits and refused to revoke them.
"Ultimately," Mr. Cooke said, "there is a real conflict between environmental issues, long-term benefits and the immediate need to generate revenues."
Federal officials say they are aware of the potential weaknesses of provincial laws but reluctant to intrude on local turf.
Steven G. Curtis, associate director general of the Canadian Wildlife Service, a branch of the federal Ministry of the Environment, said, "The principal concern was that in the draft piece of legislation, the federal Government had taken onto itself perhaps more authority than the provinces considered desirable or necessary to do a sufficient job."
In particular, provinces objected to a section of the bill that would have allowed the federal Government to step in to protect wildlife habitat if provincial efforts were considered inadequate. That provision is expected to be taken out of a new version.
Mr. Boyd of the Sierra Legal Defense Fund and other environmentalists fear this version will be weakened to the point of uselessness. The Government disagrees.
"Some people will see it that way," Mr. Curtis, "but no final decisions have been made, and the minister is considering various options for trying to address or accommodate concerns."
Mr. Curtis added that the new bill was also likely to retain some provisions that environmentalists objected to, including one that lets the federal Cabinet -- not scientists -- designate endangered species.
"There's so much animosity in the United States over the listing of species," Mr. Curtis said. "We're hoping to avoid some of that."

HEADLINE: Plan on Immigration Misses Point;
Time to Act Now

 BODY:

To the Editor:
As one of the national leaders of the Sierra Club effort to restore an immigration component to the club's population policy, I agree with much of what Bill McKibben writes (Op-Ed, March 9).
We stress that only a comprehensive approach to environmental problems can succeed. We must reduce United States consumption by making our economy more efficient in its use of resources; reduce population growth, birthrates and immigration rates, and support aid that slows worldwide population growth and promotes sustainable development. 
 Where we disagree with Mr. McKibben is in his notion that efforts to address immigration must wait until the other factors are tackled.
 
DICK SCHNEIDER
Oakland, Calif., March 9, 1998
 
The writer is chairman of Sierrans for U.S. Population Stabilization.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Group Surveys Nightclubs

BYLINE: TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
The New York nightclub industry pumped $2.8 billion into the city's economy last year and accounted for 27,040 jobs and $800 million in wages, according to a study that was released yesterday.
The report was commissioned by the New York Nightlife Association, a coalition formed in 1996 for the purpose of improving the industry's image and furthering communication between the clubs and neighborhood organizations. 
 The study suggested that the clubs attract a more affluent and civic-minded clientele than even the club owners themselves had realized, said Andrew Rasiej (pronounced Ra-Shea), the president of the nightlife association. The average age of patrons is 27 years old, their mean income is $44,000, and 79 percent of those surveyed claimed to have voted last November, the report said. Computers, communications and finance were among the most prevalent occupations.
The scope of the survey was limited to the 250 licensed cabarets and places that regularly present live music. The report, prepared by George A. Wachtel, the president of Audience Research and Analysis, a consulting company, was based on 685 interviews conducted at nine clubs throughout the city between July and January.
Mr. Rasiej, whose organization represents 75 clubs, said he hoped the study would correct some perceptions about the industry. City officials and community groups have complained about drug use, violence and other illegal activities at many clubs.
Commenting on the report, Deputy Mayor Rudy Washington said: "They're trying to make the argument that they're important, but I'm more concerned with their wanting to police themselves.
"Good establishments," he added, "need not worry about a crackdown on the part of the city." TERRY PRISTIN

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Strong Retail Sales Report Pushes Share Prices Higher

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA

 BODY:
Most major stock indexes reversed early losses yesterday and ended higher, helped by more good news on the economy and further indications that the robust demand for shares is showing few signs of slowing down.
 
 Although share prices stumbled at the opening bell, the stock market gained throughout the day, buoyed in part by reports of solid economic growth and falling yields in the bond market, which made the returns on stocks look more attractive.
 The Government said yesterday that retail sales were strong in January and February, more evidence that the American economy continues to grow despite the threat of a slowdown related to the economic and financial turmoil in Asia.
 Yields in the bond market, which tend to rise on such news, weakened instead as investors shrugged off the increased risk of inflation. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell to 5.86 percent form 5.94 a day earlier.
 Those factors helped send the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index up another 1.45 points, to 1,069.92, its third consecutive record high. The Russell 2000 index of smaller-company stocks also set a record, gaining 0.65 point to close at 467.77. The Nasdaq composite rose 7.21 points, to 1,764.06.
 The Dow Jones industrial average - which dropped by as many as 64 points early in the day - rallied near the close but still ended 16.19 points lower at 8,659.56.
 Yesterday's modest gains and narrow losses are an inaccurate snap-shot of the broader stock market, where share prices have been strengthening for nearly two months.
 The run-up has now carried all the major indexes to all-time highs in recent weeks, reflecting a flurry of mergers and acquisitions and optmism that investors, small and large continue to believe that stocks are the best single investment.
 "The small investor and the small institution are continuing to buy," said Laszlo Biringyi, president of Birinyi Associates, a market research firm in Greenwich, Conn. "We don't know what their intentions are, or how deep their pockets are, but the guys whoa re doing the buying are the small guys."
 Mr. Birinyi, who late last year forecast that the Dow could reach 10,000 by the end of 1998, is now basking in the glow of that prediction. His studies of retail money flows, he said, are pointing to smaller investors who seem eager to buy up the big-name companies.
 "People didn't pay enough attention to sentiment," Mr. Birinyi said. "But I'm a great believer in listening to the market, and it has been the smaller, marginal buyer who is at work."
 If it is the small investor at work in the market, that same investor also may be driving robust consumer spending. In February, retail sales jumped five-tenths of 1 percent from a month ago. Indeed, shares of retail stocks have been soaring on the prospects of even stronger growth.
 The S. & P. index of retail stocks is up 22 percent this year, and the Dow's two leading performers are the retail giants Wal-Mart and Sears, Roebuck up 30 and 27 percent. The Gap Inc. - which also operates Banana Republic and Old Navy Clothing - is also soaring, up 33 percent, and shares of Dayton Hudson, which operates Target stores and Mervyn's, are up 24 percent.
 Richard B. Hoey, chief economist at the Dreyfus Corporation, said that one factor driving retail sales and stock prices might be falling oil prices. A barrel of oil now costs less than $15 - the lowest level in four years.
 Mr. Hoey - who notes that bear-market spells in 1974, 1981 and 1990 all coincided with soaring oil prices - said lower oil prices were akin to a tax cut, since they gave consumers all over the world more spending money. "People are spending less money on heating oil and gas," he said. "You'll see that financial markets usually benefit from falling oil prices."
 But a larger factor, he said, is the fact that the market selloff last October over the Asian economic crisis was too severe, and now investors are feeling more confident.
 This year alone, the Dow is up 9.5 percent and the S. & P. 500 is up 10.3 percent. The Dow, in fact, has gained nearly 1,500 points, or 21 percent, since the Oct. 27 selloff that dropped the blue-chip average to 7,161.15
 "The market's been persistently strong since then," Mr. Hoey said. "It's been a pretty favorable market for our funds."

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Dropped Again In February

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
Producer prices fell in February for the fourth consecutive month, led by more steep declines in energy costs.
The Labor Department said today that the prices, which are paid to such producers as factories and food processors, declined one-tenth of 1 percent last month. In January, prices tumbled seven-tenths of 1 percent, the biggest one-month drop in more than four years. 
 Producer prices have decreased or remained unchanged during 12 of the last 14 months. Over the last 12 months, they have fallen 1.6 percent.
The price drop for finished goods bought by wholesalers, combined with moderate price increases for services, has translated into price stability for American consumers.
"Inflation won't make the radar screen in the near future," said William C. Dunkelberg, economist at the National Federation for Independent Business.
A second economic report today showed an indication of slowness. The Commerce Department said inventories at the nation's businesses were unchanged in January from December, while sales fell one-tenth of 1 percent.
Energy prices declined 1.8 percent in February after having decreased 3.7 percent in January. They also fell most of last year. The prices are being held down by El Nino, which brought unseasonably warm weather to much of the United States, and by falling demand from Asia because of the region's economic problems.
However, floods and storms from the same ocean-tide phenomenon have drowned vegetable crops in California and pushed food prices higher. Food prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent in February. Vegetable prices alone climbed 3.9 percent.
Excluding the volatile food and energy sectors, prices edged up one-tenth of 1 percent last month, the first increase in the core rate in four months. A 2.1 percent increase in wholesale cigarette costs accounted for the increase.
Computer prices dropped 6.6 percent, the largest one-month decline ever. The cost of computers and other electronic products is expected to fall further, partly because sharp currency devaluations have permitted Asian chip and component producers to slash export prices.
Auto prices fell three-tenths of 1 percent, but light-truck prices rose one-tenth of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: Yale Brozen, 80, Economist And Advocate of Free Markets

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
Yale Brozen, a retired professor of business economics who was a vocal critic of government regulation, died on March 4 at his home in San Diego. He was 80.
Mr. Brozen was suffering from heart disease, according to his wife, Katherine Hart Brozen. 
 A member of the so-called Chicago school of economics, which advocates a free-market approach to the economy, Mr. Brozen wrote and spoke extensively about regulation and antitrust issues.
In addition to spending three decades at the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business, Mr. Brozen also served as a consultant to numerous corporations and government agencies, including AT&T, General Motors and the antitrust division of the Department of Justice.
"He had a great ability to understand how to apply microeconomic theory and thinking to everyday situations, government situations and business situations," said Gary D. Eppen, a professor of operations management at Chicago.
In making his case against government interference, Mr. Brozen could often be outspoken, both in and out of the classroom. "He always expressed himself very forcefully," recalled Merton H. Miller, a professor emeritus of finance at Chicago. Mr. Brozen was a strong representative of the Chicago school, he said, along with such well-known economists as Milton Friedman and George Stigler.
One of Mr. Brozen's most ardent attacks on government intervention was during the early 1970's. The Federal Trade Commission had charged the ITT Continental Baking Company, the makers of Wonder Bread, with false advertising over its claim that the bread "helps build strong bodies 12 ways," because other bread makers could make the same claim.
While serving as a consultant to the public relations firm employed by the company, Mr. Brozen made speeches sharply critical of the agency's actions, which he likened to "shades of the Salem witch trials" and characterized as "an obvious bit of foolishness."
Mr. Brozen's attack on the agency's position, which he argued would force companies to promote a competitor's product in their advertising, was echoed by others seeking to defend advertisers and prompted a sharp response from the agency.
But the F.T.C. was hardly Mr. Brozen's only target. A proponent of fiscal conservatism, he spoke out on a variety of topics, ranging from the energy crisis to the Federal budget deficit. When describing the budget proposed by President Jimmy Carter in an opinion piece in the Sunday Business section of The New York Times in 1978, for example, he called the President's behavior "absolutely unprecedented and utterly irresponsible."
Mr. Brozen "was never interested in being politically correct or popular," Mr. Eppen said.
Before joining the University of Chicago in 1957, where he directed the school's programs in applied economics and research and development administration, Mr. Brozen taught at Northwestern University. He was also an adjunct scholar at the American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research.
Born in Kansas City, Mo., Mr. Brozen attended Kansas City Community College in the mid-1930's. He received two bachelor's degrees, one from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the other from the University of Chicago. He earned his Ph.D. in economics from the University of Chicago in 1942. During World War II, he was the director of the radar and telephone maintenance training program in the Army Signal Corps.
In addition to his wife, he is survived by his two sons, Yale Brozen 2d of Rochester, Vt., and Dr. Reed Brozen of Hanover, N.H., and a sister, Geraldine Weiner of Kansas City, Mo.

HEADLINE: Clinton Urges Asia Investors To Aid Lands Like Thailand

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
Offering Thailand as an example of proper economic management, President Clinton warned today that investors could throw Southeast Asia "into a long-term recession" if they fail to reward the countries that are effectively grappling with the financial crisis there.
Asked if the worst of the Asian crisis was past, Mr. Clinton said he was not sure. But he said: "I think what we're beginning to see is a differentiation on the part of the markets in dealing with these different countries. And that's what, first and foremost, I would like to see." 
 Mr. Clinton spoke briefly with reporters as he met in the Oval Office today with the Thai Prime Minister, Chuan Leekpai. As expected, the President agreed today to release the Thai Government from a contract to buy American-made jet fighters that it can no longer afford.
Mr. Chuan is visiting Washington and New York seeking investment and improved credit ratings for his country in exchange for the stiff measures he has taken, ranging from closing dozens of finance companies to slashing spending and raising taxes. Thailand turned last year to the International Monetary Fund for a bailout after its currency collapsed.
In total, the Administration said it had assembled a package of aid worth about $1.7 billion for Thailand this year, including trade assistance and investment in power projects.
Thailand had been particularly anxious for relief on the fighter contract, a $392 million deal for eight F/ A-18's, together with spare parts and training. The Thais have paid $75 million so far, but have not received any of the planes, which cost a total of $325 million. The Administration today agreed to pay the remaining $250 million and take the planes, which are made by the Boeing Company.
The planes will probably go to the Marines, although the Administration is considering finding another foreign buyer. Because the planes have not yet come off Boeing's assembly lines in St. Louis, they can still be built to the more advanced American standard, officials said, rather than to the export standard.
Appearing with Mr. Clinton, Mr. Chuan said Thailand was "undergoing a period of financial and economic crisis." He added, "During this time of need, we appreciate the help and support of our friends." The two leaders met for two hours today, including a lunch meeting.
In response to questions today, Mr. Clinton outlined some of his foreign travel plans, suggesting that he might visit Northern Ireland as part of a European tour in May. He said he would decide to make that stop based on the state of the peace effort and "whether I could make any kind of constructive contribution."
He said he did not plan to visit Russia until after Parliament approved the Start II nuclear arms control treaty.
Mr. Clinton also said today that he had decided to move up this year's visit to China from November to late June after his advisers said he should capitalize on President Jiang Zemin's visit here last October. "Our relationship with China is so important that we needed to try to build on it and make some more progress," he said.
The President is planning to leave at the end of next week for a two-week trip to Africa. At a fund-raiser here on Thursday night, he made what appeared to be a dismissive remark about President Jimmy Carter's 1978 trip to Africa, saying, "No President's ever made a serious trip to Africa."
Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, said Mr. Clinton meant that no other President had gone to the sub-Saharan countries that he is planning to visit.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Price Dip Ends Weeklong Rally

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities turned lower yesterday for the first time in six days, as the market encountered buyer reluctance to pay more for Government bonds without seeing further evidence of slowing economic growth.
The decline came despite a report indicating that robust growth had not shown up in producer prices. The Producer Price Index fell in February for the fourth consecutive month, dropping by one-tenth of 1 percent. Investors apparently focused instead on a rise of one-tenth of 1 percent in the so-called core rate of producer prices, which excludes volatile food and energy prices. Selling also accelerated after comments from a Federal Reserve official raised concern about inflation. 
 The price of the 30-year bond fell 3/8, to 103 5/16, and the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.89 percent, from 5.86 percent the previous day.
Bond prices slumped further after William J. McDonough, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, warned that inflation could reappear.
In a speech to the New Jersey Bankers Association in Palm Beach, Fla., Mr. McDonough said that without more gains in productivity, "it is very likely that if the economy continues to grow this rapidly we will have some cost pressures."
