HEADLINE: Blacks Carry Load of Care for Their Elderly

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: DURHAM, N.C., March 9

 BODY:
Eldora Mitchell is nearly as old as the century, and for her it has been a life of love and service, starting at the age of 12, when she went to work scrubbing white people's floors to help her family. Later, she cleaned hospital rooms to feed her own children and cared for her grandchildren while their parents were working. In her 60's, she nursed her dying husband and her elderly mother.
Now, at 95, frail and slowly going blind, it is Mrs. Mitchell's turn. Four years ago, she moved across town to her retirement home -- a bedroom in her son Charles's house here, with bright green curtains and her large-print Bible on the nightstand. 
 Mrs. Mitchell collects $568 a month in Social Security and a pension of $45 a month from Duke Medical Center, where she retired from the housekeeping department. She has about $8,000 in savings and no long-term health insurance. What she does have is her family, and her expectation -- redeemed by their promises -- that they will do for her as she has done for previous generations.
The Mitchells are following a tradition in the African-American community, where families have long been expected to care for their mothers and fathers and grandparents, as well as for their children. It is a tradition born of "certain harsh realities," as Jacqueline Jones, a historian, puts it, "of a historic lack of access to good medical care, public support and the kind of jobs that guaranteed a secure old age."
Peggye Dilworth-Anderson, a sociologist and gerontologist at the University of North Carolina at Greensboro, is directing a four-year study of African-Americans in the state who are caring for relatives. "There are lots of Mr. Mitchells," Dr. Dilworth-Anderson said.
The tradition is hardly unique to blacks. Studies show that nearly one in four American families is taking care of an elderly relative or friend, doing everything from changing diapers to shopping for groceries. With the ranks of those who are known as "the old old" growing ever larger, and the Federal Government considered unlikely to provide help in the form of a comprehensive long-term care program any time soon, more and more families are expected to find themselves taking care of elderly relatives.
Still, older blacks are twice as likely as whites to receive care from family members when their health declines, according to a recent study for the National Institute on Aging by Dr. Raymond T. Coward, dean of health and human services at the University of New Hampshire.
And while caring for one's own is a source of pride, and a statement of love and obligation, it also carries costs in terms of stress, lost wages, jobs and educational opportunities passed up, as well as health risks to the caregivers.
"It's a labor of love, but it exacts a tremendous toll from people who have few resources to begin with," said Dr. Jones, a professor of Afro-American and labor history at Brandeis University and the author of "American Work: Four Centuries of Black and White Labor."
In fact, given the economic stresses on black families, and their increased mobility, some experts worry that coming generations will be unable to take on the caregiving role.
"There is a gap between the cultural value and what is practical," said Rose C. Gibson, a gerontologist and professor emeritus at the University of Michigan, who has studied the black elderly.
The statistics highlight the need: Older blacks have more than double the rate of poverty of older whites, and they suffer from far more health problems, according to figures from the Census Bureau. They have higher rates of hypertension, asthma and diabetes and require more help with the tasks of daily living.
Yet there is more of a resistance to institutional care among blacks than whites, experts say. Years ago, discrimination and poverty barred blacks from nursing homes, or rest homes, as assisted-living facilities are known in North Carolina. The ones they could afford, when they did gain entry, often offered minimal care at best. Among African-Americans, stories abound of relatives and friends mistreated in nursing homes. While the options have improved -- at least for the middle class -- there remains a deep, cultural mistrust of institutions for the elderly.
Gloria Roberson, a retired University of North Carolina accounting clerk, spent nearly every waking moment for five years caring for her mother, who had Alzheimer's disease, at home in Chapel Hill. Her doctor, concerned about the burden she was taking on, urged her to consider a nursing home, Mrs. Roberson recalled. "We just don't do that," she said. "Not with our people."
Financially, some elderly blacks have no option other than entering a nursing home under the Medicaid program, the Federal health care program for the poor. Blacks are far less likely than whites to have spouses to help with their care.
It is not an easy burden for the younger generation. Black caregivers tend to have less money than most white families caring for an elderly relative, so they bear a disproportionately higher burden of the care themselves because they can not afford to hire help.
They are also much more likely to have the additional responsibility of children at home. More than half of all black caregivers have one or more children younger than 18 at home, compared with 39 percent of white caregivers. Many of the black caregivers are single working mothers. Thirty-four percent of blacks older than 65 live in multigenerational homes, compared with 18 percent of whites.
 
Rewarding Payback From a Caring Son
Charles Mitchell was in the kitchen, cooking supper for his mother. It was 3 P.M., eight hours before he would clock in at his paid job. A police dispatcher at North Carolina Central University in Durham, he works the graveyard shift so he can spend his days looking after his mother. Most black caregivers, studies show, hold regular jobs.
"Some of my friends say, 'You're something else, man,' " said Mr. Mitchell, who is 55 and divorced. "They say they admire what I'm doing. I say, 'Well, this is mom. I don't have but one.' She brought me up and looked after me. I feel I should do the same. I feel everybody should."
Mrs. Mitchell said of her son: "I can do for myself. He don't have to wait on me."
But wait on her he does. Three times a day he puts medicated drops in his mother's eyes. He empties the commode in her bedroom that she uses at night. He changes the sheets on her bed. He washes her back, as she did for him when he was small, as she did for her mother when she was old and blind.
He barely mentions his own health problems. A diabetic, Mr. Mitchell injects himself with insulin daily.
For all the talk about the so-called disintegrating black family, what is often ignored is the strength of the extended family. "That's the irony," Dr. Jones said. "People are constantly denigrating black family life. But if you look at how these families survive and sustain themselves over the generations it's a testament to their strength and resilience."
Mr. Mitchell has no paid home health care aides or housekeepers to help with his mother. But he has the support of family members and friends.
His sister Audrey, 52, who also lives in Durham, spends nights with their mother while Mr. Mitchell is working. His other sister, Mildred, 54, who lives nearby, comes by regularly to fix her mother's hair and provide other intimate care. Mr. Mitchell's girlfriend, Sheila Parker, helps with cooking and housework.
The Mitchells' caregiving arrangement is typical of African- American families, Dr. Dilworth-Anderson has found in her study, which is being financed by the National Institute on Aging.
That legacy is particularly strong in the tradition-minded South. Dr. Dilworth-Anderson says she has found that whether caregivers live in urban Durham or rural Warren County, whether their income is $15,000 or $50,000 a year, the sense of obligation is similar.
"What varies is how they can express that sense of obligation," said Dr. Dilworth-Anderson, a professor in the department of human development and family studies. "A high-powered lawyer may have enough resources to make sure her mother is cared for well by using formal services. In that way she feels she's living up to her sense of duty. The lower-class woman may say, 'I don't have all this money to hire all these people, but I have my sisters and brothers.' "
The caregivers are strongly motivated by faith, Dr. Dilworth-Anderson said. "You get cultural reinforcement from your neighbors, your friends, from the church," she said.
 
Two Mothers First, Husband Second
For Martha Perry, caregiving meant pulling up stakes in New Jersey, giving up her job and her daily life with her husband, deferring her own dreams.
Four years ago, Mrs. Perry, 49, who had been a supervisor at a group home for the disabled, returned to the town of Wendell, near Raleigh, and moved in with her elderly mother-in-law, who had advanced diabetes. Mrs. Perry's husband, a postal worker, is the family's main breadwinner, and they could not afford for him to leave his job.
There were also other considerations that prompted Mrs. Perry, who has a 24-year-old son, to join the ranks of caregivers, the majority of whom are women. Mrs. Perry said her husband told her, " 'I can't bathe her, I can't do the things for her that you can do.' "
Mrs. Perry took her mother-in-law, Maggie Perry, to the hospital for dialysis three times a week, lifting her and her wheelchair in and out of her car. She gave her mother-in-law insulin injections, cooked for her and bathed her.
Mrs. Perry said her husband and his four brothers paid her $200 a week. A home health aide spent two hours at the house two or three days a week. Eventually, Maggie Perry had to have a leg amputated and was placed in a nursing home, where she died in January of kidney failure.
The demands on Martha Perry have been unrelenting. She had to stay in North Carolina to care for her mother, Eula Brodie, who is 85 and unable to live on her own. For six months, Mrs. Perry was a round-the-clock caregiver, living with her mother near Raleigh.
She was eventually able to move her mother into the nearby McKissick Center, an assisted-living center. The move allowed Mrs. Perry to go back to work, as a group home manager for disabled adults.
Mrs. Brodie, the daughter of sharecroppers, had worked as a maid and a home health care aide until she was 80. She receives about $1,000 a month from Social Security and her pension, Mrs. Perry said.
The McKissick Center had been charging her $1,600 a month. For about a year, Mrs. Perry paid half the cost herself and half out of her mother's monthly income. Two weeks ago, the center learned that Mrs. Perry, unable to afford the cost, was about to quit her job and move her mother back home and reduced her mother's monthly fee to $1,150.
Mrs. Perry has five brothers and seven sisters, who live scattered across the country. They shared a chaotic, harsh childhood, Mrs. Perry said, and have not forgiven their mother for it. Together, they send about $500 a month to help with her expenses, Mrs. Perry said.
"I love my mother because I saw her working herself to death so we could eat," said Mrs. Perry, who visits her mother regularly and oversees her care.
But now it is Mrs. Perry who is exhausted. "I'll be honest," she said. "Sometimes it's tempting to just walk away. This is taking its toll on my health. I have hypertension. I'm just tired of it, I'm so tired. I've had days where I've said, 'Please, Lord, take her.' "
Her husband, who is 65, plans to retire in the spring and join her in North Carolina. They had planned to build a house. But their savings are mostly gone, Mrs. Perry said.
"The money has gone in so many different ways we didn't count on," she said. "When you get married, you think it's going to be you, your husband and your children. But it ends up being you, your husband, your children and both your parents."
Still, Martha Perry would not have it any other way. "It all goes back to slavery," she said. "Family was all anyone had."

HEADLINE: Queens Leaders Back Bookkeeper for Assembly

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Pauline R. Cummings, a 52-year-old former bookkeeper, sat quietly at a fund-raising breakfast at a Forest Hills restaurant on a recent morning, surrounded by the firmament of Queens Democratic leaders. As the parade of politicians passed by, she seemed more than a little in awe -- more like a guest than the guest of honor.
But the breakfast was for her. 
 "I feel extremely grateful to have been asked to run," said Ms. Cummings, who is running for the State Assembly in a March 24 special election to fill the seat vacated by Gregory W. Meeks, who was elected to Congress last month. "But I have to make myself known to the rest of the community," she said softly. "This is exciting, but it's also a challenge."
The race is her first, and she is expected to win handily, but more than a few Democratic officials suggest that nothing is guaranteed in a four-candidate special election in which turnout is likely to be sparse and name recognition will be significant. That is particularly the case because one of her opponents is younger, more seasoned and known for his tenacity.
He is Allan W. Jennings Jr., running on the Independence Party line after being rebuffed by the Democrats. This campaign is the seventh since 1991 for Mr. Jennings, a 31-year-old bank loan officer. And while he once won a position as a Democratic district leader and as a delegate to the party's judicial convention, Mr. Jennings has failed in four attempts to unseat City Councilman Thomas White Jr.
Ms. Cummings is being supported by a wide array of Queens Democrats that includes Representative Thomas J. Manton, the borough's party leader; Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi and Mr. Meeks himself. And Ms. Cummings, a civic group leader in Far Rockaway, appears to have every advantage in the heavily Democratic 31st Assembly District.
A bookkeeper in the Manhattan garment district for nearly 30 years, the Jamaican-born Ms. Cummings has also been the chairwoman of the economic development committee of her local community board. Her principal political benefactor is City Councilwoman Juanita Watkins, who asked Ms. Cummings to run for the Assembly seat.
Still, many in Queens political circles suggest that, despite Ms. Cummings's presence on the Democratic line and the breadth of her party support, a strong effort by Mr. Jennings is nothing to take lightly. While he lost to Mr. White, Mr. Jennings has a following: last year he received 42 percent of the vote.
"I am the only person in this race with name recognition," said Mr. Jennings, a former city corrections investigator. "Her only advantage is that she has the Democratic line, and my only disadvantage is that I don't."
Still, that may well be too much of an advantage to overcome. The 31st Assembly District, which includes the southeastern Queens neighborhoods of South Ozone Park, Richmond Hill, Springfield Gardens and, across the Jamaica Bay, Far Rockaway, has voted overwhelmingly Democratic since it was created after the 1990 census.
The other candidates are Michael Duvalle, the owner of a security business, who is running on the Republican and Conservative lines, and Evan Gray, a Baptist minister, who is running on the Liberal Party line.
Mr. Jennings and Ms. Cummings highlight the same issues. Each discusses the need to stimulate economic development in the district, where many storefront businesses have closed. They both talk about the need for more frequent rehabilitation of streets and drainage systems.
If Ms. Cummings wins, which is widely expected, she would then face a primary in September and a general election in November. If that is the case, she will likely face Mr. Jennings again.
"I get better and better at running my campaigns," Mr. Jennings said. "I expect to prevail in this race. But if not, sure, I'll be back in September."

HEADLINE: SKIPPING THE RACE -- A special report.;
Run for Congress? Parties Find Rising Stars Are Just Saying No

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: MOUNT VERNON, Ill.

 BODY:
Darla Wexstten was soaking in the bathtub one Saturday morning in December when her husband, Jim, raced up the stairs and summoned her to the phone. The White House was on the line. Wrapped in a towel and dripping wet, Ms. Wexstten listened intently as President Clinton gently tried to persuade her to seek the House seat from the 20th Congressional District in south central Illinois.
Mr. Clinton should not have needed a hard sell with Ms. Wexstten, a social worker who was born and reared in this rural town. The statistics speak for themselves: A Democrat, Richard J. Durbin, held the seat from 1982 until he gave it up to run, successfully, for the Senate in 1996. The Republican who succeeded him, Representative John Shimkus, is a freshman who was elected by a margin of only 1,238 votes in one of the closest House races in the country. And Mr. Shimkus, a former high school teacher, is still struggling to make a name for himself. 
 "I told him the truth: that it's an honor to be asked but I had not made a decision," Ms. Wexstten recalled. "It's hard to say no to your Commander in Chief. I told him I'd give it another evening of prayerful consideration. He talked about how this is a winnable seat. He said: 'This is a hard life. There are days I wouldn't want to wish it on anybody. But we have important work to do.' "
After more agonizing, more lists of pros and cons and more prayer, Ms. Wexstten decided that her most important work was not in the Congress but with her 13-year-old daughter, Erin Beth. "I could tell that she really did want me to stay home," she said as her husband kissed Erin Beth on the head. "And that's fine."
Three days after Mr. Clinton's call -- and weeks after Democratic leaders had first approached Ms. Wexstten about running -- the deadline for a Democrat to file in the race against Mr. Shimkus came and went. One of the most vulnerable incumbents in the country had escaped without an opponent.
Ms. Wexstten is not alone. Dozens of rising stars, Democrats and Republicans alike, decided not to run for Congress this year in what political strategists describe as a growing trend. Even after wheedling from the President (or, in the case of Republicans, from Speaker Newt Gingrich) and promises of money from Washington, fewer prospects are swayed by the allure of power and influence of the United States Congress, officials in both parties concede.
In interviews throughout the country, people who chose not to run in 1998 -- many for what appeared to be winnable seats -- offered many reasons. But the explanations were similar: would-be members of Congress complained that the rigors of fund-raising and of being away from home exacted too much of a personal toll.
And even if they could be assured of being elected to the $136,700-a-year position (it would have been a raise of more than $80,000 for Ms. Wexstten), many people said that serving in the House was no longer an enticing calling. Several said they could make more of a difference serving in their state legislatures than in the United States Congress.
"One of the reasons you run is to get something accomplished," said Mark O'Keefe, the state auditor in Montana, one of several Democrats who resisted pressure from the national party to run for the House. "But to get anything accomplished as a member of the minority is very difficult. Do I want to get lost in a crowd of 435 folks? Not much."
Tim Weeden, a Republican State Senator from Beloit, Wis., said he had no qualms about raising the $100,000 he needed for his re-election campaign to state office this year. But he said a major reason he backed down from what looked like a reasonable shot at winning an open House seat was that he would have had to collect 10 times that amount.
"I would have had to engage in some things that I don't find very tasteful," said Mr. Weeden, who is 46. "Like cold calling. Like asking current contributors to give me 10 times more than they have in the past. Not only do you raise that kind of money now, but as soon as the election is over you turn around and do it all over again. I can't even see doing it once. But to do it over and over again is something I just wouldn't be able to do."
Recruiting the most appealing, and formidable, candidates is more than an exercise in vanity for the political parties. Democrats need to pick up only 11 seats to win back control of the House. The success or failure of party recruiters can have an important bearing on which candidates can best raise money, draw political support -- and ultimately win. Beyond the election itself, a critical result of recruiting is the quality (or lack thereof) of candidates who end up in Congress.
The failure of people to run has consequences far beyond the November election. Besides robbing the political process of competition, there is a cost to the civic culture because the absence of the highest quality candidates feeds into the public's increasing alienation from Washington and from the process of governing.
One who is not complaining is Mr. Shimkus, who said he now felt little pressure to put his re-election campaign into full gear. "For a new member who won in a close election, it's as good as I could have expected," he said. "I'm trying to analyze, myself, why this has occurred."
 
The Money Chase
A Relentless Pace, And to What End?
Several potential contenders focused on a harsh yet unavoidable (unless you are independently wealthy) reality of running for Congress in 1998: the need to amass huge stockpiles of cash and, if successful, to turn around and hit up donors again for the race two years later.
Jay Hoffman, a Democratic State Representative in Illinois who barely lost to Mr. Shimkus two years ago, said the constant chase for money was a critical factor in his decision to pass up another run. "Last time, I raised $800,000 and it wasn't enough," he said. "This time, I'd need probably a million or so. I found the constant need to raise resources to be competitive a bit repulsive."
Former Representative Bill Martini, a Republican of Clifton, N.J., who was elected in 1994 and lost his seat two years later, said the overwhelming financial demands in the costly New York media market were too much to bear.
"The emphasis is too much on fund-raising, and that's not what led me to run in the first place," said Mr. Martini, who last month passed up a rematch against Representative Bill Pascrell Jr., a freshman Democrat.
Representative Martin Frost of Texas, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said that he was hearing such complaints with increasing intensity. "The whole thing has gone crazy," he said. "The cost of television advertising has so far outpaced the general inflation rate that it's very expensive to run, and that's a factor for people. That's why in both parties now you tend to have more candidates who are independently wealthy or who have substantial ties to the business community."
Beyond the financial costs, many prospective candidates said, simply, that serving in Congress was no longer a dream job. "A family ought to have a father -- and I'm it," said Mr. O'Keefe of Helena, Mont. "To commute every week to Washington, D.C., would have destroyed everyone's life."
Even Mr. Weeden, the Republican from Wisconsin, said the chance of being part of a House majority did not entice him. "Look what I have now in terms of seniority and position -- a four-year term and an ability to get things done here in the Wisconsin Senate," said Mr. Weeden, who was first elected to the State Assembly in 1984. "Compare that with going to Washington, where I'd be a nobody for probably two or three terms, at least. It was really no comparison." There was little appeal, he said, in "being part of an institution that doesn't seem to be achieving a great deal right now. They do a lot more talking, a lot more partisan wrangling, than working toward solutions."
But, like many others who suppressed their ambition this year, Mr. Weeden is not entirely comfortable with his decision. "My biggest fear," he said, "is that I'll be sitting in a wheelchair at 85 years old and look back on a missed opportunity."
 
The Recruiting Wars
Strong Language, Gentle Persuasion
For months, Democrats and Republicans have tried to gain an advantage in a public relations war over which side is fielding the best candidates. The National Republican Congressional Committee regularly puts out a flier called "Dropping Like Flies: Democratic Recruitment Failures," which has tallied more than 100 potential Democratic candidates who decided not to run. (Democratic officials counter that the list is misleading because it includes candidates who never seriously thought about running.)
And the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee aggressively touts its "team of first stringers," while attacking Republicans with news releases like one that proclaimed, "G.O.P. Comes Up Empty in Texas."
Democrats are so sensitive about their recruitment efforts that the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee agreed to -- and then canceled -- plans to allow a reporter to sit in on sessions in which officials tried to coax candidates into running. "For us, it would look especially bad if a candidate decided not to run," a committee aide explained, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "We'd have egg on our face."
Despite some successes for both parties, Republicans appear to be faring slightly better than Democrats, and can point to more competitive seats for which Democrats have not found particularly strong candidates -- or any candidates at all. Although filing deadlines have still not passed in several states, it is almost too late to recruit winning candidates because of the months of fund-raising and preparations needed to mount a successful race.
In many districts, Republicans and Democrats had boasted about hot recruits who never materialized. Speaker Gingrich and other Republicans tried but failed to persuade Brent Jones, the former San Francisco 49ers tight end, to take on a freshman, Representative Ellen O. Tauscher of California. And they could not come up with a challenger to Representative Chet Edwards of Texas in a district where Bob Dole easily defeated Mr. Clinton in the 1996 Presidential race. "That's what I consider the only failure," said Representative John Linder of Georgia, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee.
Democrats had their share of setbacks. For months, they said State Judge John Ellington would be the ideal candidate to challenge Representative C. Saxby Chambliss, a Georgia Republican, in a district that Mr. Clinton carried in 1996. Mr. Ellington chose not to run.
Leading lawmakers in both parties often fan out around the country to wine and dine prospects, and often hook them up with current members to discuss family matters like finding schools for their children. For the best hopes, the parties even conduct polls to show they could win.
"If we find a top-tier candidate, we really go after them pretty hard," said Representative Steny H. Hoyer, a Maryland Democrat who has recruited candidates for years. "It's like a basketball coach or a football coach. When you're recruiting, you don't want to offend the player but you want them to know you think they would be a great success."
Roger Bedford, a State Senator from Russellville, Ala., who was the state's Democratic nominee for Senate in 1996, said Mr. Clinton had telephoned to urge him to run for a House seat. "He talked about how there were good schools in the Washington area and said you could have good quality time with your children even in the Washington environment," he said, adding that the President offered to campaign in the district with him and "told me he would help me put the finances together to have a winning race."
Mr. Bedford said that the President was "a very persuasive gentleman," but that he had chosen not to run. These days, it is not just the women candidates who put family concerns at the top of their list. "I just decided it was more important to be a good dad than a freshman Congressman," Mr. Bedford said.
 
The Decision
For One Prospect, Prayer and Conflict
When Mr. Clinton called her that Saturday, Ms. Wexstten said, it was like a message from God that she should run. Only an hour or two earlier, she had received word that her husband's grandmother had died after a long illness. "My brother is a minister and he prayed with me," she said. "We needed some clarity."
Ms. Wexstten, 44, who describes herself as a charismatic Christian and a liberal Democrat, still keeps in her Bible a sheet of paper that is a blueprint of her deliberations. At the top of the list she wrote, "Family," and listed her husband and three daughters. Among her jottings: "Is this of the Lord? What impact could I make in D.C.? Is this the desire of my heart? The next five years of my life. What do I want for my life?"
Ms. Wexstten was not the Democrats' first choice, but several local elected officials decided to sit out the race. So party leaders settled on Ms. Wexstten, who had never run for public office but had been active in local politics and was considered an articulate, politically astute and lively contrast to Mr. Shimkus.
Take a look at the Wexsttens' rambling house deep in the woods, with picture windows overlooking a pond, and it is easier to understand why Ms. Wexstten could not be lulled into seeking office. As Darla, Jim and Erin Beth Wexstten sat comfortably in their living room one recent morning, it quickly became clear how Ms. Wexstten felt tugs in both directions. Although Ms. Wexstten was excited at the prospect of delving into social policy issues, it was never her dream to serve in Congress.
By contrast, Jim Wexstten, a state circuit judge who bears a striking resemblance to Bill Clinton, could barely contain his disappointment that his wife did not run. He explained that he would not give up the bench for the uncertainties of political office himself, but that he had hoped that he could "live vicariously" through his wife. He even had a campaign slogan: "Democrats for Darla!" He was so thrilled by Mr. Clinton's phone call that he listened in on the extension.
But Erin Beth Wexstten, an eighth grader who loves practicing her ballet routines, was not enchanted by the prospect of living apart from her mother. "I wanted her to stay home," Erin Beth said. "Every time I'm not with her a day or two, it's hard. I need my mom."
At the heart of Ms. Wexstten's thinking was the big white refrigerator in her kitchen. "Until my kid is grown," she said, pointing to the lists of car pools, dance classes and family photographs plastered on the refrigerator, "this is my life."
But the unrelenting telephone calls, not only from the President but from a parade of Democrats in Washington and Illinois, made it an excruciating decision. "I felt so honored by the President's phone call that I went to a high school basketball game and they played the national anthem and I cried," Ms. Wexstten said. "I don't care what four-letter words are used in describing politics these days. It's still an honor to serve. I understand that this opportunity might not come around for me."
Democrats still hope that Rick Verticchio, who plans to run as a write-in candidate in the party's primary on Tuesday, will collect enough signatures to be the nominee in November. Still, when Mr. Frost was asked about his biggest recruiting disappointment this year, he said: "If we had to point to any one, it was the Shimkus seat in Illinois. That was a seat where we really wanted to find a strong candidate."
Had she made the race, Ms. Wexstten said, she would have felt compelled to raise at least $800,000 and "give it 110 percent" of her energy -- no easy task in a rural district that takes six hours to drive from one end to the other.
Gazing at her daughter and her husband, Ms. Wexstten said she kept thinking, "What would it be like to wake up every day without my family? Not able to go in and get her breakfast, not snuggle with her, and not sleep with him?"

HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT;
Text of Monica Lewinsky's Affidavit in Paula Jones's Suit Against the President

 BODY:
Following is the affidavit by Monica S. Lewinsky, the former White House intern at the center of accusations of sexual misconduct by President Clinton, which was filed in connection with Paula Corbin Jones's lawsuit against the President. The affidavit was included by Ms. Jones's lawyers in their filing on Friday in response to a motion by Mr. Clinton's lawyers to have the suit dismissed. Although it is standard procedure to describe it as an "affidavit of Jane Doe," it is signed by Ms. Lewinsky. 

Affidavit of Jane Doe #

 1. My name is Jane Doe # number marked out . I am 24 years old and I currently reside at 700 New Hampshire Avenue, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20037.
2. On Dec. 19, 1997, I was served with a subpoena from the plaintiff to give a deposition and to produce documents in the lawsuit filed by Paula Corbin Jones against President William Jefferson Clinton and Danny Ferguson.
3. I cannot fathom any reason that the plaintiff would seek information from me for her case.
4. I have never met Ms. Jones, nor do I have any information regarding the events she alleges occurred at the Excelsior Hotel on May 8, 1991, or any other information concerning any of the allegations in her case.
5. I worked at the White House in the summer of 1995 as a White House intern. Beginning in December 1995, I worked in the Office of Legislative Affairs as a staff assistant for correspondence. In April 1996, I accepted a job as assistant to the Assistant Secretary for Public Affairs at the U.S. Department of Defense. I maintained that job until Dec. 26, 1997. I am currently unemployed but seeking a new job.
6. In the course of my employment at the White House, I met President Clinton several times. I also saw the President at a number of social functions held at the White House. When I worked as an intern, he appeared at occasional functions attended by me and several other interns. The correspondence I drafted while I worked at the Office of Legislative Affairs was seen and edited by supervisors who either had the President's signature affixed by mechanism or, I believe, had the President sign the correspondence itself.
7. I have the utmost respect for the President, who has always behaved appropriately in my presence.
8. I have never had a sexual relationship with the President, he did not propose that we have a sexual relationship, he did not offer me employment or other benefits in exchange for a sexual relationship, he did not deny me employment or other benefits for rejecting a sexual relationship. I do not know of any other person who had a sexual relationship with the President, was offered employment or other benefits in exchange for a sexual relationship, or was denied employment or other benefits for rejecting a sexual relationship. The occasions that I saw the President after I left my employment at the White House in April 1996 were official receptions, formal functions or events related to the U.S. Department of Defense, where I was working at the time. There were other people present on those occasions.
9. Since I do not possess any information that could possibly be relevant to the allegations made by Paula Jones or lead to admissible evidence in this case, I asked my attorney to provide this affidavit to plaintiff's counsel. Requiring my deposition in this matter would cause disruption in my life, especially since I am looking for employment, unwarranted attorney's fees and costs, and constitute an invasion to privacy.
I declare under the penalty of perjury that the foregoing is true and correct. Monica S. Lewinsky

HEADLINE: In Stratford, the Return of Shakespeare

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY 

 BODY:
The shuttered American Festival Theater in Stratford, Conn., which introduced tens of thousands of schoolchildren in the Northeast to Shakespeare, is being resurrected after years of dormancy and decline.
Officials from the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection are expected to announce tomorrow the sale of the theater's 14-acre site, on the Housatonic River in the heart of Stratford's historic district, to a nonprofit organization, Stratford Festival Theater Inc. The group will pay $1.5 million in several installments, said its secretary-treasurer, Louis D. Pieteg. 
 "It will be a boon for tourism and a cultural opportunity for Stratford, the state of Connecticut and the Northeast," Mr. Pieteg said.
The overall project includes renovating the existing theater and building two smaller theaters, and is to include an academy and a museum. Costs could reach $180 million, a state official said.
Mr. Pieteg said fund-raising would begin almost immediately. Financing is also being provided by Starcom, a company controlled by three Philadelphia businessmen. A structural and mechanical assessment of the existing theater will determine how much renovation is required. As a result, no firm date can be set for the first performance.
"We would love to do something this summer," said Louis S. Burke, a South African theater producer with Broadway experience who will be artistic director of the new theater company.
Built in 1955 and designed to resemble Shakespeare's Globe Theater in London, the 1,500-seat theater offered only midyear performances until its financial collapse forced it to close in 1982. It reopened only once, for a brief, failed summer run in 1989. The State of Connecticut bought the theater out of bankruptcy several years ago but never reopened it.
In 1995, State Senator George (Doc) Gunther, a Stratford Republican, prepared a law to sell the theater and surrounding land to a private developer.
But Mr. Gunther said the law's strict requirements also delayed the purchase. The law required that the theater offer at least one production of Shakespeare every year for 20 years.
"We didn't want a glitzy shopping center with hotels and motels," Mr. Gunther said. "This is a beautiful location."
Mr. Burke said the new regional theater would operate year-round. Having moved to Stratford from New York in 1993, Mr. Burke directed a production of "Murder in the Cathedral" that opened Friday night at a Stratford church.
Within 60 to 90 days, Mr. Burke's group must present a design and development plan to the state. A priority, Mr. Pieteg said, will be to determine the condition of the electrical, heating and plumbing systems in the theater. Mr. Burke recalled having noticed mushrooms sprouting in the foyer.
But Mr. Pieteg said the theater "is in surprisingly good shape considering the length of time it has been closed." Built with teak, the theater was a vibrant cultural center for decades. Schoolchildren from Connecticut and other Northeastern states were often brought in buses to see their first performance of Shakespeare.
Mr. Burke began trying to buy the theater in 1990. The state selected his nonprofit group as its preferred developer in 1995, but negotiations to complete the sale lasted three years.
"I think Shakespeare said it best," Mr. Burke said. "He said, 'Perseverance, dear my Lord, keeps honor bright.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: In 1960, a trip to Stratford to see Shakespeare also meant that students had a chance to eat lunch on the lawn outside the theater. The existing theater will be renovated and new structures added. (Sam Falk/The New York Times)
 
Map of Connecticut showing the location of Stratford: The theater will present at least one Shakespeare play a year.

HEADLINE: Charles F. Phillips, 87, President Of Bates College for 23 Years

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Charles F. Phillips, a former president of Bates College in Lewiston, Me., who helped oversee the Government's rationing of goods during World War II, died at the Central Maine Medical Center in Auburn on Tuesday. He was 87 and lived in Auburn.
When he became president of Bates in 1944, Mr. Phillips was the youngest president in its history. He was born in Nelson, Pa., in 1910. 
 He graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Colgate University in 1931 and received a doctorate in economics from Harvard University in 1934.
After short teaching stints in economics at Hobart College and Colgate University, Mr. Phillips served with the Office of Price Administration during World War II as deputy administrator for rationing.
Among his duties were warning the transportation industry of severe rubber shortages, rationing tires, keeping pleasure driving in check to conserve fuel and occasionally sparring with drivers groups.
For example, when the Automobile Club of New York proposed in 1944 that gasoline rations to American drivers be increased to match the amount being sold on the black market, Mr. Phillips fired off a letter to its president: "The vast majority of American car owners are patriotically living within their gasoline allotments. The black market lives on the small minority of people who either do not understand or who disregard the damaging effects of the traffic and the fact that it springs from criminal roots."
After the war, he became president of Bates, overseeing a large expansion in its faculty and infrastructure.
He retired from the position in 1967, but continued to work as a consultant to General Electric and other companies and as a director on several corporate boards.
He also wrote several textbooks on marketing and retailing.
He is survived by one son, Charles Phillips Jr., of Lexington, Va.; one daughter, Carol Ann Taylor, of Birmingham, Ala.; five grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. His wife, Evelyn, died six months ago.

HEADLINE: Thieves Methodically Strip Iraq Of Treasures From a Storied Past

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: HATRA, Iraq

 BODY:
A little over a year ago, in a brazen act of vandalism becoming very familiar here, thieves struck the ruins of this ancient temple city, once the capital of a mysterious kingdom whose people worshiped the Sun, the Moon and Mars. The thieves were discriminating. They lopped off the head from a priceless, recently restored statue of a king 18 centuries old.
A few hundred miles to the south, in Babylon, several glass cases in a local museum were smashed to remove the finest examples of cuneiform writing on clay tablets and small cylinder seals used to authenticate Babylonian documents. 
 A few months ago, at Khorsabad, the magnificent head of an Assyrian winged bull from a first century B.C. palace was cut off and then sawed into 11 pieces for easier shipping.
All over Iraq, the modern nation situated in the fertile crescent of ancient Mesopotamia, centuries of history are disappearing piece by piece, Iraqi archeologists and Western scholars say. American experts who worked in Iraq before the 1991 Persian Gulf war, among them McGuire Gibson of the University of Chicago and John Malcolm Russell of Columbia University, have been warning for several years that Iraq's archeological sites are in danger of being stripped clean.
Visits to several sites and museums provide a rare look at how and why this is happening.
The thieves arrive with guns, knockout drugs, cars with false license plates and armies of desert nomads prepared to dig for meager daily wages. They often have lists of what to take, said Mouad Said, director general of Iraq's Department of Antiquities and Heritage.
"This criminal world is so well organized," Mr. Said said, "that we can trace some routes directly from a Bedouin tent in the desert to one of the main dealers or collectors in England, the United States or Switzerland."
Several factors are now combining to make Iraq highly vulnerable to archeological theft.
First, there is the trove itself.
For much of this century, Iraq had been assiduously restoring and guarding its antiquities and archeological sites, prohibiting or strictly limiting the export of artifacts. The process accelerated under the Iraqi monarchy set up by the British after World War I when the defeated Ottoman Empire, which had ruled Iraq since the 16th century, was dismantled and Britain, whose troops occupied Baghdad in 1917, was given a mandate to administer the country.
A British archeologist, Gertrude Bell, who came to Iraq as secretary to the British Governor, was instrumental in helping Iraq set up institutions to preserve its exceptional heritage. She was also often a lone voice against the longstanding European practice of pillaging sites for Western museums and private collectors.
The country became a treasure house of extraordinary proportions, and everything was scrupulously catalogued. The Iraq Museum in Baghdad was ranked among the world's greatest of its kind. Around the country, dozens of history and archeological museums were built.
Iraqi archeologists say they have always been aware that they are responsible for safeguarding a heritage significant beyond the country's borders.
"Mesopotamia is not the cultural property of the Iraqi Government," Mr. Said said. "It is the property of humankind. Everybody knows that the cradle of Mediterranean and Western and Arab civilizations lies in large part in Mesopotamia as well as in Egypt and Greece."
The Garden of Eden blossomed here, legends say. More verifiably, this was the home of Sumerian, Babylonian and Assyrian empires whose collective records date back 7,000 years. Here, cities were first built and recognizable governments established. The plow and wheel and irrigation systems were perfected. Writing was systematized and the first known written legal code was compiled by Hammurabi, who ruled Babylon in the 18th century B.C.
 
Work at Site Stops, With Sanctions Cited
The work of discovering and restoring archeological sites survived the fall of the monarchy in 1958, the political turmoil that followed and Saddam Hussein's rise to full power in 1979.
Here in Hatra, Ismail Rashid, the archeologist in charge, said work went on largely uninterrupted from the 1930's until 1995, when it was abruptly stopped by the Government, which said the money for restoration had run out. The Government blamed international sanctions imposed on Iraq after its 1990 invasion of Kuwait, as it does for all catastrophes that have befallen the country since then.
But money has not run out for the construction of huge palaces for Mr. Hussein and his clan. Nor is Iraq short of soldiers or unemployed people to guard archeological sites. Most sites, however, are left unattended. At Hatra, an old man with a hunting rifle is all the security the archeologists can afford for a site scattered over hundreds of acres.
Hatra, more than 200 miles northwest of Baghdad, is of special importance because so little is known of the people who lived here and there is much to be learned from what they left behind.
This was a pre-Islamic kingdom that lasted four centuries, from the late second century B.C. to 241 A.D., when it was overthrown by Persians. These people were Aramaic speakers who had been influenced by the Greek, Roman and Hellenistic civilizations. Medusa and Hippocrates are depicted in reliefs on temple walls.
Hatra was apparently the center of a polytheistic religion, with a huge central temple complex and smaller sanctuaries. Its three primary gods -- Mirn, Marmartan and Birmin -- have been identified as the Sun God, the Moon Goddess and Mars, or "Son of the Master of the Universe."
A custom in Hatra left unusual personal records of its citizens. People apparently had statues of themselves and their families placed at their homes, with inscriptions relating events in their lives.
Iraqi scholars are fascinated by what a study of a pre-Islamic Arabic culture like this could teach the contemporary Middle East. For now, however, blocks of stone lie waiting for archeologists. And out of the emptiness of the scrubland for miles around thieves have struck Hatra again and again, Mr. Said said in an interview in his Baghdad office. He said the life-size royal head stolen from Hatra a year ago was located when it was offered for sale in London. Fortunately, he said, the buyer decided to return it to Iraq.
Mr. Said said a pattern had developed: an artifact is selected and a contract made with Iraqi smugglers to steal it.
The problem apparently predates the gulf war, though Iraqi officials do not want to talk about that. In the 1980's, a seven-year war with Iran deflected Government attention from archeology and the tourist industry that Iraq once planned to create around it. At Hatra, an abandoned tourist hotel stands forlornly on the horizon.
The situation deteriorated sharply after the invasion of Kuwait and the gulf war. Museums were widely looted, especially in the south, where a brief rebellion took place. Thirty museums are now empty, Mr. Said said. In Baghdad, the Iraq Museum was closed during the war to protect it from American bombing, the Government said. It has never reopened.
Then the looting of unprotected archeological sites began.
Mr. Said said the theft of Mesopotamian treasures had fallen roughly into three phases. The first was the wartime and postwar looting, carried out almost at random. "Then the organized smuggling began," he said, describing the second phase, from about 1992 to 1994.
For example, he said: "Gangs in the north attacked the monastery of al-Sayda at al-Qosh, north of Mosul. The monastery, one of the oldest in the Christian world, had its own museum. They gathered all the monks and put them in one room and stole all the relics."
Smugglers took pieces out of the country to Saudi Arabia and Jordan or through the semiautonomous Kurdish areas of the north to Iran and Turkey, he said. And operations became more technically skillful and more directly linked to specific "orders" placed by collectors and even indirectly by museums abroad.
Mr. Said would not name the museums or dealers, but said some were in the United States and Britain. Swiss auction houses handled some objects too hot for London, he said.
"In Ashur, thieves came in cars with fake numbers corresponding to license plates issued to members of our department," he said. "They played as if they were sent from us. They knocked out the guards with injections."
 
An Army of Diggers Find the Best Pieces
In the third phase, starting around 1994, he continued, thieves "invade an unexcavated site with hundreds of peasants and Bedouin who dig like -- shall I say -- ants for one or two days." The site is quickly stripped of the best pieces.
Mr. Said said the Government could not be blamed for poor security. A 1994 law gives courts the right to impose a death sentence on people who steal antiquities, Mr. Said said, and the police have generally been helpful in pursuing cases. He added that about 900 people had been arrested in the last six years.
Like other Iraqi officials, he blames the United Nations Security Council sanctions committee, which has turned down his request for, among other things, two additional cars for his staff, photographic equipment to document valuable pieces in case they must be traced and a computer to create a data base.
Mr. Said said that adding more experts to his staff and making them more mobile would be a deterrent. "My request was for only $57,000," he said.
The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization supported Mr. Said's request for an embargo exemption. But officials of the agency said they must abide by sanctions committee decisions.
Given the large numbers of imported cars in Baghdad, Iraqis and foreign experts say it is difficult to understand why the Security Council thinks that two automobiles for the antiquities department would help prop up President Hussein. Or one computer and a few cameras, when other Government offices bristle with technology.
But perhaps what most disturbs archeologists is the growing awareness of how many Iraqis are involved in the illegal trade, and not all of them, as the Government insists, desperate for money because of the sanctions. Sanctions, however, do make illegal trading more tempting.
 
How High Do Links To Smugglers Go?
No one will entertain questions about how high in the country's leadership links to smugglers can be traced. Mr. Said deflects blame to collectors abroad and sometimes to foreign diplomats and United Nations officials. He said Iraq had confiscated artifacts in diplomatic pouches, which he said would be displayed at the Iraq Museum, along with their contents. At the museum, however, a curator did not seem to know about these items. United Nations officials said that they had not heard of such charges.
Mr. Said told a revealing story about the head of the Assyrian winged bull stolen from Khorsabad. The police caught a gang of thieves with the 1,500-pound loot, he said. They were tried under the new law and at least six have been executed.
They appeared to be members of a new business elite based on smuggling, Mr. Said said.
"They were rich people," he said. "And they have destroyed one of the most magnificent pieces in the world. They have chopped off the bull's head and cut it into 11 pieces.
"Iraqis will never accept two things -- narcotics or the destruction of relics. But these people were willing to take handsaws and cut up this magnificent piece for $250,000."

Map of Iraq showing the location of Hatra: The ruins of Hatra lie in the fertile crescent of ancient Mesopotamia. (pg. 6)

HEADLINE: Study Finds That Youngest U.S. Children Are Poorest

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
While the number of American children living in poverty has declined from the peak of 1993, children younger than 6 remain the poorest age group in the nation, according to a study by the National Center for Children in Poverty.
The study, released on Wednesday, found that 5.5 million children, nearly 1 in 4, were living in poverty in 1996, compared with 6.4 million three years earlier. 
 And the percentage of poor young children with working parents has increased substantially in that period. In fact, 63 percent of the poor children were in families with at least one working parent, compared with 54 percent in 1993. Most of the increase occurred in 1995.
Since 1993, more than six million Americans, mostly children, have left the welfare rolls. That trend has accelerated since the Federal welfare law of 1996, which required that recipients of public aid find jobs. Although it is too early to analyze the law's effects on child poverty, the study highlights how many jobs pay too little to lift a family out of poverty. Even in families where the single mothers worked full time, the report found, 17 percent of the children under 6 still lived in poverty.
"Many working families with young children are still struggling to escape poverty," said the director of the center, Dr. Lawrence Aber. "The United States continues to have the highest rate of young-child poverty of any Western industrialized nation. Decades of experience teach us that we cannot rely on economic growth alone to overcome young-child poverty."
The poverty rate of young children rose faster among Hispanic groups than among white or black children. Over the three years, the percentage of poor Hispanic children younger than 6 grew 54 percent, compared with a 30 percent rise among whites and 15 percent among blacks.
Children living with unmarried mothers were about five times as likely to be poor as those living with married parents.
The study is based on the Census Bureau's most recent Current Population Survey. In 1996, the official poverty line was $16,036 a year for a family of four and $12,516 for a family of three. Almost half the young children in poverty, however, were in families with extremely low incomes, less than half those levels.
The study also applied an alternative measure of poverty to gauge how government programs and policies affect child poverty. Unlike the official measure of poverty used by the Government, the alternative measure includes the value of food stamps, housing subsidies, school lunch benefits and the earned-income tax credit, which supplements the incomes of low-wage earners.
Using that measure, the study found that without the earned-income tax credit, the rate of young children who were living in poverty in 1996 would have been 23 percent higher.
"Our findings," Dr. Aber said, "clearly demonstrate how the right policies can make a difference."

HEADLINE: The Gap

BYLINE: By Andrew Porter; Andrew Porter, the Rhodes Professor of Imperial History at King's College, London, is the editor of "The Oxford History of the British Empire, Volume 3: The Nineteenth Century," to be published next year.

 BODY:

THE WEALTH AND POVERTY OF NATIONS
 Why Some Are So Rich
 and Some So Poor.
 By David S. Landes.
 650 pp. New York:
 W. W. Norton & Company. $30. 
 "We live in a world of inequality and diversity. . . . Now the big challenge and threat is the gap in wealth and health that separates rich and poor. . . . Here is the greatest single problem and danger facing the world of the third millennium." It is in the interests of rich as well as poor peoples to see this gap narrowed. David S. Landes believes, however, that progress toward that goal requires us first to recognize that the causes of this division are neither merely contemporary nor even recent but historic and very long-standing. To alleviate today's disparities we must first understand that they have their roots deeply embedded in the past 600 years or so of world history.
The result is "The Wealth and Poverty of Nations," a large book, a wealth of information and a striking if stark thesis. Landes argues that the key to national wealth in the modern world has been the Industrial Revolution, "begun in Britain in the 18th century and emulated around the world. . . . Some countries made an industrial revolution and became rich; and others did not and stayed poor." His emphasis on industrialization is less contentious than his reference to the making of that revolution. In asking what made it possible, Landes robustly dismisses many of the explanations that in recent decades have had their 15 minutes of fame. Natural endowments, including landscape, water, soils, minerals or climate, have been more or less important at different times, but they were never sufficient conditions: geography is not destiny. The timing of opportunities for industrial development has brought variations in the paths of individual countries but no insuperable obstacles. The making of an industrial revolution has always been dependent ultimately on a society's prior culture and continuing qualities. Riches, without the appropriate cultural traits, have never been secure or sustainable.
The first industrial revolution -- Britain's -- was the product of a society that had developed a sense of national cohesion; a capacity to compete; a respect for, and a concern to impart, empirical and technical knowledge; and a preference for advancement by merit or competence. Its members had the ability not just to acquire but to use money, they respected honesty, and their institutions provided security both for property and for enjoyment of the rewards of labor or enterprise. Other societies were able to follow, catch up with and overtake Britain because they could emulate its achievements. Perhaps they shared the crucial medieval legacy of curiosity, inventiveness and multiple sources of initiative, or derived its equivalent from internal sources. And they were sufficiently disciplined to forego present consumption for future gain. Thus the United States, Germany, Japan and Australia are among the rich. Their preconditioning, dominant values propelled them into the attempt to increase riches; their success, even while calling for defense by incessant adaptation, has generally bred success.
Other societies, much as their rulers and people may have wanted to be richer rather than poorer, have never quite made it -- at least not so far. They have proved incapable of generating from within themselves the necessary conditions for the creation of riches. Landes offers many reasons for these failures. Although Protestantism gets high marks, religion has much to answer for. From South America to the Middle East and South Asia, notably in the forms of Roman Catholicism and Islam, it has persistently elevated authority and cramped initiative, and it has encouraged values inimical to widespread experimentation and so exacerbated other more substantial difficulties. Landes argues that Islam's coincidence with the accidental riches of oil and with authoritarian governments that often generate little loyalty, along with its capacity for discouraging domestic investment in skills and knowledge, has made it particularly damaging. Other countries have been too ready to take temporarily easy options to preserve the status quo, to avoid the rigors of necessary change or to be seduced by ignorant siren voices of "international placemen and experts," who sing "songs of innocence and inexperience."
Landes's list of false prophets with misguided diagnoses is long. It includes dependency theorists; the new economic historians, who neglect older findings and dismiss any such thing as the Industrial Revolution; econometricians in pursuit of numbers, however unreal; multiculturalists irrelevantly quibbling over the terminology of European "discovery" of the rest of the world; ethnologists denying that there are grounds for criticizing or detecting weaknesses in another culture. By contrast, he admires the champion of the Protestant ethic Max Weber, and Karl Wittfogel, the outstanding student of what he calls "Oriental despotism." "If we learn anything from the history of economic development, it is that culture makes all the difference," Landes says. In the pursuit of wealth, failure or success are ultimately determined from within, not imposed from outside.
Thus many conventional explanations of Western success and the relative failures of the rest -- the conquest of the Americas, transmission of European diseases, slavery, the supposedly imprisoning effect of Western scholarship for Oriental societies -- have been far less significant than is widely claimed. This is neither to deny nor condone "the contempt, violence and sadistic brutality" of many encounters between the West and other societies. It is rather to argue, for example, that the historical diversity of "spectacular successes" in East Asia, "mixed results in Latin America" and "outright regression in . . . much of Africa" leads inexorably to the conclusion that "colonization in itself . . . does not dictate failure." Imperial rule was of course neither a modern nor a Western invention, nor intrinsically tied to capitalism. Colonialism delayed and distorted opportunities for development -- by introducing illegitimate and alien forms of government, manipulating tariffs or neglecting education -- but such consequences could be corrected. If they wish, even late-comers can cultivate the values that count: "work, thrift, honesty, patience, tenacity." How best to encourage that ability and self-confidence, how to nurture cultural transformation and self-empowerment, remains to be decided.
Few historians could have argued this case so powerfully. Over four decades, David Landes, a professor of history and economics at Harvard, has demonstrated mastery of many themes. As a historian of economic imperialism, he explored in "Bankers and Pashas" (1958) the rapacity of Europe's investors and the encounter with international finance of Egypt's developmentally minded rulers in the mid-19th century. Wearing his hat as a student of technological change, he produced "The Unbound Prometheus" (1969), an influential study of industrial development in Western Europe from 1750. More recently, his "Revolution in Time" (1983) revealed his acute sense of how cultural convention and social habit have variously combined with technological capacity to shape societies' economic and social development. Now these themes and a lifetime's reflection have been drawn together in a passionate and hard-hitting -- or, as some will feel, blunt, oversimplified and partisan -- study of the making of the modern world. It punctures much scholarly pretension and demonstrates the poverty of economics uninformed by historical understanding. Its erudition ranges from the Aztecs to modern Zaire (now Congo), from the limits of economic rationality to the technological consequences of chopsticks. Readers cannot but be provoked and stimulated by this splendidly iconoclastic and refreshing book.

HEADLINE: Word & Image;
The Next Great Story

BYLINE: By Max Frankel 

 BODY:
I have been burrowing for a scoop far removed from Monica Lewinsky, for a discovery that might ignite entirely new curiosities and emotions. If jingo is an even greater passion than libido, I have found it, at least in dim outline: get ready for the collapse of nationhood.
The media are full of the evidence, though none have yet connected the dots of what will surely be the next century's Great Revolution. One propellant is technological: the capacity of computers to transfer information past all national barriers in nanoseconds and for nanocents. The Soviet empire could not survive the world's unmediated communication with its citizens. Now China is feeling the pressure; millions there are already reading the indigenous on-line anti-Communist magazine Tunnel.
Another propellant is financial. The world's uninhibited traffic in information has empowered investors to move vast sums of money from one country and currency to another. And that has the effect not only of erasing distances and borders but also of denying "sovereign" governments the power to command their own fates.
The permeability of financial frontiers has already produced a profound psychological shift. As George Shultz, William Simon and Walter Wriston -- a notably conservative trio of economic experts -- recently wrote in The Wall Street Journal: "The gold standard has been replaced by the information standard, an iron discipline that no government can evade. Foreign exchange rates are now set by tens of thousands of traders at computer terminals around the globe. Their judgments about monetary and economic policies are instantly translated in the cross rates of currencies. No country can hide."
The traders are disciplining countries they may have never seen, swiftly punishing mismanagement and corruption simply by shifting their money from weak to strong currencies. In recent months they not only forced Thailand and South Korea to adopt remedial austerity but also directly influenced the outcome of their elections.
National frontiers and governments can no more protect societies against economic storms than against meteorological dangers. The recent financial quakes in Asia shook banks and markets throughout the Pacific and threaten a tidal wave of consequences in the United States. Mismanagement, misjudgment and corruption in one place thus threaten standards of living everywhere and give all peoples an incentive to inspect and regulate the behavior of all others. That is why more and more societies are yielding the pretense of sovereignty to a variety of new international arrangements over which they will have to find new political authority.
Wearing the impersonal disguise of the International Monetary Fund, bankers and bureaucrats have learned to impose painful austerities even on proud dictators. Other "international civil servants" are laboring to create a new West European currency, the euro, which promises to generate powerful new political pressures on both sides of the Atlantic. The euro requires coordinating the interest rates of the participating 15 nations, and its survival will also soon require coordinating 15 different tax systems, wage patterns and welfare systems. And since the euro countries will not be content to let unaccountable bankers manage all this coordination, they will inevitably create economic and political institutions that operate outside the control of any single state.
And if the euro flies, our dollar will feel the effect. As Lester Thurow recently observed in The New York Review of Books, Europeans who possess a viable common currency will need fewer dollar reserves, while non-Europeans, like the Saudis, will shift some of their reserves from dollars to euros. The dollar will become much more vulnerable to depreciation, and even America's economy will come under foreign inspection. Bankers and traders everywhere will demand independent audits of the books and procedures of all societies, and they will agitate for standardized rules of bookkeeping and management.
In leaping across national boundaries, these auditors will be following the trails already blazed by the Trans-Atlantic Business Dialogue and World Trade Organization. As Jeff Gerth recently wrote in The Times, the "Dialogue" is an international forum in which unelected negotiators are rewriting the safety and environmental standards governing the sale of automobiles.
The same pressures for transnational action are rising in diplomacy. People living far from Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia are clamoring for the arrest, trial and punishment of those countries' "war criminals" even though there exist no duly legislated laws and police forces to conduct such a policy. And lacking a tax collector, the United Nations can ill afford the troops that operate in many regions under its global banner.
A similar and instructive condition prevailed in 18th-century America. After their rebellion against the British crown, the American colonies were so jealous of their hard-won sovereignty that they formed only the loosest political union. It had a merely advisory Continental Congress, like the U.N. General Assembly, and no real executive or judicial authority. George Washington was left in command of 13 allied armies enlisted, paid and grudgingly contributed by the individual states.
As the American economies floundered, Washington's home state of Virginia summoned a convention in Annapolis "to discuss the regulation of trade among the states," but only 5 of 13 colonies bothered to appear. In despair, these five signed an appeal drafted by Alexander Hamilton of New York for "commissioners" of all states -- large and small, mercantile and agricultural, slave and free -- to assemble in Philadelphia in 1787. And there, finally, they devised a more perfect Union.
When will the world follow our example? As Washington observed, political evils "must be sorely felt before they can be removed."
