HEADLINE: Overkill Is Not Dead

BYLINE: By Brian Hall; Brian Hall is the author of five books, including "The Impossible Country: A Journey Through the Last Days of Yugoslavia." He last wrote for the magazine on Boutros Boutros-Ghali. Paul Shambroom has photographed nuclear weapons over the years as part of a series on "hidden places of power" in the United States.

 BODY:
The B-61-11, the latest addition to America's nuclear arsenal, is known as an earth penetrator. The new nose and steel casings add weight and strength, and the fuse has been changed to delay detonation until seconds after impact. The result is a bomb that burrows several feet before exploding, enabling it to obliterate targets like command bunkers and chemical-weapons factories several hundred feet beneath the surface. All in all, it represents a significant leap in bomb design, and that's precisely the problem. Pentagon officials deny that the B-61-11 is a new weapon.
This is because the "physics package" -- the primary fission reaction and the secondary fusion reaction that power the explosion -- is the same as in the B-61-7 (which offers "dial a yield," literally a dial on the casing that adjusts the payload from 10 kilotons up to 340 kilotons, a kiloton being equal to 1,000 tons of TNT). But if you define a weapon by its military application, this one is new; the Pentagon did not previously have an earth penetrator. 
 The interesting question is what targets military planners have in mind for the B-61-11. The decision to develop it dates to 1995, five years after the proclaimed end of the cold war. Start 1, the initial strategic arms reduction treaty, was in force, committing the United States and Russia to cut their strategic arsenals deeply. Start 2 had been signed, calling for even more cuts, and awaited ratification. Russia had repudiated Communism and become a democracy, its conventional forces had withered and eastern Europe was free. Both sides had celebrated the move away from the nuclear brink, and a relieved public had stopped worrying about a nuclear holocaust. So what was the purpose of the B-61-11? Surely not to find a better way to jellify Boris Yeltsin in his underground command post.
Is the cold war really over? Has the arms race ended? Has United States policy on strategic weapons caught up with Ronald Reagan's soothing proclamation that "a nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought"? Consider:
* In the recent Iraq crisis, the Clinton Administration once again refused to rule out the use of nuclear weapons, thereby inflaming relations with Moscow and undermining its own leadership on nuclear proliferation.
* While President Clinton has repeatedly touted the "de-targeting" of American and Russian missiles, retargeting would take only seconds. In fact, retargeting doesn't add a single second to the launch -- it is standard procedure to send target instructions to the missiles before they lift off. The United States and Russia can still fire off thousands of nuclear warheads within a few minutes of your reading this sentence.
* The Administration plans to spend $4.5 billion a year -- more than the average annual cost, in constant dollars, for building up the arsenal during the cold war -- on the Stockpile Stewardship and Management Program, which is a virtual nuclear testing regime. With items like the $1.2 billion Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory's ignition facility, the program will enable the Department of Energy, in its own words, to pursue "structural enhancements" to nuclear weapons if needed because of "changes in military requirements." (But not, of course, to develop "new weapons.")
* Under Start 1, the number of "deployed" strategic warheads (weapons mounted on long-range missiles and carried in heavy bombers) is coming down to 7,000 to 8,000, but the Pentagon still reserves another 3,000 to 5,000 weapons as a "hedge" against future hostile relations with Russia. Even under Start 2, which mandates a ceiling of 3,500 deployed strategic weapons, the military intends to retain thousands more.
* The entire treaty process is paralyzed, with Start 2 mired in the Russian Duma and little headway being made on the financial and diplomatic issues that have bogged it down.
* The Pentagon is moving ahead with research on missile defenses that experts agree will be indistinguishable in capabilities from strategic missile defenses, technically in violation of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty. It is permitted to do this because in Helsinki in 1997, the White House persuaded the Russians to allow each side to decide for itself whether it was violating the treaty in this instance. The Russians, out of weakness, went along.
* Computers are being upgraded to allow faster retargeting that, with improved satellites, will allow more accurate and rapid strikes against Russian rail-mobile and road-mobile intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBM's).
* The Pentagon continues to manufacture D-5 missiles to replace the less accurate C-4 missiles in Trident II ballistic missile submarines, producing a better "hard target kill" capability against Russian missile silos.
* With the MX missile slated for retirement under Start 2, its warheads will be transferred to Minuteman III missiles, upping the yield of many of them from 170 kilotons to 300 kilotons. (By comparison, the Hiroshima bomb was about 13 kilotons.)
* This year, we are spending $25 billion just to maintain and operate our nuclear forces, according to Stephen Schwartz, who tracks nuclear weapons costs at the Brookings Institution.
 So why did the Pentagon decide to develop the B-61-11?
The reasoning goes back to Ronald Reagan's 1981 National Security Decision Directive 13, which called for the United States to develop and maintain the capacity to prevail in a protracted nuclear war with the Soviet Union.
Part of that guidance required the United States to hold the political and military leadership of the Soviet Union at risk. But new intelligence in the 1980's suggested that the Soviets had built extensive wartime command posts deep underground. So in 1987, the Reagan Administration halted the retirement of the largest warhead in the U.S. inventory, the nine-megaton B-53 -- originally developed as a "city buster" and nicknamed Crowdpleaser -- and gave it the new mission of digging out these underground command posts.
This was a hugely messy approach, even by the inelegant standards of nuclear weapons. So in 1993, the military began to look for an earth-penetrating alternative. By this time, of course, the cold war was "over," but the 1981 guidance still had not been changed. Moreover, in 1994 the Clinton Administration conducted a Nuclear Posture Review that began with hopeful talk about innovative thinking and ended with the timid conclusion that America still needed the traditional nuclear triad to deter a Russian attack -- land-based ICBM's, submarine-launched missiles and bombers. It concluded as well that America needed to maintain a reserve of warheads numbering in the thousands. As a matter of policy, therefore, Washington still felt that it needed to hold Yeltsin and company "at risk" down in that bunker, and in 1995, development of the B-61-11 was approved by the Administration and Congress. In January 1997, it entered the service.
Meanwhile, the 1981 guidance still had not been changed, meaning that the entire nuclear force was still trained on targets in Russia. (Additional plans existed to program strikes within an hour or so against China as well as selected nations thought to possess chemical and biological weapons.) We don't often think about what this targeting means, in concrete terms; in years past we couldn't, because the information was top secret. But with the easing of East-West tensions, some of the story is beginning to emerge.
 
A Pentagon Blueprint for Nuclear War
At any given time, the United States has on alert more than 2,300 warheads, delivering a combined explosive power of about 550 megatons (550 million tons of TNT) -- the equivalent, to use a popular measure, of 44,000 Hiroshimas. This is the "overkill" that has been an element of the popular myth about nuclear weapons for decades. But to measure "overkill" by Hiroshima misses the point of what the U.S. military perceives as the weapons' purpose.
The military has always devoted itself to "counterforce" nuclear targeting -- aiming for the other side's weapons and military apparatus rather than its cities. This is not for moral reasons but because the Pentagon considers it wasteful to expend munitions on things that don't fire back. The popular idea that nuclear weapons exist only to insure that they never be used is not a military idea. The blueprint for nuclear operations against Russia is the Single Integrated Operational Plan, or SIOP. Very few people, perhaps a few dozen at a time in the military and the White House, have a detailed and comprehensive knowledge of the plan. Furthermore, few Presidents have taken the trouble to enter this circle, since there are more pressing claims on their attention.
The secrecy, coupled with the extreme complexity of choreographing the destruction of concrete-fortified, buried, hidden or mobile forces by missiles and bombers, has resulted in virtually no one having a workable grasp of the war plans except the targeters themselves. "If you look at the list," said the head of Strategic Command, Gen. Eugene Habiger, about an open letter published in December 1996 by 62 generals and admirals from around the world calling for deeper cuts in strategic forces and a commitment to the eventual abolition of nuclear weapons, "there are only one or two or maybe half a dozen who really understand what's going on."
But one of them is Gen. George Lee Butler, who as a former head of Strategic Command understands very well what's going on. Butler already had doubts about the operational feasibility of the nuclear war plan when he took over what was then Strategic Air Command in early 1991. (SAC was replaced by Strategic Command, or Stratcom, in 1992, when the Air Force and Navy nuclear arsenals were finally brought under a single command.) In his first months at SAC, Butler undertook a painstaking review of the million lines of computer code that constitute the SIOP. For the first time, he saw in detail what happens when broad Presidential guidance is translated into actual weapons aimed at actual targets, what he calls "climbing down the ladder of abstraction." He was appalled at what he found at the bottom rung.
For example, of the 12,500 targets in the SIOP at that time, one was slated to be hit by 69 consecutive nuclear weapons. This, it turns out, was a result of planners following the process to its logical conclusion. At the level of a Presidential directive, a document of a thousand words or so, you begin with a reasonable-sounding requirement: to hold the political and military leadership "at risk." That guidance goes to the Office of the Secretary of Defense, which in a 15- or 20-page policy document on nuclear weapons employment adds some detail, like the criteria for choosing the kinds of leadership facilities that should be targeted. The document then goes to the Strategic Plans and Policy Directorate of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, which in a 60-page volume lists specific types of facilities to be struck and damage requirements to be met. The volume then goes to Stratcom, where the types of facilities to be destroyed are matched against a database of potential targets, yielding a list of the actual targets and the number of weapons needed to take them out.
Butler won't say which target those 69 weapons were aimed at. According to Bruce Blair, a former Minuteman launch officer and an expert on the operational aspects of nuclear war fighting who is now at Brookings, a reasonable guess would be one of the deeply buried command complexes. The target, he says, was probably Chekhov, the Russian general staff's main command post, about 40 miles south of Moscow.
Let's assume that the war plan called for a 90 to 95 percent confidence in the destruction of this command post, which is a typical figure for that class of target. Blair dug into his notes for a statement by a high official at SAC in the mid-1980's that the highest kill probability for the United States' best weapon against deeply buried, sprawling, hardened command posts was less than 5 percent. He got out a calculator, assumed a kill probability of 4 percent for one weapon and started multiplying. To attain a 50 percent confidence in destroying the target required 17 weapons. When Blair got up to 69 weapons, the "kill probability" had reached 94 percent.
As you can see, then, it is all perfectly rational. And perfectly plannable, too, since what is a mere 69 nuclear weapons out of 12,000?
Consider, as well, how petty the targets can get when you're looking to dispatch thousands of weapons. I asked General Butler about this, and he said: "Take communications sites, for example. The most likely way to cripple a communications site is to strike its antenna. Now what is an antenna? It's an ungainly spire of structural steel. If this wasn't a nuclear war, you would send an airplane with a couple of 500-pound bombs, or even send in a Special Forces team to topple the thing with dynamite. What do you do when you're a nuclear war planner? You target a nuclear weapon against it. A nuclear weapon measured in the, what, half-megaton range? Whatever it takes!
"Part of understanding the grotesque excesses of the nuclear age is to appreciate that what might have been a seemingly reasonable war plan in the Second World War -- a thousand or more bombers delivering thousands of 500-pound bombs -- in the nuclear era you had much the same thing, only the weapons were nuclear. And they were going to targets that, taken out of this apocalyptic context, you would say: 'You're going to strike a radio antenna with a half-megaton bomb? What are you thinking about?' "
But that was the old SIOP. During Butler's tenure the number of targets was reduced from 12,500 to about 3,000. And five years have passed since that effort, during which, presumably, targeting changes have continued. Nevertheless, little comfort can be derived from the reduction in targets to the 3,000 range. Many of those targets were in eastern Europe or were units of the Red Army, which has largely dissolved, or were industrial plants that have stopped producing anything of value. What has almost certainly been retained is as complete a strike as we can marshal against the single aspect of Russia's military power that we still fear -- its nuclear forces. As the independent nuclear expert and author William M. Arkin puts it, "In essence, Stratcom has been able to manipulate -- they would say 'guide' -- reductions to retain the core, which is the ability to take out all strategic Russian forces and command and control, i.e., a first strike." In other words, those radio antennae are still in the nuclear cross hairs.
The effects on the Russian people of a counterforce strike, while inevitably horrible, are hard to predict precisely because we don't know what is in the current SIOP, which is highly classified. But Butler tells a story that suggests that debate on the subject is academic. "One of the exercises I asked my staff to go through was to remove all the weapons directly targeted on Moscow and just calculate radiation levels in the city by looking at the strikes upwind of the city in various climatological scenarios. The result was exactly as I would have predicted: the city was rendered uninhabitable for generations."
This is why critics of the Start process point out that even if Start 2 is ratified by the Russian Duma (where it is currently languishing), and even if Start 3 is negotiated and ratified, and implementation goes according to schedule, then in January 2008, after another decade of peaceful and reasonable cooperation, the Pentagon will still have 2,000 to 2,500 warheads aimed at Russia. That these would be delivered in a "counterforce" posture means, at best, slow radiological slaughter of millions rather than fast, blast-pressure, thermal slaughter of millions. Our "glide path," as the Clinton Administration likes to call it -- actually a good metaphor, since it implies no impetus from the Government -- is a "reduction" in nuclear forces that masks stasis.
Last year, the Clinton administration finally moved to update the 1981 Reagan directive, but only in response to complaints from Stratcom that the old guidance could not be carried out under the ceiling of 2,000 to 2,500 weapons proposed for Start 3. And a Presidential Decision Directive issued in November only reaffirms Reagan's guidance from the depths of the cold war, with one notable exception. According to Arkin, it stipulates that although we still must plan for fighting a protracted nuclear war, we no longer have to be sure of winning it. In other words, the White House replaced a delusional cold war guidance with a merely impractical one.
The guidance also reaffirms the longstanding policy of reserving the option in some scenarios of using nuclear weapons as deterrents against other weapons of mass destruction (W.M.D.'s), like chemical and biological weapons. Since the early 1990's, the Pentagon has had plans for targeting Libya, Iran and North Korea and other countries suspected of developing or possessing W.M.D.'s.
In April 1996, Harold Smith, an assistant to the Secretary of Defense for atomic energy, spoke to a group of defense reporters about a buried Libyan chemical weapons factory under construction 40 miles southeast of Tripoli. He said that by the end of the year, the United States would have a nuclear weapon (presumably, the B-61-11) that would be capable of destroying the plant.
Good news -- except that the United States has declared since 1978 that it would not use or threaten to use nuclear weapons against a non-nuclear state that was a member in good standing of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, and Libya is such a member. When this contradiction was pointed out, William Perry, then Secretary of Defense, failed to clearly uphold the policy, saying, "We could have a devastating response without the use of nuclear weapons, but we would not forswear that possibility."
Last month, the United States Embassy in Moscow used the same formulation to counter (and yet not counter) angry speculation in the Russian Duma that Washington was considering using nuclear weapons against Iraq: "We are able to mount a devastating response without using nuclear weapons. Nevertheless, we do not rule out in advance any capability available to us." It so happens that Iraq is not a member in good standing of the Nonproliferation Treaty, but the implications for the treaty are the same because it is primarily Hussein's chemical and biological weapons, not his stalled nuclear capability, that the United States is after. Therefore the Administration has repeatedly undermined our key promise to signers of the Nonproliferation Treaty, while conceding it has no military reason to do so. The implication -- presumably, a deliberate one -- is that the United States does not accept as a matter of principle any restrictions on its nuclear posture.
 
Edging Back to the Brink
In 1980, a computer-chip failure at Norad -- the United States command post in Colorado for assessing nuclear attacks -- generated a false alarm of an all-out Soviet missile attack. The officer in charge, who fretted for eight minutes about whether the attack was real, was subsequently fired. Regulations called for him to decide in three minutes. As recently as 1995, an American research rocket sent up off the coast of Norway to study the aurora borealis so alarmed the Russians that for the first time in their history, they activated the nuclear suitcase that accompanies the president. They were a couple of minutes from a decision on whether to launch before they determined that the rocket was not headed toward Russia.
It is widely assumed that the threat of a nuclear holocaust has subsided along with the relaxation of cold-war tensions and the absence of any conceivable reason to use nuclear weapons. In fact, the end of the cold war and the attendant collapse of the Russian military have produced a situation in which the chances of a nuclear exchange have arguably never been higher.
As long as there are nuclear weapons mounted on delivery vehicles and aimed at targets, there is always the chance that they will be used, inadvertently or otherwise. A task force in the Pentagon is looking at various de-alerting options that, by significantly increasing the time needed to prepare a missile for launching, would accomplish what Clinton's "de-targeting" only pretends to. But the armed forces and the Administration are apparently in no hurry. "I don't buy, if you will, the picture that we are on a 'dangerous hair-trigger' today," says one Administration security official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. General Habiger also spoke reassuringly about the state of the Russian nuclear forces when he returned from a trip there in November.
Think about the incongruity: General Habiger can visit Russia and be shown "a great deal about specifically their strategic rocket forces, from their command and control to allowing me to be the first, as I understand it, non-Russian to ever go into a nuclear weapons storage area and to see how they keep their nuclear weapons secure and safe." And Russia's head of Strategic Rocket Forces has previously visited Stratcom. Yet we don't have something as simple and inexpensive as a direct link between Norad and its counterpart outside Moscow, so that when the research rockets take off and the 15-minute countdowns begin there would be less chance for confusion. Sam Nunn, the former Senator, suggested such a link back in the 1980's, and Bruce Blair of Brookings has talked it up for years. Blair finds no particular objection to it in the Administration. It has simply been, he says, "crowded off the plate by other issues."
Meanwhile, the Central Intelligence Agency disagrees with Habiger's assessment that the Russian Strategic Rocket Forces are safe. A recurrent computer malfunction in the Russian system has lately been switching part of the force to combat mode automatically. Two-thirds of their early-warning radar installations no longer work, and they are missing two satellites, leaving holes in their warning system.
"I worry a great deal about the erosion of Russia's defense satellites," says Sam Nunn, former chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee and hardly an alarmist. "This is a serious national security problem." Nunn says that, back in the late 1970's and early 1980's, he had SAC assess "our ability and the Soviets' ability to detect the origin of a missile attack. That report is classified, but I can say this: the United States' ability wasn't at a desirable level, and Russia's was a lot worse. Since then we've gotten better and the Russians have gotten still worse."
 
Growing Instability
Accidental launch is only the most obvious danger posed by existing nuclear arsenals. Americans tend to think of nuclear weapons as an insurance policy, admittedly expensive but necessary in an uncertain world of Saddam Husseins and dangerous Russian nationalists. But that ignores the basic fact that nuclear weapons are highly political, and that perceptions of vulnerability on either side of the nuclear equation inevitably breed instability. Here again, the paralysis in nuclear policy is creating an increasingly dangerous situation.
William Arkin puts it starkly. "We actually have a greater capacity to destroy Russian nuclear forces than we did 10 years ago." Bruce Blair agrees: "The situation is more unstable than it has been, ever since the early 60's. The Russians are very vulnerable." The impoverished Russians cannot afford to keep more than one or two of their missile submarines at sea at any one time, and all of their rail-mobile ICBM's are in garrison, as are all but one or two regiments of their road-mobile ICBM's. Their bomber force appears to have degraded almost to insignificance. Thus, while the United States at all times has about 1,600 nuclear warheads at sea, where they are invulnerable (because submarines cannot be located), the Russians have only 200 to 300 warheads that are similarly protected.
Now, it may seem obvious that having 200 or 100 or even 50 invulnerable weapons should be a sufficient deterrent. If we nuked them, they could still bomb our 50 largest cities. But that's not the way deterrence theory works. Recall the "window of vulnerability," a central theme of Ronald Reagan's 1980 Presidential campaign and a central rationale behind the subsequent defense buildup. The Pentagon feared that the Soviets had acquired enough accurate, multiple-warhead missiles to destroy America's entire land-based ICBM force with only a portion of their strategic forces. In that event, the remaining U.S. forces would lack the firepower to wipe out Soviet nuclear forces, and thus our only recourse would be to retaliate against Soviet cities. But that would spur a retaliation against our own cities, resulting in scores of millions of American deaths. Thus, Washington's threat of retaliation would lack credibility, and the Soviet Union could dictate terms to its effectively disarmed foe.
To return to the present, the point is not what America's intentions are, but what some Russians believe them to be. And if there were a new period of political tension with Russia, the Russians' fears would very much be America's fears, too, because in this mirror-image game of use 'em or lose 'em (land-based forces must be launched before they are destroyed by opposing missiles with 15- or 30-minute flight times), the weaker a partner gets, the more dangerous it is. Furthermore, it is a downward spiral: realization of Russia's desperation and the increased chance of its acting irrationally could create incentives for America to launch first. An operational posture enforces its own logic.
 
Why Start Is Stuck
No one in the Clinton Administration argues that it is desirable to be poised on the brink of nuclear holocaust with a nonadversary. Officials contend that the tortuous Start process is the best path away from the brink because treaties "lock in" agreements and establish verification regimes to make both reversion and cheating more difficult. However, it is relevant to consider why the Start 2 treaty, ratified by the U.S. Senate in January 1996, still hasn't been ratified by the Russian Duma.
During the Start 2 negotiations in 1992, Boris Yeltsin proposed a ceiling on deployed strategic weapons of 2,000 on each side. Remarkably, the United States rejected that figure, insisting on 3,500. Gen. Colin Powell, who was Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff at the time, says, "We wanted 3,500 because, targeting-wise, it was what we felt we needed." However, he goes on, "I don't think it did any damage to our modernizing programs, either. That was not the major factor, but still, you spend a lot of money on a new program. . . ." He left the sentence unfinished, but in 1992 the Navy was in the middle of refitting Trident submarines with more accurate D-5 missiles and higher-yield warheads. This was to increase our ability to "kill" Russian missile silos.
General Butler insists, contra Powell, that we did not need 3,500 weapons for targeting purposes but, like Powell, he stresses the importance of bureaucratic and economic reasons. "When you go to those levels," he says of the 2,000 figure, "you start trading off systems. That always triggers interservice rivalry. We're talking tens of billions of dollars. You're talking about the future, the pride, the standing of the ballistic missile submarine force."
Washington's insistence on a higher ceiling quickly became a stumbling block. Start 2 centers on the banning of land-based missiles with more than one warhead, the so-called MIRV's (for multiple independently targetable re-entry vehicle). Because of the high number of Russian MIRV-ed missiles, if they wanted to de-MIRV and still have 3,500 deployed warheads, they would have to build hundreds of new single-warhead missiles, which they can't afford. Meanwhile, their whole force is aging, and officials on both sides agree that the Russian force will degrade to a level of 2,000 to 2,500 warheads within the next 10 years purely through attrition.
Officials in the Clinton Administration and at Stratcom contend that no one could have foreseen in 1992 that the Russian economy would deteriorate so fast, but that leaves unaddressed the question of why Yeltsin offered 2,000 in the first place. In Helsinki last March, Clinton and Yeltsin agreed to push back the date at which Start 2 was to take effect, thereby easing the financial problems for Russia by lowering the annual costs. Thus, having first slowed down the process by insisting on a ceiling of 3,500, we have fixed the ensuing problems by slowing down the process some more.
 
A 'Fatal Miscalculation'
But when it comes to souring the United States-Russian strategic relationship, the details of Start 2 are nothing compared with NATO expansion, a centerpiece of Clinton's foreign policy that was approved recently by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Besides sending a hostile message to Moscow, the expansion of a nuclear-capable NATO means moving the nuclear threat, at least theoretically, closer to Russian borders. In a recent New York Times Op-Ed column warning against NATO expansion, Howard Baker Jr., Sam Nunn, Brent Scowcroft and Alton Frye drew the right historic parallel: Germany after World War I. "The central failure of Versailles," they wrote, "lay in the fatal miscalculation of how to deal with a demoralized former adversary. That, above all, is the error we must not repeat."
Franklin C. Miller, Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy and Threat Reduction, says that it's "counterintuitive" for the Duma to stall on Start 2 because of the expansion of NATO. "If the United States could stay at Start 1 levels indefinitely, and the Russians can't afford to stay even at Start 2 levels, the last thing you want to do, if you believe NATO expansion is a threat, is allow an imbalance to grow in the strategic arsenals of the two sides. You want to ratify Start 2 and lock the United States in." But then he goes on to concede, "O.K., politics is politics."
Exactly. Russia is now a democracy, with the same sorts of power struggles that America has, in which logic sometimes matters less than perceptions. Imagine the reverse: Russia expanding a military alliance toward our borders while the Senate debates an arms treaty that can easily be made to look unfair to the United States, its imbalances to be redressed in a future treaty that Russia promises but refuses to formally negotiate. White House officials may be right when they say Yeltsin could win ratification of Start 2 if he fought hard enough. But like any president he has to choose his battles. Why is the United States making it so difficult for him?
In September, Yeltsin, on the day of a meeting with his defense minister, Igor Sergeyev, said that Russian security could be insured "even with 1,000 warheads, not to mention the 2,000 to 2,500 which are mentioned in the proposed Start 3 treaty." Stansfield Turner, the former C.I.A. director who has recently published a book advocating unilateral cuts in the American arsenal, asked in wonderment, "Why isn't Clinton saying: 'Yes! Let's get there!' " Subsequently, on a visit to Stockholm in December, the Russian President announced a unilateral one-third cut in the Russian strategic nuclear forces. Washington responded with a yawn. "We don't take what he says all that seriously," a senior American diplomatic official told The New York Times after the Stockholm comment (which was later retracted).
The Clinton Administration continues to insist that it will commit to nothing further in the realm of nuclear policy until the Duma ratifies Start 2. Officials call this "keeping pressure" on the Russians, or "holding their feet to the fire." Whenever you ask if the strategy is working, they express optimism. "I think we've turned a corner," Robert Bell of the National Security Council told me in October.
Start 2 was sent to the Duma on June 20, 1995.
It is now conventional wisdom that President Bush's 1991 letter to Saddam Hussein, hinting at U.S. willingness to retaliate with nuclear weapons, is what kept the Iraqis from using biological or chemical weapons in the gulf war. (It is rarely recalled that the letter warned in the same terms against igniting the Kuwaiti oil fields, but Hussein did it anyway.) Our nuclear threat, as many have argued, is empty, even fatuous. We now have many more bombs smarter than the ones we used in the gulf war. We have bombs guided by Global Positioning System satellites that can land within 30 feet of their targets when fired from 10 miles away. We have bombs that count floors as they crash down through a building, and detonate on the floor we want them to. With that kind of precision, we simply have no military need for nuclear weapons.
If the United States actually did use a nuclear weapon against Iraq, it would destroy its nonproliferation efforts, make Saddam Hussein a martyr and make itself an international pariah. Furthermore, the target is inconceivable. Baghdad? Out of the question. A chemical weapons site? All right, but which one? Or would America nuke each of the 60 suspected sites?
Defenders of "calculated ambiguity," as these coded threats are often called, shrug off such argumentation, however convincing. In the last analysis, they say, no matter how ridiculous your threat, your opponent cannot be 100 percent sure that you aren't nuts enough to carry it out, and that tiny, unreasonable doubt encourages a salutary caution. This is called "existential deterrence," and of the various deterrences, it seems to me the most plausible. If there is any utility to nuclear weapons, it resides here.
But remember, we are in a hall of mirrors. Is it in our interest to be broadcasting this utility, which after all is a much better argument for a conventionally weak nation than a conventionally powerful one? Why shouldn't Iran, which has been a victim of Iraqi gas attacks, argue the same?
It is often countered that the behavior of the United States has no effect on would-be proliferators. In the words of Franklin Miller, "Any proliferant is going to develop nuclear weapons based on their own desires to either dominate their region or respond to their neighbor's development program." That may be true, but to contain those countries we need the support of France, Germany, England, Russia and China -- and they will be swayed by the perception that we are or are not serious about reducing our own reliance on nuclear weapons.
 
Easing the Paralysis
As the only conventional superpower in the world -- with a military research-and-development budget that, at $38 billion, is nearly twice as large as that of all other nations of the world combined -- the United States is in the unprecedented position of having no vital threats from any quarter, other than the use of nuclear, biological or chemical weapons. At the same time, as the only conventional superpower in the world, America has no practical use for its nuclear weapons, because they will always be weapons of last resort. The United States, more than any other nation, has an interest in reducing the numbers of nuclear weapons in the world and marginalizing those that remain by devaluing their importance.
The Iraq crisis pointed up a contradiction. When President Clinton responded to Kremlin objections to the use of force against Baghdad by saying things like, "'Nyet' is not 'no' for the United States," he was openly discounting the importance of Russian opinion. Well, which is it? Are the Russians so weak that we no longer heed their foreign policy desires? Or are they so threatening that we have to keep thousands of warheads trained on them to preserve our security? In fact, they are both weak and strong, and this is an explosive combination. Our blindness to the consequences of shaking this particular vial is appalling.
The current perverse paralysis is not inevitable. Vice President Al Gore and Russia's Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, were scheduled to meet last week to discuss nuclear matters, with the hope of resolving enough issues to prepare the way for a summit meeting in the summer. That is promising but, by itself, insufficient. The United States needs to take a more proactive role in nuclear policy. There are several practical steps Washington can take immediately:
* Place a high and public priority on exploring de-alerting options. But more than this, America can act unilaterally. Bruce Blair, who has studied de-alerting for years, has proposed that Washington unilaterally remove the warheads from its MX missiles and pin open the safety switches of the Minuteman III's, a procedure that would take a couple of hours to reverse for each missile. If the Russians reciprocated, we could go further. Ideally, Blair and Sam Nunn envision an arrangement in which warheads would be removed from all land-based missiles and stored in the vacant silos of missiles that had been cut from the force. They further recommend that the silos be partly filled with concrete to insure that they could not quickly be made operational. In this posture, both the warheads and the missiles would be secure in hardened silos, so it would take two attacking warheads to "kill" one missile-warhead pair (this is stabilizing, since the attacker would be disarming faster than the victim), and it would be easy to verify compliance, since remating warheads and missiles would be highly visible.
The Administration and Stratcom like the idea but argue that the Russians have no secure storage for their warheads, and thus if we're worried about "loose nukes," the safest place for them is on the missiles. But if that is the only problem, it could be solved by financing Russian construction of the secure storage they need, an expense that Blair's most generous estimate pegs at less than $1 billion. Since 1991, Washington has spent more than $3 billion through Cooperative Threat Reduction and associated programs to help Russia secure its fissile materials and reserve warheads; the Congressional Budget Office puts the cost of maintaining U.S. forces at Start 1 levels pending Duma ratification of Start 2 at $12.5 billion through 2010, or roughly a billion per year.
* Immediately and unequivocally declare that the United States would not use nuclear weapons except in response to a nuclear attack, and push for a global treaty of No First Use.
* Try something to move the Start process forward. Stansfield Turner proposes a provisional, unilateral "cut" in strategic forces -- in fact, a de-alerting arrangement -- of 1,000 warheads (which even Stratcom concedes are unnecessary). Robert Bell of the N.S.C. counters that unilateral moves are undesirable because they are reversible, but that is exactly the point of Turner's idea. Instead of arguing endlessly about what the Russians would or would not do in response to such a bold move on our part, the United States could simply try it. If they didn't respond, we could put the warheads (which we don't need) back on alert.
* Propose formal negotiations on Start 3. (We negotiated Start 2 before Start 1 went into effect.) For that matter, the White House could propose immediate negotiations toward deeper reductions irrespective of Start 2 ratification. This was one of the proposals in a recent statement issued by 128 world leaders, including Mikhail Gorbachev, Jimmy Carter and Paul H. Nitze. We could take Yeltsin seriously and propose a ceiling of 1,000 warheads.
* Change the Presidential guidance, so that it contains no references to the deterrence of biological and chemical weapons and lowers the requirements of counterforce targeting, to diminish the first-strike threat to the Russians.
Presidential power in the area of national security, as opposed to that of domestic issues, is huge. President Clinton, like Ronald Reagan with his bolt-from-the-blue Star Wars speech of 1983, could change the terms of the debate tomorrow. Lamentably, he gives no indication that he will. The Administration projects an image of a superpower of elephantine helplessness. Not a giant, tied down by little nations, but a knight fallen from his horse, pinned to the ground by his own oversize armor.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 24; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 940 words

HEADLINE: On Language;
Paddling Your Own Canoodle

BYLINE: By William Safire 

 BODY:
Senate judiciary chairman orrin Hatch told The New York Times that if allegations concerning the President and the former White House intern Monica Lewinsky prove to be true, "we have perhaps the first Presidential canoodler in history."
The Utah Senator is a devotee of American slang; his 1996 use of hissy fit, meaning "temper tantrum," stimulated the speculation in this space that the etymon was hysteria. 
 Whence canoodle? Slanguists J.S. Farmer and William Ernest Henley in their 1890 dictionary defined the term as "to fondle; bill and coo; indulge in endearments," its synonym firkytoodle, a verb that seems to have slipped into desuetude. Their earliest citation was from an 1859 book by the English journalist George Augustus Sala: "A sly kiss, and a squeeze. . .known to our American cousins (who are great adepts at sweet-hearting) under the generic name of canoodling."
The derivation is in furious dispute. One school is influenced by H.L. Mencken's assertion that the word was an extravagant invention created by Americans in the Missouri-Mississippi basin, home of many German immigrants. The etymologist W.E. Umbach found the German verb knudeln, "to cuddle," which has a second, fondling-related sense of "to pat, knead," as in the making of dumplings called Knoedel. Samuel Jones of the University of Wisconsin informs me that the German schmusen, also meaning "to hold close," is defined in the 1980 Collins German Dictionary as "to canoodle."
The knudeln theory (with the k pronounced as ca) is knocked (with the k silent) by the school that argues that the word is not an Americanism at all. Drawing on the 1945 research of B.J. Whiting, James Rader of Merriam-Webster says that "Merriam files have nothing to suggest it is an Americanism. The British Notes and Queries for Sept. 3, 1927, recorded it as 'Nottingham dialect for "to cuddle."' Australia's New South Wales Bulletin in 1928 wrote, 'This fuss over the possibility of the Alsatian dog canoodling with his lady dingoes annoys me."'
Merriam-Webster bases its judgment on an entry in Wright's English Dialect Dictionary that treats canoodle as a Somerset noun meaning "donkey.. . . Used also figuratively of one who makes love foolishly or 'spoonies."'
Which side to believe? Is the origin in the squeezable German dumpling or the fumbling caresses of a lovesick English lass? Fair-minded readers are urged to disregard leaks from self-serving etymologists and to reserve judgment on canoodle.
 
 SPECIAL FOR TONIGHT
William Schaefer, 76, former Governor of Maryland and a lifelong bachelor, faithfully visits Hilda Mae Snoops, 73, a divorced mother of three usually described as his "longtime companion," in her retirement home.
In a warm and sentimental Valentine's Day feature, The Washington Post's Karl Vick wrote of the lasting quality of the friendship that included the time they kept house together during his two terms in the Governor's Mansion. However, no one was quite certain how to refer to her.
"This is his girlfriend?" said Nelson Sabatini, Schaefer's friend and former Secretary of Health, running through the usual options for the reporter. "This is his close friend? His dear friend? You know, lady friend?" Then he decided on what he felt was the perfect word: "His special friend!"
Special is a Rashomon word, gleaming with different facets of meaning. Rooted in the Latin species, "a particular group," the most common sense is "out of the ordinary," one step shy of the solitary "unique." That was its meaning in The Economist recently: "All this points to a relationship between President and intern which was in some way, sexual or not, special."
But the special relationship is a phrase with its own historic connotation. Winston Churchill first referred to "our special relationship with the United States and Canada about the atomic bomb" in the House of Commons in 1945 and repeated special relationship in his 1946 "Iron Curtain" speech, meaning "the fraternal association of the English-speaking peoples."
During the 1980's, the adjective became a euphemism for "mentally or physically handicapped": special children were dealt with in special ed classes. A related meaning was "difficult."
Then there was the use of special, again with relationship, to describe gay males living together, which in the 90's is also applied to two men living together who are not lovers. The word was used against gay political activists seeking what they called equal rights by opponents who charged they were seeking special rights -- using the adjective to imply more or superior rights.
This explosion of use, on top of the previous generation's television special and journalism's Special to the New York Times, caused a backlash. On "Saturday Night Live," the comedian Dana Carvey, as "the Church Lady," derided her targets in a nasal twang with "Isn't that special!"
"The use of special in this way," notes Jim Crotty, author of "How to Talk American," "is a hyperironic spoof of the way a Mr. Rogers-type might speak, or the way a kindergarten teacher might talk down to a 'young person.' The humor is in mocking the patronizing quality of another type of person's sincere use of the word special."
When too much use debases a word's currency, it becomes specially priced.
 
 LANG SYNE
"We've been languoring here in Washington," said TV's omnipresent attorney, William Ginsburg.
Languor, a noun only, is "a state of weariness or listlessness." To languish is "to pine away" or "be neglected."
You cannot languor away. On the other hand, through such mistakes we grow the English languish.

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND GUIDE

BYLINE: By BARBARA DELATINER

 BODY:

Free Choices
TODAY The Mineola Choral Society marks its 50th anniversary by sending out one of its ensembles, the County Seat Singers, to perform songs from the 1940's to the 1990's at 2 P.M. at the Bethpage Library on Powell Avenue (931-3907). 
 WEDNESDAY Nassau Community College in Garden City is the host of a conference on "A Politics of Caring: Confronting the Forces That Divide -- Race, Sex, Ethnicity and the Economy." The daylong program, in the College Center, features lectures by Michael Lerner, founding editor of Tikkun, at 11 A.M.; Cornel West, professor of religion and Afro-American studies at Harvard University, at 2 P.M., and Rosemary Bray, an author, at 3:30 P.M., and a panel discussion by the three participants at 12:30 P.M. (572-7185).
Matt Haimovitz, the young cellist, joins the Massapequa Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Adam Rosenbloom, in an all-Dvorak program at 8:30 P.M. at Berner Junior High School on Carmans Mill Road. The dress rehearsal Friday at 8 P.M. will also be open to the public (795-4071).

More Irish
Observances of St. Patrick's Day continue today as Jim Hawkins performs "Irish Songs, Stories and Instrumental Music" at 2:30 P.M. at the Baldwin Library (223-6228); Paddy Doyle's Boots, the traditional music trio, plays Irish tunes at 2:30 P.M. at the Freeport Library (379-3274); Kevin O'Rouke, the author of "Currier and Ives: The Irish and America" speaks about "Images of the Irish in Currier and Ives Prints" at 2 P.M. at the Rockville Centre Library (766-6257), and the Rogers Memorial Library in Southampton presents a program of Irish songs and poems at 3:30 P.M. (283-0774).
On Tuesday there is a "St. Patrick's Day Sing-Along" with the Gilleece Twins and Chris Benedict at 7 P.M. at Theater Three on Main Stret in Port Jefferson (928-9100), while on Wednesday Greg Ryan, an entertainer, and Jim Hawkins join forces with Eileen Ryan, a step dancer, in a concert of Irish music and dance at 8 P.M. at the Plainview-Old Bethpage Library in Plainview (938-0077).

Music in Southold
The Arts in Southold continues its series of chamber music concerts today at 3 P.M. at the Church of the Open Door on Main Bayview Road in Southold with a joint recital by Yuri Karigut, a pianist, in an all-Chopin program, and Philip Cutlip, baritone, who will sing Mozart and Ibert arias and Broadway tunes (734-7696).

Choral Concerts
The spring choral music season opens today as the Long Island Choral Society performs Handel's "Samson" at 4 P.M. at the Cathedral of the Incarnation on Cathedral Avenue in Garden City (679-2136). Come Saturday and fans of the genre will have to choose between "A Tribute to Mozart" by the Long Island Concert Choral and the St. Rose of Lima Choir at 8 P.M. at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church on Merrick Road in Massapequa and Haydn's "Lord Nelson Mass" and other works by Beethoven, Bruckner and Mozart from the Babylon Chorale at 8 P.M. at St. Peter's Episcopal Church on Montauk Highway in Bay Shore (221-3211).

'Israel at 50'
Hofstra University marks the 50th anniversary of the state of Israel with "Israel at 50," three months of lectures, films, concerts and exhibitions. It starts tomorrow when the films "Jerusalem: Rhythms of a Distant City" and "You, Me Jerusalem" are shown at 7:30 P.M. at the Monroe Lecture Center Theater (463-4873). On Wednesday at 8 P.M. Dore Gold, permament representative of Israel to the United Nations, opens the lecture series with a talk on "Israel's Quest for Peace and Security" in the Student Center Theater (463-5669). For a complete schedule: 463-5669.

Circus in Town
The Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus opens a weeklong run Tuesday, through March 23, at the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum. This year's edition with its international flavor features acrobats from Gabon in Central Africa; Olympic silver medal-winning rhythmic gymnasts from Bulgaria; the Quiros of Spain on the high wire; Khan, the "World's Tallest Man," and Michu, "the Smallest Man on Earth," from Pakistan; Tong, "the Prince of Pythons" from Vietnam, and Marina, a contortionist, from Russia (794-9300).

'An American Journey'
The Waverly Consort, an early music ensemble of singers and musicians, comes to Staller Center on the Stony Brook campus of the State University Friday at 8 P.M. with "An American Journey: Bound for the Promised Land," a mix of songs, dance and instrumentals that traces the musical pathways of America from Colonial times to the Civil War (632-7230).

'Spring into Poetry'
Although Poetry Month isn't until April, Teenspeak and the Cinema Arts Center in Huntington are starting early -- Saturday to be exact -- with the first of four "Spring Into Poetry" programs designed to bring together poets and poetry lovers. There will be workshops for would-be poets from high school age and up led by professionals like Gerald Stern, Thomas Lux, Marie Howe and performance poets, A Little Bit of Louder, from the Nuyorican Cafe at 10 A.M., readings at 11:30 A.M. and, from 12:15 to 1 P.M., book signings and an open mike. The series continues on April 4, 25 and May 2 at the center on Park Avenue (549-8831).

Long Island Philharmonic
The Long Island Philharmonic begins its spring season Saturday at 8 P.M. at Staller Center on the Stony Brook campus of the State University with a program that offers a world premiere along with standards from the repertory. Under David Lockington's baton, the orchestra will introduce "Three Places on Long Island," by Dana Perna, a Long Island composer; a series of three orchestral essays depicting the Walt Whitman Birthplace in Huntington; Theodore Roosevelt's home, Sagamore Hill, in Oyster Bay, and the Montauk Point Lighthouse. Joined by Dylana Jenson, a violinist, the Philharmonic also plays Tchaikovsky's Violin Concerto in D major (Op. 35) and Beethoven's Symphony No. 2 in D major (Op. 36). The concert will be repeated next Sunday at 7:30 P.M. at Tilles Center in Brookville and Ms. Jenson will conduct a master class at 1 P.M. Friday at North Shore High School in Glen Head (293-2222).

'Celebrating Bach'
Since Johann Sebastion Bach was born on March 21, the Long Island Baroque Ensemble on Saturday marks his 213th birthday with a program of his works, including trio sonata duets for lute and harpsichord and obligato arias for oboe and tenor. William Zito on lute, guitar and Baroque oboe; Daniel Pincus, tenor, and Sonia Grib, harpsichordist, will do the musical honors at 8 P.M. at St. Andrew's Lutheran Church on Brooksite Drive in Smithtown. The concert will be repeated at 3 P.M. next Sunday at Christ Church on East Main Street in Oyster Bay (724-7386). BARBARA DELATINER

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 15; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1623 words

HEADLINE: In the 90's, Take-Out Becomes Take-In

BYLINE: By LESLIE CHESS FELLER 

 BODY:
WHAT does a molecular biologist have in common with a 73-year-old widow, a restaurant chef, two dentists, a police detective and a teacher of gifted children? They all want to enjoy hot, fresh, healthy dinners in the comfort of their own home. They want to eat the kind of food they would prepare themselves if only they had the time. None have the time. Instead, they are becoming happily addicted to different forms of gourmet takeout, an option that puts dinner on the table efficiently, creatively and perhaps most importantly, guilt-free.
Harry Balzer, vice president of the NPD Group, an international market research company with headquarters in Port Washington, said Americans were changing the way they prepare food at home. For many, there is no better shortcut than eliminating it altogether. 
 "Restaurant visits are up, but in-restaurant dining is not," he said. "The number of takeout suppers has doubled in the past decade."
Although the new buzz word in the industry is "home meal replacement," Mr. Balzer suggests this is merely the 1990's version of an old trend. "In 1876, Heinz Ketchup was marketed as a new product 'for the blessed relief of mother.' In 1930, Kraft Macaroni's slogan was 'a meal for four in nine minutes.'
"In the 1950's,there were frozen dinners that moms could just heat and serve."
These days, Mr. Balzer said, "grab-and-go" is the usual preliminary for "heat-and-serve" and the person doing the pick-up is as likely to be dad as mom. Dual-career couples juggling jobs and children are relying on teamwork and innovative meal solutions.
Gary Sokaitis, a Sag Harbor resident who was once Richard Nixon's personal chef and is currently cooking at the Bay Street Cafe in Sag Harbor, is happy to get out of the kitchen at the end of his work day.
"My wife works as an insurance agent until 5 P.M. and then we have to pick up our two sons, one from the baby sitter and the other from school," he said. "My boys want to eat right away."
Mr. Sokaitis uses some sort of takeout option at least two to three times a week. He is a frequent customer of Razzano's, a gourmet Italian restaurant with locations in Port Washington and Bridgehampton.
"I like the quality of their food," he said. "I might pick up a prepared lasagna or frozen pasta and one of their sauces and it's delicious and convenient."
From 7:15 A.M. until 6 P.M., Anita Bickman, a Long Beach middle school teacher, does not have one second to spare. "I teach sixth-grade English and coach the cheerleaders," she said. "Then I have to take my daughter to gymnastics or pick up my son from track practice. And then there's his S.A.T. course. Once I leave school, I'm busy car pooling. Plus there are activities scheduled in the evenings."
To keep pace with a life style that has become "even more hectic as the kids have grown older," the Bickmans bring in dinner two or three times a week.
"My husband is an electrician who commutes from our Lido Beach home to New York City," Ms. Bickman said. "We discuss it in the morning. If I don't have time to pick up dinner, he'll do it on his way home. If we're both tight for time, we'll order in from a place that delivers."
As consumers explore takeout options, retailers are scrambling for their share of this newly defined food dollar. On Long Island, the competition between small specialty gourmet shops and giant supermarkets like King Kullen, Edwards and Waldbaum's is fierce. Lou Mairitis, one of the owners of Stony Brook's Three Village Inn, said, "home meal replacement on Long Island is booming and it is busting."
Mr. Mairitis cited the demise of the North Country Market in Setauket and the Three Village Inn's own auxiliary Gourmet Shop and Bakery (recently converted from retail to an all-catering operation) as an indication that high-end suppliers are struggling.
"Manhattan-style markets like Balducci's or Zabar's don't work in suburbia," he said emphatically. "There's not enough density, too much overhead and the supermarkets are overwhelming competitors. They don't offer the same quality, but they are charging less and it's convenient, one-stop shopping."
Nancy Moore, owner of Moore's Gourmet Market in Port Jefferson, agreed. "It's extremely difficult to compete with the supermarkets," she said. "Also, lately, it seems like there's a gourmet shop on every corner. In 1985, when I opened, there were three others in this area. Now there are eight."
Ms. Moore revamped her store two years ago and offers a menu that includes a variety of vegetarian and specially labeled "heart-smart" choices along with the sort of personal service that keeps people coming back. "We're all on a first-name basis here," she said. "Our customers feel like friends."
"We consider Nancy part of the family; it's a delight to have her cooking for us," said Elliot Taynor, a Port Jefferson orthodontist whose wife, Kathleen, is a police detective who frequently works night shifts. "We are often on opposite schedules," he said. "Sometimes our main meal together is lunch. Whoever has the time will call Nancy and pick up the food."
Dr. Iris Mastrangelo, a molecular biologist, and her husband, Dr. Paul Hough, a biophysicist, can both end up working six or seven days a week, round the clock, doing research at Brookhaven National Laboratory.
"I have built Nancy's offerings into the way I prepare our meals," said Dr. Mastrangelo. "I stock up over the weekend on things we like, her grilled cajun chicken breasts, for instance. I might add rice or peas I saute with shallots. Nancy's food is healthy and very tasty. It has a homemade quality, like it was prepared in a household where the cook is really particular."
The Red Horse Market's general manager, Gregg Deger, described his East Hampton store as a countrified Dean and DeLuca's. "Business is good," he said. "There is competition, of course, like the Barefoot Contessa, which is on a smaller scale but has very good food."
Regarding the new King Kullen 10 minutes down the road, Mr. Deger said: "It's certainly drawn away customers because we don't carry paper products and diapers, but their prepared foods are nothing compared to what we offer. We've built a clientele that appreciates quality."
Meg Young, a 73-year-old widow and retired real-estate agent, relies on the Red Horse Market for "fresh, delicious food" and courteous personal service to match.
"They know me by name," she said. Along with The New York Times the staff puts aside for her every day, Mrs. Young appreciates the individual, pre-prepared servings of dishes she loves.
"Everything is of the highest quality," she said, "and they have daily half-price specials. I find it much more economical than going out to buy all the ingredients to do it myself. These days, unless I am giving a dinner party, I don't choose to cook."
Ina Garten, owner of the Barefoot Contessa, cited her shop's location on Main Street in East Hampton as a major advantage. "We're in the center of town, right in the walk-by traffic pattern, so people in to do some shopping can easily pick up dinner."
By contrast, Razzano's which offers a selection of 25 or 30 hot, fresh home-style entrees, is what the manager Joe Dia calls "a destination retailer."
"We are not on the main drag," he said. "People drive to us specifically. We do a big takeout business from 4 P.M. to the final rush before closing time at 6:30 P.M."
The Golden Pear, with locations in Southampton, East Hampton, Bridgehampton and Westhampton Beach, describes itself as a "food boutique." Their "Home in a Hurry" takeout dinners, available for the past three months, have been selling well to professional people between the ages of 40 and 55.
"We're getting dual-career couples, empty nesters and singles," said the manager, Keith Davis, pointing out that the Golden Pear is actively advertising its new option. "We make it easy for customers to take advantage of it," he said. "They can phone us to order in advance and we'll have it packaged and ready."
Dr. Robert Reiner and his wife, Dr. Ann Nasti, Old Field residents and dentists, jumped on the gourmet takeout bandwagon at its inception.
"We've been in practice together for 15 years," said Dr. Reiner. "Neither of us ever wanted to come home and cook." For many years, the couple had a standing arrangement with Elegant Eating in Stony Brook to prepare their dinners. "We told them what we liked and didn't like and they took it from there," Dr. Reiner continued. "We would be surprised when we opened the bag. To be very honest, I don't think there is a single adult meal consumed in this house that hasn't been brought in pre-prepared. Since our son was born, seven years ago, we want to spend quality time with him when we get home from work."
Cooking in the 90's is regarded as recreation rather than obligation. People who can't stand the heat during the week can't wait to get into the kitchen on the weekends.
"I see people wandering the aisles with cookbooks," said the Red Horse Market's Gregg Deger. "They've never cooked before, but suddenly it's fun. They're into it."
Ina Garten pointed out that many Barefoot Contessa customers were more than just capable cooks. "Some of them are superb chefs, but they are too busy to cook," she said.
A case in point. At Lindell Elementary School in Long Beach, Susan Abraham of Great Neck, a teacher of gifted children, is orchestrating another fairy-tale trial. "Last year, we sued Mother Goose for being an unfit mother," she said. "Now Captain Hook is suing Peter Pan for slander.During the school year, who has time to cook? But in the summer, I love to get creative. I do really fancy main courses and extravagant desserts."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Florham Park, N.J.;
Once Sleepy Hamlet Now Bustling Corporate Haven

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
A GENERATION ago, Florham Park, N.J., was a sleepy residential hamlet nestled along the Columbia Turnpike between Morristown and South Orange, known largely for its bowling alley and roller skating rink. But due to a combination of improved transportation and accidents of history, the borough has become a corporate haven, with over a million square feet of office space completed in the last decade, and more on the way.
Stanley C. Gale, one of the principals of the Gale & Wentworth, L.L.C., a development and management firm based in Florham Park, is about to begin building a speculative 175,000-square-foot office building in the company's campus-like development called Park Avenue at Morris County. The building will complete a 1.15 million-square-foot office park started in 1988, but slowed by the real estate recession of the early 90's. 
 Slightly to the west, the Rockefeller Group is constructing a 175,000-square-foot building for AT&T Laboratories, which has an existing 240,000-square-foot building on the site that was modified for its purposes.
The company, which formerly owned and managed the Rockefeller Center properties east of Avenue of Americas in Manhattan, has made arrangements to acquire 80 acres of land in addition to the 63 acres occupied by the AT&T project, and is developing plans to build 440,000 square feet of office space in two buildings.
Officials of the Rockefeller Group say they are reluctant to build entirely on speculation, despite the booming office market in northern New Jersey. They say they want advance commitments for about 50 percent of the space in each of the planned two buildings before a spade goes into the ground. Nevertheless, they say they expect to start building before the end of the year.
Mr. Gale of Gale & Wentworth said the reason for the attractiveness of the Florham Park site was its good transportation, with I-287 just a short distance away and the proximity of the relatively new Route 24, which provides high speed access to the interstate route. He said the ease of movement combined with the availability of housing in many price ranges convinced companies like Allied-Signal, AT&T, Merck and Warner-Lambert to put their headquarters closer to where their executives lived.
The proximity of Morristown Municipal Airport, which can accommodate corporate jets, was a big help as well, added Rick L. Genthe, a vice president of Gale & Wentworth.
The corporations who chose to locate in northern New Jersey "proved you could function outside the central business district," Mr. Gale said. "Now there is 21st century corporate activity in a bucolic community. "
THE corporate offices have attracted the lawyers, accountants, consultants and other businesses that tend to their needs and whose principals did not mind trading a punishing daily commute into the city for a short car ride. The list of tenants at Park Avenue at Morris County includes McKinsey & Company, Price Waterhouse, Smith Barney, Prudential and Merrill Lynch.
And, Mr. Gale, the presence of of Fairleigh Dickinson University, Drew University and the College of St. Elizabeth close by provide a cultural assurance for executives being transferred to the area.
Mr. Gale said it was thanks to the Sisters of Charity who continue to operate St. Elizabeth's and other institutions in the area, that a 138-acre parcel of undeveloped land was available in a crowded state. The site was formerly operated as a farm by the Sisters, who grazed cattle there until shortly before the site was made available for development in the late 80's.
"This was the first open land west of Short Hills," Mr. Gale said. The big brick barn that was part of the farm remains, although it is no longer used to house cattle on the lower level and to store hay in the upper loft. After extensive renovation, it was reopened in 1994 as the Park Avenue Club, a private gathering spot for meals and meetings.
Another attraction of the area, real estate executives say, is the presence of the Short Hills and Livingston malls, both a short drive from Florham Park.
Around the turn of the century the Morristown area was where as many as 100 millionaires from New York built their country houses and owned expansive estates. The Erie Lackawanna Railroad line, now a part of New Jersey Transit, which serves tens of thousands of commuters today, was originally built, in part, to spare the wealthy from having to endure the primitive roadways of the time during their trips from the city to the country. Madison Avenue, the old Route 24, now Route 124, was called "millionaires' row" because of the number of mansions lining the road.
The 143-acre Rockefeller Group Corporate Park is a legacy of one wealthy couple who contributed, among other things, the name of the borough. Florence and Hamilton Twombly named their 100-room house, now the chief administrative building of Fairleigh Dickinson University, using a combination of their first names, Florham.
When the Afton section of Chatham Township broke away in 1899, it took the name of its largest landowner and became Florham Park.
THE Rockefeller development is on part of the old 900-acre Twombly farm, which had been preserved as relatively open space by Exxon Corporation as a site for some of its research and development operations. Part of the tree-lined driveway that led to the Twombly house still exists on the property, as does a small pond, formed by damming a small stream. It was at this location in 1893 that the Twomblys spent $6,000 to build an electrical generating plant to illuminate a barn dance.
"Florham Park is our kind of neighborhood," said Jonathan D. Green, president of the Rockefeller Group Development Corporation. He said the ambiance of the location and the scarcity of other sites for development are producing some of the highest rental rates in the state. Real estate executives said gross annual rentals in the area were in the high $20's per square foot.
Mr. Green, whose company also is developing the 685-acre International Trade Center in the far western part of Morris County, said the woodsy nature of the location belied its proximity to New York. With the new direct service into Penn Station, real estate executives said, a trip from the nearby station in Madison to the city is no more than 50 minutes.
Plans for the new development are still incomplete pending approvals from the borough, said Eugene A. Preston, a vice president of Rockefeller Group Development. This means prospective tenants have some ability to shape the future buildings to their needs.
"Our initial thought was to make the two buildings of equal size," he said. "But we could make one a little larger and the other a little smaller, depending on what a tenant needs."
The long building drought in New Jersey, has led to a pent-up demand for high quality office space in the area, said Charles Kushner, president of Kushner Companies, real estate developers and investors, which are headquartered in Florham Park. "Morris County is very desirable now, but there is no real space of any size available," he said. "Tenants who need 100,000 square feet are begging me to build."
As a result, he said, developers are busily planning new projects, although few are under way as yet. "There is not a lot going on, but there is a lot on the drawing board," he said. He said he had land under contract on another part of the Exxon site to build 750,000 square feet of office space and is negotiating for land to build an additional 250,000 square feet.
Although the empty parcels of land in places like Florham Park are being developed, a lot of green remains. Mr. Preston of the Rockefeller Group said that even when fully developed, about 77 percent of the 143-acre site would still be open space.

HEADLINE: Historic Buildings in Houston Getting New Roles

BYLINE: By DEBRA BEACHY 

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
THE homeless people who once congregated under the cast-iron portico of an abandoned old downtown hotel have been replaced by construction crews working to transform the historic, red-brick 18-story Rice Hotel into 312 rental apartments.
The reincarnated 1913 structure, which will be known as The Rice, will have a restaurant, a coffee house, a health club, ballroom, art gallery and an Italian grocery. 
 Directly behind The Rice, an 1882 vintage building on the edge of the theater district has been transformed into the Solero, a trendy Spanish restaurant.
On Travis Street, three blocks north of The Rice, the eight-story Hermann Lofts, an office building completed in 1917, has been converted into 26 condominium apartments, all but one of which has been sold, and a restaurant. Apartment prices range from $95,000 for 700 square feet to $350,000 for 2,100 square feet. Its 6,500-square-foot penthouse has been sold for in excess of $1.4 million.
Nearby, another historic turn-of-the-century red-brick office building, Hogg Palace, has reopened with 79 open-loft apartments renting for $800 a month for a small studio to a two-bedroom for $2,100, a gym and a restaurant. Its penthouse office, with a large terrace, rents for $8,500 a month.
Four blocks to the east, work has begun on the conversion of the 1910 Southern Pacific office building into 105 apartments. Completion is expected within a year.
The historic buildings being revived for re-use are in a downtown best known for its modern glass-and-steel skyscrapers. Most are within 10 blocks of the city's theater district, home to the Houston Ballet and the Houston Grand Opera, the Houston Symphony and theaters where Broadway plays and musicals are performed. The new $23 million Bayou Place, in the theater district, opened last November with restaurants, clubs and an eight-screen movie theater.
The proximity of renovated buildings to the city's cultural center and the eclectic mix of remodeled turn-of-the-century buildings and futuristic skyscrapers is drawing residents like John Axelrod, who rented a fifth-floor one-bedroom apartment in Hogg Palace six months ago for $1,000 when he returned to his native city after living in Vienna, Prague and St. Petersburg.
"I like the juxtaposition of the old and new buildings," he said. "They represent some of the most outstanding architecture in the country, and they're all next to each other."
MR. AXELROD, a conductor who founded Orchestra X, which performs classical music in clubs and restaurants, said he also likes living close to the action. "Downtown Houston is like Lincoln Center and Broadway all rolled into one," said Mr. Axelrod. "You have one of the top 10 musical theaters, symphonies, operas, and ballets in the country that are consistent in their excellence, and they're all right next to each other."
Houston's museum district is five minutes away, and the University of Houston, nationally recognized for its creative-writing program, as well as Rice University, with its renowned music school, add to the draw downtown for the young and artistically inclined, Mr. Axelrod said. "I don't think there is one person over 35 living in Hogg Palace," he said.
The accent on saving these historic buildings is far different from just a few years ago, when conservationists could not keep a three-story red-brick 1883 historic Victorian office building on Main Street from being demolished, said Stephen Fox, an architectural historian and author of the Houston Architectural Guide. He teaches at Rice University and the University of Houston.
"What is so great is to see Houstonians waking up to the value of these buildings," said Mr. Fox.
The Rice is the crown jewel of the buildings, he said. Historically, the site itself is significant. It was where a temporary capitol building for the Republic of Texas stood from 1837 to 1839. President John F. Kennedy napped at the hotel the day before he was assassinated in Dallas, and a special suite with his name and memorabilia is on the building's fifth floor.
At the turn of the century, Main Street was the most prestigious downtown address. A major public food market was in what is still known as Market Square, where loft buildings are a recent addition.
Randall Davis, a local developer who is renovating The Rice, along with his partner, Post Properties of Atlanta, said the $32 million redevelopment project could not have occurred without $6 million in a tax abatement and grants from the city.
Before all the financing for the project was in place, Mr. Davis said, he would "drive around the building asking myself if I wanted to fight all the battles."
The building had an absentee owner and violations for asbestos and lead paint throughout the building, a leaky roof and chemicals in the basement. The city bought the building in 1996 for $3 million, then gave a 40-yearlease to Mr. Davis and his partner with the stipulation that they redevelop it.
"How many times do you get to do something in your life that really makes a difference," he said.
Mr. Davis said that a third of the apartments at the Rice, where rents range from $750 for an efficiency to $3,800 for the largest three-bedroom, had been preleased. The opening is scheduled for next August, he added.
The renovated condominium and rental apartments are expected to attract 1,000 new residents to downtown, adding to the 2,000 people who already live there, said Nancy Brainerd, president of the Downtown Houston Association.
Chuck Russell, part owner of the Solero tapas restaurant and bar, which opened last April, said business at 910 Prairie Street was three times greater than projections at the outset.
THE pioneering efforts of Mr. Davis in renovating historic structures, local developers say, helped to spur the current downtown revival. That effort, begun in 1993, has sent prices soaring in the area. In all, Mr. Davis is responsible for the creation of 525 apartments in four historic buildings, including the Rice Hotel.
"People expected a lot of downtown housing," he said. "Prices were cheap. Now the economics don't make sense for rental apartment buildings."
The prices have risen from the $8 a square foot that Mr. Davis and his partners paid for the Rice Hotel to $20 a square foot, said Michael Hassler, vice president of CB Commercial Real Estate Brokerage Services here.
"The single event that changed downtown for inventory was the sale of the Rice Hotel," said Mr. Hassler. The fact that the city provided some financing for the conversion, he said, was "an endorsement" for other such projects downtown.
ANOTHER downtown developer, Doug Crosson, who with his partner, the Spire Realty Group, based in Houston, is renovating Hermann Lofts, said that although the economics had changed for renovating rental properties, there still were profits to be made in resurrecting older buildings as condominiums and small hotels.
Six blocks east of The Rice, land is being cleared to build a new baseball park to open in 2000 and replace the Astrodome as the home of the Astros. The project has attracted developers to what was a blighted neighborhood, said Mr. Hassler of CB Commercial. The Astrodome will continue to host the Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo, and other events. "Five months ago, the area around it was in a dormant state, surrounded by liquor stores and low daily rental hotels," he said. Now, he added, "the area is cleaning itself up."
