HEADLINE: AGRICULTURE;
Farmers Hear From Young Members of Their Fan Club

 BODY:
This is National Agriculture Week, an annual celebration of the farmers who provided food and fiber to consumers worldwide. This year the New Jersey Agriculture Society sponsored an essay contest, asking students from the 6th grade to the 11th grade to write on this theme: "New Jersey Agriculture -- How It Makes My Life Better." Here are the first-place winners, who will be honored this week at a ceremony in Trenton.
 
From Rich Soil, Lots of Jobs and Food 
 New Jersey is among the top 20 states in the commercial production of vegetables and plants. New Jersey has approximately 8,000 farms with an average of 104 acres per farm. These farms include fruit, vegetable, plant and livestock farms. I will explain each of these as follows.
All of the above are made possible by New Jersey's very rich soil. New Jersey had previously been heavily covered by forests and in fact 40 percent of New Jersey is still covered with forests. The soil was made rich by wood chips, animal waste and dead plants. Over the years, New Jersey's soil became among the richest in the region.
Vegetables and fruits are the chief produce of New Jersey. They are raised in orchards and farms throughout the state. Significant fruits and vegetables are soybeans, tomatoes, peaches, apples, potatoes, eggplants, onions, peppers, asparagus, cranberries, blueberries, strawberries and, most popular, corn. Corn is grown in several varieties, being consumed in vast quantities by both people and livestock. I have been on several trips with my family where we picked apples and peaches and my mom made homemade pies.
Livestock is important because New Jersey's large corn crop supports many farms which are livestock farms. Cows and pigs and chickens are important industries in New Jersey. Cows provide an important source of dairy products to our region. Also cows provide beef to our markets. Pigs and chickens are also important to our market. On a recent field trip to Popcorn Zoo we saw many animals that are important to New Jersey's agriculture.
New Jersey also has a large amount of farmers who specialize in growing flowers and plants. While New Jersey grows many flowers and plants outdoors, many are raised in greenhouses and nurseries throughout the state.
Jobs are my last topic and a very important one. It is easy to see why New Jersey is called the Garden State. Many of the people who live in New Jersey are employed in the state's agricultural economy. While farmers would be the obvious answer, many people have jobs because of selling all the products from the Garden State.
In conclusion, I think New Jersey agriculture is very good and profitable. When the economy is good in New Jersey, we all prosper. I think, living in New Jersey, I will never have to worry about lacking in vegetables, fruits and livestock.

Pete Guerriero
 Grade Six, Memorial Middle School
Point Pleasant
 
Good for Economy And Environment
When you think of New Jersey, do you think of dirty factories pumping out pollutants? Or do you envision pastoral farms and peaceful cranberry bogs? Many do not realize that about two-thirds of New Jersey's land is farms and forests. The state of New Jersey stands in the front ranks of the agricultural states. Out of the whole nation, it ranks second in production of blueberries, third in cranberries and fourth in tomatoes. New Jersey also produces cabbage, lettuce, cucumbers, squash, pumpkins, melons, peaches, apples and grains. The abundance of food New Jersey produces gives it the nickname "The Garden State." The Garden State provides many benefits for the residents.
The agriculture of my state, New Jersey, is important to me and makes my life better. One way it makes life better is by providing excellent fruits and vegetables for me. I can eat sumptuous blueberries, peaches, squash and other produce, thanks to Jersey farms. Cranberries from New Jersey go perfect with Thanksgiving turkeys!
Another way New Jersey agriculture benefits me and everybody in the state is to make an environment-friendly use of the land. The orchards, farms and bogs help enrich the atmosphere in which I live. They do not contaminate the air we breathe but put the land to good use.
Finally, New Jersey agriculture makes my life better by contributing to our national economy. Jerseyans help feed people all over the United States, so our country does not have to import as much food. My state contributes to the food self-sufficiency in America. This self-sufficiency helps to make my country great. New Jersey's farms do their part in making me a citizen of a great nation.
For all these reasons, and more, the agriculture of New Jersey is very beneficial to me. Good food, a clean environment, and a productive country are only some of Jersey agriculture's benefits to me, The agriculture of the Garden State truly makes my life better.

Joanna Perrick
Ninth grade, home-schooled
Haskell
 
Eating Fresh Means Eating Healthy
New Jersey agriculture is very important to me. I've always lived in New Jersey and eaten New Jersey food products, I've grown up with New Jersey's agriculture. Tomatoes in the summer and apples in the fall. The fruits and vegetables in New Jersey always taste fresh and are always good to eat.
Without New Jersey's agriculture, I wouldn't be able to take a fresh apple out of the refrigerator any time I wanted. I would have to buy fruits and vegetables from a different state or country that wouldn't taste as fresh. New Jersey's agriculture has, sort of, spoiled me because I always want everything to be fresh and taste good.
Everything you eat in New Jersey is fresh and so I've grown up to be very healthy, which has made my life much better. Eating right has become very important to me since I've always eaten healthy New Jersey food.
Without New Jersey's agriculture, Halloween wouldn't be the same. We wouldn't take hayrides out on the farms and pick fresh pumpkins off the vines. This has always been an exciting tradition to our family and friends every year.
Growing up with New Jersey's agriculture, I've been able to be healthy and go to school each day and to avoid getting sick. Having what New Jersey's agriculture has to offer has been what I've grown up to. Tomatoes, cherries, apples, peaches, pears, pumpkins, green beans, broccoli and many more. All of them are fresh and I feel very fortunate to be able to have them nearly all year round.

Kristen Costa
Grade 10
Hunterdon County High School

HEADLINE: SEASONS;
The Winter That Wasn't Means Woe For Many

BYLINE: By DAVID HERSZENHORN 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
The cherry blossoms are blossoming here in Branch Brook Park. The shad have started swimming up the Delaware to spawn. Pollen floats through the air, irritating noses, making eyes burn red. Yes, spring is here and it is early, very early.
Remember when there used to be four seasons? 
 Last week's cold snap notwithstanding, meteorologists are ready to declare this the winter that never was. September somehow turned into March, pausing, it seemed, only briefly for New Year's Day, the one day this winter when the temperature in Newark stayed below freezing for an entire 24 hours.
At Newark International Airport, for the first time on record, there was no measurable snow in the month of February, according to Paul Knight, a meteorologist at Pennsylvania State University. This followed a January in which average daily temperatures were 8.5 degrees above normal.
While there may have been no complaints from household snow shovelers and heating oil customers, for businesses that rely on wintry weather, the unseasonably warm temperatures, lack of snow and heavy rain made this the worst winter ever, economically speaking.
All but one of New Jersey's handful of ski slopes have already closed for the year. "It's hurt a lot of people who sort of count on snow," said Don Benanti, whose New Brunswick concrete company, D. F. Benanti Inc., also does snow plowing and removal.
There is an economic domino effect, Mr. Benanti said. "Body shops don't have the work they used to have from fender benders. The auto parts places aren't selling parts to the body shops. It just mushrooms from one thing to another."
Even though the warm temperatures might have permitted it, the heavy rains often prevented construction companies from working through the winter. Mr. Knight, the meteorologist, offered an expert assessment: "Things turned to mush pretty quickly," he said.
In a normal winter in Newark, there would be 22 days when the temperature remained solidly below freezing for an entire 24 hours, Mr. Knight said. This year, there was only New Year's Day, which was followed by a warm spell and temperatures as high as 60 degrees.
The only snow to fall in urban, northeastern New Jersey was a half inch on Jan. 18. Some areas of southern New Jersey had no snow at all this year and in higher-altitude areas to the north and west, there were 5 to 10 inches of snow, well below the seasonal norms, Mr. Knight said.
School districts have been left with unused snow days. In Bridgewater-Raritan, officials allocated four days in this year's schedule as snow days. None have been used.
"They are days that we have contracted for our teachers to teach," said the superintendent, Joseph P. McGarry. "If we don't have any snow, we are lucky. We have more instruction for our students."
The mild temperatures coupled with the lengthening hours of daylight have sparked a premature budding of spring. Allergy suffers have started sneezing weeks earlier than usual.
Visitors to flower festivals, like the cherry blossom celebration in Branch Brook Park, may see no flowers. Ed Obdens, the assistant parks superintendent in Essex County, predicted that the park's 2,000 cherry trees -- a larger grove than the more famous collection in Washington, D.C. -- would be in full bloom 10 to 15 days before the mid-April festival.
The budding trees are threatened by dips in temperature. "With this cold right now, water in the tissues of the blossoms will freeze and will in turn damage the blossoms that are out," he said.
The early spring is breeding other frustrations.
"People want to get on the ball fields right now," Mr. Obdens said. But the fields are not ready and cannot be worked on yet. "Since the ground did not freeze this year, we have to wait until it dries out. You take the truck out, you tear all the turf up trying to get out to it."
Mosquitoes are one problem not affected by the early spring.
"It is a popular belief that a mild winter means you are going to have a lot of mosquitoes the following year," said Wayne Kranz, an entomologist. He said mosquito eggs "are well adapted to survive the worst winters. Generally, weather patterns over the winter have nothing to do with what you can expect over the summer."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Mortgage ABC's in a Borrower's Market

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
TRADITIONALLY, the biggest challenge faced by first-time home buyers, typically a young couple or family, was coming up with a big-enough down payment to qualify for a mortgage. After that, they would need the right combination of confidence, brashness and humility to be able to walk into a lender's office, ask for a huge amount of money and wait nervously for an answer.
Today, the need for amassing a large down payment to buy a house has all but disappeared. It is not uncommon for buyers with good credit and steady incomes to get mortgages with as little as 3 percent down -- and in some areas of the country even that can be borrowed. 
 In fact, bankers and brokers say, the mortgage market is so competitive, with so much money available and so many lenders willing to lend, that the balance of power has shifted dramatically. Now picky borrowers audition eager lenders rather than the other way around. Even first-time buyers often have the luxury of choosing the lender and loan most suitable to them. And that, the bankers and brokers say, combined with interest rates near historic lows, makes right now one of the best times in recent memory for first-time buyers who may be short on cash but long on dreams of owning a home.
"The mortgage market today offers consumers an incredible array of choices," said Barry Zigas, a senior vice president of Fannie Mae, a Washington-based, government-regulated shareholder-owned company that is the largest source of residential mortgage funds in the country. "And no one considering purchasing a home should make any assumptions about what isn't possible."
Effectively navigating the quirky, murky waters of mortgage finance, however, requires at least a basic understanding of some of the more arcane concepts and insider jargon that are certain to be encountered. Here, then, is a primer for neophytes, first-time buyer-borrowers and anyone else who has ever struggled with the question: "What's the difference between a note and a mortgage, and what does P.I.T.I. mean, anyway?"
"Think of a mortgage as two documents," said Richard Nardi, a Manhattan real estate lawyer and past president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of New York. "One document is a promissory note that memorializes a debt you owe to a lender. The other is a pledge of security that gives the lender the right to take your house away if you don't pay what you owe."
And while details of different mortgages vary on such specifics as the amount of the loan, the term, the interest rate, whether the rate can change over the life of the loan and the property secured by the mortgage, Mr. Nardi said, most mortgages are similar in most other respects.
"These are basically non-negotiable documents on standardized forms," he said, explaining that since many lenders ultimately sell their mortgages on the secondary market, in which large groups of individual mortgages are packaged as securities for sale to investors, most mortgage forms contain terms and conditions required by Fannie Mae, the dominant force among secondary-market lenders.
Mr. Zigas, the executive director of Fannie Mae's National Housing Impact Division, explained that the secondary market is what enables mortgage lenders to come up with the seemingly endless supply of money needed to continue making loans to consumers. Secondary-market lenders, he said, typically use investor capital to buy blocks of loans packaged by consumer and commercial lenders. And of the millions of mortgages sold on the secondary market, he said, more than half are bought by Fannie Mae, formerly the Federal National Mortgage Association, and another government-regulated company, Freddie Mac, formerly the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
In 1938, "Congress wanted to create a standardized national system of housing finance," he said. "Before Fannie Mae, there was no secondary market." In 1997 alone, Mr. Zigas said, Fannie Mae provided funds for 1.45 million residential mortgages amounting to more than $129 billion.
As a result, most lenders want to keep open the option of being able to sell mortgages on the secondary market -- whether they intend to or not -- and since Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are the biggest kids on the block, the standards they use have become the de facto standards for the industry. And while there are different standards for different types of loans, the loans that meet the minimum standards for sale to the secondary market are generally considered "conforming" loans, while those that do not are typically considered "nonconforming."
"Most nonconforming loans are loans that exceed our $227,150 maximum loan limit," Mr. Zigas said, adding that loans can also be considered nonconforming if the criteria used to approve the borrower for the mortgage do not meet Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac standards.
There are scores of different mortgages available to borrowers today, each with its own combination of terms, qualifying standards and costs, some designed for buyers seeking the smallest possible down payment, others for borrowers for whom the size of the down payment is of less concern. Some are Government-insured mortgages, from the Federal Housing Administration, designed for low-and middle-income borrowers, or the Veterans Administration. SOME are sponsored by Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac, some are underwritten by other big investors on the secondary market, such as pension funds and insurance companies, and some are offered directly by lenders who may keep the loan in their own portfolio.
F.H.A.-insured loans, for example, allow for mortgages of up to $170,362 on single-family homes with as little as 3 percent down, and no income limitations. Fannie Mae, for example, also offers 3-percent-down mortgages of up to $227,150 under what it calls the 97 Percent Neighborhood Mortgage Program to first-time buyers in New York City and Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester Counties.
Ellen Bitton, president of Park Avenue Mortgage Group in Manhattan, said that the program, which is limited to one- and two-family houses and condominiums, allows borrowers to get a mortgage with a down payment of as little as 3 percent. To qualify, Ms. Bitton said, total household income cannot exceed $75,570 for borrowers in New York City; $66,500 in Nassau and Suffolk, and $69,800 in Westchester. Another Fannie Mae program, Flexible 97, also permits a 3 percent down payment, but that program, available only in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, allows borrowers with very good credit to borrow the down payment.
At the other end of the spectrum, Ms. Bitton said, is a program offered by a lender who makes mortgages available on one-family homes for borrowers who have a down payment of 25 percent or more. The program, which does not require borrowers to provide any information whatsoever about income or profession, clearly falls outside the "normal" standards of the secondary market. Yet, Ms. Bitton said, the terms of the mortgage are quite reasonable.
"For a borrower with a good credit history, this loan would cost about a half-percent more in interest and one point more than a more traditional loan," Ms. Bitton said, explaining that in mortgage-speak, one point is equal to one percent of the mortgage amount. Generally speaking, she said, points reflect the amount of money being charged by a lender or broker for a particular loan. The number of points being charged, she said, can vary from none to several, depending on factors such as the type of loan sought, the interest rate, the amount of the down payment, the creditworthiness of the borrower, and the relationship that the broker has with its lenders.
"You might go to one broker who'll quote you a mortgage at 7.5 percent and two points," Ms. Bitton said, and "the broker next door" will "quote you 7 percent and one point."
The bottom-line question for most first-time buyers, of course, is whether they will qualify for the mortgage they need.
"Most mortgage decisions are made in four dimensions," said Oded Ben-Ami, a senior loan officer for Sterling National Mortgage, a mortgage banker and broker based in Great Neck, L.I.
Those four dimensions, he said, are income, assets, creditworthiness and the value of the mortgaged property.
"The borrower obviously has to have enough income to afford the mortgage payments, taxes, insurance, and whatever other debt the borrower is carrying," Mr. Ben-Ami said, adding that while employment income is the easiest to document -- W-2 forms or pay stubs along with a verification of employment from the employer are usually sufficient -- self-employment income is equally acceptable as long as it can be documented. Generally, he said, that can be done by producing tax returns for the previous two or three years.
The second dimension -- the borrower's assets -- is considered because the lender wants to know that the borrower can pay for closing costs and still have some reserves left over, Mr. Ben-Ami said.
The third factor, credit history, he said, "should be predictive of prompt and responsible payment of the new obligation." That means that while minor blemishes on credit may be overlooked if an acceptable explanation is provided, more serious problems should be addressed -- if at all possible -- before applying for a mortgage.
In fact, Mr. Ben-Ami said, anyone considering applying for a mortgage in the near future should obtain a copy of his or her credit report from one or all of the national credit reporting agencies to insure that the reports are accurate. Incorrect entries, he said, can and should be removed from the reports by immediately contact the credit bureaus in writing.
The fourth dimension -- the value of the property to be mortgaged -- is actually more than just an assessment of whether the market value exceeds the amount of the mortgage. Instead, Mr. Ben-Ami said, it is an assessment of the relationship between the market value of the property and the equity the borrower has invested in the property -- typically referred to as the "loan-to-value ratio."
"By factoring in the borrower's equity, the bank is betting that the borrower has enough of his own money invested to keep him making payments on time," Mr. Ben-Ami said. "And by factoring in the market value of the property, the bank is making sure that the property is salable enough that the bank can afford to lose that bet."
But if the borrowers' equity is so important to a lender, how is it possible for borrowers to obtain mortgages with down payments of as little as 3 percent?
"With Private Mortgage Insurance," said Mr. Zigas of Fannie Mae, referring to insurance coverage that protects the lender for the difference between the borrower's down payment and the amount of equity needed to make the lender feel the investment is secure -- generally around 20 percent.
"P.M.I. is not a significant expense for the borrower," Mr. Zigas said, "but it enables the mortgage industry to extend credit much more broadly and with interest rates that are no higher than the rates charged on conforming mortgages." He explained that since Fannie Mae's standards require a loan-to-value ratio of at least 20 percent, P.M.I. is necessary to make the loan acceptable to Fannie Mae.
"Most people just starting out haven't been able to accumulate the down payment and the closing costs they would otherwise need to get a mortgage," he said. "P.M.I. helps put those people into homes and at the same time protects the investor." Mr. Zigas said, for example, that the monthly insurance premium on a $150,000 mortgage with 3 percent down would be $112. A homeowner may be able to discontinue the insurance when the equity reaches 20 percent.
Qualifying for a mortgage, of course, involves more than just proving you have an income, a bank account, good credit and a down payment. Lenders need to be satisfied that a borrower's income is going to be sufficient to cover the additional expense involved in carrying the mortgage. Accordingly, many lenders follow Fannie Mae's "debt-to-income ratio" standards.
Regina Huber, director of banking operations for Park Avenue Mortgage Group, explained that most Fannie Mae loan programs permit borrowers to spend no more than 28 percent of their gross income on fixed housing expenses. Those expenses -- which include principal and interest on the loan, real estate taxes and any insurance required -- are often referred to as P.I.T.I. (principal, interest, taxes, insurance).
IN addition, she said, Fannie Mae generally will not allow a borrower's total fixed monthly payments -- which include P.I.T.I. expenses plus recurring debt like credit cards and automobile loans -- to exceed 36 percent of the gross income.
Moreover, Ms. Huber said, since the amount of income considered adequate to support a mortgage is determined largely by the monthly payment, and since different types and terms of mortgages result in different monthly payments, it is possible that a borrower who does not qualify for one mortgage may qualify for another.
For example, she said, the monthly payment on a 15-year mortgage is usually going to be greater than the payment on a 30-year mortgage for the same amount and for the same borrower, even though the interest rate on the 15-year loan will be slightly less. For example, she said, a 15-year, $150,000 mortgage at 7 percent -- the current interest rate for such loans -- is $1,348.24. A 30-year mortgage for the same amount but at 7.25 percent -- also the current rate -- would be $1,023.26.
On the other hand, she said, the monthly payment on the 30-year fixed-rate mortgage is generally going to be more than what will be initially required on, say, a three-year adjustable-rate mortgage for the same amount. The reason, she said, is that adjustable rate mortgages carry, for a specific period, an interest rate lower than that on a fixed-rate mortgage.
When the period ends, the rate can fluctuate up or down based upon a predetermined formula. An adjustable-rate mortgage with an initial interest rate of 6 3/8 percent, Ms. Huber said, would cost $935.81 a month, making such a loan easier to qualify for than either the 15- or 30-year fixed-rate mortgages.
By contrast, in 1982, when rates rose as high as 18.75 percent on new fixed-rate loans and 14.75 percent on new adjustable-rate loans with a three-year intial fixed rate, the monthly payments on a new $150,000, 30-year fixed-rate mortgage were $2,352.62, while the payments in the first three years of the variable-rate loan were $1,866.72.
Ms. Huber added that while adjustable-rate loans may carry lower interest rates than fixed-rate mortgages, they also carry some inherent risks because their interest rates can increase if rates in general rise. At the same time, however, most adjustable mortgages being written today, she said, contain interest increase "caps" of 2 percent per adjustment and 6 percent over the life of the loan.
Paulette Bonanno, a vice president of the National Cooperative Bank in Manhattan, said that even though co-op share loans are technically not mortgages -- which only apply to real estate -- but are pledges of stock certificates and the proprietary lease, the criteria used to qualify borrowers for share loans are typically the same standards used by Fannie Mae.
Ms. Bonanno added that the influence and consistency of Fannie Mae were what made it possible for mortgage brokers to arrange loans, because the brokers can be sure they are submitting only qualified borrowers to the lenders. On the other hand, she said, since not all lenders sell their loans to Fannie Mae, an efficient broker who works closely with several lenders will know the procedures and requirements of each and submit borrowers accordingly.
"Lenders have their particular way of doing things," Ms. Bonanno said. "And a good broker knows what the lender wants."
As a result, Ms. Bonanno said, while a borrower may end up paying for the broker's services, a reputable one is usually worth the extra cost. "You just have to ask around, shop around and compare brokers," she said.
Many first-time buyers, of course, make their initial contact with a mortgage broker or lender only after finding a property to buy. And while those who go shopping for mortgages at that point are no less likely to obtain one than others who do it sooner, the ones who wait may be overlooking a valuable tool that can be used when negotiating the terms of a sale with an owner. "The first thing we do is make sure our buyers get prequalified for a mortgage," said Peter Bell, chief executive officer of Balch Buyers Realty, a buyers-only broker based in Mamaroneck, N.Y.
Mr. Bell explained that prequalification means that a specific lender has determined that a specific borrower has the ability to obtain a mortgage for a certain amount of money and that the lender is likely to provide that mortgage if the value of the property warrants it. That, he said, can be useful in two ways: first, it provides the buyer with a clear assessment of how costly a house he can buy, and second, it provides the buyer with leverage in negotiating with a seller.
IN fact, whether or not prequalification is the goal, it usually pays for a borrower to begin shopping for a mortgage sooner rather than later.
"You're going to spend six months looking for a home and then find you have just a couple of weeks to go shopping for the mortgage," said Keith T. Gumbinger, vice president of HSH Associates, a mortgage-industry publisher in Butler, N.J. "So giving yourself as much time possible to shop in advance is crucial to getting the best deal." He added that in addition to comparing mortgages offered through brokers, borrowers should contact lenders directly and check the Internet for prevailing rates and fees. Some useful Web sites include Fannie Mae's Home Path (www.HomePath.com), which provides lists of lenders offering Fannie Mae mortgages; Intuit's Quicken Mortgage (www.QuickenMortgage.com) where borrowers may be able to get pre-qualified for a mortgage by one of the 11 participating national lenders; and the HSH Associates home page (www.hsh.com) which lists current rates offered by area lenders and other information of interest to borrowers.
 It is also prudent, Mr. Gumbinger said, for buyers who find a mortgage with terms they like to lock in the interest rate. While some lenders permit lock-ins at no additional cost, others can charge as much as a half point for a lock-in that exceeds 60.
A lock-in, he said, insures borrowers against unexpected increases in the interest rate. And while a rate lock may deprive the borrower of a lower rate if interest rates fall, Mr. Gumbinger said, the benefits of a lock-in usually outweigh the risks.
"My feeling is that by not locking in a good rate," he said, "you leave yourself with too little to win and too much to lose."
 
Guide to Vocabulary of Mortgage-Speak
 Here is a glossary of terms used in the mortgage process, with definitions provided by Fannie Mae, the name formally adopted by what was once the Federal National Mortgage Association, which purchases mortgage loans from issuers, either as an investment or for resale in secondary markets, and as such is the largest source of residential mortgage funds in the country.
Amortization: The gradual repayment of a mortgage by installments, calculated to pay off the principal at the end of a fixed period of time.
 Amortization Schedule: A timetable for payment of a mortgage showing the amount of each payment applied to interest and principal and the balance remaining.
Cap: A provision of an adjustable rate mortgage limiting how much the interest rate or mortgage payments may increase or decrease.
Commitment Letter: A formal offer by a lender stating the terms under which it agrees to lend money to a home buyer.
Conforming Loan: A loan that meets the underwriting guidelines of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and does not exceed the maximum allowable loan limit of $227,150.
Due-on-Sale Clause: A provision in a mortgage allowing the lender to demand repayment in full if the borrower sells the property that is securing the mortgage.
Equity: A homeowner's financial interest in a property. Equity is the difference between the fair market value of a property and the amount still owed on the mortgage.
First Mortgage: A mortgage that has first claim to the secured property in the event of a default.
Fixed-Rate Mortgage: A mortgage in which the interest rate does not change during the entire term of the loan.
Foreclosure: The legal process by which a mortgaged property may be sold when a mortgage is in default.
Lock-In: A written agreement guaranteeing the home buyer a specified interest rate provided the loan is closed within a set period of time. The lock-in also usually specifies the number of points to be paid at closing.
Mortgage Banker: A company that originates mortgages exclusively for resale in the secondary market.
Mortgage Broker: An individual or company that, for a fee, acts as intermediary between borrowers and lenders.
Mortgagee: The lender in a mortgage agreement.
Mortgagor: The borrower in a mortgage agreement.
Origination Fee: A fee paid to a lender for processing a loan application.
P.I.T.I.: Stands for principal, interest, taxes and insurance, the components of a monthly mortgage payment.
Points: A one-time charge by the lender to increase the yield of the loan; a point is 1 percent of the amount of the mortgage.
Principal: The amount borrowed or remaining unpaid; also, that part of the monthly payment that reduces the outstanding balance of a mortgage.
Qualifying Ratios: Guidelines applied by the lenders to determine how large a loan to grant a home buyer.
Underwriting: The process of evaluating a loan application to determine the risk involved for the lender. It involves an analysis of the borrower's creditworthiness and the quality of the property itself.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK ON LINE;
A Voice for the Irish

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
No shamrocks or leprechauns here.
 "Traditional musicians and their year-round fans view St. Patrick's Day in the same jaundiced light that seasoned drinkers see New Year's Eve: it's amateur night," said Don Meade in his column On the Fiddle, a regular feature of a Web site called Irish Voice Online. Music events on "Paddy's Day," he continues, "tend to attract a lot of once-a-year, 'Kiss-me-I'm-Irish' types who can't tell a hornpipe from a gaspipe." 
 Behold Ireland for the Irish (and the Irish in America). Mr. Meade, who is Irish-American, also writes for the Manhattan weekly newspaper Irish Voice. It was founded some 10 years ago as a forum for Irish immigrants, who were flocking, legally and illegally, to the Northeast when Ireland's economy took a nasty spill in the 1980's. A rudimentary version of the paper went up on the Web in summer 1996. The latest site, with many of the articles in the newsstand version, went up last August.
 "We are still writing for the Irish newly arrived," said Darina Molloy, 27, a former reporter for The Connaught Telepgraph in County mayo who came to New York in 1994. Besides writing and reporting for the Irish Voice, she also organizes stories for the Web. "But we've also tride to expand the audience to Irish-Americans and to anyone interested in Ireland and Irish affairs," she said.
 The number of visitors to the site, while still small, is growing quickly. Weekly hits, or page views, are averaging 3,000, up from 800 hits a week last fall. The Irish Voice says the newspaper's circulation is 65,000.
 WHAT YOU SEE Irish Voice Online covers news about the Republic of Ireland, Northern Ireland and Irish communities in America, especially those in the New York region.
 An article on Feb. 11 by Ms. Molloy, for example, reported that recent Irish immigrants were returning to a New York institution where their numbers had been dwindling: the New York City Police Department.
 An article on March 4 bearing the headline " 'I Owe Nothing,' Says gertie Byrne," brings readers up to date on a complex lawsuit pitting two Irishmen in County Mayo against an Irish-American woman in New York over a festival held at Yonkers Raceway in 1994.
 OUTSIDE LINKS Scores, including news groups and chat rooms in Scottish Gaelic, Irish Gaelic and Manx, a nearly extinct language spoken on the Isle of Man.
 WHAT YOU GET A work in progress. Ms. Molloy says the newspaper's first priority is to establish digital archives so more than one issue at a time can be displayed on the Web.
 IRISH VOICE ONLINE
(http://www.irishvoice.com/index.htm)

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Redeveloping the Hammerstein Estate in Queens;
Wildflower to Blossom Again in Beechurst

 BODY:
For the last decade, there have been several proposals to develop the Tudor-style mansion built in 1924 for Arthur Hammerstein, the Broadway producer and uncle of lyricist Oscar Hammerstein 2d. The two-story, 15-room house called Wildflower, for Arthur Hammerstein's 1923 hit play, sits abandoned along the waterfront in Beechurst, Queens, a victim of arson, vandalism and time.
But now the five-acre grounds of the estate at 168-11 Powells Cove Boulevard have been cleared and work is to begin this month on restoring the mansion and reshaping it into six residences. 
 Thirty-two simplex and duplex units will also be built on just over two acres in four, three-story town-houses designed to blend with the mansion, which was designated a landmark in 1982.
The aim is that the community "looks like it has been there from the start," said Faruk Yorgancioglu, a Bridgehampton L.I., architect who designed the project in association with Beyhan Karahan & Associates of Manhattan
The mansion and duplex units will have two to four bedrooms and 1,329 to 2,342 square feet; the two-bedroom simplexes will have 1,013 to 1,117 square feet. Prices are expected to be $232,690 to $276,060 for the simplexes and $373,930 to $682,740 for the duplexes. Monthly charges are to be $194 to $425.
The developer of the $10-million project is Wild Flower Developers of Whitestone, Queens. It is the real estate arm of Kiska Construction Corporation U.S.A. -- the North American subsidiary of a Turkish engineering firm based in in Ankara.
Kiska is no stranger to the site. In 1987 the company bought it and proposed making the mansion a clubhouse for a 171-unit condominium project, which was thwarted by local opposition.
In 1993, Kiska sold the site to another developer and last October repurchased it believing the current project "was economically viable and pleasing to the community," said Meir Kahtan, a spokesman for the developer. Future plans call for 30 more town houses.
The mansion is one of the last architectural links to a time, in the 1920's, when Beechurst was a retreat for Broadway's elite and stars of the budding film industry.
That sense of history and the site's setting "will be a big plus" to attract buyers, said Mr. Yorgancioglu. Sales are expected to begin in May.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 12, 1998, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Postings column on March 15 about redeveloping the former Arthur Hammerstein estate misspelled the name of the estate's Queens neighborhood. It is Beechhurst, not Beechurst.

HEADLINE: Taxing Sales on the Internet: Many Governors vs. Congressional Legislation

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Buoyed by White House support and facing only tepid opposition from the nation's governors, Silicon Valley has state and local tax collectors on the defensive: Congress is on the verge of passing legislation that would effectively bar sales taxes on Internet transactions until 2004.
"The outcome is not in doubt," said Representative Christopher Cox, Republican of California, who is sponsoring the Internet Tax Freedom Act in the House. 
 The bill responds to fears that a thicket of conflicting taxes will choke off the growth of Internet commerce, in particular inhibiting its use by small businesses that could not cope with the burden of the paperwork. But some analysts -- and many governors -- worry that a Federal moratorium would set a precedent that would permanently deprive state and local governments of a huge potential revenue source.
"If we don't tax Internet commerce now, it will never be taxed," said William Gale, an economist at the Brookings Institution, the research group in Washington.
With a few exceptions, states have made little effort to tax Internet service providers like America Online. Retail sales through the Internet are, in theory, covered by "use" taxes that require consumers to pay taxes in their home states no matter where they buy. But under Supreme Court rulings, one state cannot compel a merchant in another to collect use taxes unless the merchant has a substantial business presence in the state where the buyer lives.
That has not prevented businesses from imagining a day when states try to tax Internet use. In a survey of executives from large retailers and media corporations conducted by KPMG Peat Marwick in 1996, half said that tax ambiguities had already tempered plans for Internet commerce. And Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, along with Representative Cox, has been leading the charge for a legislative remedy.
The Senate and House bills that have emerged from committee would bar taxes on monthly Internet access charges until January 2002. State and local governments would remain free to tax purchases made on the Internet, but the Cox-Wyden bill would bar attempts to go beyond the limits on out-of-state collection set by the Supreme Court. "The states would be no less able to collect sales taxes than they are today," Mr. Cox said.
Many tax specialists sympathize with efforts to avoid discriminatory taxes on Internet service providers. "States are notorious for their inconsistencies, taxing services on a hit-or-miss basis," said Joel Slemrod, an economist at the University of Michigan's business school.
By the same token, many sympathize with the problems that businesses -- particularly "mom and pop" stores expanding onto the Internet -- potentially face in selling to customers in thousands of different tax districts. But they are wary of precedents that effectively put Internet sales out of bounds to state and local tax collectors. "Internet commerce is small today," Mr. Gale said, "but what happens to local tax bases when the Net becomes a major presence in retailing?"
With flat-out opposition to the Internet legislation no longer a realistic option now that the President and the Governors of New York, California and Virginia have taken a stance in favor of the Cox-Wyden bill, the National Governors' Association is pressing an alternative.
Led by Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah and Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, the association is willing to accept a permanent prohibition on taxing access to the Internet. But in return, it wants Washington to give individual states a powerful incentive to create a single consolidated tax on out-of-state purchases, both electronic and mail order.
The association's proposal would override the Supreme Court ruling by requiring large vendors to collect use taxes on behalf of states as long as the states conformed to a single tax structure. "Now is the time for a system that creates a level playing filed for all sellers," Governor Leavitt said.
But the governors' approach faces strong opposition. Although their bill would meet the primary objective of Internet service providers, it would also open Internet commerce to taxation. "We see this as a new tax that would generate $16 billion in revenue by the year 2000," Senator Wyden said.
Probably more important, it would tie Internet tax legislation to the fate of the states' attempts to force mail-order vendors to collect taxes from out-of-state customers. And because there is hardly a ground swell for such a move in Congress, there might be no legislation at all -- a result that would not unduly disturb most opponents of the Internet Tax Freedom Act.
The governors, it is generally conceded, are playing a weak political hand. House leaders are promising a floor vote on the Cox-Wyden bill this month. And last week, Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, predicted that the bill would come to a vote in the Senate by May.
The real question, then, is whether the governors can salvage a compromise with the bill's Congressional sponsors. "I'm persuaded there is still a lot of common ground here," Governor Leavitt said.

HEADLINE: MEDIA: ENTERTAINMENT;
The Simpsons and their progeny colonize television in a golden era for animation.

BYLINE: By James Sterngold 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
AS everyone knows, television viewers are growing increasingly sophisticated and are demanding ever more thoughtful shows from an expanding number of channels. And so, as the networks look for ways to appeal to our high-mindedness, they have latched on to a new tool: a flood of animated shows.
When Fox Broadcasting put "The Simpsons" on the air in 1989, featuring an odd family with overbites and brilliant yellow skin, most experts scoffed. After all, it had been years since "The Flintstones" and "The Jetsons" had attracted audiences with what was often characterized as contrived silliness. 
 Now, the networks are ushering in a golden era of animated shows. "The Simpsons," a hugely profitable show about a deliriously dysfunctional family, has been joined by another Fox success, "King of the Hill," a chronicle of the woes of a conservative Texan confronting changing times. (There are also animated shows on cable including "Daria" on MTV; "Spawn" on HBO, and "South Park," "Dr. Katz: Professional Therapist" and "The Critic" on Comedy Central, plus, coming this summer, "Bob and Margaret.")
There are at least six more adult animated shows in the works, two on Fox, three on the WB Network and one on UPN. Many more are being developed and could be on the air within three years.
The sudden proliferation of animated shows is a tribute not just to the desire of network executives to try to replicate the success of "The Simpsons," which has earned hundreds of millions of dollars, but to tap into a medium with several economic advantages: It does not get dated like live-action shows and thus can run in syndication longer, it tends to sell well overseas, and it tends to generate large merchandise sales. "You don't see a lot of 'Home Improvement' T-shirts out there, but we get an enormous number of requests for 'The Simpsons' merchandise," said Rick Jacobson, the president of Twentieth Television, Fox's syndication unit. "It can be very profitable."
Dean Valentine, the president of UPN, which is developing a show based on the "Dilbert" comic strip, noted the breadth of the audience for well-made animated shows. "Animation has the capacity to appeal to a broader audience than many live-action shows," he said. "It has an inherent appeal to kids, but over all it is far more culturally transportable. It is easier to sell internationally, and that can be very important to a show's financial success."
Fox is adding "The PJ's," about a family in the projects in New Jersey, starring Eddie Murphy as the voice of the lead character, and "Futurama," a futuristic show by Matt Groening, who created "The Simpsons." Negotiations to finalize the contract for "Futurama" have not been completed, said Peter Roth, the president of Fox Broadcasting. But he said that the show had been in development for three years and that Mr. Groening had already made a three-hour pitch for the show, which he described as "staggering."
"The PJ's" will be slightly unique in that it will employ a form of claymation, which involves using clay models -- or in the case of "The PJ's," foam models -- and numerous still shots of the models as they are bent and twisted to create the illusion of movement.
Mr. Roth emphasized, though, that the success or failure of the shows would depend on their writing, not the realism of the figures. "The animation enhances the success of the show, but the real basis of the appeal is the writing and the characters," he said.
The WB Network is developing three shows: "Invasion America," which is being done by Steven Spielberg; "Baby Blues," based on the comic strip about a young couple raising a baby, and an untitled show aimed mostly at teen-agers that is being produced by two "Simpsons" alumni.
Mr. Roth of Fox summed up the simple logic behind the new wave of animated shows. "The animated form is slightly more expensive to produce," Mr. Roth said. "On the other hand, the profit potential on a show like 'The Simpsons' is astronomical. The animated form is universal in its appeal."
There are, in fact, several potential liabilities to animation. For one, it can take six months or more to produce a single episode compared with a few weeks or so for a live-action show. There are many more steps in animation as the shows are written and rewritten, the voices recorded, the basic animation laid out and the material sent overseas -- usually to Korea or Taiwan to save money -- for the final animation to be generated.
Several executives said that a typical animated show, in its first year, could cost $600,000 to $800,000 an episode to produce. A sitcom will usually cost closer to $500,000 to $700,000.
On the other hand, animated characters do not make increasing salary demands as a show's success grows. In addition, writers can have more latitude.
"You can have 40 scenes in an animated show, whereas there might be 7 or 8 in the typical sitcom," said Garth Ancier, the president of entertainment at the WB Network. "That's a big difference, and a good writer can really take advantage of that. You can go anywhere, do anything."
The real payoff for any television show is syndication; if a show remains on the air for about four years, it has accumulated enough episodes to be offered to independent stations. If "The Simpsons" is any indication, this is a particularly rich realm for animated shows. "The Simpsons" has been earning about $1.5 million an episode in syndication, a handsome sum, but less than the top shows, like "Seinfeld," which has received closer to $3 million.

HEADLINE: Second Chance at Defiance For a British Newspaper

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: LONDON, March 15

 BODY:
The Independent, the newspaper that defiantly challenged the partisan practices of Britain's press at its founding in 1986 but has been losing money, staff and readers in recent years, has been given a new start.
Coming to the newspaper's rescue and pledging a return to its founding values is Anthony J. F. O'Reilly, the Irish industrialist who is the chief executive of the H. J. Heinz Company in Pittsburgh and who heads a chain that owns newspapers in Ireland, Australia, New Zealand, Portugal and South Africa. 
 In an announcement that ended months of uncertainty about the future of The Independent, Mr. O'Reilly's Independent Newspapers, based in Dublin, said on Wednesday that it was taking full control of the paper, promising an end to cutbacks and establishing a United States-style division between the news and editorial departments to reinforce the notion, rare in Britain, of coverage free of bias.
"It's the American model, very important, something that guarantees a sort of separation of powers," Mr. O'Reilly said on Friday in an interview from his vacation home in Lyford Key in the Bahamas.
Mr. O'Reilly, 61, is himself a storied figure, starting out as Ireland's greatest rugby player and becoming one of America's leading executives with a renown for his after-dinner speeches, his talent at mimicry, his friendships with world leaders and the peripatetic life he leads on private jets around the world.
He said he had no quarrel with the right of papers like The Times, The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian to have their particular points of view, but he felt Britain lacked and needed "an independent voice, neither right nor left, a voice for inquiring, skeptical Britons."
The Independent's original owners placed the paper at the top end of the market, pursuing readers disenchanted with the new popular direction The Times of London took after Rupert Murdoch bought it. The Independent proved to be a strong attraction not just for readers but for writers from The Times and other broadsheets.
Its founding editor, Andreas Whittam Smith, wrote in its first issue, "We will both praise and criticize without reference to a party line." This phrase, unremarkable in some societies, resonated in Britain, where newspapers often reflect the views of their owners in their news pages as well as on their editorial pages. The Daily Telegraph and The Times are notably conservative, and The Guardian is dependably liberal.
Just this month, The Times demonstrated the limits on its editorial independence by ignoring for a week reports that the HarperCollins publishing house had disguised its reasons for dropping the memoirs of Chris Patten, the former British Governor of Hong Kong, to cloak the involvement of Mr. Murdoch, who owns HarperCollins and The Times. Mr. O'Reilly said Mr. Patten was joining the board overseeing operation of The Independent.
Using the slogan "It is . . . are you?", The Independent had astonishingly developed a circulation of 415,000 by 1990, running slightly ahead of The Times and The Guardian. It also established an eye-catching policy of running photographs on its front page of a size and artistic composition unusual in daily journalism.
Then came a series of blunders compounded by a recessionary downturn in advertising and a rise in newsprint prices. Its management controls proved to be too lax, and it started a costly and ill-timed Sunday edition. When Mr. Murdoch began a price war in 1993, selling some editions of The Times at less than cost, The Independent was particularly hard hit. The circulation of The Times doubled while that of The Independent declined to 200,000, and its staff of known writers deserted the failing ship.
Faced with enormous financial problems, The Independent was sold to an odd partnership led by the tabloid Mirror Group and Mr. O'Reilly's Independent Newspapers, publishers of upscale broadsheets. Each ended up with 46 percent, with the remaining shares in the hands of Spanish and Italian publishing groups and Mr. Whittam Smith.
Sales continued to slide, and the two principals, Mr. O'Reilly, and the head of the Mirror Group, David Montgomery, took different approaches to the problem. Mr. Montgomery wanted to make further cuts in the editorial budget and take the paper into the middle market dominated by the tabloid Daily Mail, while Mr. O'Reilly favored aiming it higher and feared the effect of further reductions in financing.
The paper's editor, Andrew Marr, ordered up a stylish redesign opposed by Mr. Montgomery, who ordered a reduction in its promotional budget and other cutbacks. In January, Mr. Marr, a cerebral and literate man who is a favorite of Mr. O'Reilly, refused to carry out the order and was dismissed. Rosie Boycott, already running The Sunday Independent, was made editor of the daily, too, and she quickly undid Mr. Marr's redesign and promised a livelier read.
Mr. O'Reilly then made his move, buying out his partners for $49.5 million and inviting Mr. Marr back as editor in chief, running the editorial and opinion pages. Ms. Boycott was named the editor of the news and feature pages. In a letter to readers in Friday's issue, Mr. Marr wrote: "Rosie Boycott and I have been told in simple terms to make the paper steadily more intelligent and serious. During an era when most papers are dumbing down, it came as an unusual and exhilarating instruction. Further, we have been given some money to spend on journalists -- another happy surprise."
Asked why he should be considered different from other wealthy newspaper owners who meddle in their newsrooms, Mr. O'Reilly said: "Get a telephone and ring any of the 200 papers we have around the world, The New Zealand Herald, The Cape Times, The Johannesburg Star, Diario in Portugal and ask, 'Has he ever interfered, has he ever phoned and talked to you ?' and you will get a 100 percent response. Not that I don't have the right to do it; it's an entirely valid thing for a proprietor to do, but it simply is not applicable to me. I don't do it."
He said that he was not promising any "quick fixes" and that he thought his plan to restore The Independent would take three to five years. If he can get the circulation of the daily up to 250,000 and the Sunday to 300,000, he said, the papers would be "modestly profitable."
Mr. O'Reilly, who will step down next month as chief executive of Heinz and become the company's chairman, disputed British news reports that it had been his "dream" to become a publisher in Britain. "This is not a trophy purchase," he said.
"The London market is the centerpiece of a great deal of both political and newspaper activity as far as printed words in English are concerned, and to own a major broadsheet, a quality paper at the top end of one of the most visible markets in the world has a halo effect on Independent Newspapers and its claim to be a truly independent newspaper group," Mr. O'Reilly said.
He compared his belief in hands-off proprietorship to that of the last Irishman to become a London press baron, Brendan Bracken, who once held a controlling interest in The Economist and The Financial Times. Mr. O'Reilly recalled a time when the editor then, Gordon Newton, placed a call to Lord Bracken. "He talked at some length about some problem he had at the paper, and Bracken answered by saying, 'Are you the editor of the FT?' Then he hung up."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Rosie Boycott, The Independent's editor for news and features, and Andrew Marr, the paper's editor in chief. (Andrew Buurman); Anthony J. F. O'Reilly has taken control of The Independent. (Tony Andrews/FT Pictures & Graphics)(pg. D7)

HEADLINE: Aetna Deal for New York Life's Health Unit Is Expected Today

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
Aetna Inc., the giant health insurer, is expected to announce today that it is buying the health care business of the New York Life Insurance Company for $1.05 billion in cash.
Reflecting some of the negotiating that has gone into the deal and some of the uncertainties in the health care business, Aetna has agreed to pay New York Life as much as $300 million more if the unit, NYLCare Health Plans, meets certain growth targets in the next two years, people close to the transaction said. 
The deal would significantly increase Aetna's market share in metropolitan New York, in the Washington-Baltimore area and in Texas. It would also enable New York Life to concentrate on the sale of life insurance and annuities and on strengthening its money management businesses, including the Mainstay mutual funds.
"This should work out well for both sides," said Kenneth S. Abramowitz, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. "Aetna will be acquiring more regional strength and more management talent. And New York Life will be getting some funds it can immediately use in its core businesses."
Spokesmen for Aetna and New York Life said company policy forbade them from discussing reports of pending transactions. Aetna has been negotiating since late last year to buy NYLCare, which provides health insurance for 2.2 million people, including 1.5 million under managed care. Aetna has 13.7 million health insurance customers.
The merger is not expected to have an immediate effect on costs, benefits or physician relationships for customers of the two companies. Eventually, it should provide a wider choice of physicians.
New York Life is following the lead of several other big life insurers in selling health care businesses in the last few years. Health insurers are buying these companies to gain market share, which gives them leverage in negotiating better prices with doctors and hospitals. And the life insurers are happy to be able to focus on selling life insurance and other financial services.
Since becoming the chief executive of New York Life last April, Sy Sternberg has been painting a picture of growth through acquisition for his company, the nation's fourth-largest life insurer, and analysts said yesterday that they expected him to use the proceeds from the sale of NYLCare and other money he has been accumulating to carry out those plans.
The analysts said they thought Mr. Sternberg was looking at life insurance and mutual fund companies in the United States and abroad. While he might buy a company for $1 billion or so, the analysts said, it would not be surprising to see a series of acquisitions in the range of $200 million to $300 million.
Aetna, which had sold its property and casualty business and is looking for a buyer for its individual life insurance unit, became one of the nation's biggest health insurers with the purchase in 1996 of U.S. Healthcare for $8.2 billion. Richard L. Huber, chief executive of Aetna, has told analysts to expect further acquisitions, particularly of companies like NYLCare that could offer large concentrations of managed-care customers in fast-growing regions like the Southwest and the Atlantic Seaboard.
In metropolitan New York, including New Jersey and Connecticut, NYLCare has about 146,000 managed care customers, which would give Aetna 1.5 million customers in the region. In Texas, one of NYLCare's strongest markets, it has 634,000 managed-care customers compared with 157,000 for Aetna, giving a merged company 791,000. In another main market, the Washington-Baltimore area, NYLCare has 477,000 managed-care customers, which would be combined with Aetna's 176,000 to give a combined company 653,000.
Because New York Life is formally owned by its policyholders and is not required to disclose as much financial detail as publicly traded companies, analysts said it was difficult to evaluate the price Aetna was expected to pay for NYLCare. But they said that with health care companies struggling for profits, sale prices have been much lower since Aetna paid the equivalent of about $2,000 per health plan member when it bought U.S. Healthcare.
While U.S. Healthcare had been turning good profits, NYLCare just about broke even in 1996 and it lost about $30 million on revenue of $3 billion last year. Still, analysts said NYLCare was clearly a potential money maker when coupled with Aetna's huge operations.
"Strategically this makes sense," said Peter Patrino, an insurance industry analyst with the Duff & Phelps Credit Rating Company in Chicago. "The health insurance companies that are going to succeed are the ones that have the large-scale economies to offer the best price and the top level of service."
Even so, analysts say melding NYLCare with Aetna may prove challenging, especially in light of the difficulties Aetna has had in absorbing U.S. Healthcare. Third-quarter earnings for Aetna, for example, were 16 percent below the consensus estimate on Wall Street. Part of the problem was that in the course of integration, Aetna had lost track of rising health claim costs.
But Douglas Meyer, another Duff & Phelps insurance analyst, said most of the Aetna-U.S. Healthcare merger had been completed and "the hope is they've learned some of the pitfalls and things they need to be wary of" as they take on NYLCare.
One person close to Aetna said the company had, indeed, learned some lessons and planned to merge the NYLCare business "much more gradually," beginning with the smaller, more manageable operations in states like Illinois, Delaware, Washington and Maine. Aetna plans to operate the two largest segments of NYLCare's business -- those in Texas and in the Washington-Baltimore area -- separately for the first two years, partly because they will be harder to blend. It will also be easier to follow the performance of the acquired company in calculating how much of the additional $300 million goes to New York Life.
Aetna was advised in the transaction by Wasserstein Perella & Company and Davis Polk & Wardwell. The advisers for New York Life were Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company and Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
'Primary Colors': Hollywood Offers an Apology

BYLINE: By ELEANOR RANDOLPH 

 BODY:
When the book "Primary Colors" appeared in early 1996, it seemed like a sleazy parody of President Clinton's 1992 campaign. Now, here comes the movie "Primary Colors," and suddenly it feels like an apology.
The story line has not changed much, as adapted by the director Mike Nichols and his longtime teammate Elaine May. It is our political world that has changed, not merely in the last two years, but in the last two months. With news of a Presidential intern boasting about sex in the Oval Office and a prosecutor veering from real to surreal in his pursuit of Clinton wrongdoing, Americans cannot help being politically distracted. President Clinton's lofty speeches about education, Social Security and the Asian economy fall on ears now pricked for innuendo, eyes focused on the small signs of personal distress. And then, there are the jokes. Every locker-room knee slapper has been recycled in the last few months to include our President. 
 So a movie that might have appeared to be in extremely bad taste in December is suddenly a sad lesson in modern politics by March. That lesson, boiled down a bit, is that it is not a good idea to expect a totally decent human being underneath a splendid politician. The passions, the rages, the pettiness, the grand appeal to history, they are all part of the same imperfect package.
To drive home this point, even the humble doughnut takes on higher symbolism. John Travolta, in his role as the barely fictional governor of Arkansas, Jack Stanton, does a good imitation of the real President, his accent, his petulant lower lip, even the little sashay as the President struts away from some political victory. So, if President Clinton is also known as a man who likes his food jumbo, Mr. Travolta does a good glutton, and when Governor Stanton tucks into an oversized cruller, it is not a pretty sight. The sugar cakes his lips as he talks, making some point that is lost under the crystalline flakes drifting onto his midriff. We wince, gag even, at the combination of sugar, fat and philosopher king.
That counterpoint of the exalted and the gross, in fact, seems to be the movie's most basic point. It serves to remind us that our politicians are people and that even the best were never ideal. Franklin Roosevelt was a rascal. So was Harry Truman. Even President Eisenhower had imperfections that went far beyond his golf swing.
With Matt Drudge and the media "scorps," as the Stanton team refers to the press corps, we know more about Presidential defects in real time instead of a few decades later. Details are not sifted and mulled over by historians so much as they are handed out raw to the American public. We have to do the sifting and mulling now for ourselves.
That next step, of course, is more difficult, and this movie could not manage to sort out something that is far more complicated and subtle than the basic primary color chart offered on the screen. Now that we know too much about every candidate's "character," how do we figure out which sins are peccadilloes and which are deep human flaws? Where do we give the candidate a break? A sideline romance? A shady stock deal? How does a weakness of the flesh compare with a weakness of the will to govern?
The movie, of course, does little more than hint at these bigger questions. After all, this is Hollywood, where larger thoughts have been known to provoke smaller profits. No matter. "Primary Colors" will probably get its public laughs in the movie houses and its private salutes from the White House. Jack Stanton is a long way from being a good person, but by the end of the movie, the audience has been seduced into thinking that he's about as good as we'll get in today's Oval Office.

HEADLINE: Foreign Policy Held Hostage

 BODY:
House Republican leaders flaunt their disregard for America's broader interests by letting anti-abortion crusaders hold up funding for the International Monetary Fund and the United Nations. The money is being held hostage to an obnoxious amendment by Representative Christopher Smith of New Jersey that would block American financing of any foreign group lobbying for less restrictive abortion laws abroad. President Clinton rightly threatens to veto any bill with the Smith language.
A similar ploy by Mr. Smith blocked I.M.F. and U.N. funding measures last fall. Speaker Newt Gingrich should understand that I.M.F. and U.N. payments are too vital to American interests to be ensnarled in abortion politics and ought to let an unencumbered bill pass the House. 
 The $18 billion for the I.M.F. is meant to replenish its reserves after the recent bailouts of Thailand, South Korea and Indonesia. Asia's financial crisis is not over, and the fund may need the money in the coming months. America's trade interests and even the health of the economy could be jeopardized by delaying this funding.
The nearly $1 billion for the U.N. would pay off most of America's debt to the world organization. For years, Congress has withheld some of America's dues to leverage reforms at the U.N. Many of those changes have now been adopted under the leadership of Kofi Annan, the new Secretary General. Other countries have had to make up for the loss of American money, undermining Washington's bargaining power in the U.N. If the back dues remain unpaid, the United States will lose its voting rights in the General Assembly next year, an embarrassment for the nation that led the effort to create the United Nations half a century ago. Abortion politics has no place in determining America's role in the U.N. and the I.M.F.

HEADLINE: Seoul Journal;
Korea Deflated, but a Diplomat's Hopes Are High

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea

 BODY:
Last year, Stephen W. Bosworth agreed to be the American Ambassador to a booming industrialized nation with a single dominant political party.
Now Mr. Bosworth has taken up his duties in what seems quite a different country. South Korea's economy popped in November, just as Mr. Bosworth arrived, and it is now as limp as a burst balloon. Meanwhile, a former political prisoner named Kim Dae Jung has just been inaugurated as President and is promising sweeping change. 
 The vast uncertainties about Korea's future give an ambassador here unusual leeway, and that prospect helped lure Mr. Bosworth, 58, out of diplomatic retirement to take the job (although it seems that the tennis court on the grounds of the Ambassador's residence here played a supporting role).
"Because of the nature of the relationship, you have the opportunity to have an influence that is not often true elsewhere," Mr. Bosworth said. "This is one of the three or four embassies in the world where you really have an opportunity to make a difference."
Mr. Bosworth and his wife, Christine -- who, he says, persuaded him to take the job when he was initially reluctant -- are now unpacking their furniture in the Ambassador's residence (and watching the weather for the beginning of tennis season). Mrs. Bosworth, a formidable cook with 200 cookbooks to unpack, is planning a good deal of entertaining and is also writing a book about the role of food and entertainment in diplomacy.
A Michigan native, whom his wife describes teasingly as "so Midwest," Mr. Bosworth attended Dartmouth -- where he is now chairman of the board of trustees -- and then faced a key career choice. After some debate, he turned down law school and joined the Foreign Service.
Why?
"I was broke."
Presumably expressing his motivations in more eloquent terms at the time, he quickly impressed his bosses. By the age of 38, he was the Ambassador to Tunisia, one of the youngest career diplomats ever appointed to an ambassadorship in American history. Later he served as Ambassador to the Philippines in the 1980's during the "people power" uprising that ousted Ferdinand E. Marcos, but Mr. Bosworth quit the State Department in 1987 to move to the private sector.
Why?
"I was broke again."
In 1995, his finances apparently remedied, Mr. Bosworth returned to diplomacy as head of a consortium to provide energy to North Korea in exchange for its dismantling its nuclear program. That led to an interest in Korea, and to a call from the White House last year asking if he would like to be Ambassador.
President Kim, who by all accounts has an excellent relationship with Mr. Bosworth, was inaugurated on Feb. 25 and is now aiming to improve relations with North Korea. This is an area of special interest to Mr. Bosworth, for he is the first American Ambassador to be appointed here with experience visiting and dealing with the Government in the North.
"The fact that he's been to North Korea, that he's dealt with the North Koreans, gives him a whole new dimension which is going to stand him in good stead," said Donald P. Gregg, a former American Ambassador to South Korea.
In many countries, American ambassadors have arguably been victims of improvements in telecommunications. They still get nice homes and cars with flags, but they are sometimes reduced to delivering messages that are formulated in Washington -- or, worse, plaintively reading copies of messages transmitted by other channels.
Korea, however, has been an exception. James T. Laney, Mr. Bosworth's predecessor, took advantage of uncertainties in Washington to promote an American policy of engagement toward North Korea. He got away with making policy rather than carrying it out.
Mr. Bosworth is not a longtime Korea buff like Mr. Laney, and he does not speak Korean. On the other hand, Mr. Bosworth does speak economics.
While the most prestigious postings for young diplomats are as political officers, Mr. Bosworth rose as an economics officer. He later took graduate-level courses in economics, and his background has won him praise from Koreans in the Government.
"He's an excellent Ambassador, and especially in a time of economic crisis to have somebody well versed in economics is a great plus," said You Jong Keun, the economic adviser to President Kim. "He's very well respected."
The same could not be said of the American Embassy's economic work during the fall. The embassy appeared to be well behind private commentators and analysts in anticipating the crisis, and some in Washington thought its economic reporting was wildly insufficient. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and other top economic officials are said to have been greatly relieved when Mr. Bosworth arrived to take charge.
The problem apparently was that American diplomats and military intelligence experts in Seoul are first-rate in monitoring North Korean troop movements but much less attuned to capital flows. Mr. Bosworth has long argued that embassies need to re-orient themselves to pay more attention to economics, and since becoming Ambassador he has allocated more embassy resources to the economic work.
"There has always been a feeling in the State Department and Foreign Service that economics officers were not quite the creme de la creme, that what you really wanted to be was a political officer carrying diplomatic notes to the Foreign Ministry and making demarches," Mr. Bosworth said.
He added, "I think it's a justifiable criticism, though I don't know quite what you do about it, that the State Department does not have enough first-rate economic talent."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Stephen W. Bosworth, 58, America's new Ambassador in Seoul, hopes this is a moment when a diplomat can really make a difference. (Nicholas D. Kristof/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bill to Push Africa Trade Is Approved

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
In approving a broad trade bill with Africa last week, the House gave President Clinton an important carrot to bring on his trip to the continent later this month.
The legislation, which still needs Senate approval, promotes private United States investment for the 48 countries of sub-Saharan Africa, many of which are some of the poorest in the world. Nations are eligible for preferential treatment if they move toward democracy and free-market economies. 
 In many respects, the bill has more symbolic than substantive importance because trade with Africa is only a tiny fraction of the United States' total foreign commerce
But in a refrain repeatedly heard on the House floor, and one that Mr. Clinton will undoubtedly hammer home during his six-country visit that begins next Sunday, the bill's proponents say the measure underscores a fundamental shift in American relations with Africa that favors trade over aid.
"This legislation creates a reward system that insures those market reforms in Africa are more likely to continue," said Representative Doug Bereuter, a Nebraska Republican.
The bill allows duty-free and quota-free exports to the United States for 10 years, encourages the creation of free-trade zones, and creates a position in the office of the United States trade representative to focus on African issues.
It would encourage the Overseas Private Investment Corporation to set up two investment funds -- one $150 million and another for $500 million -- to stimulate private-sector and public works development.
Only countries demonstrating progress in adhering to human rights, a commitment to a free-market economy and a reduction of tariffs would be eligible. House aides said of the region's 48 countries, 6 to 8 might qualify now, including South Africa, Uganda, Ghana, Ethiopia, Botswana and the Ivory Coast.
The legislation would not affect the $700 million a year in American foreign assistance to Africa, an amount that has been dwindling steadily as Africa's strategic role in the post-cold-war world diminishes.
Africa received sporadic attention from the United States during Mr. Clinton's first term. But Hillary Rodham Clinton visited there in 1997, and the White House has been working with Congress since then on legislation to remove tariffs, particularly on textiles and apparel, for African countries that reduce trade barriers and promote private investment.
Mr. Clinton's 11-day visit includes stops in Ghana, Uganda, Rwanda, South Africa, Botswana and Senegal.
"When the President of the United States visits these countries, it not only sends a message of friendship, but also says to investors, the U.S. has an interest," Representative Charles B. Rangel, a New York Democrat and a main sponsor of the bill, said in an interview.
The vote in the House last Wednesday was 233 to 186, with 92 Democrats joining 141 Republicans in favor. Eighty-four Republicans, 101 Democrats and one independent opposed the bill.
It is unclear whether the Senate will act on the bill this year. Senator Richard Lugar, an Indiana Republican who is the bill's main sponsor in the Senate, said he was encouraged by the House vote.
No vote will happen before May, Senate aides said.
The House bill drew bipartisan support from lawmakers who emphasized that many of sub-Saharan African countries were moving toward the political and economic reforms that would qualify them for the new incentives.
Representative Newt Gingrich, the Speaker of the House, gave a rare floor speech in favor of the bill, saying it would promote jobs in the United States through more exports to Africa.
But the bill ran into opposition from some lawmakers, like Representative Jesse Jackson Jr., Democrat of Illinois, who expressed fear that the legislation would lead to the exploitation of African workers. Randall Robinson, president of TransAfrica, a Washington-based group that seeks to influence United States policy in Africa and the Caribbean, raised similar concerns.
Indeed, the vote divided the Congressional Black Caucus, whose members backed the bill by a vote of 24 to 12.
But African nations strongly supported the bill, and sent representatives to lobby for the measure.
"The legislation is drafted in such a way so as to allow African countries themselves to determine what should be the proper balance between foreign corporations and indigenous African economic interests," Roble Olhaye, Djibouti's Ambassador to the United States and the dean of African diplomats here, wrote in a letter to Mr. Robinson.
