HEADLINE: Fighting Over the Ugliest Wilderness;
Developer's Megamall Plan Forces Decision on Meadowlands' Future

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

DATELINE: CARLSTADT, N.J., March 13

 BODY:
For generations, travelers have usually rushed past the Meadowlands, barely acknowledging its long, flat marshes, the acres and acres of tall, brown reeds bowing low in the wind, the murky waters and, more recently, the unnatural peaks of former garbage dumps, the squat warehouses and vapid office parks.
It is here, in these forgotten badlands, where for decades only dump trucks, mobsters and the most determined muskrat trappers dared to go, that the Mills Corporation of Arlington, Va., plans to spend $1 billion to build the state's largest mall, Meadowlands Mills. It is to be a 2.1 million square foot compound of brand-name outlet stores and flashy entertainment venues accompanied by office towers and a 1,000-room hotel. 
 By any measure, it is a bold proposal, particularly in a state some already regard as the shopping mall capital of the Northeast. And because the mall would be in Bergen County, which has a blue-law ban, it could not open on Sundays. Undeterred, Mills, one of the most ambitious builders of megamalls in the world, is determined to push ahead with what would be its biggest project ever.
The location -- at the heart of the largest retail market in the country, just nine miles from midtown Manhattan -- could not be more perfect for Mills. The company, a publicly traded real estate investment trust, has generated billions in sales by taking outlet shopping from out-of-the-way places to the shadows of major cities across the United States, including Los Angeles, Miami, Dallas and Phoenix.
But some environmentalists see the meadows as the last great unprotected wilderness area in the New York region. Building the mall would require filling 206 acres of polluted but still federally protected wetlands, a move the environmentalists utterly oppose.
The fight over Meadowlands Mills is just one aspect of a larger, decadelong battle over the destiny of the Meadowlands as a whole. The Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission, the state agency with zoning authority in the area, has proposed a "special area management plan" that, in essence, concedes that some development in the Meadowlands is inevitable. But the plan would limit the number of acres of wetlands that could be filled and developed and would require developers to pay for more than $800 million in environmental repairs.
For its part, the Mills Corporation says it would restore 380 acres of wetlands, more than any other developer under the commission's plan. "I think it's a wonderful opportunity," said Edward B. Vinson, the company's vice president for development: "To develop one-third and mitigate the balance and return the property to a true wetlands, functioning fresh water and brackish water wetlands, which has not existed on this site in 80 years."
Local environmental groups, however, say sacrificing some wetlands to save others is unprecedented and violates Federal environmental policy, which since the Bush Administration has mandated no net loss of wetlands. Until now, builders who obtain permits to fill wetlands have generally been required to create an equivalent amount of wetlands elsewhere.
"One of our biggest fears here is that this would set a national precedent that would essentially put public trust wetlands up for sale to finance other schemes," said Andrew J. Willner, director of New York-New Jersey Baykeeper, an environmental group, and one of the most vocal opponents of development in the Meadowlands. "We don't think the case law nor the moral code allows for that."
 
A Place Some Say Is Not Worth Saving
The standoff in the Meadowlands is unlike traditional feuds between developers and environmentalists. It is a dispute not over a tract of pristine natural territory but rather over a swath of some of the most highly polluted land in the country, a nasty mix of closed landfills, toxic waste sites and waterways fouled by garbage.
Developers argue that parts of the Meadowlands are so degraded they are not worth saving, and they point to the overwhelming presence of phragmites, the common brown reeds that grow where little else will and that choke out other life. But environmentalists note that the water quality in the Meadowlands has improved markedly since the garbage dumps were closed. Since 1970, when the Meadowlands hit its low point, the number of bird species has risen to more than 260 from fewer than 200, they say.
The wrangling continues as President Clinton has made wetlands preservation his top environmental priority. Last month, Mr. Clinton announced a five-year, $2.3 billion plan to combat water pollution, with a goal of restoring 100,000 acres of wetlands a year by 2005.
In recent weeks, national environmental groups have joined local organizations in sending letters to the White House urging protection of the Meadowlands. The Mills Corporation has already enlisted several heavyweight lobbyists in Trenton and in Washington, including Ann Richards, the former Governor of Texas, who was known to be pro-environment in a state where such causes often have little support.
Since last summer, the President's Council on Environmental Quality has been involved in trying to broker an agreement on the future of the Meadowlands. Officials said this week that they hoped to reach a deal within a month.
"This 10-year impasse over the environmental and economic issues not only diminishes confidence in the regulatory system but also threatens the wetlands themselves," said Bradley M. Campbell, associate director of the White House council, "because we lack any comprehensive constraints on wetlands fill in the district."
Wetlands are considered ecologically valuable because they shelter wildlife, act as a water filtration system and provide flood protection. Even the damaged Meadowlands plays these roles to varying degrees.
Under the Meadowlands Commission's plan, about 8,500 acres of remaining wetlands would be restored. The plan also includes complex provisions to compensate private landowners who would not be allowed to develop.
The commission says it fears that a ban on all construction, which the environmentalists would prefer, would result in lawsuits by private landowners. Under the Fifth Amendment to the Constitution, private land cannot be taken for public use without just compensation.
Commission officials said they saw little alternative but to allow some development.
"These are probably the most assaulted wetlands in an urban area anywhere in the world," said Anthony Scardino Jr., executive director of the commission. "How do you go about the process of cleaning it up? Where do you get the resources, the financial resources?"
Final approval of the plan requires the cooperation of many government agencies, including the commission, the State Department of Environmental Protection, the Army Corps of Engineers, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
Officials have been trying to decide how few acres could be filled and still allow enough development for the plan to remain economically viable. The commission's plan would also streamline the state and Federal reviews of developers' proposals.
"We have gone back to the drawing board to see if we could come up with a development program and an environmental improvement program and other benefits that would be acceptable to the stakeholders and ultimately achievable," said Joseph J. Seebode, chief of the regulatory branch of Army Corps of Engineers in the New York District. "We're not there yet."
 
Mastodons, Oysters, Farmers, Mobsters
To understand the problem requires a brief review of several millennia. The Meadowlands started as a vast glacial lake stretching roughly from Perth Amboy north across what is now the border of New Jersey and Rockland County, N. Y. The area was inhabited by mastodons. The lake began receding in 8000 B.C. and the metamorphosis of the Meadowlands was under way.
Its fate has always shifted with its inhabitants. Thousands of years ago, refuse left by people in the Meadowlands amounted to piles of oyster shells. Native tribes fished and hunted here. In the 1700's, Dutch and British colonists farmed salt hay and chopped cedar trees. More recently, industrialists built factories and heaped trash. Murderous mobsters dumped corpses.
By 1970 it had become one of the largest, most toxic dumping grounds in the world. Starting in 1974, the state built a huge sports complex with a football stadium, a horse racing track and an indoor basketball and hockey arena. From 1977 to 1997, the Corps of Engineers granted 34 permits for filling and developing wetlands in the region. The entire Meadowlands district, including the 750-acre sports complex, encompasses 32 square miles, making it larger than Manhattan.
The Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission was created by state legislators in 1969 when the dumping situation seemed to be at its all-time worst. The goal was to create a single state agency and centralize authority over zoning and other planning matters for the whole Meadowlands, which stretches across parts of 14 municipalities in Bergen and Hudson counties.
Legislators gave the commission three contradictory missions: to protect nature, to provide for orderly development and to provide space for the disposal of solid waste.
For the last decade the commission's main objective has been pushing its plan to chart the course of the Meadowlands for the next century. And there is a real chance that the debate will be resolved soon, officials say.
One obstacle to the Meadowlands Mills project has been surmounted. Carlstadt, the site of the proposed mall, now supports the plans after winning several concessions from Mills, including elimination of plans for housing.
"My feeling is this company owns that property and they are going to develop it and we got the best deal we could out of it," said Buddy Davis, a Councilman. Carlstadt stands to gain millions of dollars in tax revenues from Meadowlands Mills, which will also generate 2,500 construction jobs and about 9,000 permanent jobs once completed. A decision from the Army Corps of Engineers on the Mills project is expected by the end of the year.
Mills already operates some of the most popular malls in the country, including Potomac Mills in Prince William County, Va., which attracts more visitors annually than Colonial Williamsburg, and Ontario Mills, about 40 miles east of Los Angeles, which is rivaling Disneyland.
For designers and department stores, outlets offer the chance to appeal to more shoppers and to sell past seasons' styles. Retail financial analysts say outlets and their parent stores are complementary, not competitive, even when they are just a few miles apart.
Market researchers say that Meadowlands Mills would serve an existing market about twice as large as that for the other Mills projects. "At the Meadowlands, the density is at your front doorstep," said Mr. Vinson, the company's vice president for development. He added, "This is not a development program for the faint of heart."

HEADLINE: Giuliani and Council Want to Cut a Tax, but Not the Same One

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
With New York City government awash in cash for the second year in a row, the talk in City Hall revolves around cutting taxes. The question is which one to cut.
Peter F. Vallone, the Speaker of the City Council, says that a cut in the city's personal income tax will put more money in people's pockets. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani prefers to eliminate the sales tax on clothing. 
 Those differences are coming into focus as the City Council prepares to respond later this month to Mr. Giuliani's preliminary budget, setting off negotiations that should lead to a final budget in June. Despite the disagreement, the consensus in City Hall that money should be returned to taxpayers reflects how much things have changed in a city that in a more liberal era would have used budget surpluses to finance popular programs.
The Mayor has been a tireless cheerleader for the tax cut on clothing, crisscrossing the city during tax-free weeks to shop in store after store. The Speaker, who declared his candidacy for governor last week and is sharpening the themes of his campaign, is hoping to link himself with tax cuts.
Mr. Vallone's aides said the Council's response to the Mayor's budget would call for changing the city's income-tax structure, in keeping with the Speaker's message that, under Gov. George E. Pataki, working-class and middle-class New Yorkers have not shared fully in the national economic recovery. They said the Council would also recommend that a 12.5 percent surcharge on the city's personal income tax, approved in 1990 to help the city balance its books and reauthorized in 1991 to help hire thousands of new police officers, should be allowed to expire at the end of the year.
"It's time now to give a break back," Mr. Vallone said last week. "And while we're doing it, I don't think that this personal income tax is as progressive as it should be. It hits the middle class a little bit too hard."
Mr. Vallone's aides said they were willing to compromise on the size of the personal income tax cut, so long as the Speaker could claim to have cut taxes significantly. If the surcharge were eliminated, the city would lose about $190 million in revenue next year and $530 million the year after that.
To a family of four with a $60,000 annual income, the elimination of the surcharge would yield a savings of $184 a year, Thomas L. McMahon, the City Council's finance director, said. The Speaker's proposal to overhaul personal income tax rates would increase that savings to $325 a year. The change in tax rates, which would lead to savings for middle-income families but to higher taxes for wealthier ones, would not cost the city revenue, Mr. McMahon said.
In January 1996, Mr. Giuliani himself suggested letting the surcharge expire, but quickly abandoned that idea. Now, his aides say that its elimination would cause a revenue loss that would worsen future budget gaps. Randy M. Mastro, the Deputy Mayor for operations, said the Mayor favored targeted tax cuts, like the 8.25 percent one on clothes, consisting of 4 percent in state tax, 4 percent in city tax and a 0.25 percent tax assessed by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Albany has approved the elimination of the 4 percent state tax on clothes under $100, to take effect on Dec. 1, 1999. The change would allow local governments to eliminate their own sales taxes -- usually 4 percent.
But the Giuliani administration is pressing to remove city taxes on all clothes, beginning this December. If the Mayor gets his wish in Albany, the city will lose $176 million in revenue next year and $312 million the following year. The average saving per household would be $103, according to the Mayor's projection. "The Mayor has implemented tax cuts that directly stimulate the local economy," Mr. Mastro said. "A personal income tax cut has a less direct effect."
Charles Millard, the Mayor's senior economic adviser, said that the elimination of the tax on clothing that costs under $500 would eventually create 20,000 jobs and bring the city hundreds of millions of dollars in new tax revenue. The Independent Budget Office, a city-financed watchdog agency, said that a tax cut on clothes would increase sales, though it would not create such a high number of jobs.
Charles Brescher, the research director for the Citizens Budget Commission, an independent fiscal monitor, said his organization preferred to eliminate the surcharge instead of the sales tax. The city's personal income tax is much higher than those of other municipalities, whereas the sales tax difference is not so great, Mr. Brescher said.
Both Mr. Vallone and Mr. Giuliani agree that the city cannot afford to cut both taxes. They also agree that most of this year's projected budget surplus -- an estimated $1.6 billion -- should be set aside to close future budget gaps. But the politics of taxation are influencing the rhythm of budget negotiations this year, just one sign of how the workings of city government are becoming linked to the gubernatorial race.
By calling for deep tax cuts, Mr. Vallone is also seeking to inoculate himself against inevitable charges in a race that he is a tax-and-spend Democrat, his aides said. It was Mr. Vallone who endorsed Mayor David N. Dinkins's surcharge proposal in 1990. What is more, they hope to draw a sharp contrast between Mr. Vallone and the Republican incumbent, Mr. Pataki, whose recently proposed state budget would increase spending by 7.6 percent.
Mr. Vallone said he is not opposed to cutting the sales tax on clothes. Indeed, his aides said that cutting the tax would be politically more popular than letting the surcharge expire. But they said that the Mayor had become so identified with the policy that it would be hard for the Speaker to share any credit in its elimination.
The Council has seized on the surcharge, partly because it is in the unusual position of having leverage over the Mayor in this particular case. Albany has final say over taxes. But in practice, the surcharge will likely die at the end of the year unless Mr. Vallone agrees with the Mayor to renew it.
What is more, the Speaker's aides said their position was strengthened by the fact that last year the State Legislature rejected a proposal to cut the tax on clothing under $500. This year, they said, elections made it even less likely that lawmakers from outside the city would endorse a measure that would draw shoppers from the suburbs to New York City.
But given the popularity of tax cuts in New York, both sides of City Hall are reluctant to criticize the other side's proposal. "There may be differences of views about how to cut taxes, but there's unanimity that we should," Mr. Mastro said.

HEADLINE: States Appear Ready to Raise Their Spending on Education

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
Lawmakers in many states are negotiating budgets that include substantial increases in education spending in response to a strong economy, widespread concern about the quality of public schools and, in some cases, court decisions requiring new systems of school financing.
With these increases, states will likely shoulder a larger share of overall education financing, while local districts will bear a smaller share. 
 "In state of the state addresses, we heard a strong interest in education," said Kathy Christie of the Education Commission of the States, a nonprofit group that tracks education issues. "There was a lot of talk about making technology available in schools, reducing class sizes and doing more early childhood education. And thanks to the economy, more states have surpluses this year."
While it is too soon to know exactly where the numbers will come out, David Liebschutz, associate director of the Center for the Study of the States in Albany, estimated that state education spending would increase 5 percent to 7 percent in the next fiscal year.
He and others said, however, that what is happening is less an increase in overall education spending, than the states taking over a greater share of school budgets from the local districts.
"You have the states, with these big surpluses this year, riding in on their white horses to rescue the local districts, and offer property tax relief, and taking on a bigger share of the education budget," Mr. Liebschutz said. "That may make taxpayers happy, but it has some real long-term risks for the schools."
The most serious danger is that in a bad economy, state revenues drop far more precipitously than property taxes, the most common source of local financing. So schools dependent mostly on state money would face large budget cuts. And there are many competitors for the state dollars, so if the political winds shift, and the current enthusiasm for education gives way to concern about crime or health, school spending could suffer.
But there are potential benefits, too. Increased state involvement in education can pave the way for greater equity: Generally, the larger the share of school budgets the state controls, the less disparity there is between rich districts and poor ones.
"Over all, I think it's a good thing for states to carry more of the burden, both for equity reasons and because it's appropriate for the states to be out in front as we move to more emphasis on standards and assessment," said Terry Whitney, a senior policy specialist with the National Conference of State Legislatures.
Until the mid-1970's, the lion's share of school money came from local property taxes. But that shifted as many states began to face legal challenges to their systems of financing education. Critics said the states discriminated against students from poor districts that could not raise as much revenue as rich districts, even if they imposed high tax rates.
In 1994-95, states provided 47 percent of all education spending; local districts, 46 percent, and the Federal Government, 7 percent. And next year, the state share will likely increase further.
Part of the proposed increase in state education spending, the largest single component of state budgets, is due to higher enrollment, since the number of students in public schools has grown steadily since the mid-1980's, and, at nearly 47 million, tops even the old baby boom records.
But per-pupil spending -- $6,564 last year, according to the U.S. Department of Education -- is rising as well. In recent years, overall per-pupil spending, on average, has risen 4 percent to 5 percent a year -- twice the rate of inflation.
Based on the proposed state budgets and enrollment projections, Mr. Liebschutz estimated that per-pupil spending in several of the largest states would grow substantially next year. In Illinois, where Gov. Jim Edgar has proposed raising education spending more than $600 million for fiscal 1999, per-pupil spending would increase 12 percent next year. The proposed increase in per-pupil spending would be 9 percent in New Jersey, 7 percent in Florida, 5 percent in Ohio and 4 percent in New York, Michigan and Pennsylvania.
"Education has definitely taken a priority in this year's state of the state messages and budget addresses," said Steven Murphy, director of the public finance department at Standard & Poor's. "It's easier than in the past to put money into schools, because there's more money in the coffers. When a state has a big surplus, there's pressure to do one of two things: cut taxes, or spend it on something most of the population benefits from. Since taxes haven't increased much in the last few years, there's not much pressure for cuts. And a whole lot of people care about education."
In New Jersey, which has been mired in school finance litigation for two decades, Governor Whitman swept into office four years ago pledging to cut taxes and did so -- and now she proposes a $540 million increase to local school districts.
"A lot of this is the economy, but a lot is demographics," Mr. Liebschutz said. "You have all the baby boomers with kids in school, and quite frankly, education is in vogue. The Presidential jawboning on education has proved to have some staying power, and it doesn't take a genius politician to know that if you've got elections coming up and a huge population worrying about their kids' schools, you spend money on schools. In states like Georgia, where the hiring of teachers has been a real bugaboo, raising teacher salaries has become a politically salable issue."
In Georgia, Gov. Zell Miller's proposed budget for fiscal 1999 includes nearly $200 million for education pay increases. In most states the proposed budget increases would go toward meat-and-potato education concerns like reducing class sizes and expanding kindergarten and pre-kindergarten programs.
But there are capital needs, too. In states with older schools, there is a push to rehabilitate crumbling buildings. In states where the population is growing fast, the struggle is to build enough schools to accommodate the baby boomlet -- and hire enough teachers to educate those children.
Almost everywhere, the rewiring of schools and purchasing of computers is a political and financial issue.
"In Iowa, they put together a fiber optics network and so the next question is upgrading all the electrical outlets and training the teachers," said Chris Pipho, of the Education Commission of the States. "But technology is a onetime expenditure. If you use your surplus on it, you're done. Reducing class size is harder, because it's expensive and once you start, you've got to keep going."
In several states, the pressure for increased education spending comes directly from the courts. The mechHanisms for school funding in more than a dozen states have been found unconstitutional because of disparities between rich and poor districts, and in several states, legislatures are scrambling to comply with court mandates to revamp their systems.
"New Hampshire, Colorado and Ohio and some others still have school finance litigation forcing them to do something," Mr. Pipho said. "One factor in where the numbers end up is what kind of legal settlements there are, and it's not clear where they'll come out. I've been watching the education budget process for a long time, and I think most of the budget proposals are going to come down before we get to the real numbers. But if there was ever a year to be optimistic, this is it, because the proposed numbers are coming in so high and so many states have surpluses."

HEADLINE: SOUTH'S EMBRACE OF G.O.P. IS NEAR A TURNING POINT

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, March 15

 BODY:
One by one, they have fallen. During the last three decades, each of the once solidly Democratic states of the old Confederacy have elected Republican governors; each, that is, except Georgia.
Now the Republicans have a chance -- a better than even chance, polls and political analysts say -- to complete the transformation. If they win this year's gubernatorial race in Georgia, Republicans can declare with some authority that their party, once held in contempt in the white South because of its associations with emancipation and Reconstruction, has become the dominant political force in the region. 
 "If the Republicans elect a governor in Georgia, I think the South is moving irrevocably and irreversibly toward being a one-party region," said Ralph Reed, the former executive director of the Christian Coalition and now a Republican political consultant based in the Atlanta suburbs.
The symbolically significant Georgia race, which Mr. Reed calls "the big enchilada," along with important gubernatorial campaigns in Florida, Alabama and Texas, make the South one of the critical battlegrounds of the 1998 election year.
Because governors and their political networks can give an enormous lift to their parties' Presidential nominees, the campaigns in those states are drawing intense interest from Vice President Al Gore and a host of prospective Republican candidates. And with several Southern states expected to gain Congressional seats in the reapportionment that will follow the 2000 Census, both parties are also deeply aware that the governors elected this year will hold veto power over redistricting plans.
"I'm looking for the tide to turn," said Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee. "We've had some down times but I think now the economy is going our way and the package of issues are our issues, like education and child care. The Republican issues -- balancing the budget, smaller government, welfare, crime -- have been taken off the table."
If that is so, Republicans respond, it is only because Democrats have embraced conservative initiatives in an effort to slow the Republican advance. The Republican Party's breathtaking gains in the South, rooted largely in the rejection of Democratic positions on economics and race, played a major role in the party's takeover of Congress in 1994 and in the Democrats' efforts under President Clinton to reposition themselves toward the center.
The party's Southern strength today, particularly in statewide and Congressional elections, is virtually a mirror image of Democratic dominance as recently as 1980. Even in state legislatures, where Democratic power once seemed unassailable, Republicans have taken control of houses in several states.
Republicans today hold eight governorships in the 11 states of the old Confederacy, the same number that Democrats held in 1980. Republicans now have 15 of 22 United States Senate seats; Democrats held 16 in 1980. The Republican advantage in the House of Representatives, now 71 to 54, reverses a Democratic majority of 77 to 31 in 1980.
In 1980, Republicans held 17 percent of the state legislative seats in the South; now they hold 41 percent. While they did not control a single legislative chamber in 1990, they now control both houses of the Florida Legislature, the House of Representatives in North Carolina and South Carolina and the Senate in Texas and Virginia. They are within striking distance of taking several other houses.
The party's legislative gains are starting to have a tangible impact, particularly on social issues. Republican lawmakers in South Carolina last year beat back a call by their own Governor, David M. Beasley, a Republican, for removing the Confederate battle flag from atop the State Capitol. The Florida Senate last week voted to override a veto of a ban on late-term abortions by Gov. Lawton Chiles, a Democrat, completing the first successful override of a governor's veto in that state in 12 years.
The unified Republican support for bans on late-term abortions has helped smooth over differences within the party, both in the South and elsewhere, on divisive social issues like abortion, school prayer and gay rights, said Jim Nicholson, the chairman of the Republican National Committee.
"One of the things that's helped in the area of social conservatism is that people have really come together around this partial-birth abortion ban," Mr. Nicholson said. "It's given everybody a common place to go."
In the seven gubernatorial races in the South this year, no Democratic incumbent is running for re-election. Four of the five Republican incumbents are considered favorites to win re-election, and Republicans are favored in early polls to win the open seats now held by Democrats in Georgia and Florida.
There are seven races for United States Senate in the South this year. At the moment, Republican incumbents are favored in North Carolina, Georgia and Alabama; Democratic incumbents are favored in Louisiana, Florida and South Carolina, and the campaign in Arkansas to fill the seat of Senator Dale Bumpers, a Democrat who is retiring, is considered a tossup.
The only Republican Governor considered vulnerable is Fob James Jr. of Alabama, who has alienated his state's business community with his active support for school prayer and other conservative stands on social issues. While Mr. James is expected to receive a vigorous challenge from Lieut. Gov. Don Siegelman, a Democrat with solid financial backing, few political experts in Alabama bet against the incumbent right now.
If Republicans sweep this year's gubernatorial races, Gov. Jim Hunt of North Carolina, who won re-election easily last year, would become the lone Democratic head of state in the South.
In Tennessee, Mr. Gore's home state, the Democrats have yet to find a credible candidate to challenge the popular Republican incumbent, Gov. Don Sundquist. In Mississippi, the party has not fielded a candidate to run against a freshman Republican Congressman, Chip Pickering.
After primaries in Texas last Tuesday, a poll conducted by Scripps Howard and the University of Texas showed Gov. George W. Bush, a Republican, with a 46 percentage-point lead over the Democratic nominee, Garry Mauro, the state land commissioner. Mr. Bush has a Texas-size campaign bankroll of $13 million and has been endorsed by the Democratic lieutenant governor, Bob Bullock, the godfather of Mr. Mauro's daughter.
The state Republican chairwoman, Susan Weddington, predicted boastfully last week that there was a "strong possibility" that Republicans would sweep all 14 statewide elections in November.
Such unbridled optimism may later haunt Ms. Weddington, said several political scientists in Texas. But it is also clear, they said, that the only challenge this year for Mr. Bush is not to win, but to win by the kind of margin needed to maintain his position at the head of the pack of potential Republican Presidential candidates.
"The main worry he has at this point is not living up to expectations, a landslide figure," said Bruce Buchanan, a professor of government at the University of Texas at Austin.
In Georgia, the only state in the nation not to have elected a Republican governor this century, both parties have endured their share of turmoil long before the July 21 primaries.
The chances of the onetime Republican front-runner, Michael J. Bowers, a former Attorney General, were seriously wounded last year by his disclosure that he had had a 10-year affair with a woman who once worked for him. That revelation enticed Guy Millner, a wealthy businessman who narrowly lost previous campaigns for governor and United States senator, to enter the race.
On the Democratic side, the presumptive front-runner, Lieut. Gov. Pierre Howard, dropped out of the race last year, citing family concerns. Secretary of State Lewis Massey and State Representative Roy Barnes are now the leading contenders.
A Georgia State University poll published last week showed Mr. Millner defeating either Mr. Massey or Mr. Barnes by about 20 percentage points. But the Democrats dismissed those numbers as the product of Mr. Millner's name recognition from previous campaigns and of more than two months of unchallenged radio advertising.
Mr. Millner has used the advertising to endorse anti-crime and education programs initiated by Georgia's popular Democratic Governor, Zell Miller, who defeated Mr. Millner in 1990.
"I'm glad I'm not running against Zell Miller," Mr. Millner said. "He's been a successful and popular Governor. I want to build on his successes."
Mr. Massey, who was appointed by Mr. Miller, and Mr. Barnes, who lost a primary to him in 1990, also hope to trade on the Governor's formula for Democratic success in a Republican world.
"I think the reason the Democrats have been able to maintain a strong base in Georgia is because the Democratic Party has been the party of cutting taxes and being tough on crime and moving families off the welfare roles and improving education," said Mr. Massey, who is 35.
Mr. Barnes said: "The reason Democrats win in Georgia is that we've done a good job. We're the fastest growing state east of the Rockies and we've produced programs that click with the voters."
In neighboring Florida, the presumptive Republican nominee, Jeb Bush, was ahead of his most likely Democratic rival, Lieut. Gov. Buddy MacKay, by eight percentage points, according to a poll conducted last month by The New York Times Regional Newspapers Group. The Democrats have endured two months of divisive infighting after the party's caucus in the state House of Representatives removed a black member, Willie F. Logan, as its chairman.
Some black leaders are openly encouraging their followers to abandon the Democratic Party in retribution. Political scientists question whether Mr. MacKay or any Democrat can win a statewide election in Florida without unified and enthusiastic black support, particularly against a well-financed and experienced politician like Mr. Bush, Governor Bush's younger brother.
Those kinds of rifts provide a perfect opening for Republican strategists who have searched for ways to diversify their party in the South.
"Historically, the way the Republican Party has made its stand in the South has been through the subtext of being a white conservative party opposing a shrinking Democratic Party dominated by minorities, labor unions and the left," Mr. Reed said. "I think by the time this story is done being written you're going to see a new Republican Party that is still primarily white and that is fiscally and morally conservative, but that also is attempting to project an image of racial tolerance and moderation."

HEADLINE: Gay Cleric Among nominees to Replace Newark Bishop

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
An openly gay cleric has been chosen as one of five nominees to succeed the Rt. Rev. John S. Spong as Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark, diocesan officials said yesterday. If elected eventually, he would be the first openly homosexual bishop of the 2.5 million-member Episcopal Church in America.
The gay nominee, the Rev. Gene Robinson, 50, has been a top official of the Diocese of New Hampshire for more than a decade, is a founder of and counselor for AIDS organizations and support groups for gay and lesbian youths, and has led racism-education projects and raised funds for low-income housing. 
 Mr. Robinson, who is Canon to the Ordinary of New Hampshire and executive secretary of the Province of New England, was on vacation and unavailable yesterday for comment on his selection by a committee that considered 70 candidates to succeed Bishop Spong, who is scheduled to retire in less than two years.
But in a telephone interview from Concord, Bishop Douglas Theuner of New Hampshire said of his executive assistant: "He has worked for me for nearly 12 years. His colleagues in New Hampshire have great confidence in him. He is a very worthy candidate, and I am delighted with his nomination."
In a statement to the diocesan nominating committee, Mr. Robinson noted that he was the divorced father of two daughters and lived in Weare, N.H., with a partner, Mark Andrew, a program manager for the New Hampshire Department of Health and Human Services.
Asked what risks he had taken for his faith, Mr. Robinson wrote: "I answered God's call to acknowledge myself as a gay man. My wife and I, in order to keep our wedding vow to 'honor each other in the name of God,' made the decision to let each other go. Risking the loss of my children and the exercise of my ordained ministry in the church was the biggest risk I've ever taken, but it left me with two unshakable things: my integrity and my God."
In a church long regarded as the most upper crust of America's denominations -- producing more Presidents, from George Washington to George Bush, than any other -- questions about homosexuality and the ordination of gay priests have been deeply divisive. Bishop Spong has led movements to bring blacks, women and homosexuals into the full life of his church, and the choice of successor is widely regarded as critical to the future of the diocese and the church.
Dale Gruner, a spokeswoman for the diocese, said yesterday that besides Mr. Robinson, the nominees were the Rev. Rosemari Sullivan, 51, Rector of St. Clement's Church in Alexandria, Va.; the Rev. Jack Croneberger, 59, rector of the Church of Atonement in Tenafly, N.J.; the Rev. Gray Temple Jr., 56, rector of St. Patrick's Church in Atlanta, and the Rev. Will Wauters, 48, chaplain of the private Lawrenceville School in New Jersey. The selections were posted on a diocesan Web site on Friday.
Ms. Sullivan, if elected, would be the sixth female bishop named to head a diocese. Mr. Croneberger has long been active in the church struggle over gay rights; he was a leader of the defense of a now-retired Bishop, Walter Righter, who ordained an openly gay man in 1990. Mr. Temple has led church dialogues on same-sex marriages and the ordination of homosexuals. Mr. Wauters, who has served ministries in New Jersey, California and Texas, was active in efforts to unionize farm workers and end gang violence, and served on a governor's council in Texas on work force and economic development.
The process of selecting a successor to Bishop Spong is to be lengthy and complex, Ms. Gruner noted. She said additional nominations could be made by a petition process before April 15. In June, a 600-member convention of clerics and lay leaders will be held to elect a successor, but the person selected must be approved by majorities of the standing committees and bishops of the 110 Episcopal dioceses across the nation.
The person selected would be consecrated Bishop Coadjutor on Nov. 21. The title confers the rank of top assistant to the Bishop with an automatic right of succession. Bishop Spong, long regarded as a maverick in his church, ignited a controversy in 1991 when he wrote a book and said that St. Paul, the apostle, was a "self-loathing and repressed gay male." He was elected Coadjutor in 1976 and became the Diocesan Bishop in 1979. He has said he will retire on Jan. 31, 2000.

HEADLINE: United Nations Bill Is Bargain for U.S.;
A Plan on Kosovo

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Peter Maass ("It's Risky to Talk Tough on Kosovo," Op-Ed, March 10) claims that "it is far easier to be the world's conscience than to be the world's policeman." He argues that there are only two possible responses to the Serbian campaign against ethic Albanians in Kosovo, a Serb province. The United States can either take direct action through military and economic measures or it can engage in more talk. 
 Why not let the world's conscience do the job for the impotent policeman? The United States can weaken President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia in one blow. It can delegitimize him by delivering intelligence of violations committed at his command in Bosnia to the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague.
If the international community really wants to promote respect for human rights in the former Yugoslavia, it should stop protecting Mr. Milosevic. Punishing war criminals may deter new acts of war in the Balkans.
 
BRAD K. BLITZ
Seaside, Calif., March 10, 1998
 
The writer is a lecturer in global studies at California State University, Monterey Bay.

HEADLINE: China's New Premier: Fast Riser Who Tamed Economy in Chaos

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM with SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 15

 BODY:
Zhu Rongji, who is expected to be chosen as Prime Minister of China on Tuesday, is a career Communist planner whose meteoric rise to power has been driven largely by the sheer force of his achievements.
In the last five years, as chief of economic policy, Mr. Zhu, 69, has steered the economy out of runaway inflation without stifling its growth, a record that would do the International Monetary Fund proud. 
 Well before the Asian financial crisis hit last year, Mr. Zhu (whose name is pronounced Joo Rong-JI) had applied bitter medicine to China, including denying loans to officials' pet projects.
By this year the annual rate of inflation had dropped to just 1 percent, from 24 percent in 1993. Mr. Zhu won the respect of other Chinese leaders and superlatives from Western business executives.
He will become head of China's Cabinet at a time when the world's most populous country is emerging as an economic and political heavyweight. He will serve under the President and Communist Party chief, Jiang Zemin, who remains No. 1 in the ruling circle.
By any measure, Mr. Zhu will face daunting tasks: remaking an economy still rooted in thousands of money-losing companies owned by the Government, salvaging banks that by outside standards are insolvent, reversing the calamitous pollution of air and water, finding work for tens of millions who once thought they had jobs for life and building a new system of social welfare from scratch -- just for starters.
As he takes on new economic and social issues, Mr. Zhu will also, for the first time, have direct responsibility for foreign policy questions like volatile relations with Taiwan and for China's stand on human rights issues, which has been much criticized in the West.
Perhaps the ultimate issue that will face Mr. Zhu in his five-year term is how the Communist Party can maintain control over a society that is becoming more complex and pluralistic by the day. Trained as an engineer and state planner, Mr. Zhu has so far betrayed no strong interest in democracy, only in a more efficient economy and party.
"I see him as a classic Leninist apparatchik," said David Shambaugh, an expert on Chinese politics at George Washington University. "But it is true that he is also a no-nonsense, tough bureaucrat who is very decisive."
The two sides of Mr. Zhu were shown during a speech he gave in 1995 to the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. Impressing the gathered business and financial leaders by speaking in English, he told them to "call me" if they had any problems in China. But when asked for a phone number, he became flustered and said, "That is a state secret," recalled a person who attended the meeting.
In a system that rewards conformity, where leaders typically retreat behind dogmatic cant, Mr. Zhu is famous for his frank talk, his sometimes brutal impatience with officials and his results-oriented manner.
That approach has gained him the admiration of ordinary Chinese people, as well as the begrudging regard of the sprawling bureaucracy he will head. Those who work under him refer to him as "the Boss."
 
Reforms Gain Him Foes in the Bureaucracy
But with his determined pursuit of economic cutbacks, and now his goal of slashing the bureaucracy, he has gained many enemies around the country, too, perhaps leaving him vulnerable should his magic touch with the economy fail him.
Mr. Zhu is replacing Li Peng, who is moving to another senior position after serving the two five-year terms as Prime Minister allowed by China's Constitution. Chinese people often compare Mr. Zhu favorably with Mr. Li, who is widely disliked for his central role in the violent suppression of the 1989 student-led democracy movement.
Mr. Zhu has angrily rejected the label, sometimes applied to him by Western admirers, of "China's Gorbachev." The man who presided over the dismantling of the Soviet Union is officially loathed here. Mr. Zhu's own views on broadening participation in political decision-making have remained private, but he has not been known to question the primacy of the Communist Party.
"The touchstone for a Chinese leader is how much chaos is being created," a Western diplomat said. "If there is the threat of serious social disturbance, I don't doubt for a moment that he'll use the necessary force to stop it."
Mr. Zhu, who spent long years as a political outcast, has scaled the heights of power with astonishing speed, in large part because he was sponsored by Deng Xiaoping, another pragmatist, who also suffered under Mao.
 
Humble Birth, Technical Education
Mr. Zhu was born in humble circumstances in Changsha, Hunan Province, on Oct. 1, 1928. His father died before his birth, and his mother died while he was still a small boy, leaving him to be raised by relatives.
He studied electrical engineering at Qinghua University in Beijing, China's M.I.T. There he was chairman of the student union and in 1949, the year the People's Republic was founded, he joined the Communist Party.
There, too, he met his wife, Lao An, now said in an official biography to be on the board of directors of an engineering company. The couple has two daughters, according to the biography, but little is known publicly about the family.
Mr. Zhu worked as an industrial planner in China's northeast, then in the State Planning Commission in Beijing. But he met disaster in 1956, when he took at face value Mao's invitation to "let a hundred flowers bloom" -- that is, criticize party policy. By the next year labeled a rightist, he was ousted from the party and relegated to low-level jobs. Later, during the Cultural Revolution of 1966-76, he was forced to spend years working on farms.
Deng's climb back to power in the late 1970's allowed Mr. Zhu's rehabilitation, too, after 20 years in the political doldrums. In 1982, the Minister of Petroleum Industry, Kang Shien, gave him a senior position and brought him to the attention of Deng, who put him on the fast track.
Mr. Zhu gained national notice in 1988 when he was named Mayor of Shanghai, China's largest city and the vibrant rival of Beijing. There, too, began a complex relationship with Jiang Zemin, who as the city's Communist Party chief was his superior.
His first project in Shanghai was an anti-corruption drive, immediately winning him popularity. He instructed the city's anti-corruption body to aim its sights on 506 director-level bureaucrats. If officials at that middle level remain upright, Mr. Zhu said, they will see that the people below them do so as well.
Today, Shanghai officials who worked with Mr. Zhu recall being amazed by how relentlessly he drove those working with him, and how he took to scolding lackluster officials in a most un-Chinese manner -- in public.
As Shanghai's Mayor, Mr. Zhu went out of his way to woo foreign investors and took the unusual step of setting up a business advisory council of foreign executives. Playing host to high-powered members like Maurice Greenberg, chairman of the insurance giant AIG; John Reed, chairman of Citicorp, and John F. Smith, chairman of General Motors, once a year not only exposed them to Shanghai, it also forced recalcitrant local officials to consider outside ideas.
Another celebrated Zhu innovation was the "one-chop shop," the creation of a single office in the Shanghai government to grant swift approval for foreign investment projects. As often as the concept has been praised, though, Mr. Zhu has admitted that it never actually worked as advertised.
 
Keeping Shanghai Cool During '89 Protests
For Mr. Zhu, as for many Chinese, 1989 was a searing and telling year. As student-led demonstrations grew in Beijing and Mr. Jiang was called to the capital, Mr. Zhu took charge in Shanghai. After June 4, when the army crushed the demonstrations in and near Tiananmen Square, outraged students and workers in Shanghai threatened to mount a general strike.
Mr. Zhu went on television to address Shanghai residents directly and delivered what is still widely remembered as a brilliant address. Amazingly, he did not repeat the official line, that the killings by the army in Beijing had been a necessary response to a "counterrevolutionary rebellion."
"Historical facts cannot be covered up by anybody," Mr. Zhu said. "The truth will always come out." All sides were free to interpret his comments in their own way, and demonstrators dispersed without bloodshed.
Deng moved Mr. Zhu to Beijing as a Deputy Prime Minister in 1991. Mr. Zhu soon opened the Economic and Trade Office, which he filled with reform-minded economists and officials and used as a power base.
When Communist leaders from all over China gathered for a party congress in 1992, Mr. Zhu was just an alternate member of the Central Committee, placing him only in the top 300 members of the party hierarchy.
But at that congress, on Deng's instruction, Mr. Zhu made a rare "triple jump" -- into the 150-member Central Committee, the 20-member Politburo and even the Politburo's 7-member Standing Committee, all at once.
Suddenly, Mr. Zhu ranked fifth in the Party. Beijing's political cognoscenti saw a future Prime Minister, and some in the old guard began taking pot shots at the impudent reformer.
 
As Boss of Economy, Zhu Curbs Inflation
But the leadership, increasingly dominated by Mr. Jiang, would soon desperately need Mr. Zhu's help. By 1993, the economy was in danger of overheating, growing 14 percent on a reckless surge in money supply, rampant real estate speculation and inflation that raged at 24 percent a year, raising fears of social turmoil.
When Prime Minister Li disappeared from public view in early 1993, apparently from a heart attack, Mr. Zhu was promoted to Executive Deputy Prime Minister and given broad authority to get the economy under control.
Mr. Zhu promptly dismissed the head of the central bank and took over the job himself, personally directing an unpopular policy of tightly limiting loans and curbing Government spending. His strict enforcement of austerity measures, aided by the tongue-lashings he doled out when visiting officials in the provinces, would earn him enemies as well as admirers.
Soon, officials began spreading a Zhu-inspired line that China would aim to achieve a "soft landing" by bringing down inflation while maintaining a high and steady growth rate. The notion that was roundly ridiculed by outside economists.
But a 33 percent devaluation of the yuan, China's currency, in 1994 spurred exports without worsening inflation. By 1995 inflation declined to 10 percent, in 1996 it hit 6 percent and by 1997 inflation was close to 1 percent. Meanwhile, growth remained high, though it is projected to slide to 8 percent in 1998.
In Mr. Zhu's strategy, China is entering a difficult phase, with a vast array of state-owned companies that must be made solvent or discarded. At the same time, the old "iron rice bowl" that provided lifetime job security is being dismantled, to be replaced by a modern system of social insurance and welfare programs. It is a dangerous course politically, with the potential to breed unrest, but senior leaders seem to agree that they have no alternative.
Since Deng's death early last year, Mr. Zhu has stayed aloft politically without a senior patron, and if events go badly in years to come, he will be an easy scapegoat. Although President Jiang and Mr. Zhu have worked together for nearly 10 years, Mr. Zhu has never been considered part of the President's inner circle.
"Jiang and Zhu have always had some tension between them because of their different backgrounds and leadership styles and their shared political ambitions," said Li Cheng, a political science professor at Hamilton College. "I think this tension will become stronger as Zhu moves to the front seat now."
He will also be in a potentially awkward situation with his predecessor as Prime Minister, Mr. Li, who will apparently remain in second place in the all-powerful party hierarchy while serving in a less powerful Government job, as Speaker of the National People's Congress, the nominal Parliament. Yet Mr. Zhu, the aggressively competent achiever, has in recent years shown that he can do his own job well without totally upstaging his superiors.
And Mr. Jiang, a skilled politician and consensus builder who has surprised everyone with his ability to lead China's global emergence in recent years, may know he needs Mr. Zhu to keep the engines of China's progress running smoothly.

An article on Monday about Zhu Rongji, China's new Prime Minister, referred to his children incorrectly, based on erroneous information in an official biography. He has a son and a daughter, not two daughters, according to a new official biography.

Atal Bihari Vajpayee, the parliamentary leader of India's main Hindu nationalist party, was summoned to the presidential palace and handed a letter asking him to become Prime Minister. HEADLINE: MUSIC REVIEW;
Hunting the Heft Amid the Delicacy

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH 

 BODY:
A California orchestra playing a Mahler symphony on one day and a mixed program on another: next weekend, it is the Los Angeles Philharmonic, led by Esa-Pekka Salonen at Avery Fisher Hall; last Thursday and Friday evenings, it was the San Francisco Symphony, conducted by Michael Tilson Thomas at Carnegie Hall.
The San Francisco's Mahler, on Thursday, was the Sixth Symphony, which never used to be a particular favorite of performers but is now ubiquitous. Perhaps in these millennial days, its tragic overtones are heard in terms of apocalypse. 
 If so, we should be grateful to conductors like Mr. Thomas, who honor Mahler's second thought in deleting the third, fatal hammer blow in the finale. Valery Gergiyev inflicted that last wallop with the New York Philharmonic in January, and it was Mr. Gergiyev's dark vision with which Mr. Thomas was undoubtedly competing in many a mind here.
This was an altogether different sort of performance: contained, beautifully balanced and superbly played. But beauty is not necessarily the first thing one looks for in a Mahler Sixth. Indeed, it seemed a fine thing when the brasses began to blare and other roughnesses cropped up in the finale. The performers, it appeared, were finally coming to grips with that subtext. Where were the power and the sheer loudness that could have added so much to the earlier movements?
That question continued to rankle the next evening, when the orchestra produced all the heft anyone could want in Stravinsky's "Firebird" and Copland's Orchestral Variations. Once again, even with the added strength, the playing was generally beautiful in ensemble if not invariably in solos. What was lacking here, at times, was atmosphere, a matter made difficult by the repertory.
The Copland was given an excellent, virtuosic performance, but this 1957 inflation of the composer's Piano Variations, from 1930, seems not only pointless for the most part but also destructive of the original work's essence, its brilliant pithiness and point. And there is no compelling reason to play the "Firebird" ballet score complete for concert purposes. Taken simply as music, it is often diffuse, a fact that even a fine performance here did not obscure.
Rachmaninoff's Fourth Piano Concerto, a rather watery soup made from scraps of his earlier works in the genre, filled out the program. Jean-Yves Thibaudet, the soloist, complemented the orchestra's qualities nicely, playing with lovely tone and agility.
His refusal to resort to clangor kept him from being heard against some of the louder orchestral outbursts but paid dividends in a performance of such sheen that a listener was willing to overlook the sizable lack of compositional polish and inspiration.
These concerts made clear that wonderful things are happening in San Francisco with this combination of conductor and orchestra. It was too bad that with the repertory added into the mix here, the performances never carried a listener from the level of admiration to genuine excitement.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: What Else Lurks Out There? New Census of the Heavens Aims to Find Out

BYLINE: By JAMES GLANZ; James Glanz is a writer at Science magazine.

DATELINE: APACHE POINT, N.M.

 BODY:
PERCHED on a platform that extends like a diving board from this wind-whipped ridge 9,200 feet above sea level, between the foothills of the Sacramento Mountains and the close night sky, the new Sloan Telescope hardly looks imposing.
By astronomical standards, its 100-inch-diameter primary mirror is modest in size, and outside of its small roll-away storage garage, the squat cubelike structure of the telescope seems almost lost standing naked in the night air. 
 But next month when it is joined to a new camera that now sits, carefully tended, in a "clean room" nearby, the little Sloan will instantly become powerful enough to plunge into the largest and most comprehensive census of the visible universe that has ever been undertaken.
The project here in rugged mountain terrain 80 miles northeast of El Paso is called the Sloan Digital Sky Survey. At its heart will sit a dark array of 54 silicon chips, known as "charge-coupled devices," or C.C.D.'s, that will convert the light from huge swaths of the New Mexico night sky into digitized images that can be poured onto magnetic tapes and into computers for study. Built by Dr. James Gunn of Princeton University and his collaborators, the C.C.D. camera will be hoisted into its place behind the Sloan telescope this spring when it makes its first test observation, a moment astronomers call "first light."
Once the problems have been worked out, over the next six years or so, these C.C.D.'s should pour out a cornucopia of data: images in five different colors of 50 million galaxies, 100,000 quasars, millions of individual stars in this galaxy, and a whole menagerie of celestial oddballs. The survey will be used for everything from finding the sources of distant X-ray bursts to catching the glint of asteroids whose orbits cross that of Earth.
"We are going to compile a field guide to the heavens," said Dr. Michael Turner, an astronomer at the University of Chicago and the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory who is the spokesman for the $80 million project. It involves researchers at Princeton, the University of Chicago, Fermilab, the Johns Hopkins University, the Institute for Advanced Study, the United States Naval Observatory, the University of Washington and a collaboration called the Japan Participation Group.
"There is nothing in the world that comes close to this," said Dr. Alan Uomoto, an astronomer at Johns Hopkins, crouching in the clean room beside the array. It represents by far the largest such device ever built to do astronomy, he said. "This is at the top."
The survey will blanket a quarter of the northern sky -- where astronomers can most easily peer into deep space, away from the disk of this crowded, dusty galaxy -- and probe selected slices in the south, Dr. Turner said.
Astronomers in many fields say that like charts guiding explorers through unfamiliar continents, the digital census will be crucial in making sense of the welter of activity that is turning up in the cosmos.
"The digital survey is absolutely unique, and it will be a gold mine of data for many, many years," said Dr. Marc Davis, an astronomer at the University of California at Berkeley.
But the Sloan Survey will not stop there. The consortium of cosmologists plans to use the data from Sloan to produce a three-dimensional scale model of a large chunk of the universe.
As images rush out of the C.C.D. camera at the rate of six trillion bytes of data a year, supercomputers at Fermilab will sift the million brightest galaxies out of the "field guide," and the Sloan telescope will more closely examine the light from them using spectrographs built by Dr. Uomoto and others. This will let team members measure precise distances to those galaxies, leading to the creation of an exquisitely detailed, three-dimensional map of Earth's corner of the universe. The filigreed patterns traced out by the galaxies -- walls, voids, clumps and filaments -- will be tracked over 1.5 billion light-years of space with an accuracy that has never before been possible.
Many cosmologists believe the seeds for those colossal structures were sown by "quantum fluctuations" in the first fraction of a second after the Big Bang, when the entire observable universe was no larger than a grapefruit. The patterns of the ripples would have depended on just how the elementary constituents of matter interacted inside that superhot ball. So mapping the galaxies today should not only tell cosmologists how the large-scale structure grew out of those ripples, but also just what kinds of matter -- and how much of it -- the universe is made of.
"We're looking into outer space to see back into inner space: the first moments of the universe and the inner space of the elementary particles," Dr. Turner said.
The Sloan project had its start around 1990 in meetings between, among others, Dr. Donald York and Dr. Richard Kron of the University of Chicago and Dr. Gunn, who had been instrumental in building the original camera for the Hubble Space Telescope.
Not since the National Geographic Society-Palomar Observatory Survey of the 1950's has a comprehensive census been attempted. Although it became part of astronomy's intellectual bedrock, the Palomar Survey relied on a 48-inch telescope and photographic plates. Dr. Gunn and his colleagues realized that with the far more sensitive C.C.D. technology and a larger telescope, they could reach much deeper into the sky, with higher precision and more detail.
The result, says Dr. Timothy Heckman of Johns Hopkins, the Sloan Survey's current chief executive officer, would be a digital "universe in a box" accessible to virtually anyone who can handle copious amounts of data. The Sloan telescope at the Apache Point Observatory was designed from scratch with this survey in mind. Perched among the tips of pine trees sticking above the edge of the platform, the Sloan telescope even looks different from its fellow instruments.
It will be protected only by wind baffles once a sort of garage-on-wheels is retracted for a night's observing. The design eliminates temperature differences that can drive air currents through the slit of a traditional dome. The platform itself keeps the telescope above turbulent flows of air along the ground. Both of these effects would tend to smear images.
"There's still the romantic idea of the lone astronomer in the dome," said Dr. Heckman. "The Sloan is a very different kind of model."
In a single image, the Sloan telescope can drink in a piece of the sky the size of the Big Dipper's bucket -- an area much wider than a typical astronomical telescope can observe in a single frame.
The images will be built up as Earth's rotation scans the telescope's field of view across strips of the sky. Almost two square feet of those light-hungry C.C.D.'s comprise the camera. Different filters over rows of C.C.D.'s will produce each series of images in five different colors -- the better to distinguish humdrum reddish stars from, say, the pristine blue stars that are nearly as old as the universe itself. With more than 50 times the number of light-sensitive "pixels" as the Wide Field/Planetary Camera on the Hubble Space Telescope, the Sloan C.C.D. camera will produce 200 billion bytes of data on a clear night.
Crediting faster computers, Dr. Gunn says coping with that data stream "is not nearly so harrowing a technological thing as it would have been just a few years ago." Magnetic tapes carrying the images go to Fermilab, where analysis by supercomputers will generate an enormous catalogue of objects inside and outside this galaxy.
The objects will be sorted by their shapes, colors, locations, brightnesses, approximate distances and other qualities. Those objects could be galaxies, hyperactive beacons called quasars, aged stars, stars on the verge of exploding, or the "failed stars" called brown dwarfs -- "every sick animal in the stellar zoo," said Bruce Margon of the University of Washington, the scientific director for the survey, adding, "There is something in this for everyone."
To find precise distances to the million brightest galaxies in that catalogue, the survey team will use a spectrograph to subdivide the colors of light coming from them even more finely. Because the universe is expanding, galaxies are rushing away from Earth at speeds that are nearly proportional to their distance away. Like the whistle of a receding train, the light from a galaxy is shifted to lower and lower frequencies -- meaning redder and redder colors -- the faster its recession speed.
That allows astronomers to measure a galaxy's distance by measuring the displacement, or red shift, of features in its spectrum. The chore will be assigned to a pair of spectrographs containing mirrors, prisms and gratings and built by a group that includes Dr. Uomoto. Such observations will be made on nights that are not clear enough for the imaging survey, said Dr. Uomoto, who projects the air of a country doctor as he makes his rounds in a down jacket and a blue flannel shirt, while a small black flashlight dangles from a leather strap around his neck. ("I'm working in the telescope at night and I can't find my way back," he said, explaining the flashlight.)
Spectra of galaxies and other objects will be taken 640 at a time through holes drilled in large aluminum disks by robots that have been given coordinates from the catalogue. Light from the sources will fall on the holes when the telescope is pointed in a particular direction and the proper disk is fitted into the focal plane. The holes will be stuffed with fiber optics that feed C.C.D. cameras in the spectrographs. On a good night, the survey team hopes to expose 10 disks.
Combining the galaxies' distances with their positions on the sky, the Sloan team will construct far and away the largest and most accurate three-dimensional map ever seen of Earth's cosmic neighborhood. The tapestry of filaments, voids and walls that will emerge was first glimpsed in smaller surveys in the late 1970's and the 1980's. But like a connect-the-dots drawing with some of the numbers missing, the sketchiness of existing surveys has frustrated astronomers' attempts to read its meaning.
Astronomers would like to compare those structures to the ripples seen in the cosmic microwave background radiation, widely regarded as the afterglow of the Big Bang. Those ripples should reflect the primordial inhomogeneities from which the large-scale tapestry grew. But those ripples have been measured with high accuracy only on scales much larger than those studied by intensive galaxy surveys.
The Sloan Survey, by stretching to 1.5 billion light-years, will let cosmologists test whether they truly understand where the structure came from. If it turns out that they do, then according to their computer models, the detailed "strength," or commonness, of galaxy structures of various sizes should reveal how much matter there is in the universe.
"A complete survey of the northern sky should have tremendous cosmological power," said Dr. Jeremiah P. Ostriker, a cosmologist who is provost of Princeton University. "The Sloan Survey will vastly repay the effort put into it."
Since the galaxies are thought to be a glowing "froth" on a much larger quantity of dark, or unseen, matter, the structures should also shed light on just what most of the universe is made of -- exotic, slow-moving, theorized particles called Wimps, perhaps, or more ordinary stuff.
The approach of first light has some Sloan members marveling over the changes technology has wrought. "When I started, cosmology was very much like philosophy," said Dr. Alexander Szalay of Johns Hopkins, who received his doctorate in Budapest in 1975. "There was very little chance of measuring something precisely. It's now turning into high-precision science."
Others are simply itching to get the survey off the ground. "Do I ever," said Dr. Gunn when asked whether he felt relief that starlight would soon fall on his C.C.D. camera. "I'll feel better when it gets on the telescope and we actually start getting some images."

Map/Chart: "Cosmic Architecture"
By analyzing and mapping the present-day structure of the cosmos, cosmolo-gists hope to learn more about conditions during the Big Bang and the properties of the mysterious dark matter that apparently makes up 90 percent of the universe.
 
The map at right shows the distribution of some 6,000 galaxies in a slice of the northern sky. It was produced in 1986 by Margaret Geller, John Huchra, and Valerie de Lapparent of the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics. Earth is at the vertex of the pie. The dense conglomeration of dots at the center, forming the body of the little man is the Coma cluster of galaxies. Equally dramatic as Coma are several voids,regions up to 200 million light-years across apparently devoid of galaxies. Over the last 20 years, diagrams like this have slowly disabused astronomers of a long-standing presumption that galaxies are scatter-ed more or less evenly through space. In-stead the universe seems to have a bubble-like archi-tecture with the galaxies arranged in giant clouds, chains and sheets. Why and how galaxies should arrange themselves this way is a mystery. Cosmologists theorize that this pattern was originated in quantum fluctuations in the density of matter and radiation when the universe was very young and microscopic. (pg. F1)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Wells BDDP's post-mortem begins, looking to Darwin and snowballs by clients and employees.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
AS once-mighty Wells BDDP in New York prepares to close, it joins a growing list of problem-plagued agencies that have dissolved faster than cookies in hot tea.
As Madison Avenue ponders that lengthening roster, which includes Leonard/Monahan, Ally & Gargano and Geer, DuBois, a question arises: Has the agency industry become so Darwinian that troubled shops are no longer afforded time to solve their difficulties and as a result must inevitably crumble? 
 In the past, it seems that struggling agencies were able to spend time restoring themselves to competitive positions. Earlier in this decade, McCann-Erickson, Ogilvy & Mather and Young & Rubicam all confronted tumultuous account losses yet managed to rebound -- even bettering their previous positions. But nowadays, to turn a Cole Porter lyric inside out, are besieged agencies fated to become too cool not to heat up?
"There are agencies that have rough patches and get through them," said Kenneth S. Olshan, who was dismissed as chairman and chief executive of Wells in 1995 and is now a director of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. in New York.
"But clients are not as loyal as they were once upon a time," he said, and their departures often bring on "a point at which the critical mass isn't there to keep an agency going forward."
Soon, "there's no momentum anymore," Mr. Olshan added. "When that threshold is reached, it's out of control."
Wells, a unit of GGT Group P.L.C., is scheduled to cease operations on May 13 after being battered by a skein of lost accounts as well as management and ownership changes. Billings, which peaked at almost $1 billion in 1991, had fallen to about $500 million at the start of 1997; when the decision to close came on Friday, they had declined to less than $200 million.
Such situations have a tendency to snowball, said Lauren Rich Fine, an equity analyst who follows advertising and new media for Merrill Lynch in New York, as clients and employees "begin to think 'If that great account left, they might know something.' "
And in a strong economy, she said, when employees "know they can get jobs elsewhere," their departures can in turn accelerate the departures of important accounts, "which makes it harder to get new clients."
Indeed, the last time Wells underwent a similarly stressful period in the early 1990's, the agency industry was mired in a painful recession. Wells was able to do then what it was unable to do now: woo several big accounts to compensate for lost clients.
"I don't think it's impossible to get out of trouble," said Patrick J. McGrath, president and chief executive at Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor in New York, who is the 1997-98 vice chairman of the American Association of Advertising Agencies. "There are agencies that go through hard times and turn around.
"But when the trouble is so deep, so beyond repair, when you get to a certain point maybe there's no coming back. Wells reached that point -- and beyond."
So even for an agency like Wells, Mr. McGrath said, "which was big and important to the industry, with great campaigns and a fascinating history, that's tough to recover from."
The biggest blow to Wells came in late January, when turmoil on its largest account, the Procter & Gamble Company, prompted P.& G. to dismiss the agency and pull all its billings, estimated at $125 million.
P.& G. accounted for "half our revenue and a much bigger chunk of profits," said J. Steve Davis, who joined Wells as chairman and chief executive after the dismissal.
Losing P.& G. caused GGT's stock to plunge, which "put the company in play," he added, and attracted the interest of WPP Group. GGT ultimately agreed to be acquired by Omnicom Group in New York, which is hiring some Wells employees as it absorbs some Wells accounts.
"This was really a roller coaster ride," Mr. Davis said, still clearly taken aback that the ride is over.
"It hasn't really hit me yet," he said.

HEADLINE: Let Doctors Sleep

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "12 New York Hospitals Receive Surprise Visits From State Inspectors" (news article, March 12): Attention to residents' training in New York State hospitals over their legally mandated working hours has received much press coverage. What is less well known is that the mentors of these residents -- the attending physicians -- are frequently subjected to sleepless schedules, as the law does not pertain to them. 
 Financial crises in some hospitals have forced many supervising physicians to work extended hours: for some, a 36-hour shift can be the norm. The law should be extended to cover all physicians so that everyone who is charged with making lifesaving medical decisions can do so with adequate rest.
 
LAURIE MELTZER
East Norwich, N.Y., March 13, 1998

HEADLINE: Indonesia's New Cabinet Takes Office

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 16

 BODY:
A new nationalist-oriented Cabinet took office today facing tough negotiations with international lenders over how best to dig Indonesia out of its deepening economic crisis.
As if to emphasize his autonomy, President Suharto announced the formation of a Cabinet on Saturday that appears to represent business as usual at a time when the International Monetary Fund is demanding fundamental changes in the economy. 
 Cabinet members said today that they would set to work immediately to form their policies, as representatives from donor nations gathered in Jakarta to meet with them.
Already here or soon to arrive are senior officials from the I.M.F., the United States, Germany and Japan, all of which have urged Mr. Suharto to proceed with austerity measures to which he agreed two months ago.
The stock market and Indonesia's currency strengthened slightly today, maintaining what financial analysts said was a holding pattern as investors wait to see whether some accommodation can be reached between Indonesia and the I.M.F.
The fund has delayed the continued disbursement of its $40 billion aid package because of doubts over the carrying out of its conditions, and Indonesia has indicated it might strengthen its currency by pegging it to the dollar, which the I.M.F. opposes.
