HEADLINE: Thomas H. Johnson, 98, Cosmic Ray Physicist

BYLINE: By FORD BURKHART 

 BODY:
Dr. Thomas H. Johnson, a cosmic ray physicist whose findings were part of the foundation for the field of high energy physics, died on Feb. 25 at his home in Denmark, Me. He was 98.
Dr. Johnson worked at the Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island before becoming vice president for research at the Raytheon Corporation in Lexington, Mass., in the 1950's. 
 Working at the Bartol Research Foundation in Swarthmore, Pa., in the 1930's, Dr. Johnson set out to count cosmic rays at different elevations and help explain the radiation that constantly bombards Earth.
He and his associates sent up balloons, sometimes taken for unidentified flying objects, with film to record cosmic rays at points from sea level to mountain tops as high as 10,000 feet in Colorado, Mexico and Peru. They found that the rays came mainly from the Western sky, were weaker at the Equator and were strongest at higher elevations.
The findings confirmed that cosmic rays are attracted by Earth's magnetic field to the North and South Poles, said Dr. Nicholas D. Samios, a senior physicist at Brookhaven and former director of the laboratory.
"Beyond his research, Dr. Johnson was influential in the development of science, generally, by obtaining Federal resources and improving facilities for research," Dr. Samios said.
Dr. Johnson was assistant director of Bartol from 1927 until the onset of World War II, when he turned to military projects. At the Aberdeen Proving Ground in Maryland, he was chief physicist at the Ballistic Research Laboratories from 1942 to 1947 and measured the blast force of bombs and used microwaves to record movements of bullets and other projectiles.
He was one of the original scientists at Brookhaven, set up by the Atomic Energy Commission in 1947 in Upton, N.Y. Brookhaven was one of several national laboratories created to study peaceful applications of atomic energy. Dr. Johnson, who became chairman of its physics department, led efforts to investigate the fundamental nature of matter.
In 1951, he became vice president for research at Raytheon and remained there until retiring in 1965. In his years there, Raytheon worked on electronic countermeasures for the Air Force and on marine electronics, sonar for nuclear-powered submarines and flight-tracking radar. The company also developed the guidance computer for the Apollo spacecraft.
Dr. Johnson was born in Coldwater, Mich. He received a bachelor's degree in mathematics and economics from Amherst College in 1920 and a doctorate in physics from Yale University in 1926.
His first wife, Ann Benedict Johnson, died in 1964. His second wife, Dorothy Durfee Montgomery Johnson, died in 1981.
Surviving are a stepdaughter, Katherine MacGregor of Chicago; a stepson, Charles Montgomery of Peterborough, N.H., and two brothers, Corbett Johnson of Seneca Lake, N.Y., and Lyman Johnson of Silver Spring, Md.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES;
Oil Prices Tumble as Producers Give No Signal of Restraint

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Futures contracts for crude oil fell 5.6 percent to the lowest level in more than nine years yesterday on skepticism that OPEC, which supplies a third of the world's oil, would cut production to reduce a glut.
The latest drop means prices have fallen 31 percent since late November, when the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries decided to raise its production quota by 10 percent. On Friday, OPEC postponed a committee meeting that had been set for yesterday, reducing the chance that the group would soon cut output. 
 "The only salvation for prices is if OPEC stopped producing more than their quota," said Robert Nance, president of the Nance Petroleum Corporation in Billings, Mont. "It appears they're not going to do that."
Crude oil for April delivery fell 78 cents, to $13.28 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. That was the lowest closing price for next-month delivery of crude since Oct. 25, 1988. It was the biggest one-day decline in crude since a drop of 83 cents on Oct. 6.
Saudi Arabia, the world's largest producer, and Venezuela, considered OPEC's biggest quota violator, have rejected calls from other member nations to cut production.
In London, April Brent crude fell 45 cents, or 5.2 percent, to $12.37 a barrel on the International Petroleum Exchange, the lowest for a near-month contract since Nov. 21, 1988.
The decline in crude spilled into refined products as well. April heating oil fell 1.73 cents, or 4.3 percent, to 38.52 cents a gallon, the lowest closing price since Oct. 7, 1988. April gasoline fell 2.01 cents, or 4.3 percent, to 45.24 cents a gallon, the lowest since Sept. 28, 1994.
Several OPEC members, like Libya and Indonesia, have said they want to expand the committee meeting into a gathering of all 11 members to discuss cutting production to bolster prices.
The prospect of a full meeting and output reductions are still far off, the Middle East Economic Survey said, because Saudi Arabia will not agree. Also, Venezuela has shown no sign of ending its policy of producing above its OPEC quota.
"People are disappointed OPEC has not come forward to do anything," said Tom Bentz, an energy trader at Cresvale International in New York. "There's still no sign of a rescue effort."
Perhaps as much as $2 a barrel of the drop can be attributed, he added, to diminished concern about a United States attack on Iraq, which promised last month to allow United Nations weapons inspections.
Oil traders said that weaker Asian oil demand because of the region's economic turmoil and milder-than-usual winter temperatures in American heating oil markets have also helped prices fall this year.
The decline in futures prices came as the Energy Department reported that the average price of a gallon of gasoline fell last week to the lowest level in more than four years.
Motorists paid an average $1.008 a gallon for regular, unleaded self-service gasoline in the week ended yesterday, according to a weekly survey from the department's Energy Information Administration. That was down from $1.018 a gallon last week and the lowest since $1.007 a gallon on March 21, 1994.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Buoyant Investors Push Dow Above 8,700 for First Time

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
In the psychology of the stock market, buying begets buying.
Major stock market indexes soared to records yesterday, as investors, seeing a rosy economic outlook of declining interest rates and strong corporate profits, rushed to buy stocks. 
 After slipping more than 57 points on Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average surged 116.33 points, or 1.35 percent, to 8,718.85, closing above 8,700 for the first time.
Bank stocks, like J. P. Morgan, telecommunications companies like Worldcom, Lucent and Bell Atlantic, and drug companies like Pfizer were among the leading gainers.
Merger news also continued to buoy markets, as prospective couplings were announced between companies including the Alltel Corporation and 360 Communications, and between Aetna and the health insurance business of New York Life. Other companies, like Liberty Media and the Cendant Corporation, increased takeover bids for BET Holdings and American Bankers Insurance Group, respectively.
The rally also gained momemtum as prices of Treasury bonds rose, pushing down yields, and crude oil prices fell to their lowest levels in more than nine years on fears that a supply glut will continue.
"The message coming from the market is that things look perfect," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation.
Despite the lofty levels of stock prices and price-earnings ratios, investors feel compelled to purchase stocks, rather than err on the side of caution and miss out as the market moves higher, Mr. Johnson said.
Since the beginning of the year, the Dow has risen 810.60 points, or 10.25 percent.
Yesterday, the Standard & Poor's 500 index gained 1 percent, or 10.66 points, to 1,079.27, another record. It is up 11.22 percent this year. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index picked up 16.52 points to 1,788.18, a new high and has risen 13.87 percent in 1998.
The gains yesterday were fueled by comments from Warren Buffett, the chairman of Berkshire Hathaway and a famed value investor. In Berkshire Hathaway's annual report, released over the weekend, Mr. Buffett said he did not believe that the stock market was overvalued now, given the current level of interest rates and the strong profit margins posted by American companies.
Mr. Buffett also said that he was having a hard time finding stocks that are cheap, but investors seemed to pay little attention to that statement. In fact, Walt Disney shares rose $3.625, to $110.625, despite news that Berkshire had sold more than three million of its shares last year.
Over all, Mr. Buffett "gave reassurance to investors that stocks aren't a bad place to be," said Tom Galvin, the chief equity strategist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	Bond Prices Move Higher
 
 
 The prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday, helped by a firm dollar and by the continuing drop in oil prices.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond rose 1/2, to 103 23/32, and the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.86 percent from 5.89.
Oil prices fell yesterday to their lowest level in more than nine years, which should help keep inflation at bay; bond investors are wary of inflation because it erodes the value of their holdings.
Traders said the results of the Treasury's weekly auction of short-term bills yesterday were typical,with the average discount rate of a three-month bill at 4.985 percent, only slightly higher than the 4.970 percent a week ago. The six-month bill came in at an average rate of 5.025 percent, up from 5.010 percent.

HEADLINE: Omaha Tribe Turns to Cigarettes for a Better Life

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: MACY, Neb.

 BODY:
The thrumming green machines in the new factory here are the hope of the Omaha Indian tribe. Early sales are encouraging, and soon the tribe will be tripling production.
"Our dream," said Jerry Montour, the factory's consultant, "is to have like 100 people working here at one time." 
 And who would quarrel with that?
As it turns out, many might. The Omaha tribe is manufacturing cigarettes.
Even if the factory were not in a building that previously held the tribe's health club and wellness center, the debut of the Omaha Nation Tobacco Company might seem a little misguided.
After all, big cigarette companies are under fierce fire from states and the Federal Government, with proposed legislation and lawsuit settlements designed to force them to restrict cigarette advertising, raise prices and pay penalties to cover the costs of smoking-related afflictions like lung cancer and heart disease.
And those afflictions hit Indians particularly hard. Cancer and heart disease rates are rising faster among American Indians than in the general population, smoking is much more common than in other groups and Indians start smoking at a younger age.
Several tribes have even filed lawsuits in tribal courts against companies like Philip Morris, seeking direct compensation for illnesses related to tobacco, instead of relying on money that states expect to receive. The Omaha are thinking of filing such a suit as well, said the tribe's Washington lawyer, Robert Rosette.
"Smoking is much more severe on Indian reservations and has a much harsher impact," Mr. Rosette said. "As a sovereign government we have just as much right to recoup from the big tobacco companies."
Still, Mr. Rosette argued: "You can't mix that in with our manufacturing cigarettes, because we're a legal business.
"We have a great product, and we need avenues to get it out in the market."
If the logic seems cloudy, it is largely a reflection of the circumstances many Indian tribes are grappling with these days.
Facing high unemployment, poverty and dwindling Federal grants, reservations, especially in remote areas, are struggling to create jobs. They have only a few economic advantages over non-Indian communities, including the right to operate casinos, and to be exempt from state taxes on gasoline and cigarettes sold on Indian land.
The Omaha, whose reservation spills from northeastern Nebraska over the Missouri River into Iowa, is the first tribe to start a cigarette company. But it will soon be joined by another, the Confederate Tribes of the Chehalis Reservation, near Seattle, which is investing enough to add two assembly lines to the one in the Omaha factory and is setting up a cigarette plant on its own reservation. Mr. Montour said another joint venture is being negotiated with an East Coast tribe.
"People aren't going to stop smoking," said Gary Lasley, Omaha tribal chairman, puffing on an Omaha Full-Flavor cigarette. "They're addicted now."
Omaha leaders even traveled to Washington recently to testify before the Senate Indian Affairs Committee, hoping to influence Federal legislation to exempt tribal manufacturers from some penalties and proscriptions on big tobacco companies. They want out of advertising restrictions like a proposed ban on cartoon characters (Omaha cigarette packs feature an Indian's face) and absolution from payments for illnesses that predate the Omaha company's existence.
While these special pleadings are unlikely to be endorsed by the Indian Affairs Committee, the committee is likely to recommend that tribes be able to excuse themselves from price increases or marketing bans that state governments layer on top of whatever Federal restrictions are approved.
That means tribal cigarettes could not only continue to hold an edge on Indian land, but even off reservations in some states. To Indian leaders this is only fair, given the tribes' historical and ceremonial use of tobacco.
"We understand there's a lot of negativity about the tobacco industry right now, but we're not the ones who misrepresented and did all the marketing to teen-agers," Mr. Montour said. "Native Americans have been involved in tobacco for hundreds of years."
Roped by fields yellow-gray with corn stubble, the Omaha reservation is home to about 3,400 of the tribe's 6,000 members and has 60 percent unemployment.
Six years ago, the tribe opened Casino Omaha on its Iowa property, but profits have been gutted by competing riverboat casinos.
Since September, when the tribe began selling its cigarettes, made from North Carolina tobacco, it has taken orders from 26 tribes around the country and a few off-reservation outlets, and is promoting its product overseas.
On reservations, without state taxes, the cigarettes cost just 80 cents a pack, less than half the price of big-name brands. Even off-reservation stores are keeping prices low.
"It actually has doubled our cigarette profits," said Lance G. Morgan, whose company, Ho-Chunk Inc., sells Omahas for 99 cents at its Amoco store in South Sioux City, Iowa. (He said a local Marlboro representative was irked enough to insist the store not upstage Marlboros with Omaha displays.)
"I switched myself -- from Marlboro Medium to Omaha Lights," said Harry B. Wallace, the chief of Unkechaug Indian Nation in Mastic, N.Y., and the brand's New York distributor. He is working on a Web site and planning advertisements trumpeting the cigarettes as "Indian made" and without chemical additives.
Nationally, more than 36 percent of American Indians smoke. But even though heart disease and cancer are the leading causes of Indian deaths, Omaha officials say these afflictions are not their first health priority.
"The life expectancy isn't high enough for there to be a lot of cancer," said Greg Phillips, the tribe's vice chairman, who said the average tribe member dies at 57. More obvious threats, he said, are alcoholism and diabetes.
"Are they going to object when we try to manufacture Twinkies?" he said.
Dr. Nathaniel Cobb, director of cancer prevention and control for the Indian Health Service, has heard this before. "When someone dies of lung cancer they're usually in their 60's or older and they usually die pretty quickly, and it's sad, but it's not devastating to the community, compared to alcoholism or suicide," Dr. Cobb said. "There's a little disconnect there."
To Omaha tribal leaders, the priority is jobs -- they even use 20-year-old cigarette machines that require more than twice as many employees as modern ones.
Norman Walker, 62, the tribe's longtime alcoholism counselor, now mans the vestibule. His cousin, Sterling Walker, 37, who was an unemployed construction worker, became the factory floor supervisor -- and started smoking. Amelia Morris, 24, a former welfare recipient who is pregnant with her fifth child, now scoops freshly rolled cigarettes off a conveyor belt.
Employees said the health implications did not bother them because people would smoke anyway. But some on the reservation are uncomfortable.
"Maybe there's something else besides cigarettes," said the wellness center director, Barry Webster, whose basketball court and weight rooms were bumped to a smaller building. "Why not souvenirs?"

HEADLINE: A Tough Town, on Screen Anyway;
Despite Drop in Crime, New York's Gritty Image Prevails

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
Even on the station house set, reality can no longer be denied: crime is continuing its precipitous decline in New York City. And as they hung out in their famously scruffy squad room between takes, Detectives Leonard W. Briscoe and Reynaldo Curtis, New York's quintessential crime stoppers, were pondering what it meant when truth was safer than fiction.
"If this continues, the detectives could be forced to give out jaywalking tickets," said Jerry Orbach, the actor who plays Detective Briscoe on the NBC police show "Law and Order," which is shot on New York's not-quite-so-mean streets and happens to be the longest-running drama series now on network television. 
 "Maybe you'd have shows where the detectives would be sitting around, just eating doughnuts and drinking coffee," said Benjamin Bratt, who plays Detective Curtis. "You know, the Maytag repairman."
Unimaginably, Gotham -- the perennially reliable crime capital of celluloid classics from "The Naked City" and "Serpico" to more recent films like "The Peacemaker" and "Donnie Brasco," and currently the home turf of those televised homicide festivals "N.Y.P.D. Blue," "Brooklyn South" and "Law and Order" -- is now statistically a safer city than Boise, Idaho.
Moviemakers and television producers are being betrayed by the police blotter. Homicides in New York City last year hit a 30-year low, and the decline has continued so far this year. Other violent crimes also continue to drop. Most ominous of all, for filmmakers who think of "Taxi Driver" as the ultimate New York tale, is the news that the F.B.I. now ranks the city 150th out of the 189 most populous American cities in reported crimes per capita.
"The fact is, we are the safest large city in America," said Howard Safir, New York City's Police Commissioner, "and movies and television shows are giving the wrong impression of New York."
Fearlessly challenging this troublesome trend of goodness, some producers and directors -- particularly for television -- are keeping their fingers in the dike, steadfastly churning out New York mayhem as though they had never heard the words Disney and Times Square in the same sentence.
Others, though, are trying to happy-face the new reality. Even some of the masters who defined the era of New York movie-crime noir are uttering, well, heresy. "I just don't feel New York is menacing now," said the director Sidney Lumet, the laureate of police corruption whose "Serpico," "Prince of the City," "Q & A" and "Night Falls on Manhattan" won critical praise for their evocations of a brooding and soulless metropolis. "The movies and TV created a stereotype of the city," Mr. Lumet said, "but that was then, and this is now."
He added that his next film, "Gloria," to be released in the fall, reflects his revisionist view of New York. Although the story is crime-themed (Sharon Stone is a New York woman on the run from the mob), "you have to portray New York accurately, and I'm portraying it as a beautiful city now," he said. "There is no doubt that the city has changed, and the city itself is not a threat."
Irwin Winkler, a producer of such dark New York classics as "Goodfellas" and "Raging Bull," is also lending the city a new glow in his current project. "At First Sight," starring Val Kilmer, Mira Sorvino, Kelly McGillis and Nathan Lane, is about a man born blind whose sight has been surgically restored. "In this film, Val's character sees New York as a wondrous, magical place," Mr. Winkler said. "Where better to regain your sight?"
But some filmmakers reject the notion of a mid-course correction, pointing out that the new New York isn't exactly Shangri-La. "Tell that to Abner Louima, or mugging victims, or others who've lately had upsetting experiences in New York," said the director Edward Zwick, who is currently shooting a police-heavy terrorist thriller, "Martial Law," around the city with Denzel Washington, Bruce Willis and Annette Bening. "We're delighted that the crime rate is lower, but it still means there are two murders a day," he said, referring to the 767 in the city last year.
Dick Wolf, creator and executive producer of "Law and Order," contends that the new crime statistics do not undercut the credibility of his series, which is in its eighth season. "Look, the number of murders on 'Law and Order' doesn't even add up to three months' homicides in New York," Mr. Wolf said, referring to the show's 175 episodes so far.
He defended the show as "a celebration of New York, and a model of what the criminal justice system should be," adding, "It's a show about catching them and cooking them, and 95 percent of the time they do get cooked." Will he change the series to reflect the new statistical order? "We aren't going to fix what isn't broken," he said.
Ditto from Steven Bochco and David Milch, the co-creators and executive producers of "N.Y.P.D. Blue" and "Brooklyn South." "If we started doing episodes about the lack of crime in New York, we'd be out of business," Mr. Bochco said. "Can you imagine Simone and Sipowicz sitting around, just waiting for Godot?"
Like Mr. Wolf, Mr. Milch defended his two series as depicting "the way in which the criminal atmosphere is compelled to submit to the force of order," he said. Many classic New York crime films "portrayed the police as disempowered or corrupt or compromised," he said, "but our shows are representative of a new prevailing sensibility about the cops -- that they are aggressive, empowered, capable and possessed of a real decency."
The author Peter Maas, whose crime chronicles "The Valachi Papers" and "Serpico" have been made into movies, said filmmakers were "addicted to the notion of New York as the Bad Apple."
"I think there is a vested interest in perpetuating the stereotype of New York," he said. "They have created New York as an alien nation, and they are going to keep doing it for a while, because it plays so well. They will only stop when they decide it doesn't sell anymore."
The city itself also profits handsomely from those who would portray it. Last year, spending on movie, television and other such productions rose to $2.37 billion in New York, from $2.23 billion in 1996, making the film industry the fastest job-growth sector in the city's economy.
"The city certainly likes to have all that work here," said Patricia Reed Scott, New York City's Commissioner of Film, Theater and Broadcasting. She, for one, said she was not going to lecture the filmmakers. "We are not in the business of telling Hollywood not to do some kind of film," she said.
The depiction of New York as a blood-drenched metropolis is a venerable tradition. "Film images of New York as a hotbed of crime date back before 1915, when Raoul Walsh did a silent movie about gangsters on the Bowery called 'Regeneration,' " said Bruce Goldstein, the repertory program director of Film Forum in Manhattan.
But among the citizenry, there is some evidence to suggest that traditional perceptions of New York as a crime den may be changing. Although 43 percent of Americans said New York City was accurately portrayed in movies and on television, a surprising 35 percent said the city is presented "worse than it really is," according to a national New York Times Poll this month.
Of course, New York has not lacked for positive film depictions over the years, either, ranging from Park Avenue drawing-room scenes in the early silents to "On the Town" and Woody Allen's "Manhattan."
Today, on television, "when you have 'Seinfeld,' 'Spin City' and 'Cosby,' how can you say that New York is being depicted unfairly?" asked the comedian Jackie Mason, who himself added to the city's layers of crime scene tape by starring in "The Stool Pigeon," a 1973 film about a mob informant on the run.
Nora Ephron, the writer, director and New York die-hard, contends that the city has been romanticized even in the bloodiest of crime dramas. "New York could not be photographed more lovingly than in 'The Godfather,' and even Sidney's movies are secretly romantic," she said of Mr. Lumet.
She herself is currently romancing the city by shooting her next movie in New York. Titled "You Have Mail," it stars Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan and celebrates "the wonders of New York as a series of small towns," Ms. Ephron said.
But if New York becomes much safer, Mr. Goldstein said, perhaps entrepreneurs "will have to create a New York Noir Land, where they stage crimes for tourists like they stage gunfights at the Universal Studios." And maybe some remakes of old shoot-'em-ups would be in order, he said, suggesting " 'The Returning of Pelham One Two Three' and maybe even 'Escape to New York.' "

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Scandal Erodes the Power of Japan's Bastion of Fiscal Austerity

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 16

 BODY:
Yoichi Otsuki seemed to be enjoying a life of power and prestige, until he fastened a noose to a curtain rod in his apartment and looped it around his neck.
A longtime official at the Finance Ministry, Mr. Otsuki, 54, was ensconced in an influential job in the ministry's castle-like bastion near the Imperial Palace. Behind these walls, in the "House of the Great Coffers," as it is known in Japan, Mr. Otsuki worked in the nation's nerve center, the most powerful organization in Japan. 
 The ministry's tentacles touch so many facets of political and economic life that its officials wield power without parallel in the West. It has traditionally been more influential than the Prime Minister or any political party, and because it steers the world's second-biggest economy, the Finance Ministry's smallest maneuvers can move financial markets around the globe.
So it has been an extraordinary comedown since late January, when prosecutors first breached the Finance Ministry's seemingly impregnable walls. Thus far, they have arrested four ministry officials, including two of Mr. Otsuki's subordinates, for accepting bribes from the financial institutions they oversee. When prosecutors moved in on Mr. Otsuki, however, he could not stand the humiliation. Just before he was to be interrogated by police at 1:30 P.M. on Jan. 27, Mr. Otsuki went home and hanged himself.
The scandal in which he found himself enmeshed is still unfolding, with critics pointing fingers at prominent officials day after day. Just last Wednesday, prosecutors entered the central bank, traditionally a dominion of the ministry, to seize a high-level official. Private bankers have been detained as well, top executives have resigned at major financial institutions and one Parliament member, another finance ministry official and numerous businessmen have committed suicide to escape disgrace.
The scandal is shattering Japan's old faith in public servants and suggesting to a growing number of Japanese cynics that their bureaucracy may be rotten to the core. With economic troubles dogging all of Asia, the Finance Ministry is the single institution most able to orchestrate a revival of the region, but it increasingly resembles a fortress under siege, attacked both at home and abroad for errant behavior and policy mismanagement.
Critics worry that the ministry may have lost its way at a moment when leaders in the United States and other industrial nations are demanding that it take more steps to help prevent an Asian tailspin. Economists say that by trying to tighten the country's belt even during hard times, the ministry risks throwing Japan into recession.
Japan's politicians, accustomed to staying on the sidelines in formulation of economic policy, are now stepping in to take the lead, further threatening the ministry and preventing its experts from fully concentrating on the task of nursing the sick economy. Particularly on the eve of a broad restructuring of the financial industry, the ministry appears distracted by its scandals and by turf battles with politicians -- battles that it may be beginning to lose.
"There will be a very drastic shift of power from the bureaucrats to the politicians," said Koichi Kato, secretary general of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party. "In the last year, the bureaucrats who were thought to be the best and the brightest in this society, handling all policies, were proved to be not as effective and competent as we had thought. Now it is time for us politicians to make our own policy."
"This is a very dangerous time for us," Mr. Kato said.
A real devolution of power, if it occurs, will have major policy implications for Japan and the world. Just last week, for instance, executives in the governing party indicated they would devise a spending package of more than $80 billion to stimulate the economy.
For now, the Finance Ministry has fended off a formal attempt by Sakigake, a small party in the governing coalition, to break it up into a handful of agencies. Until recently, the ministry was seen as the bedrock of Japanese prosperity, so few balked at the extent of its power -- roughly equivalent to a combination of the United States Treasury Department, the Internal Revenue Service, the Office of Management and Budget, the Securities and Exchange Commission and parts of the Federal Reserve.
Amid recent calls by politicians to curb its powers, however, the ministry has agreed to spin off a financial surveillance agency in June. Both the Finance Minister and the Vice Finance Minister were forced out of their positions earlier this year as casualties of the widening assault on the ministry.
But while the ministry's power appears on the wane for now, its strength and expertise, which make it arguably the most important repository of power outside of Washington, continue to dwarf that of Japan's elected officials. Politicians have called for more spending, but attempts to alter the ministry's steadfast policy of fiscal austerity have bounced off the ministry's stone walls.
Still, the attack on the ministry has been debilitating. Japan's weekly magazines are accusing it of everything from dishonesty to ineptitude. And the public is learning that Finance Ministry officials do not always spend their time laboring in neckties over statistical charts but also have been known to cavort -- sometimes at the invitation of those they are supposed to regulate -- at the raunchiest of sex clubs.
"They are losing control," Toru Nakakita, an economics professor at Toyo University, said of the ministry's bureaucrats. "They are demoralized. They are a group of very proud people, but they made an awful lot of fallacies. They've blundered so many times."
The crisis in the ministry is particularly inopportune because it is supposed to be busy overseeing a "Big Bang" deregulation of the financial markets that aims to make Tokyo a financial center as dynamic and free as New York or London.
Critics point out that the ministry has a checkered record on managing free markets. Economists and politicians blame the ministry for inflating Japan's "bubble" economy during the 1980's, bursting it in the early 1990's and then allowing the economy to stagnate for the last seven years.
At stake for Finance Ministry bureaucrats -- predominantly graduates of the country's top university who are for the most part brilliant, dedicated, but unelected -- is whether they will continue to occupy the center of the Japanese universe. It is unclear what would replace the ministry and how it might usher in changes that would diminish its own powers, enabling the economy to function more freely and openly.
"We're at a crossroads, and the catchword today is transparency," said Kiichi Miyazawa, a former bureaucrat who has served as both Prime Minister and Finance Minister. "This transparency really means sometimes a very, very brutal confrontation, which is not really a part of our culture. But it matters in economics, in legal matters as well. Transparency is the must. That should mean that the discretionary power of the bureaucrats should be reduced."
For years, the ministry had a say in virtually every move a financial institution made, from opening a new branch or closing a subsidiary to introducing a new product to inspecting the giveaways offered in marketing campaigns. One bank told a Japanese newspaper that it felt it had to consult the ministry on the size of dividends a couple of years ago. One banker said privately that sometimes banks felt obliged to confer on the kind of calendars they could offer to customers and the kind of uniforms their female clerical workers could wear.
Ministry officials dispute that, saying that banks setting up new branches would face almost no obstacles as long as they submitted the proper documents with their application. As for picayune issues like uniforms and calendars, one official snorted, though he refused to be named, as did other ministry officials interviewed for this article.
"That's quite unthinkable," he said, adding, "Those stories are quite exaggerated, in my personal opinion."
Ministry officials say they have been on the defensive for some time. "We have been losing power for the last several years," said Sei Nakai, deputy director of the ministry's prestigious banking bureau. "That is why we are being attacked."
"From the outside, it sometimes seems that the Ministry of Finance decides everything, but it's wrong." he added. "We are destined to be a scapegoat."
The ministry is accused not just of economic ineptitude but, perhaps more important in the public mind, of corruption and misbehavior. While lavish entertainment of government officials by corporate executives has long been commonplace in Japan, the public has been particularly angered by the revelation that banks entertained Finance Ministry officials at "no-pan shabu-shabu" clubs.
Shabu-shabu is a kind of cooked meat, but the specialty of the restaurant is the waitresses, who wear short skirts and no underwear: In Japanese, "no-pan" refers to "no panties." So "no-pan shabu-shabu" has become a national joke. The idea of these officials discussing bank regulation in such a setting is so absurd that it is becoming difficult for the ministry to be taken seriously.
Traditionally, ministry bureaucrats had been viewed almost universally as honest and extraordinarily hard-working -- choosing a life of Government service over far more lucrative options in the private sector.
"Somehow it became a fashion of the day to criticize the bureaucrats," said Kaoru Yosano, a prominent Liberal Democratic Party member of the Parliament. "This is a very safe way for politicians."
Often it is the ministry that ends up taking the blame because no one else wants to take responsibility, Mr. Yosano and others say. For instance, when Japanese bankers met with their counterparts from other countries to discuss South Korea's debt crisis, the banks apparently did not want to make a decision without consulting the Finance Ministry, according to Mr. Nakai of the ministry.
Ministry officials read this as a sign that the banks did not want to take the blame if the loans went sour, so they turned to the ministry for guidance and security.
Many say the ministry cannot ignore the blunder it made a year ago when it declared that the economy was recovering and insisted on increasing a national sales tax last April. The tax increase sent the Japanese economy tumbling over a cliff, plunging at an annual rate of 11 percent in the second quarter of 1997.
Ministry officials now admit they underestimated the impact of the sales tax increase. But they also point to a sharply rising fiscal deficit and national debt that is rising faster than that of other advanced countries. So despite American pressure, the officials are determined to proceed with what they call fiscal reconstruction, meaning austerity, to put Japan's budget in order.
The ministry's budget bureau regards this goal as sacred, according to a high-level ministry official who is not in the budget bureau.
With only a touch of levity, he said, "It's a kind of religious sect."

HEADLINE: Ruling by Federal Judge on Leasing Planes Worries Airline Industry

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
An unexpected ruling by a Federal judge in Colorado last week sharply increases the risks associated with financing and leasing airplanes, threatening to depress the value of billions of dollars worth of deals and to make it much harder for new and financially troubled airlines to get airplanes, said lawyers and an airline industry analyst.
The ruling, by Judge John L. Kane Jr. of the United States District Court in Denver, severely weakens a provision in the bankruptcy code that gives special protection to companies that finance airplane purchases and lease airplanes. Many airlines lease aircraft to expand their fleets without having to tie up millions of dollars buying aircraft. 
 The provision, known as Section 1110, was intended to give leasing companies the right to repossess their airplanes if an airline in Chapter 11 defaults on its lease payments after a 60-day grace period. The provision gives investors confidence to put up the millions of dollars needed to buy commercial jets because they believe they can take back the planes quickly and lease them to another operator if an airline defaults.
But Judge Kane ruled that if an airline makes good on its lease payments during the 60-day grace period and then defaults again, the leasing company does not automatically get to take its plane back and must wait in line with other creditors.
Philip Baggaley, the chief airline analyst at Standard & Poor's, which rates billions of dollars worth of debt used to finance airplanes each year, called the decision "amazing."
"If that interpretation is upheld, not only would few creditors and lessors be willing to extend credit, Standard & Poor's might have to downgrade a lot of debt," he said.
The decision stems from an appeal of a bankruptcy court ruling by Western Pacific Airlines and Smith Management Inc., a New York investment firm that invested more than $24 million in the Colorado carrier after it filed for Chapter 11 in October. At issue was a relatively minor point: whether Western Pacific had 30 days before it had to return 10 airplanes after defaulting on its lease payments the second time, or less time, as the leasing companies argued.
But Judge Kane ruled that Western Pacific was not obligated to give up the planes at all unless the bankruptcy judge decided it should. Western Pacific announced on Feb. 4 that it would stop flying, and the leasing companies have reclaimed their 10 planes. But the decision opens the door for Western Pacific to ask for the planes back and lease them at a higher rate to another airline so that Smith Management can earn back some of its investment.
But getting the planes back may not be so easy. Boullion Aircraft Holding, which leased three 737's to Western Pacific, has already transferred two of the planes to Southwest Airlines and is very close to signing a lease agreement on the third, said Brad Johnson, the company's general counsel. He said that he did not think that Smith Management, which is behind Western Pacific's legal maneuvers, was interested in actually taking possession of the planes.
"We have received repeated letters from Smith asking for money," he said. "What they want is the ability to make some money off the airplanes, not the airplanes themselves."
Smith Management declined to comment yesterday.
Mr. Johnson would not say whether Boullion would appeal Judge Kane's decision. Short of that, the leasing companies have 10 days from last week's ruling to ask the judge to reconsider his decision.
Many people are concerned not so much about the current case as about the larger issue of what Judge Kane's decision would mean to the airplane leasing and finance industry if it is allowed to stand.
"The whole theory of Section 1110 was to give special protection because of the importance of the airline industry to the economy," said Marvin E. Jacob, a partner at Weil Gotshal & Manges in New York who specializes in airline bankruptcy. "If there is nothing special about being an aircraft lessor, there should be nothing special about airline financing. The increased risk will have to be factored into the price."
Mr. Baggaley of Standard & Poor's said, "Creditors will be much less willing to finance aircraft for weak and start-up airlines if they believe that they will not be able to repossess the aircraft if that airline later fails to meet its obligations."
That would make it even harder for new and small airlines, which have been struggling in recent years, to challenge the major carriers.
Even if Judge Kane's decision is overturned on appeal, some believe that more action will be needed to restore investor confidence. "The damage has been done," Mr. Johnson said. "It's going to take an act of Congress to fix the uncertainty."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Do Blinders Become Bulls On a Run?;
Wall Street Searches For a Silver Lining In Lower Earnings

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
They call it the "confessional season," the period when corporate America begins to warn Wall Street of the troubles that lie ahead.
It is a time near the end of each quarter when companies begin to leak out their bad news, acknowledging slowing sales growth at home, declining sales abroad, backlogs in inventory and cyclical downturns in business. 
 Walt Disney, Nike, Intel and Compaq Computer have all made dire first-quarter forecasts, causing Wall Street stock analysts to lower their estimates not just for these companies but for the market over all. And these analysts, according to First Call Inc., which tracks earnings estimates, now expect profits at the nation's biggest companies to grow less than 2 percent in the first quarter, the slowest pace of the decade.
But attention is beginning to shift to the end of the year. Will the coming slowdown be just a blip or something more sustained? Expectations for the second half of the year remain quite robust from stock analysts, an optimistic group by nature. By their count, profits could show tremendous gains, up 17 percent in the fourth quarter.
Perhaps this explains why the stock market has rocketed to records in the face of weakening results. But if these forecasts prove overly optimistic, as some vocal market strategists suggest, investors may be in for a sharp selloff in the latter part of the year.
"We think there's going to be a big squeeze on profits this year," said Cynthia Latta, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill. "We're calling it a big turning-point year."
Indeed, after six years of mostly double-digit profit gains, the case for a longer-lasting slowdown is growing. Labor costs are rising, companies are grappling with the year 2000 problem, and the economic squeeze in Asia is only beginning to take its toll on American business. And after years of restructuring and productivity improvements, companies appear to be running out of ways to expand their profit margins.
Even the rosy stock analysts now accept that these factors have conspired against companies early this year. First Call said that estimates have been "falling like a stone" in recent weeks. I.B.E.S. International Inc., another earnings watcher, said that estimates suffered the largest downward revision last month in more than five years. Since Jan. 9, estimates of first-quarter earnings growth have plummeted from 10 percent for the stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500 to 2 percent, the lowest since 1991.
"We haven't seen anything like this since the recession of 1990," said James E. Glassman, a senior economist at Chase Securities. "Throughout the 90's we've been spoiled; we've only seen double-digit growth. So this year could be sobering."
The same people racing to ratchet down their early-year forecasts -- Wall Street analysts -- are undaunted, forecasting a pickup in growth in the second half that will lead to a 10 percent profit gain for the entire year. But many economists and market strategists, who look at the big economic forces instead of the prospects for individual companies, are forecasting a more sizable slowdown, well below last year's 11 percent growth rate.
The most optimistic among this group forecast 8 percent gains in corporate profits; the less optimistic see gains of less than 5 percent.
Corporate outlooks start with the economy, which grew at a 3.8 percent clip last year -- the fastest pace in a decade. Blue-chip profits jumped nearly three times as much.
So the question is: can blue-chip companies produce solid gains in the eighth year of an economic cycle, and extend the longest continuous period of profit growth on record? "I don't think so," Ms. Latta said.
The financial crisis in Asia -- seen last October as the prime threat to the great bull market of the 1990's -- is a big factor, she says, but just one among many.
For instance, the unemployment rate in the United States is 4.6 percent, the lowest in 24 years, and as corporations struggle to find skilled workers and retain their best employees, pressure mounts for higher wages and more training programs. That means corporate costs could rise and cut into earnings growth.
"We've got rising labor costs, rising fringe benefit costs and fierce competition, and so margins are getting squeezed," Ms. Latta said. "We're probably not going to see as much of a productivity gain this year."
There are also currency problems emanating from a strong dollar and a widening trade deficit because of cheaper imports from Asia. Eastman Kodak, for instance, said that profits declined 38 percent in the fourth quarter, partly because of the strong dollar.
If the stock market's recent strength is any indication of investor sentiment, many are dismissing the earnings warnings and cautionary tales, perhaps because they have heard them so many times during the great bull market of the 1990's.
The Dow Jones industrial average -- after a record three consecutive years with gains of 20 percent or more -- is up 10 percent this year. And the S. & P. 500, a broader gauge, is up 11 percent.
Such gains have pushed stock valuations into record territory. The price-to-earnings ratio on S. & P. 500 stocks has reached 26, meaning that investors are paying about $26 for every $1 earned by those companies in the last year.
Share prices generally reflect future earnings prospects instead of past gains. But even on that basis, stocks are trading at 20 times future earnings, at or near a historic high.
"The only way you can support these kinds of ratios is to see profit margins expand," said Steven Leuthold, an analyst at the Leuthold Group in Minneapolis. "And I don't think we're going to see that."
The threats to the market are several. Byron R. Wien, the United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter and a long-time bear, expects a big economic growth spurt will come in the second part of the year, pushing up interest rates and knocking stocks for a loss.
Others, pointing to Asia's continuing economic woes, expect the economy to go in the opposite direction.
"Those who think this is a one-quarter phenomenon in Asia are just not in touch with reality," Mr. Leuthold said. "I've talked to a number of people in Asia and they say that in the U.S. we're just not cognizant of the devastation in Asia."
Of course, there are those, like Abby Joseph Cohen, the co-chairwoman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company, who expect the slowdown in Asia to temper a robust economy in America and eliminate the need for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, a positive for stocks.
Profits may moderate, she says, but the United States economy is like a "supertanker," not the fastest or flashiest ship on the sea, but because of a well-balanced economy and well-managed companies, perhaps the sturdiest.
To some strategists, the earnings numbers in recent years seem almost too good to be true. Skeptics say that companies have managed their earnings, through such things as special charges and mergers, to the point where creative accounting can no longer help them out.
Barton Biggs, the erudite global strategist at Morgan Stanley, likens the American stock market to the Titanic, and he has written repeatedly about how companies distort their earnings through accounting sleight of hand. "It is well known that the S. & P. 500 sells at the highest valuations of earnings in history," Mr. Biggs wrote recently. "But it is less well recognized that the index's earnings are overstated.
"For example, a company may take care of a mistake with a one-time writeoff, in which it also buries other expenses that are to come. In effect, future earnings are enhanced."
James S. Chanos, president of Kynikos Associates, a New York firm that specializes in betting on which stocks are poised to fall, agrees. "Earnings quality has gone downhill," he said. "The longer the bull market has lasted, the lower the quality of earnings companies have reported. We're seeing companies play games in write-offs.
"Companies know they have to show bottom-line earnings growth," Mr. Chanos added. "So by hook or by crook they'll do it."
In fact, the S. & P. earnings game is becoming so difficult to understand -- in part because of the recent changes in how companies report earnings -- that Ms. Latta at DRI/McGraw-Hill says she does not trust her own firm's projections for S. & P. 500 growth in 1998.
She does, however, trust her projections for earnings growth for all United States corporations, as listed in statistics compiled by the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis. Those figures have steadily fallen, from 16 percent in 1995 to about 8 percent in 1997, she said. Her projection for 1998 is just 1.2 percent.
If earnings slow sharply, that could depress share prices, which have vastly outpaced earnings growth since the 1980's.
Although earnings growth and share prices tend to rise equally over time, they alternate leadership roles, according to a Federal Reserve study released last year. And for a long stretch, since 1982, share prices have been the leader, with an average annual stock gain of 12 percent, compared with an average earnings gain of 8 percent.
"The implication is that we're in the next 15-year period, when earnings will do better than the index," said Robert Farrell, a longtime strategist at Merrill Lynch. "And if that's the case, we can't afford to have earnings disappoint."
Still, shares of many companies are soaring. Even companies that have warned of trouble ahead -- or had their earnings estimates slashed in the last month -- have done well.
Disney and Intel, for instance, saw sharp declines after issuing earnings warnings, but remain strong this year, with shares of each up 11 percent. Sears, Roebuck warned of a 50 percent decline in first-quarter profits because of difficulty in its credit card business, but its shares are up 30 percent. A month ago, Nike warned of profit trouble, caused by sales declines and inventory buildups in Asia and the United States. Still, shares are up 15.5 percent.
A growing array of economists and market historians are baffled.
"It's like all news is good news," Mr. Farrell of Merrill Lynch said. "I've spent my life saying the market's right, but the sustainability of this is questionable if earnings are going to disappoint beyond a quarter or two."

Even though the bull market continues to charge ahead, corporate profits are being squeezed for the first time in years. Wall Street stock analysts have sharply cut their forecasts for earnings growth in the first half of the year, but they remain optimistic about the future. HEADLINE: Loss at Micron Technology Much Steeper Than Expected

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
Stung by pricing pressure from Asian competitors, Micron Technology Inc. yesterday reported a steeper-than-expected loss for its second fiscal quarter. A major maker of memory chips for personal computers, Micron said it had been hard hit in recent quarters by Asian manufacturers' sales of chips below cost.
Micron's personal computer subsidiary, Micron Electronics Inc., warned last month that it would have an operating loss, which it attributed to pricing pressure on notebook computers, and poor forecasting, which left the company with excess inventory. At that time, Micron also announced plans to reassign about 10 percent of its work force -- roughly 450 people -- and move its California server operations to Idaho, where the company is based. 
 Micron reported its results after the close of the market. Micron shares closed at $33.75, up 75 cents on the New York Stock Exchange. Prices did not change in after-hours trading.
For the quarter ended Feb. 26, Micron reported a net loss of $48.1 million, compared with earnings of $142.7 million, or 67 cents a share on a fully diluted basis, for the corresponding period a year ago. Revenue dropped 14 percent, to $755.4 million, from $876.2 million a year earlier.
Micron said operating losses for its memory chip and personal computer systems operations were partly offset in the fiscal second quarter by a one-time gain of $157 million, or 18 cents a share fully diluted, on the sale of 90 percent of the company's contract manufacturing subsidiary. The quarter also included charges of $13 million resulting from a work force reduction in the PC business and $4 million related to the write-down of chip-making equipment.
Analysts expected a loss of 17 cents a share, according to First Call. Published estimates, however, ranged from 3 cents to 29 cents, with some analysts privately advising clients of a potential loss as high as 40 cents. The actual loss, excluding the one-time gain, was 41 cents.
"Semiconductors was a larger loss than we expected," said Jonathan Joseph, an analyst with Montgomery Securities. "The PC business, at the margin, was about as expected."
Given the tremendous pricing pressure created by the Asian economic crisis, the company has performed about as well as could be expected, he said. "Obviously, they're in an extremely tough environment," he added.
Micron said its semiconductor memory operations lost 26 cents a share fully diluted, on net sales of $283 million, down from $440 million in the first quarter of fiscal 1998. The decline was primarily a result of lower pricing for memory chips and fewer total megabits sold, Micron said.

HEADLINE: Port Authority Won't Increase Tolls on Bridges and Tunnels

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
Tolls on the Port Authority's bridges and tunnels will not go up next year, the authority said yesterday as it announced record profits for 1997 resulting from higher traffic at its bridges, tunnels, airports and rail line.
But the authority's executive director, Robert E. Boyle, refused to rule out increases in PATH train fares and tariffs paid by bus companies at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan because those two operations lost money last year. 
 "I don't foresee increasing the tolls," Mr. Boyle said. But he added, "We continue to study the possibility of fare increases, hoping to avoid any increase to the traveling public for as long a period as practicable."
The higher traffic levels, coupled with an accounting adjustment related to the World Trade Center bombing and modest cuts in expenses, produced net income of $161 million -- $72 million, or 81 percent, more than in 1996. Total revenue was $2.2 billion -- $52 million more than revenue in 1996. Operating expenses fell $8 million, to $1.5 billion.
But the PATH line ran a deficit of $166.8 million, and the bus terminal lost $51.2 million. Both losses, though, were smaller than those in 1996.
Almost 20 percent of the agency's profit last year came from a $29.4 million accounting adjustment connected to insurance payments for the losses caused by the bombing of the World Trade Center in 1993. The adjustment also means that the authority has recouped from insurance companies all but $3 million of its losses related to the bombing.
Mr. Boyle attributed the increased traffic to a healthy regional economy and winter weather that was warmer than usual.
Traffic at Kennedy, La Guardia and Newark Airports totaled about 83.9 million passengers, 3.6 percent more than in 1996. At the agency's four bridges -- the George Washington, Bayonne, Goethals and Outerbridge Crossing -- and two tunnels -- the Lincoln and Holland -- total vehicular traffic, measured in the eastbound direction only, was approximately 118 million, 3.9 percent more than 1996 levels. Tolls at these crossings are $4.
On PATH, ridership grew 2.6 percent to about 62.2 million passengers.
John S. Dyson, a special adviser to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, said, "Most of the gains are a result of growth in New York City and not because of anything they did." The Giuliani administration has long asserted that the Port Authority is biased toward New Jersey at the expense of New York City.
In a statement, Lewis M. Eisenberg, the Port Authority's chairman, said that the agency's strong financial position would allow it to continue its long-term capital development program, including $1.1 billion in improvements this year -- the largest ever spent in one year on capital improvements -- at Kennedy International Airport.
The Port Authority's long-term capital program emphasizes Kennedy, where $4.4 billion in Port Authority and private investment is rebuilding the airport. The agency this year will also begin construction of a light-rail line linking Kennedy to rail lines at Jamaica Station in Queens. At Newark International Airport, it will break ground for the extension of the airport's monorail to the nearby Northeast Corridor rail line.
Cost-cutting at the agency included the elimination of nearly 300 positions through attrition, a retirement incentive program and the privatization of Kennedy's International Arrivals Building and the World Trade Institute. Continued productivity gains on the PATH system and reductions in police overtime also saved money, the agency said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Surges 116 Points, As Market Sets Records
Stock market indexes soared to records, as investors bought on expectations of strong corporate profits and declining interest rates -- the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 5.86 percent.
The Dow Jones industrial average surged 116.33 points, or 1.35 percent, to 8,718.85, closing above 8,700 for the first time. Since the beginning of the year, the Dow has risen 810.60 points, or 10.25 percent. Page D10. 

Crude oil contracts fell 5.6 percent to the lowest level in more than nine years on skepticism that OPEC will cut output. D10.
 
Micron Loss Exceeds Expectations
Micron Technology, a leading maker of computer memory chips, reported a steeper-than-expected $48.1 million quarterly loss and cited Asian competition. D6.
 
New Japan Central Bank Governor
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan appointed as central bank governor Masaru Hayami, left, a former executive director of the bank who later became a powerful business executive. He succeeds Yasuo Matsushita, who offered his resignation last week after a subordinate was arrested in a widening financial corruption scandal. D4.
 
Menem in Rebuff to Business
President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina, in an uncharacteristic rebuff to big business, plans to propose labor rules that leave populist Peronist laws intact. D7.
 
Aetna-NYLCare Deal Announced
Aetna will purchase the New York Life Insurance Company's health care subsidiary, NYLCare Health Plans, for $1.35 billion. D2.
 
Higher Risk Seen on Airplane Deals
The risks associated with financing and leasing airplanes are expected to rise sharply, as a result of a ruling by a Federal judge in Colorado last week. D3.
 
Kodak to Grant Employees Options
Eastman Kodak, seeking to lift the sagging morale of its 90,000 workers, despite planned dismissals, announced it was granting them stock options. Facing stiff competition from Fuji Photo, it promised to "make a significant dent in losses." Investors reacted positively, sending the company's stock higher. D7.
 
Big Hotel Companies Plan Merger
Capstar Hotel and American General Hospitality agreed to a $530 million merger, combining fast-growing companies that have premium hotels in big cities. D2.
 
Exel in Mid Ocean Deal
Exel, which sells directors' and officers' liability insurance, said that it would pay about $2.1 billion for the 75 percent of Mid Ocean, a reinsurer, that it does not own. D2.
 
Financial Overhaul Bill Criticized
A top Treasury official said that the Republican-sponsored financial overhaul bill, which would let banks, securities firms and insurance companies get into each other's businesses, had "bad provisions." D8.
 
Alltel to Buy 360 Communications
As expected, Alltel, an independent local telephone company, agreed to acquire 360 Communications, a big cellular carrier, for more than $4 billion. D3.

HEADLINE: Gore Brings a Little Fire to Kennelly's Race for Governor

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., March 16

 BODY:
The Democratic Party's most famous wooden figure came to Connecticut today to bring life and light to Barbara B. Kennelly's sluggish campaign for Governor.
Vice President Al Gore, at a fund-raising luncheon, told just one stiff-guy joke about himself before adopting a fire-and-brimstone tone in support of Mrs. Kennelly's challenge to Gov. John G. Rowland, a Republican. Much of the banquet-hall buzz was about the accusations of sexual misconduct in the White House, a signal that the visit could have a mixed effect on voters. But Mrs. Kennelly could not have appeared happier to see Mr. Gore. 
 "I know we have a long way to go between now and Election Day," Mr. Gore said. Then, stirring the crowd of 500 to waves of applause, he called her campaign "a great cause" and thundered, "How much intensity are you willing to bring to this campaign? How hard are you willing to fight?"
While Mr. Rowland's campaign seemed to relish the opportunity to link the Kennelly campaign to Washington liberals, Mr. Gore's visit was intended to energize Democratic Party faithful in the state. And it seemed to work.
The Vice President's speech raised $250,000 for Mrs. Kennelly (pronounced keh-NELL-ee), the Representative from the First Congressional District and a daughter of John M. Bailey, who at his death in 1975 was the state's most powerful Democratic leader.
Even her own supporters concede that Mrs. Kennelly's campaign has drifted since she announced her candidacy in September. Today, they said they hoped Mr. Gore's visit would shake the doldrums out of the "Kennelly for Connecticut" campaign.
She has one advantage that no other Democratic candidate for governor has had since 1966: a clear shot at the party's nomination. Her last expected rival, Mayor Joseph P. Ganim of Bridgeport, endorsed her two weeks ago, so she expects to avoid a costly battle in the September primary. Now, she can spend the coming months trying to convert swing voters instead of dividing Democrats.
However, her standing in polls has slipped this winter as she focused on fund-raising and organizing. In the summer before she announced, polls showed her in a statistical tie with Mr. Rowland. By February, she had fallen 26 percentage points behind him, in a poll taken by the University of Connecticut.
Her own supporters have complained that she does not have a clear message and has not been visible enough. "People are not overenthusiastic, because they don't know exactly what her platform is," said Annette W. Carter, a Democrat who represents Hartford in the State House of Representatives. "They're warming up."
Elizabeth A. Marafino, the president of the Congress of Connecticut Community Colleges, a faculty union, said: "She kept herself too isolated in the first few months. I hope she learned a lesson."
Mrs. Kennelly says that she has. Hoping to capitalize on some new momentum from Mr. Gore's visit, Mrs. Kennelly plans to move on several fronts to reassure her partisans. She has begun a tour of Connecticut's 169 cities and towns, with plans to walk the main street of each one. On March 29, she hopes to capture some of the hoopla associated with this month's college basketball finals by holding simultaneous March Madness House Parties at 100 homes throughout the state. A campaign video will be shown and each host is being asked to invite 20 people and ask each one for $20.
Also, Democratic officials said campaign officials plan to announce a new manager, probably from outside Connecticut, within several weeks. The current manager, James E. Meehan, said he was interested in another role in the campaign. "I'm not a professional politician," said Mr. Meehan, formerly an insurance lawyer. "The goal here is to win in November."
Fergus P. Cullen, Mr. Rowland's deputy campaign manager, said Democrats "may be unified, but that doesn't make them enthusiastic."
"Just because she has cleared the field, after a surprising struggle, doesn't solve the Democrats' raw material problem," Mr. Cullen said. "She is a poor speaker, and she is a consistent and reliable vote for the liberal Democratic leadership in Washington."
Mr. Rowland, 40, is emphasizing his gubernatorial role and has so far mostly ignored Mrs. Kennelly, 61. "The campaign will come later," Mr. Cullen said.
Instead, the Governor is using his office to full advantage. On Mrs. Kennelly's big campaign day today, he rode a Metro-North train into the South Norwalk station to highlight several state plans for relieving congestion on Interstate 95, including more than $50 million in previously announced renovations at railroad stations. "All aboard!" Mr. Rowland said jovially, turning to glad-hand local business leaders.
A few hours later and eight miles away at the Stamford Marriott, Democrats dining on poached New England salmon with Mr. Gore said the Governor's popularity, his statewide visibility and the state's improving economy were high hurdles for Mrs. Kennelly.
She has taken some ribbing for her propensity for oratorical fender-benders. During her remarks today, she stumbled by referring to Mr. Gore as "Mr. President," then awkwardly corrected herself. But the audience liked it the first way, and whooped with delight.
She quickly ran through an agenda that will include reducing juvenile crime, making college more affordable, encouraging lower property tax rates, and increasing discipline and standards in elementary schools. "Connecticut absolutely can do better than it's doing today, and I want to lead the state," she said.

Vatican Offers Repentance For Holocaust Failings
The Vatican offered a document it called an "act of repentance" for the failure of Roman Catholics to deter the slaughter of Europe's Jews during the Holocaust. But the document skirted the issue of the church's long silences during the Nazi era. A1

More Names of the Missing

Iraq Wants War Crimes Trial
Iraq's Parliament will recommend that President Clinton and other Western leaders be brought to trial for war crimes against the Iraqi people, the official Iraqi News Agency said. The action is in retaliation for a United States Senate vote on Friday urging the United Nations to form a tribunal to try President Saddam Hussein of Iraq for war crimes, the report said, quoting a National Assembly committee chairman. (AP)
 
Arrest in Belfast Jail Death
The police in Northern Ireland arrested an inmate in the jail cell hanging of a pro-British militant, David Keys. The police said the suspect was a compatriot of Mr. Keys in the Loyalist Volunteer Force. (AP)
 
Results Strengthen French Left
France's political parties jockeyed for leadership of the country's regions after the governing Socialists defeated conservative parties in local elections. In official results, the Socialists and their leftist allies won nearly 40 percent of the vote Sunday. Mainstream conservative parties won 36 percent, while the far-right National Front won 15 percent. (AP)

He will retire and receive a pension for his 29 years of military service. It was also disclosed that the sergeant major had filed a libel suit against one of the female soldiers who accused him of sexual misconduct. The suit seeks $500,000 in actual damages and $1 million in punitive damages. A1

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Get a Job

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: HENG DAO, China

 BODY:
While monitoring village elections in northeastern China with a U.S. observer team, I wandered through the hamlet of Heng Dao, dropping in on a farmer-turned-mechanic who had geese and pigs in the front yard but a stereo and color television inside his brick hut. Our interpreter asked him what had happened to the loudspeaker that the Communist Party had in his "brigade," as small villages were known in Mao's day. The loudspeakers were used to blare out instructions and propaganda from the party. "We took it down last year," the villager said. "No one wanted to listen to it anymore. We have stereo and TV now."
There are many things you learn observing village elections in China, but the overriding impression is this: Not only is China's move toward a free market irreversible, it is now being driven as much from the villages up as from Beijing down. When people say that in China today the Government's only ideology -- and basis of legitimacy -- is its ability to keep incomes rising, they are so right. Ideologically, the Chinese Communist Party is dead. 
 In the village campaign speeches we heard, the Communist Party was mentioned in only the most perfunctory references. Instead every candidate dwelled on his commitment to be "practical" or "pragmatic" in finding ways to raise village incomes. Sure, the party is still in control, but without any message. None. That's why they've taken down the loudspeaker. There's only one message from the party to the masses now: GET A JOB.
Indeed, what is so striking out here on the Nebraska-like plains of Manchuria is that the same pressures on advanced economies -- to downsize and streamline government, to seek out foreign investors, to plug into global markets and to become more competitive and more diversified -- are squeezing Chinese villages as well. Almost no one is beyond the frontiers of globalization anymore, even Heng Dao village. As China becomes integrated into the global market, the Chinese regime is being forced to reduce subsidies to state industries, reduce social benefits and pressure the whole society to become more competitive. That leads to pressure on the provinces and then the counties, and ultimately it trickles down to Heng Dao, where water buffalo share the roads with motor scooters. Listen to the campaign speeches for village chief here and tell me they don't sound as if they're running for mayor of Toledo, Ohio.
The incumbent, Jiang Ying: "I have tried to be very pragmatic in leading the village on the road to wealth. Our annual income is now 2,300 yuan per year. The budget is much smaller and during my tenure we've gotten many cadres off the village payroll. If elected, we need to introduce more science and technology into agriculture, get more enterprises here and speed up procedures for generating wealth . . . because the whole world is turning into one big market for merchandise."
I asked him where he got such ideas. The village has only one phone. He answered: "I read newspapers. I listen to radio. We have a window-frame factory here. Right now we only sell locally, but we were told that if we improved the quality, we can sell abroad, make more money."
His challenger, Chen Guoshuang, vowed: "I will bring happiness to the village. I will use more technology, which is the key to bringing wealth. First, we must diversify our economy. Families in Brigade 8 planted strawberries in hothouses and made much profit. We are near the paved road. We should be in the shipping business. One of our villagers did that last year and earned 10,000 yuan. Really! We can walk with many legs. We will operate our window-frame factory according to market demands. We must learn all about the market for aluminum and improve our factory. With profitable village enterprises, we can reduce taxes and our children can go to school without us having to pay fees."
So there you have it: Tip O'Neill was wrong. All politics isn't local. All politics is global. Almost everyone now is feeling the same pressures, constraints and opportunities, almost every government, no matter how big or small, is having to put on the same Golden Straitjacket -- which increases economic growth, but shrinks political choices.
Just ask Chen Guoshuang, Jiang Ying and the Mayor of Toledo, Ohio.

HEADLINE: U.S. Training of Indonesia Troops Goes On Despite Ban

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
The Pentagon has been training Indonesian military forces in specialized arts of warfare since 1992, despite a Congressional ban intended to curb human rights abuses by those soldiers, Defense Department documents show.
The Indonesian forces trained by the Pentagon include a special-forces commando unit called Kopassus, which human rights groups say has tortured and killed civilians. The unit has received training from United States special-operations soldiers in skills like psychological warfare and reconnaissance missions. 
 Pentagon officials said the training program was entirely legal, since it took place under a program different from the one curtailed by Congress. Deputy Secretary of Defense John J. Hamre said in a letter to a member of Congress last month that the training "enhances rather than diminishes our ability to positively influence Indonesia's human rights policies and behavior."
Some members of Congress question that. Representative Christopher H. Smith, a Republican of New Jersey, said the training program "appears to be a dramatic end run around the rules that Congress has carefully prescribed for military training and education of Indonesian forces."
Indonesia is undergoing its greatest political and economic crisis since President Suharto took power in 1965. Last week the newly appointed Minister of Defense, Gen. Wiranto, warned that the Government would crack down hard on demonstrators protesting repression and corruption.
The troops trained by the Pentagon over the past five years include Kopassus, whose Red Berets have been deployed this year against street demonstrators in Jakarta; an army strategic command group called Kostrad that helps control the center of Java and Mr. Suharto's presidential guard. General Wiranto did not specify what troops would be used in such a crackdown.
Mr. Hamre's argument and the documents detailing the training were contained in a letter sent last month to Representative Lane A. Evans of Illinois, a Democrat. The letter and the documents were made public today by the East Timor Action Network, which is a human rights group, and by a reporter and activist, Allan Nairn. Mr. Nairn, who was beaten severely, arrested and permanently banned from Indonesia in November 1991 after witnessing a massacre of more than 270 civilians by Indonesian troops on the island of East Timor, published an article in The Nation today describing the training.
In 1992 Congress banned Indonesia from receiving Pentagon training in the arts of war under the program most commonly used for such courses, known as International Military Education and Training, or Imet.
The Pentagon kept up its training -- but under a different program, known as Joint Combined Exchange and Training, or J-Cet. This was a legal way to avoid the Congressional ban, since the joint program was financed through "a different pot of money" than was Imet, and thus was unaffected by the ban, a Pentagon official said.
Representative Evans conceded that the training was legal, but called it "the Pentagon's loophole to the ban." He said he was "curious to know why U.S. taxpayer dollars are being wasted on aiding and abetting a ruthless military organization."
The training "is certainly not within the spirit" of the law, said Representative Nancy Pelosi, a Democrat of California. "It raises serious questions about a violation of Congressional intent. It is clear that it is a circumvention of Congress."
Grover Joseph Rees, an aide to Representative Smith, said: "We have all these restrictions on Imet and they just get around it by using J-Cet." He added: "They did the same thing in Rwanda -- they give marksmanship training to people who may be participating in massacres."
The J-Cet program provided training in psychological operations and marksmanship to the Rwandan Patriotic Army, which has been accused of the massacre of civilians in eastern Zaire.
The Pentagon was unable to say today how much the J-Cet training program for Indonesia cost, how many troops were trained or which military office ran the program.
A Defense Department official, who would not be quoted by name, said the program was no secret to well-informed members of Congress. She said it was "better to train and engage and interact and gain influence with successive generations of Indonesia officers" than to stop the training. She could cite no evidence that the training improved those officers' respect for human rights.
Congress partly restored financing for training in Indonesia in 1995, under an expanded Imet program, which was intended to limit training to human rights, civilian control and accountability. But under the program, Indonesia was able to buy at least one course in military training directly from the Pentagon, which was another legal way around the legislation, Pentagon officials said.
