HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE VOLUNTEER;
White House Attacks Credibility Of Aide Who Accused Clinton

BYLINE: By JILL ABRAMSON and DON VAN NATTA Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
In the four years since she said she endured an unwanted sexual encounter in the Oval Office with President Clinton, Kathleen E. Willey seemed to maintain a cordial relationship with the President, according to correspondence released by the White House today. She wrote him a series of friendly notes and asked him for help getting jobs, the letters show.
The former White House aide, who vividly described an aggressive sexual advance by the President in an interview on Sunday night on the CBS News program "60 Minutes," also enthusiastically praised Mr. Clinton during a visit with a mutual friend one year after the disputed encounter at the White House, the friend said. 
 A fuller portrait of Ms. Willey began to emerge today as the Clinton Administration questioned her credibility, by releasing letters and messages from Ms. Willey in an effort to undercut her claims that the President behaved improperly toward her. The notes contained many warm messages to the President, some signed, "Fondly, Kathleen" and one describing herself as Mr. Clinton's "No. 1 fan."
On Nov. 29, 1993, the same day that Ms. Willey met with the President, her husband committed suicide although she did not learn of his death until the following day. Former business associates of her husband have raised questions about her behavior in the days following her husband's death, saying today that she blamed them in a series of late-night threatening phone calls.
In all, the White House released 15 notes written by Ms. Willey, beginning in May 1993 and ending in November 1996. Nine of the notes were written after the Oval Office encounter.Within a month of their meeting, Ms. Willey wrote Mr. Clinton a note, wishing him a "wonderful Christmas" and thanking him for "the opportunity to work in this great house." She added that she hoped that she would get a "meaningful job" in the White House. Ms. Willey was hired for a secretarial job in the White House counsel's office several months later.
Some notes are effusive. In one hand-written card, dated nearly a year after they met in 1993, Ms. Willey wrote: "Dear Mr. President: You have been on my mind so often this week -- There are so very many people who believe in you and what you are trying to do for our country.
"Take heart in knowing that your number one fan thanks you every day for your help in saving her wonderful state -- With appreciation, Kathleen."
In the interview broadcast on Sunday, Ms. Willey described herself as shocked and angry at Mr. Clinton's attempt to kiss and grope her. She said she was outraged by the President's "recklessness" and that she had considered slapping him across the face. "And then I thought, 'Well, I don't think you can slap the President of the United States like that.' "
At an appearance at a high school in Silver Spring, Md. today, Mr. Clinton, repeated his denial of any inappropriate actions toward Ms. Willey. "Nothing improper happened," the President said. Page A20.
"I am mystified and disappointed by this turn of events," he added.
The White House carefully culled and released Ms. Willey's correspondence and messages to him. But the White House provided only a partial record of the President's communications with Ms. Willey.
The letters are not definitive and do not clear up all the questions arising from Ms. Willey's account of the Oval Office episode, said Joe Lockhart, deputy White House press secretary. In his deposition last January in the Paula Corbin Jones sexual misconduct lawsuit, Mr. Clinton denied under oath Mrs. Willey's accusation that he kissed her and touched her in a sexual manner.
Some of the notes from Ms. Willey include requests for the President to help her find work, a fact her lawyer readily acknowledged. "The letters were nothing more than an attempt to get work because she was unemployed," said the lawyer, Daniel Gecker. "She needed a job." Ms. Willey had no college degree, so her most promising employment connections were at the White House.
The President's lawyer, Robert S. Bennett, said in an interview tonight that Mr. Clinton had not been treated fairly on "60 Minutes."
"It is a show with a viewpoint," Mr. Bennett told Larry King on the Cable News Network, adding that the CBS News program had omitted crucial facts. For one thing, Mr. Bennett said, Ms. Willey's lawyer, Mr. Gecker, had been trying to sell a book on Ms. Willey's behalf until a few days before her Sunday appearance on "60 Minutes."
Mr. Gecker denied tonight that he is seeking a book contract for Ms. Willey. However, he said that four or five months ago, he had approached Michael Viner, the head of New Millenium Press, about a book by Ms. Willey. "I had just read that Paula Barbieri got $3 million, and I thought that was a lot of money," Mr. Gecker said in an interview from his home in Richmond. Ms. Barbieri was once a girlfriend of O.J. Simpson.
But Mr. Gecker said that Mr. Viner told him that such a book was worth "next to nothing," and the discussions ended there. They did not resume until this past Friday when Mr. Gecker said that Mr. Viner called him to inquire again about a book on Ms. Willey, suggesting that her upcoming appearance on "60 Minutes" might ignite new interest.
Mr. Gecker said that he was noncommittal with Mr. Viner, but he said tonight: "We're not looking for a book deal. There is no market for anti-Clinton books."
The correspondence released by the White House today shows that, as Ms. Willey's secretarial job in the counsel's office was ending in 1994, she met again with the President. She then wrote him a note to express her disappointment, and asked to be considered for an ambassadorial post.
"I have invested almost three years with your campaign and Administration and am not very willing to depart yet," Ms. Willey wrote in the Oct. 18, 1994, note. "I would like to be considered for an ambassadorship or a position in an embassy overseas."
Subsequently, Ms. Willey succeeded in winning appointments to two overseas Government conferences in Copenhagen and Jakarta, Indonesia. President Clinton also named her to the board of the United Service Organization.
The friendly tone of Ms. Willey's correspondence with the President is consistent with a description of her given by a friend, Thomas Siebert, who worked with Ms. Willey in Mr. Clinton's 1992 campaign.
Mr. Siebert, an Annapolis, Md., lawyer who served as Ambassador to Sweden, and his wife invited Ms. Willey to Stockholm over the Christmas holidays in 1994. Mr. Siebert said it was a difficult time for her because Ms. Willey was away from her children.
The Sieberts and Ms. Willey spent much of the week talking about the President. Mr. Siebert said Ms. Willey spoke in glowing terms and said she believed he was doing an outstanding job. Mr. Siebert said he was at a loss to explain her description of Mr. Clinton on "60 Minutes" because he thought Ms. Willey had only friendly feelings toward him.
Before she departed to visit the Sieberts, Ms. Willey wrote the President to wish him a happy holiday and to tell him about her trip. "I can hardly contain myself -- I am so excited," she wrote.
In late 1995, Ms. Willey contacted the President again to ask for a fund-raising job for his re-election campaign. In a Dec. 21, 1995, letter, the President responded, "It sounds like you're on the right track."
At the request of the White House, Ms. Willey was interviewed for a paid fund-raising position at the Democratic National Committee in February 1996. She was offered a job but turned it down, said a Democratic Party aide who insisted on anonymity.
New details also emerged today about the aftermath of the suicide of Ms. Willey's husband, Ed Willey Jr. Ms. Willey had gone to the White House on Nov. 29, 1993, in a attempt to get a paying job because her husband was facing mounting legal and financial problems.
The night following her husband's death, Ms. Willey placed several harassing phone calls to some of her late husband's clients, said a former client of her husband. At the same time, she left a more composed message for the President, saying that he could contact her "anytime."
The client, Anthony Lanasa, said Ms. Willey called him in the middle of the night and accused him of driving her husband to kill himself. "She called at three in the morning and said, 'You killed my husband. It's your fault that he's dead,' " said Mr. Lanasa, 59, who owns a produce company in Richmond, where Ms. Willey lives. Ms. Willey made similar calls, late at night, to Mr. Lanasa's lawyer, Mr. Lanasa said.
Both men filed a complaint against Ms. Willey and a warrant was issued for her arrest, said Joseph Kaestner, who represented Mr. Lanasa in litigation over the $275,000 Mr. Willey embezzled from him. Ms. Willey has not repaid the money, according to Mr. Kaestner.
Ms. Willey was charged with allowing a telephone to ring without intent to converse, a misdemeanor in Virginia, said Mr. Gecker, her lawyer. The charge was dismissed six months later, he said.
Last November, Ms. Willey wrote a note to Nancy Hernreich, the President's appointments secretary, to ask to be invited to the White House Christmas party. Three months earlier, Ms. Willey had been subpoenaed to testify in the Paula Jones lawsuit.
"I think of you often," she wrote to Ms. Hernreich, "and hope that you are managing to escape the intrustions that have plagued so many of us who are friends of the President."

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK;
Connecticut Man Guilty Of Internet Indecency

 BODY:
A 57-year-old unemployed sales consultant was convicted in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday of sending indecent materials over the Internet to a person he thought was a 13-year-old girl and trying to coax her into having sex.
The man, James Barrows of Madison, Conn., was arrested in December 1996 after showing up for what he thought would be a sexual rendezvous with the girl in Gerritsen Beach, Brooklyn. The meeting resulted from an undercover operation involving a detective posing as a 13-year-old girl on the America Online Internet service. 
 Prosecutors said they believed the case was the first successful conviction under a 1996 state law prohibiting the dissemination of pornographic material to minors on the Internet.
Mr. Barrows was convicted of two counts of attempting to disseminate indecent material to minors and one count of promoting an obscene sexual performance by a child. Sentencing is scheduled for April 27. He faces two and a third to seven years in jail.

HEADLINE: Jury Selection Begins in First Death Penalty Case Since 1983

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
For the first time in 15 years in New York State, a group of potential jurors was bluntly asked a life-or-death question yesterday: If they convicted a man of murdering three people during a robbery, could they sentence him to die?
The people who were asked the question in a Brooklyn courtroom often answered with words or tones or pauses that showed they were struggling with uncertain or conflicting feelings -- whether they answered that they could impose the death penalty on the defendant, Darrel K. Harris, or could never impose it under any circumstances. 
 The prospective jurors were closely questioned to determine whether they should be selected for the first death penalty trial in the state since capital punishment was reinstated in New York three years ago.
Mr. Harris, 40, a former New York City correction officer, is accused of the triple murder while robbing patrons of a social club in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, in 1996.
The jury selection, which began last week with about 500 prospective jurors filling out questionnaires about themselves and their views on capital punishment, moved to the courtroom yesterday as the judge, prosecution and defense began interviewing the more than 300 who were not excused based on their written answers.
By the end of the day, seven potential jurors had been closely questioned, one at a time, and two had been chosen for the preliminary pool from which the final selections are to be made in about a month.
If yesterday was any indication, the selection process will be a searching one not only for those asking the questions in State Supreme Court, but for the prospective jurors themselves.
"I think capital punishment is necessary but I wish it were not," said a middle-aged woman who works as a customer service representative for a financial company. But asked whether she could ultimately vote for the death penalty, the woman said, "Yes, after everything is taken into consideration."
The woman, who like all the other prospective jurors, was identified only by number, cited such factors as Mr. Harris's background and the circumstances of the crimes.
Under the death penalty law, a jury that finds a defendant guilty of first-degree murder then must decide between execution by injection or life in prison without possibility of parole.
But an unemployed mechanic, a Vietnam veteran who was also middle-aged, said he did not think that he could vote for the death penalty.
The woman was accepted for the pool, the man was not. Under the death penalty law, lawyers may object to prospective jurors whose views are so fixed that they could never vote for this penalty, or those who would always impose it. Prosecutors raised objections about the man, and Acting Justice Anne G. Feldman excused him from serving.
Three of the seven potential jurors questioned yesterday said they could vote for the death penalty if they deemed it warranted, three indicated they never could vote for execution, and the views of one, who was among those excused, was unclear.
The last death penalty trial in the state occurred in 1983 under a provision of the previous capital punishment law.
The defendant, Lemuel Smith, was convicted of first-degree murder and sentenced to death, but the state's highest court struck down the provision the next year and Mr. Smith is serving a life sentence.

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 2; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1844 words

HEADLINE: Eating Out in Moscow: Theme-Park Cuisine

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 17

 BODY:
Unruly and almost lawless, Russia today is often compared to Chicago in the roaring 20's -- a free-market jungle where businessmen settle scores with gun blasts, bureaucrats line their pockets and vast fortunes are amassed overnight. But when it comes to the novel pursuit of fine dining, Moscow is closer to Los Angeles in the 30's.
A little like the early Hollywood land-grabbers whose homes reflected their delusions of grandeur -- Moorish castles, Spanish haciendas, Gothic chateaus, Roman villas -- today's Russian restaurateurs are unfurling their richest fantasies uninhibited by tradition or conventional notions of good taste. In Soviet times, there were few restaurants, and no good ones. Over the last two years, newly rich Russians have confected dozens of restaurants that have less to do with haute cuisine than high concept -- lavish gastronomic theme parks for rich adults. 
 At one of the most popular, Czar skaya Okhota, whose name means "the Czar's hunt," guests are sucked into a culinary Disney World of wolf skins, cannons, bearskin rugs, busts of Russian emperors, mounted reindeer heads, stuffed partridges hanging from wall sconces and even an indoor water mill and a curved wooden bridge.
Hordes of waiters, dressed as serfs in red tunics and red boots, scurry from table to table, silently and deferentially serving dishes like Bonfire-Scented Leg of Game and Herring Under Boyar's Fur Coat. Only the incessant beeping of cellular phones punctuates the feudal atmosphere.
Czarskaya Okhota was created a year ago as a playground for the bankers, businessmen and mobsters who make up the class known as new Russians. They are about the only ones who can afford the ticket: dinner for two is rarely under $250 at restaurants like this one, high even by New York standards. The prices are unthinkable by ordinary Russian standards; the average monthly salary in Moscow is $200.
The restaurant is the brainchild of Arkady Novikov, 35, a former Soviet chef who has transformed himself into the leading new Russian restaurateur. With little foreign travel or background in European dining (he was rejected for a job at a Moscow McDonald's), Mr. Novikov grabs for inspiration like a shopper hellbent on completing a supermarket sweepstakes.
The czarist motif came to him in an antiques store as he leafed through an old leather-bound book about imperial hunting lodges. The inspiration for the restaurant's heavy wood paneling and wooden beams came from a Swiss chalet scene in the Jim Carrey comedy "Dumb and Dumber."
"I never went abroad until 1993," said Mr. Novikov, who studied cooking at the Soviet Institute of the People's Economy. "I get my ideas where I can."
GUIDED by the giddy thrill of sudden, seemingly limitless wealth, rich Russians take an almost childlike delight in fanciful nights out. They are drawn to theme restaurants that combine good, costly food with opulent fantasy and gastronomic special effects.
Partly, it is a cultural tradition. Under Communism there were few restaurants, and almost all were vast, dingy hotel dining rooms with hostile service, drab food, live (very loud) music and frenetic dancing.
"Russians' relationship to restaurants was never functional, and it was never about dining -- you didn't go out to get something to eat," said Stas Namin, 46, a rock musician and big real estate investor, who is a co-owner of Czarskaya Okhota. Namin is his stage name; he was born Anastas Mikoyan, the grandson of the one of Stalin's top aides in the Politburo.
"In Soviet times, there wasn't any good food anywhere," Mr. Namin continued. "People went out for special occasions expecting to be entertained."
And they still do. If in New York the cognoscenti seem on an endless quest for the burnished understatement of a neighborhood Parisian brasserie, Russians like their food served up aux Folies-Bergere.
Serena, a seafood restaurant that Mr. Novikov opened in 1992 as a nautical wonderland, has huge sturgeon and pike swimming beneath glass floors under diners' feet. Waiters in blue and white sailor suits look as if they had just left the imperial yacht. The dinner plates are shaped like clamshells. Even the food has a rich fantasy life: Broken Heart of Scotch Salmon ($37), salmon baked in a flaky puff pastry, is served heart-shaped and pierced by a long, thin wooden dagger, with blood (actually cranberry sauce) oozing from the wound.
Beloye Solntze Pustyni, which Mr. Novikov opened four months ago, offers expensive and delicious Uzbek food in a dizzyingly exotic desert-oasis setting borrowed from a popular Russian movie, "White Sun of the Desert." Guests feast on plov, a spicy Central Asian rice dish ($18) and lamb shashlik ($20), alongside plaster figures of Central Asian bandits being massacred by handsome Red Guards. Russian waitresses are dressed in bejeweled Uzbek native costume, and water trickles from fake waterfalls and rock gardens.
He also created Club T, an Empire-style haute cuisine restaurant that is less 18th-century Paris than 1950's Bel Air; with its gilded putti sconces, crystal chandeliers and pink and gold draperies it could be a boudoir designed for Eva Gabor.
The food, prepared by a 31-year-old French chef, Patrice Tereygeol, is excellent if old-fashioned, with entrees like feuillete of pheasant stuffed with foie gras ($36) and stuffed cabbage with scampi in a butter caviar sauce ($66). A recent lunch for two, with one of the cheapest wines on the menu, a 1993 Medoc ($70), came to just over $300 without dessert.
The clientele, which includes some of Russia's richest and most powerful tycoons, does not blink at dropping nearly $1,600 for a 1978 Petrus. Mr. Tereygeol explained with an apologetic shrug that the cost of flying in French wines and fresh turbot is high. So are customers' expectations.
"I would love to lower the prices and attract more expatriates," he said. "Foreigners cannot afford to eat here. But Russians think that if it costs less, it must be less good."
KONSTANTIN ERNST, a filmmaker and television executive, joined the trend and recently opened Shinok, whose name means roadside cafe in Ukrainian. This restaurant, in busy downtown Moscow, offers gussied-up peasant food, including $12 krovyanka (blood sausage) and an appetizer of salo (salted pig fat) for $3.50 in a contrived setting worthy of Marie Antoinette: live horses, chickens and goats graze amid fake grass and bushes in a glassed-in farmyard. The prices, however, are urban: about $70 a person, wine not included. And there is nothing folksy about the unsmiling armed security guards at the front door who look over visitors as if they were poorly disguised suicide bombers.
The Prague, a famous old restaurant on the Old Arbat that was a favorite haunt of Tolstoy, was reopened in August after a $31 million makeover, the pet project of Telman Ismaelov, a wealthy businessman. It now houses a variety of theme restaurants -- Brazilian, Asian and Italian -- as well as the Czar's Hall, where waiters wear gold-embroidered coats and powdered wigs and patrons pay at least $100 each.
Mostly, it is the new rich who can afford such places, though there is a rising Russian middle class -- salesmen, accountants, advertising executives -- that is increasingly able to afford a night on the town, if a less extravagant one.
A Western-managed Russian chain, Rosinter, has several Moscow restaurants, including the American Bar and Grill, Patio Pizza and a recently opened TGI Friday's. (The bill at TGI Friday's is about $28 a person, nearly twice as high as in the United States.) Henrik Winthur, an American who is the general director of restaurant operations for Rosinter, said he believed that less expensive restaurants aimed at the new middle class were the key to the future. Mr. Winthur expressed some puzzlement about the theme restaurants preferred by the city's wealthiest citizens.
"I'm not sure I am able to explain it," he said, "except that it's like being locked up in a candy store overnight."
When capitalism made its debut in the late 1980's, restaurants, like casinos, shops and outdoor kiosks, were easy prey for gangsters, who either invested in them to launder money or extorted a cut of the profits. Restaurants remain a risky business: the Russian partner in Tren-Mos, one of the first American restaurants in Moscow, was gunned down in 1993. His American partner left the country, and the restaurant has since closed. This winter, a bomb was tossed through the window of a McDonald's restaurant under construction in central St. Petersburg. No one was injured, but the damage was extensive.
Many restaurants are mob-owned, but few flaunt it anymore. The market, moreover, has matured since the early 1990's. Small establishments are still vulnerable to extortion (from gangsters or corrupt municipal officials), but the chains and big operators have established close relationships with leading law enforcement officials. To further hedge their bets, they also pay private security companies (usually staffed by former K.G.B. officers) to rid them of pesky intruders.
Behind carved doors watched by armed security guards and men dressed as boyars, Czarskaya Okhoya opened last year in Zhukovka, a dacha community outside Moscow that once was the exclusive, well-guarded preserve of Politburo members and is now the exclusive, well-guarded preserve of bankers, oil tycoons and real estate developers.
Expatriates refer to the area as the Hamptons, and on Saturday nights, the restaurant's parking lot is jammed with Mercedes 600's, Lexuses, Audis and Jeep Cherokees. Ambassadors, visiting rock stars like Tina Turner and Rod Stewart and foreign dignitaries rub shoulders with muscle-bound men in black turtlenecks and their scantily clad molls. President Boris N. Yeltsin took President Jacques Chirac of France there for dinner last year. Mr. Chirac signed the guest book, a huge leather-bound volume kept in a locked glass case, by scrawling, somewhat dryly, "It is true that there is a market economy in Russia."
MR. NOVIKOV, who got his start as a cook at Viktoriya, one of the first cooperative restaurants, which was opened by Mr. Namin during perestroika in the late 1980's, is building a huge dacha in the neighborhood. The old Mikoyan dacha -- a vast, sprawling estate where Mr. Namin spent his childhood -- is now rented by one of Moscow's most successful real estate developers for $35,000 a month. Mr. Namin has built his own dacha, a modern ski-lodge-style house the size of a cathedral. Like those of most of their customers, the two men's country houses are a few minutes' drive from Czarskaya Okhota.
Mr. Novikov is already dreaming up his next gastronomic adventure, a giant pink restaurant in the shape of an elephant's rear, where waitresses would dress according to the food they served: mutton served by a waitress dressed as a lamb, chicken by one in a hen costume.
He does not intend it as a children's restaurant. "In Russia, adults are children," he said. "This is for them."

HEADLINE: Industrial Production Is Unchanged; Housing Soars

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
Industrial production was unchanged in February even as the nation's housing market boomed, signs that domestic demand was offsetting whatever ill effects the economy was feeling from Asia's crisis.
The Federal Reserve reported today that production at factories, mines and utilities stalled last month after rising one-tenth of 1 percent in January. Manufacturing output also also held steady last month, the first time that has happened since October 1996, suggesting that American exporters might have been reacting to less demand for their goods. 
 In a separate report, the Commerce Department said that housing starts rose 6 percent in February, well above January's increase of two-tenths of 1 percent. February's gain brought the annual rate of new starts to its highest level in more than a decade.
"Manufacturing is probably being slowed by an impact from Asia, but it's not showing up in the overall economy," said John Ryding, senior economist at Bear, Stearns & Company in New York.
As industrial output slowed last month, the amount of factory capacity in use fell to 82.7 percent from 83 percent in January. That was far below the 85 percent level at which economists believe inflationary bottlenecks might develop.
Unusually mild February weather helped limit industrial production and aided housing. Utility output rose only nine-tenths of 1 percent, while home builders worked in regions where winter weather usually halts construction.
Led by big gains in the Northeast, housing starts rose to an annual rate of 1.64 million units in February, the highest since November 1987.
February was the sixth consecutive month in which the annual rate of new starts exceeded 1.5 million, the longest such stretch since the end of 1987. In January, starts rose a revised two-tenths of 1 percent, in contrast to the decline of three-tenths of 1 percent reported initially.
Permits for new housing construction, a gauge of coming demand, rose 6.5 percent, to a 1.63 million annual rate in February.
Housing's strength was also evident in the Fed's production report, which showed that output of construction supplies rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month, while household appliance production rose two-tenths of 1 percent. Those bright spots were offset by declines in the production of other consumer goods and business equipment. Each category fell two-tenths of 1 percent.

SECTION: Section B; Page 9; Column 1; National Desk; Education Page

LENGTH: 1887 words

HEADLINE: Be It Wharton or Darla Moore, Not for Nothing Is a B-School So Named

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
Darla Moore really does have it all: After growing up on a small South Carolina farm, she goes to Wall Street and becomes a queen of capitalism. She marries a fellow deal maker worth around $1.5 billion and has a career so meteoric that it propels her onto the cover of Fortune magazine, which terms her the "toughest babe" in business.
Now, Ms. Moore, 43, who mixes a soft Southern drawl with cutthroat business instincts, is entering a realm typically reserved for aging captains of industry. She is having a business school named after her. 
 This month, the University of South Carolina business school will become the Darla Moore School of Business after the woman who made a fortune specializing in bankruptcy financing, including that of Macy's.
And like Joseph Wharton (University of Pennsylvania), Amos Tuck (Dartmouth College) and John Kellogg (Northwestern University), Ms. Moore was able get this honor because she was rich enough to write a check big enough -- $25 million -- to warrant the renaming of a school.
In the world of philanthropy, this is called a naming opportunity -- a chance to immortalize one's name, be honored by one's alma mater and donate a significant amount of money to a worthy cause. As a roaring economy has created massive wealth in the last decade and as business schools solicit even more money to compete for students and rankings, naming opportunities are on the rise.
In 1997, $87 million was donated to business schools for renamings, according to the American Assembly of Collegiate Schools of Business, a trade association. This compares with $77 million in 1996, $45 million in 1995 and $29 million in 1994.
There is the Michael F. Price School of Business at the University of Oklahoma, named for the mutual fund wizard who donated $18 million for the honor. Edward W. Kelley, an executive who heads the Steak 'N Shake food chain and who helped develop Tang beverages, Lean Cuisine foods and Grey Poupon mustard and first put pearl onions into frozen peas, just donated $23 million to Indiana University for the Kelley School of Business.
A $35 million donation from Gordon S. Marshall, a computer parts distributor, led to the Gordon S. Marshall School of Management at the University of Southern California. A $10 million donation from the late Roberto C. Goizueta caused Emory University to rename its school in honor of the former chief executive of Coca-Cola.
The same amount, $10 million, from Jenny Craig Weight Loss Centers named the Sid Craig School of Business at California State University, and $10 million from the late Hugh F. Culverhouse, owner of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, created the Culverhouse College of Commerce at the University of Alabama.
The money comes from the famous as well as the obscure. A $15 million donation led to the naming of the J. Willard and Alice S. Marriott School of Business at Brigham Young University, and Carol Martin Gatton, a Tennessee car dealer, gave $14 million to create a business school in his name at the University of Kentucky.
An Ivy League opportunity awaits. Columbia University made it known that it would consider renaming its business school for $60 million. So far there have been no takers, even after several years of looking.
"One obvious reason we see this is because there is more money around," said David H. Blake, dean of the graduate school of management at the University of California, Irvine. "And there's a bit of a competitive element to it. You are talking about people who have made a career out of being competitive. 'By gosh, if I can do this, I can help my school.' "
Mr. Blake added that his No. 1 priority is to get his school renamed. The asking price is $25 million.
Renaming a business school does more than raise money; it can also raise a school's visibility and give it new connections. For the donor, the payoff is in increased status and recognition. For the school, an association with a famous entrepreneur, a notable industrialist or a Wall Street wizard makes a statement about the school's image and identity.
And that's what brought the University of South Carolina together with Ms. Moore, who created a name for herself, and her first millions, as a Wall Street specialist in bankruptcy financing. Later, after her marriage in 1991 to Richard Rainwater, one of American's nimblest investors, she took over her husband's stock portfolio and tripled his net worth. Along the way, she developed the reputation as a business toughie, leading investor charges that brought down the corporate raider T. Boone Pickens and helped shake up the scandal-ridden hospital company Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation.
But what characterized Ms. Moore was her style. She was as comfortable with flirting as with finance.
"I have a soft way of swinging the bat," Ms. Moore said, adding, "A bankruptcy friend once said, 'She'll take your shirt off, but it will feel so good while she does it.' "
For the university, the association with Ms. Moore was a way to raise its visibility. It is the first major business school to be named after a woman, and a daughter of rural South Carolina, as well. She received a bachelor's degree in political science from the school but received her master's in business administration from George Washington University after moving to Washington and working for Senator Strom Thurmond, the South Carolina Republican.
The South Carolina business school, which has an undergraduate and graduate enrollment of 3,000 and a $10 million endowment, is ranked No. 2 in international business by U.S. News & World Report but has yet to break into that magazine's list of the top 50, or crack the rating list of Business Week.
"The school consciously wanted to do something that was different," Ms. Moore said in an interview. "And I had the female thing, the native-daughter-who-went-away-and-made-good thing, and the youth thing. All of these are different than the image of the Deep South, and that appealed to the school in a big way. I think it was very shrewd on their part, frankly."
The wooing took place at the Florence, S.C., country club where two South Carolinians, Hugh McColl, chief executive of Nationsbank Corporation, and W. W. Hootie Johnson, chairman of the bank's executive committee, met last October with Ms. Moore and Mr. Rainwater. Mr. McColl would like to get the school's graduates to work at his bank, just an hour's drive away, while Mr. Johnson, an alumnus, heads the university's current $300 million capital fund-raising drive.
"We had a call from Hugh McColl and he said he had to see us," Ms. Moore said. "He actually called Richard, and would fly anywhere on the face of the earth to see us. We thought it had something to do with our real estate company. We told him we were at my farm in South Carolina, so we met at the country club for lunch. And Hugh brought Hootie along. Hugh didn't have to go far, even though he was willing to go to Timbuktu.
"We were waiting for the punch line and wondering when they were going to bring up the real estate company when finally McColl says, 'We're here to propose naming the business school at U.S.C. after Darla.' "
Their reaction? "Neither of us could say anything for a while," said Ms. Moore, whose donation, which is tax deductible, will be spread over four years. "I was dumbfounded for all the obvious reasons. It's not with my being female, but with being young. It's a risk they are taking. Anyone my age could go out and blow their reputation. I've still got time to blow my reputation in the business community."
As for Mr. Rainwater, a man who wooed his wife by telling her he viewed her as he would an "equity investment," Ms. Moore said, "He was clear in saying, 'You should do it.' "
It was really Hootie Johnson who got the ball rolling. "First, she is a South Carolinian and a highly successful businesswoman," he said, "and she is very wealthy. It just made sense to me when we contemplated naming the school for a person who could make a substantial gift. She is a high-profile person and that would be important to the university from a national standpoint."
The naming of schools after wealthy benefactors goes back to 1638, when John Harvard, a minister from Charlestown, Mass., gave his library to a new school, a bargain by today's standards.
The first business school was started by Joseph Wharton, who endowed the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania with $100,000 in 1881. The business school naming trend got a big lift in the late 1970's when Northwestern University and Duke University each received $10 million and created the Kellogg School of Management and the Fuqua School of Business, respectively.
But it was in this decade that the trend accelerated. "Naming prices are escalating," said Charles Hickman, director of projects at the American Assembly of Collegiate Schools of Business. "I have no reason to think it will stop because the factors driving it are not going away."
Lucky for business schools, their graduates go out and make a lot of money. "We have a large number of graduates who have capacity to make a $60 million donation," said Meyer Feldberg, dean of the Columbia Business School. "We are fortunate in that we have quite a large number of alums whose assets are in excess of $1 billion."
Money, however, does not always lead to a successful outcome. After Karl Eller, a business entrepreneur, gave money to have the business school at the University of Arizona named for him, he went bankrupt. Lucky for both, he has since recovered and is back in business.
Business school deans cringe when they think about the Robert O. Anderson business school at the University of New Mexico. Mr. Anderson, the former chairman of Arco, gave the school about $500,000, and the school, hoping he would give more, named the business school for him. To their dismay, he did not. Still, the business school held a "Robert O. Anderson Appreciation Day" last year, and Howard Smith, the dean, said, "we treasure" the school's relationship with Mr. Anderson.
Then there was Ivan Boesky, who went to prison for insider trading violations and had to withdraw a $1.5 million pledge to Princeton University's religious center.
"The most creative and puzzling example of fund-raising was at a school where there was a plaque to an alumnus outside the men's room," said Mr. Blake of the University of California, Irvine. "I couldn't figure out if the donor had a great sense of humor, the school was just a terrific fund-raiser and raised money for everything or if this was put up for a donor who reneged on his pledge."
Ms. Moore is not the first woman to have a business school with her name on it. There is the Gladys Kelce School of Business at Pittsburg State University in Pittsburg, Kan. Mrs. Kelce, the widow of a wealthy coal company owner, donated $500,000 to the school in the late 1970's. The money was used to move the business school out of a local high school into a new building.
Marshall University in West Virginia named its 2,000-student business school after Elizabeth McDowell Lewis, an alumna who donated more than $2 million. "It wasn't a naming opportunity," said Wade Gilley, the school's president. "She was just such a terrific supporter that we wanted to honor her."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Rally Fades on Mixed Economic Signs

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
An early bond market rally quickly faded yesterday and prices finished lower, hurt by mixed signals on the economy's strength.
The 30-year Treasury bond fell 7/16 in price, to 103 9/32, while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.89 percent, from 5.86 percent Monday. The market got an initial boost from a report by the Federal Reserve that showed industrial production remained unchanged last month, well short of the two-tenths of a percent gain expected, and that factory use fell to 82.7 percent of capacity in February compared with 83 percent in January. Still, investors were reluctant to pay more for Treasury securities without stronger proof that the economy is slowing. 
 The market may also have been weakened by a report from the Commerce Department that showed housing starts surged 6 percent last month to an annual rate of 1.6 million units, higher than 1.5 million units expected. Although the strength partly reflected the unseasonably warm winter, it was also a reminder that growth in housing could lead to higher consumer spending and greater inflationary pressure.
There was speculation that the bond market might receive more friendly data tomorrow when the Labor Department releases its February Consumer Price Index.
Some forecasters are calling for only a marginal gain in the index, which could help diminish fears of higher inflation. But Anthony Chan, managing director and chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said the market was also focused on the weekly unemployment data.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES;
Crude Oil Falls Further; Some Gasoline Near $1 a Gallon

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Crude oil sold below $13 for the first time in nine years yesterday, and gasoline declined to the lowest level since 1995, flirting with an average price of $1 a gallon.
With the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in disarray, analysts predicted that the good times for consumers and energy-intensive industries like trucking and airlines could continue for months. 
 Most experts said that any reversal of the slide in oil prices depended on agreement by the OPEC nations to cut production at a special meeting the end of this month. But with the two largest producers, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela, locked in a dispute over which should absorb the bulk of financial sacrifice, that prospect seemed increasingly remote.
The lack of OPEC cohesiveness continued to depress prices. At one point yesterday, crude oil was down 32 cents a barrel, after a much steeper fall Monday, at $12.96. It recovered some later in the day to settle on the New York Mercantile Exchange at $13.21 a barrel, off 7 cents.
The decline helped propel a rise in stock and bond prices on Monday. Yesterday stocks were mixed over all, with losses by oil and energy-services companies. Shares of trucking companies and airlines rose.
The Energy Information Administration said yesterday that the national average price of regular unleaded gasoline fell over the last week to $1.008 a gallon, compared with $1.22 in November and $1.20 a year ago. In some metropolitan areas, such as Atlanta, regular unleaded gasoline was selling as low as 75 cents.
Truckers also got good news, with the agency reporting that the average price of diesel fuel fell to $1.057 a gallon from $1.22 a year earlier.
However, analysts cautioned that with demand for gasoline strong in the first two months of 1998, and the vacation season ahead, retail prices are expected to edge up a little over the next few months. The increases are expected to be small. "You're probably talking 5 cents a gallon at most by the summer," said Lynn Westfall, director of development at Ultramar Diamond Shamrock, one of the largest independent refiners.
To be sure, the OPEC nations may surprise the market with an agreement to reduce their total output. If that happens, and if demand for gasoline remains high and refineries keep running at full capacity, prices could shoot up. But for now, the trends are in favor of consumers.
"I'm ecstatic," said Miangelo Moore as he filled his turquoise Chevrolet Blazer at an Exxon station on Route 4 in New Jersey, one of a cluster of stations selling regular gasoline for 99.9 cents or less. Mr. Moore said he was taking advantage of the bargain prices to treat himself to a premium grade selling for $1.129 a gallon.
Even as OPEC members argue among themselves, two world developments -- the softening to a degree of sanctions against Iraq and the Asian financial crisis -- are also putting downward pressure on crude oil prices.
Ann Louise Hittle, director for world oil at Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Cambridge, Mass., estimated that 800,000 to 900,000 barrels more a day could come on the market from Iraq by June. And projections of demand in Southeast Asia may have to be revised downward, she added, as the economies of that region worsen.
Ken Haley, who is in charge of forecasting the price of crude oil at the Chevron Corporation, said, "A response by OPEC is the only thing that will change the balance." The OPEC nations set a quota at 27.5 million barrels a day last November, but violations by members like Venezuela has pushed output closer to 28.8 million barrels, analysts say.

HEADLINE: Business Travel: Open Skies, Closed Markets?;
Growing Debate Over Keeping Airlines Competitive

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
When the bankrupt Western Pacific Airlines stopped flying last month, Frontier Airlines, one of its rivals at Denver's sprawling new airport, offered to honor its outstanding tickets, splitting the revenue 50-50. But just when Frontier thought it had sealed the deal, United Airlines, which controls more than 70 percent of the seats flown in and out of Denver, swooped in and reached its own agreement.
"United offered us a better deal," said Robert A. Peiser, Western Pacific's president and chief executive. 
 Sam Addoms, the chief executive of Frontier, acknowledged that United flies to all the cities served by Western Pacific, while Frontier had some gaps. But the effect of the deal was that United, a unit of the UAL Corporation, had denied Frontier a shot at winning the loyalty of Western Pacific's customers.
"Those moves might be construed as a means to increase their monopoly status," he said.
It is hardly an academic issue.
Twenty years after Washington deregulated the airline industry, there is a growing debate over whether the major carriers are unfairly reining in their smaller rivals, curbing their growth and even blocking their access to new markets. More is at stake than simply the number of carriers flying out of a particular airport -- ticket prices tend to drop when competition increases, and rise when it narrows, studies have shown.
The Justice Department has started an antitrust investigation of the biggest airlines and the Transportation Department is on the verge of issuing guidelines that would define for the first time when the Government might take action against a carrier for competing unfairly. In addition, several bills have been introduced in Congress that aim to blunt the dominance of the big carriers and promote competition.
As a result, the lines are quickly being drawn for a bitter battle that pits the airlines against a loose contingent of travel agents, consumer activists, business groups, local communities and the Clinton Administration. Both sides say they are the true champions of deregulation, which everyone agrees brought affordable air travel to millions of first-time passengers.
The big airlines say that their critics are trying to turn back the clock and "reregulate" the industry. AMR's American Airlines and United recently formed the Airline Competition Committee to celebrate the 20th anniversary of deregulation and "educate" the public about its benefits. Along with Northwest Airlines and Delta Air Lines, American and United gave $1.1 million last year in Federal campaign contributions, accounting for 72 percent of all airline industry donations, according to a study by the Center for Responsive Politics.
Critics of the big airlines respond that they are merely trying to remove the last vestiges of regulation, which they say have been exploited by the major carriers to fend off new competitors. But they are clearly eager for the Government to take a stronger hand in helping new low-cost airlines.
"Our goal is to expand deregulation to meet the original intent of the Congress," said Ivan Michael Schaeffer, president of Woodside Travel Trust, a consortium of 132 travel agencies that cater mostly to businesses. "No one in 1978 believed that deregulation would lead to more concentration of the industry."
What corporate travel agents, businesses and many communities are most concerned about are the so-called fortress hubs at key airports around the country that are dominated by the large carriers. In addition to United's pre-eminence in Denver, it and American control 84 percent of the available seats in Chicago. Northwest Airlines has 79 percent of the capacity in Detroit and an even greater 82 percent in Minneapolis. Delta flies 80 percent of the seats out of Atlanta.
As the carriers have tightened their grip on major airports, the prices for walk-on fares, which are mostly purchased by business travelers, have soared to record levels. Many members of Congress, along with local officials, complain that the lack of competition is hampering economic development because businesses cannot afford to be situated where travel costs are too high.
One Federal study of the impact of deregulation found that fares at hub airports dominated by a single carrier were 22 percent higher than what was charged in other markets. To Washington policy makers, the solution has been the introduction of more low-cost airlines modeled on the success of Southwest Airlines.
For a time, the approach seemed to work. A 1996 study concluded that passengers traveling in markets with low-cost competition saved $6.3 billion a year, $2.6 billion of which came from large hub airports.
But a month after that study was issued, a Valujet plane crashed in Florida, killing all 110 people aboard. The subsequent discovery of numerous safety violations by the carrier turned many passengers away from low-cost airlines. Applications to start new discount carriers slowed to a trickle.
Before the crash, Valujet had proved popular with many travelers. At its peak in 1995, it flew 7 percent of the available seats out of its base in Atlanta and was growing fast. Critics of the big carriers believe that the Valujet disaster was seen as an opportunity by the major airlines to knock off other small competitors before they became a threat -- a charge that the big carriers deny.
Whatever their motivation, large airlines have a number of competitive tools at their disposal that have the effect of isolating small rivals. These range from exclusive deals with large corporate customers to discounts for travel agencies that book a high percentage of their tickets on one airline. But the most potent way of driving out competition is so-called predatory behavior: cutting fares and then flooding a small airline's routes with cheap seats until it is forced to abandon them.
That is exactly what the Detroit-based Spirit Airlines contends Northwest did on the Detroit-Philadelphia route in the aftermath of the Valujet crash. Northwest matched Spirit's $49 one-way fare and added more seats to its existing service.
After Spirit stopped flying the route in September 1996, Northwest reduced capacity and raised its prices. "Their strategy only made sense if their goal was to push us out of the market," said Mark Kahan, Spirit's executive vice president.
Northwest denied that it was doing anything more than competing aggressively. "Spirit Air is complaining because we matched their prices," said Jon Austin, a spokesman. "That is the central tenet of a free market."
The carrier is also accused of using similar tactics against Reno Air, which filed an antitrust suit against Northwest last March.
In addition, Frontier has a litany of complaints of unfair practices by United. While United vigorously denies the charges, Frontier's complaints were apparently substantive enough to get the Justice Department to begin its antitrust investigation early last year. The Department of Transportation also began investigating United and other big carriers, with officials finding evidence of some foul play.
"I've seen dozens of examples in routinely reported data where fare matching and undercutting by major airlines have been taking place," said Patrick V. Murphy, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Transportation, in a speech last fall.
But predatory behavior is one of the thorniest areas of antitrust law. Judges are extremely reluctant to rule in favor of those who say they are victims because it raises the specter of denying consumers the benefit of what at first appear to be wider choices and low prices.
"Virtually every student of antitrust law will tell you that predatory pricing, like purple suede shoes, doesn't exist," said Robert L. Crandall, American's combative chairman and chief executive.
But in a speech last year, Roger W. Fones, who is leading the Justice Department's antitrust investigation of the airlines, said that the airline business was one of the few industries where predatory behavior could be demonstrated to be a rational strategy.
Still, the cloudy legal questions mean that the large carriers would likely fight any lawsuit brought by the Government, a battle that could last for years. "Drafting a court order that gets surgically at these problems is difficult because it says 'don't charge such low prices,' " said one Justice Department lawyer who insisted on anonymity.
The Department of Transportation says it has more far-reaching powers to rein in the big airlines than the Justice Department. It can levy fines and even revoke an airline's operating license. But the department has never used these powers against a major airline for competing unfairly, choosing instead to pressure carriers behind the scenes.
The new guidelines have been widely anticipated. Officials said last year that they would issue them in January. Then they were pushed back to February. The department had been planning to release them last week but held off again.
Airline executives have been appealing to the White House in an effort to weaken the guidelines, leading some to credit them with the delay. But a White House official who requested anonymity said that the only problem was that the Transportation Department's 15-page draft needed to be in plainer English.
Administration officials may be nervous that the rules will appear to prevent the airlines from lowering their fares, drawing the wrath of a public whipped up by the carriers.
"What kind of competition policy precludes large carriers, or anybody, from selling large numbers of seats at low prices?" said Cyril D. Murphy, vice president of regulatory affairs at United.
In a speech on Jan. 30, Rodney E. Slater, the Transportation Secretary, said that the Administration deliberately chose not to pursue an "enforcement strategy" against the major carriers. "Some in industry said, 'Give us guidance,' " he added. "And that is what we will do."
Whether this means the agency will use its enforcement powers if airlines violate the new guidelines is not clear. Critics of the airlines hold out little hope that the Administration will take tough action. Instead, they place more faith in Congress. The bills that have been introduced would open up more landing rights at the country's busiest airports for upstart carriers and force the Department of Transportation to respond to complaints of predatory behavior within 90 days.
But a large number of lawmakers are opposed to new legislation. At a hearing early this month, Senator Slade Gorton, Republican of Washington, the chairman of the aviation subcommittee of the Commerce Committee, argued that "telling airlines how to schedule flights and what fares to charge is a cure far worse than the disease."
Even Ed Faberman, executive director of the Air Carrier Association, the chief lobby for the upstart airlines, acknowledged that many small carriers failed because they were underfinanced, poorly managed, or both. "No one is pretending that the only reason start-ups are failing is because of the big carriers," he said.
Still, said Mr. Addoms, Frontier's chief executive, deregulation should not mean that "anything goes."
"We are going to have a debate about this stuff for the first time in 20 years," he added. "Everyone is going to get their oar in, and I am sure it is going to be loud."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
British Company Is Acquiring Inland Steel

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: LONDON, March 17

 BODY:
Ispat International N.V. said today that it plans to buy the Inland Steel Company of Chicago for $888.2 million plus $538.6 million in assumed debt to expand in the United States, where construction and manufacturing growth has fueled steel demand.
The acquisition by the London-based steelmaker is the latest sign of consolidation in the global steel industry, as slower economic growth in Asia reduces demand and pressures steelmakers to cut costs to improve profits. The move would give Ispat's mills in Canada, Mexico and Trinidad greater access to the United States. 
 For Inland, the sale could satisfy shareholders who have been complaining of little return on their investment.
"Ispat is very aggressive, and as they continue their strategy here in the U.S., the pace of consolidation is going to accelerate," said Waldo Best, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company. "There's a lot of value in the industry right now at current price levels in the U.S."
The takeover would double Ispat's revenue to $4.6 billion and increase annual steel production 74 percent, to 12.5 million tons, making it the world's eighth-largest steel producer. It is currently ranked 16th.
Ispat would pay $650 million in cash for the common stock of the subsidiary of Inland Steel Industries. It would also pay $238.2 million for the preferred shares.
"In order to be a truly global steel company, we needed a stronger presence in the U.S.," Lashmi Mittal, the Indian entrepreneur who founded Ispat in 1989, said in an interview. "It's the most demanding market."
In Amsterdam, where Ispat is registered, the company's shares rose 2 guilders, or about $1, to 53 guilders. Inland rose $4.3125, to $27.6875.
Other American steel company shares rose as well on the possibility of further takeovers in the United States. The AK Steel Holding Corporation rose $1.3125, to $20. The Bethlehem Steel Corporation jumped 87.5 cents, to $13.1875. The National Steel Corporation rose $1.875, to $18.6875.
For months, major shareholders in Inland had been urging the board to sell the steel division and spin off its 87 percent stake in the metals distributor Ryerson Tull Inc. -- which would be Inland's only remaining unit after the sale to Ispat is completed -- to increase shareholder returns.
Inland Steel Industries, with market capitalization of $1.14 billion, is the world's 34th-largest steelmaker.
In recent years, it forged sales alliances with Tata Iron and Steel of India, Macsteel of South Africa and Canada's Federal Industries to bolster steel exports from its United States plants.
"It became clear that steel companies with an international production capability and global market reach will have a major edge over other producers," Robert Darnall, chairman, president and chief executive of Inland, said in a statement. Mr. Darnall will become head of Ispat's North American operations.
Mr. Darnall said the company would distribute a "significant portion" of the net proceeds to Inland Steel Industries shareholders through stock repurchases, dividends, or a combination. The transaction is expected to be completed in the third quarter.
Mr. Mittal has built Ispat through acquisitions, most recently bidding for a steel plant in Venezuela thought to be worth more than $1 billion.
In the 1980's, Mr. Mittal left family-owned steel mills in India to patch together Ispat, which in the last six years has acquired steel mills in Germany, Trinidad, Mexico, Ireland and Canada, and worked to turn them around by cutting costs and jobs.
Mr. Mittal said Ispat would try to cut $120 million in annual costs at Inland, but it was unclear whether that means jobs would be cut. Inland makes about 5.5 million tons a year.

HEADLINE: 2 State Mental Hospitals Are Providing Medical Staff Who Speak Chinese and Korean

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
Faced with the threat of a lawsuit, the State Office of Mental Health has agreed to set up a special system for treating patients with mental illness who speak only Chinese or Korean.
Under the system, the patients will be clustered together on units at two state hospitals in New York City, which will be staffed by nurses, doctors, social workers and psychiatrists fluent in Mandarin, Cantonese or Korean. 
 Advocates for immigrants and people with mental illnesses said that the move was an important and necessary step in assuring that patients received appropriate care and understood the treatments and therapies prescribed for them -- a virtually unattainable goal when patients and the medical staff do not speak the same language.
These advocates say it is difficult enough for patients to get routine or even emergency medical care when language barriers separate them from the doctors treating them -- a growing problem in the New York region. In those cases, diagnostic tests and physical examinations can at least provide some information.
But when the underlying condition involves mental health, experts said, the inability to communicate in the same language makes diagnosis and treatment a guessing game.
Dennis Feld, a lawyer with Mental Hygiene Legal Services, a state-financed organization that represents psychiatric patients, said that when his group and others threatened to sue the state if it did not provide better linguistic services for these patients, state officials quickly agreed to address the problem.
The first of the two clusters, as they are being called, opened earlier this month at South Beach Psychiatric Facility, a state hospital on Staten Island, with staff members fluent in Mandarin and Cantonese and beds for eight patients. The second eight-bed cluster is scheduled to open in April at Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens and is to have staff members fluent in Mandarin and Cantonese, as well as in Korean.
"How can people isolated linguistically respond to their peers or to clinicians?" Mr. Feld said. "How can clinicians evaluate people when they have no idea what they are saying?"
In 1995, Mr. Feld's group sued the state to force the opening of psychiatric units for patients who speak only Spanish. The success of that initiative, Mr. Feld said, helped ease the way for this recent victory.
Linda Rosenberg, deputy commissioner for operations for the state's Office of Mental Health, said that having the medical staff and patients speak the same language improves the results of treatment and decreases the length of time that patients need to be hospitalized. Appropriately evaluated and treated, she said, many patients could be followed more effectively and economically in an outpatient setting.
The state first began evaluating the problems facing Korean and Chinese psychiatric patients about a year ago, Ms. Rosenberg said. Working with psychiatrists fluent in those languages, officials found 19 patients who had been treated in state facilities by people who did not speak their language: 16 were in the hospitals, 2 were outpatients and 1 had been discharged and was not being helped.
John Gresham, a lawyer with New York Lawyers for the Public Interest, an advocacy group that worked on the case, said that one patient had been living in a state institution for more than three years without being properly diagnosed.
"We think as this program moves forward, that patients will be discharged who should probably have been discharged years or months ago if someone had understood them," Mr. Gresham said.
Kin Wah Lee, vice president for the New York Coalition for Asian-American Mental Health, an organization of mental health workers, said that although she was pleased with the state's new initiative, she hoped more efforts would be focused on providing appropriate language services in hospital emergency rooms, where many mental health patients are first seen.
"This is a great beginning," Ms. Lee said. "But we need better crisis management, too."

HEADLINE: New Dose of Anxiety At Ever-Changing Bank

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
From outward appearances, it was a normal day at the Park Avenue headquarters of Chase Manhattan, except perhaps for the spectacle next door on 48th Street, where St. Patrick's Day marchers gave an oddly festive air to one of New York City's most bankerly addresses.
But inside, after Chase announced big job cuts, it was grim. "Of course people are nervous," said an executive in Chase's foreign currency data processing department who identified himself only as Abraham. "We won't know from one day to the next who will stay, and who will go." 
 Chase said the cuts would be especially deep in New York City, where it is the largest private employer, and in the suburbs.
Beginning in the next three months, the company said, 1,125 workers in the New York region -- out of a total of 36,594 -- will be told that they are being let go. Chase would not specify where the cuts would be made, but they could come at the Park Avenue headquarters; at the lower Manhattan office tower, known as One Chase Plaza; at a technology complex built during the 1980's in downtown Brooklyn and at its national credit card processing center in Hicksville, on Long Island.
Chase's cutbacks come at a time of buoyant expansion in most of the region's economy. The culprits, analysts say, are mergers, consolidation and a steady migration of some operations like data processing to lower-cost regions.
Chase itself provides a corporate genealogy of such shifts in the region's banking. The largest recent merger was Chase's combination with Chemical Banking in 1996, leading to thousands of job cuts and the elimination of 100 retail bank branches.
That came close on the heels of Chemical's 1993 acquisition of Manufacturers Hanover.
No more branch closings are planned, Chase officials said.
For the bank's employees, the long-running turmoil has made some of them stoic. "I'm a survivor," said an executive in the information technology division, whose career path has tracked recent banking history. Hired first by Manufacturers Hanover in 1990, he was retained after Chemical took it over. Then, amid the steep cuts after Chase's 1996 acquisition of Chemical, he was spared once again.
"This is all just part of what goes on every day in this industry," he said. "But listen, the economy is generally strong, and even if I don't survive these layoffs, I'll find something else."
